Jan ÄŒeÅ¡piva accredited medical expert under Â§ 114 of the Penal Code . Witness Melanie ScheinovÃ¡ born 11.7.1920 in NÃ¡mestkovo/GPE District of NÃ¡m/LOC . Domicile Prague/GPE 11 Baranava/LOC 2 . Occupation Manual worker . Former occupation household service . Evidence of identity Citizen identity card No . 267692 Series issued MOVB Prague/GPE 11 6 . 2 . 1956 Evidence reference VB 1942/56 . Testimony heard in criminal proceedings against Karl Clauberg . The witness was duly advised of her right under Â§ 108 of the Penal Code to refuse to testify likewise of the importance of witness testimony in the public interest and of the consequences under Â§ 109 of the Penal Code of making FALSE statements in evidence likewise of the opportunity that would be afforded under Â§ 112 of the Penal Code to correct the minutes in accordance with her evidence . I think it was in January 1943 when we were paraded for roll call that a man in civilian clothes came who I found out later was Dr. Clauberg . We were told he would select fifty women but for what purpose was not disclosed . I myself had been in the concentration camp since about March 1942 . The situation in the Birkenau/CAMP concentration camp was so dreadful that the impression would arise immediately anyone in civilian clothes arrived as in this case that the purpose for which the women were being selected could not possibly be worse than the situation in the camp . I was among those who volunteered and five of us were brought before Dr. Clauberg . We were made to strip and were asked by Dr. Clauberg whether we menstruated . On hearing my reply that this was not the case he sent me away . Even at the time we felt this was strange . A few days later one of the women prisoners came 2 and reported that a block was being prepared inside the men camp in Auschwitz/CAMP it was Block No . 10 and that they required nurses there and that I could volunteer . I knew another prisoner who at one time had managed the laundry facilities and as I thought she would be better informed on the matter I asked her advice as to whether or not I should volunteer as a nurse for Block No . 10 . She advised me against this because it would be something that involved some kind of contact with the SS and in the event of the camp ever being dispersed they would execute us because we had knowledge of things that would be awkward for them . Later on I found myself in the Staff building where I worked in the laundry . This was between Birkenau/CAMP and Auschwitz/CAMP . The girls who worked there or had their accommodation there also went to the men camp in Auschwitz/CAMP . In this way we soon learned what was happening in Block No . 10 . It was experimentation on women being carried out there by Dr. Clauberg . It was now that I established that the civilian who had been selecting women earlier was the same man . We gradually got to hear more and more about the ghastly things they were doing in Block No . 10 i.e. the experiments on women mentioned earlier . We found out that mass deaths of women were happening during and after these experiments . This information spread through the camp . As a result there was immediate panic and scenes whenever Dr. Clauberg came to the camp to select women . The women prisoners knew from others about the atrocities being committed in the experimentation block No . 10 and wanted above all not to be taken there even though conditions in the camp were unbearable . For preference he would take women direct from the transports but if he did not get a sufficient number there he would pick out further women in the camp . I know that later Block No . 10 was moved to another location . That was shortly before the evacuation of the concentration camp . At this point they cordoned it off behind barbed wire but it was not far from the Staff building where I myself worked and often we heard screams and groaning coming from where these women were kept . From the accounts being passed on in the camp at this time I know that women from Block No . 10 were sent back to the Birkenau/CAMP concentration camp and would shortly afterwards die there as a result of their physical condition . I also know that these women were divided up between different places so that they would not be together as a group . I know from prisoners on so called work deployment that a certain number of women from Clauberg/LOC Block No.10 were sent back to Birkenau/CAMP and that those unable to work after their return were sent to the gas chambers immediately . Those who did work could usually only keep going for about three to four days . This meant that for all these women being sent back by Clauberg was synonymous with a death sentence . I knew some nurses and talked to them quite often e.g. 3 Rija Hans and they told me that in Block No . 10 the most dreadful things were being done and that if Dr. Clauberg so much as appeared in the block and was seen by the women it would drive them completely out of their minds for fear of the experiments . I know also that for example Sylvia Friedman worked in Block No . 10 . Read approved and signed . 
Sattler a well to do merchant in Krakow/GPE Poland/GPE was arrested together with 31 Jews and Poles and taken to the Gestapo to Prison/STREET St./STREET Michael on 11 September 1939 where seven prisoners were shot instantly the rest sent on to the Military prison Monte Lupich to Skwochowice/LOC near MÃ¤hr/LOC . Ostrau/LOC to the prison at Somorn/LOC and finally via Weimar/LOC to Buchenwald/CAMP horrible transport from 6 10 October 1939 . In order to take vengeance on the Jews for the so called Bier kellerputsch in Munich/GPE the SS distributed no food from 7 11 November 1939 and after that such food as to make everybody sick . Typhoid and spotted fever followed . On 15 January 1940 Mr Sattler and some hundred survivors of his group of originally were transferred through the camp doctor to a special barracks where political prisoners among them was Ernst Thaelmann took care of them p.2 . Horrible ill treatment through Kapos SS atrocities p.2 3 . Himmelfakrttransporte 1940 twice saved through LagerÃ¤ltester Jupp . Murder camp for chemical experiments of I.G. Farben p.3 . Awful conditions on transport to Auschwitz/CAMP of 300 15 October 1942 160 gassed at arrival . Mr Sattler escaped declaring himself a locksmith . Ill treatment at road making . Dreams which came TRUE p.4 5 . For a murder a man would get a reward of 3 days leave and vodka . The Ukrainan Black Guard was inhumanly cruel and dangerous p.4 . Most critically ill after a kick from an SS man in 1944 Mr Sattler was operated on in a masterly way evidently by a Jewish surgeon but had to return back to work too early he has been suffering all the time since and will have to undergo another operation . Death march to Gleiwitz/CAMP on 18 January 1945 horrid transport to Buchenwald/CAMP 21 days march back to Poland/GPE at Krakow/GPE he learned that 31 of his near relatives had been murdered by the Nazis . Remarried he lives in Melbourne/GPE since 1950 where he runs a restaurant . 9 . Further References LagerÃ¤ltester Heinemann Stephan Buchenwald/CAMP a Communist p.2 Extra Tortures to Speed Up Liquidation of Jews Report of the experiences in KZs concentration camps Buchenwald/CAMP Auschwitz/CAMP etc on the basis of Herr Salo S. Sattler communications b. 31 March 1907 Krakow/GPE . Herr Sattler lived in his native city as a well to do metal ware merchant specialising in tools . Since 1936 he had been married to Frau Rena nÃ©e Fajner they had a son Jerry George and a daughter Salomea . After the German troops occupied Krakow/GPE on 5th September Gestapo arrested Herr Sattler on the 11th Sept. along with 31 Jews and Poles mostly journalists and took them to the Polish prison Sankt Michael Saint Michael which the Gestapo had taken over . During the second night they fetched seven of the detainees from the cells and shot them amongst them was an Orthodox Jew Herr Schickmann and his sons 18 and 16 years old . From there the remaining captives were taken to the military jail Montelupich/LOC where they were divided into different groups and subjected to gross ill treatment . After Yom Kippur they were transported to the Sammellager Skwochowice near had been converted from an old sugar refinery that had been de commissioned it possessed neither windows nor light and where approximately Jewish prisoners from Moravia/LOC and some from Poland/GPE had been rounded up . After a transitional stay of ten days in a normal prison Somornj a group consignment of 40 men to which Herr Sattler belonged were moved in closed cattle wagons the openings intended for the cattle had been closed off through barbed wire the journey to KZ/CAMP Buchenwald/CAMP lasted for three days and three nights . The journey took a major detour it stopped for one night in Wroclaw/LOC . On the 10th October 1939 a Sunday when the prisoners arrived in Weimar/CAMP they were forced to march the long stretch ten kms . uphill to the KZ Buchenwald/CAMP with hands on their hands during which the SS escort struck them with rifle butts without break . Those of the prisoners who broke down on the way were picked up by a truck that was following . In the KZ Buchenwald/CAMP Herr Sattler was placed in a tent camp which the SS ironically dubbed The Rose Garden it was the worst sort of place . Jewish prisoners were herded together to which number came as well Viennese Jews as a result of the so called September Aktion . Although the prisoners had to work dreadfully hard in the quarry their subsistence after about a month was fit only for dogs . As a revenge for the so called Bierkeller Putsch in Munich/GPE November were forced to go hungry for 94 hours during which the SS guards remarked â€˜ You are supposed to die that going too slowly ! After that the inmates were given some herb soup as well as rotten and acrid salted cucumbers and when after that they drank water epidemics broke out dysentery and redwater fever from which 80 100 prisoners fell ill every day the entire camp was ailing . On top of dysentery and redwater fever came typhus and since the prisoners were gruesomely plagued by three different types of lice i.e. clothing hair and body lice tick typhus as well . In spite of the snow and biting cold the prisoners were obliged to live in mere tents â€“ seven circus marquees with 500 men in each â€“ from which they were collected to schlep stones this went on until Dec. 1939 when the camp physician established a state of quarantine at the tents and would not allow their inhabitants to go to work anymore . From 15th January 1940 the camp doctor took some hundreds of prisoners those remaining of the original and put them in a special hut inside the sickbay area where they were better treated and given food thanks to the solicitude of the political prisoners working there one of whom was Ernst ThÃ¤lmann leader of the KPD German Communist Party . After the circus tents had been emptied the camp doctor had them incinerated for reasons of hygiene . Whereas Herr Sattler had weighed 81 kilos when arrested his body weight by now was down to 38 kilos when he was taken into the sickbay . His stomach had shrunk so much that he could only keep down two to three spoons of the camp evening meal . During the first period of his imprisonment he lost eight teeth three of which were knocked out by capos . After he had spent about two weeks in the sickbay he reached a hut which was managed by the Block Senior Stephan Heinemann a Communist and of the original 300 inmates only about 50 remained . After Herr Sattler had worked some weeks in the stone quarry an SS man threw him 11 metres downhill which broke a foot . When he was treated in the sickbay under the control of political prisoners he was placed in the Fahrkolonne transport crew consisting of 21 prisoners capos included one man on the trailer coupling who instead of horses had to load stones get rid of tree stumps transport bricks and deliver sand from the quarry for road building to do so they themselves had to push heavy trucks . When Herr Sattler fell ill with pleurisy he was treated by a construction worker who possessed no medical knowledge the latter punctured a blister like growth and drew out the pus which flowed into a bowl held by an assistant . During that process the construction worker noted that the patient was behaving very bravely during the intervention . When Herr Sattler had to return to the Fahrkolonne after some weeks he became so weak that he was hardly able to mount the three steps to the hut . Through the gift of a cigarette he obtained a few days respite before he was again obliged to return to work . When on one occasion three or four prisoners amongst them Herr Sattler took a puff on a cigarette an SS man caught and reported them whereupon each was hung by their arms from a tree for half an hour . Although the torture took place on a cold autumn day Herr Sattler became drenched with sweat and after the tree hanging he could not make use of his hands for six long weeks either for the food which he sipped nor for the completion of the act of defecation because his tendons had become powerless . At the beginning of 1940 a new doctor at the camp put together the so called â€˜ Himmelfahrt Transport Ascension Day transport . 300 400 invalids in the camp all Jews were lined up in a death transport . At first the prisoners did not know what such transports entailed when however the clothes of the inmates who had been sent away were returned they knew what had happened . Herr Sattler was saved from a transportation to death because the Block Senior Jupp a Communist from Berlin/GPE fetched Sattler papers along with the documents of four other inmates in the sickbay with the result that Herr Sattler and the others names were not called by the roll call for the allocation to the death transportation . When Herr Sattler in order to get away from KZ/CAMP Buchenwald/CAMP volunteered for the office of a different camp it was likewise Jupp who advised him urgently not to because that camp was known as a death camp whereupon Herr Sattler resolved to remain in Sattler learned that it was an experiment barracks belonging to I.G. Farbenindustrie ? in which the prisoners were subjected roughshod to life threatening experiments . On the 16th October 1942 of the group of 350 Jewish prisoners only 50 young people remained behind in Buchenwald/CAMP KZ so as to take part in a bricklaying training course whereas the other them Herr Sattler were sent to Auschwitz/CAMP KZ in closed cattle wagons on a journey lasting three days . During the ride they were given no food and in each of those totally overfilled cattle wagons only a single bucket was available for urination and defecation . That bucket was completely unsuitable in size for the passengers to eliminate their faeces as a result they had no choice but to soil themselves4 in a sickening manner even if the deprivation of food and drink had a retarding affect on the functioning of their digestive and excretory organs . After they had arrived in Auschwitz/CAMP 18th October 1942 they were sorted into groups during the following day 160 of the 300 were sent at once to be gassed while 140 remained . One of whom was Herr Sattler who replied to a question by claiming he was a welder and 30 years old and so saved himself because business people and intellectuals were immediately liquidated . Since Herr Sattler knew that those who had a trade useful in the camp lasted longer he registered voluntarily as an electrician for he hoped to be employed in the installation of electric cables in the barracks however he was allocated to the putting up of high voltage transmission lines . He slipped off during that and could not do any further work because his hands were completely battered and weak . When he then came to road construction a terribly hard time for him ensued in which an SS man seriously wounded him by a blow with a rifle butt . After that he was employed as electrician and welder in the BUNA factory . In the night of 13th March 1942 he had an appalling dream he saw in the dream very clearly how his wife and his children were being followed on the street his son blond hair was sticky with blood . When he awoke in the middle of the night a camp comrade said to him â€˜ What is the matter with you Sattler you screamed so terribly in your sleep ? In reply Herr Sattler narrated the content of his dream . After the war he learned from a Polish female servant who had earlier been in his employ and whom he later met in Krakow/GPE that on Saturday 13th March 1942 that is at the same time as he had the dreadful dream the Krakow/GHETTO ghetto had been liquidated during which his wife and his children perished . In particular Herr Sattler emphasised that events in the war led to reactions affecting the fates of the KZ/CAMP prisoners each victory by the Nazis â€“ for example the conquest of Paris/GPE Mussolini entry in the war or the capture of Crete/LOC â€“ was so to speak a defeat for the inmates because the SS then felt less restrained than ever in treating the prisoners with appalling brutality . If one of them was murdered with some excuse or other the SS man would be given vodka and three days holiday . Just as dangerous as the SS were the so called Black Guard of the Ukrainians which consisted of 17 or 18 year old fellows they were as stupid as they were inhumanly cruel . On the basis of his experiences Herr Sattler declared that he was convinced that any animal who had experienced the burden of suffering which the KZ inmates were subjected to would have long ago been broken .. In 1944 an SS man gave Herr Sattler a brutal kick in his stomach the latter realised the blow had serious consequences in his abdomen he was then in a critical state for weeks after without being allowed to report to the sickbay . When however he then collapsed and could neither swallow nor eat nor walk he managed to makecontact with friends of his in the sickbay where a Communist Silmann from CzÄ™stochowa/LOC admitted him at that time a number of Jewish medical specialists were working there . When on the 20th June 1944 Herr Sattler was operated on he was already in a highly critical condition . The surgeon after opening the abdominal cavity established that 1-Mar of his stomach gallbladder and duodenum were already septic he removed them by mean of a surgical intervention . After that Herr Sattler through the use of a half litre of ether fell ill with pneumonia in both lungs . Sadly Herr Sattler has completely forgotten the name of the surgeon . On the other hand he recalls the names of two of the assisting doctors Dr Budziavrek from Krakow/GPE and Dr Silber from the Ruhrgebiet/LOC . It is thanks to the excellent reputation which Herr Sattler enjoyed in the camp that the doctor carried the operation out at all afterwards the surgeon told him â€˜ Sattler for anybody else I would have simply stitched you up i.e. let him die because his case was hopeless . Herr Sattler was one of the so called Old 68ers i.e. he had the number 68652 whereby he belonged to the group of prisoners originating from Buchenwald/CAMP KZ whom the SS ironically dubbed the old . Although Herr Sattler stayed alive due to the operation he was released too early from the sickbay and sent back to work . As a result the stitches in his stomach burst and even today his abdomen has still only partially healed only another operation which Herr Sattler has still not been able to have â€“ would resolve those medical issues . Because of the physical abuse he suffered Herr Sattler has become 70 % invalided . When the Buna Factory was liquidated on the 18th January 1945 the surviving prisoners were forced to undertake a Todesmarsch death march to Gliwice/LOC lasting two days and a night without any food during which many died underway . Herr Sattler attributes his survival during both that death march and the entire period of suffering to a curious dream which he had during the beginning of his time in KZ/CAMP Buchenwald/CAMP his father who had died a year earlier appeared to him in his dream and shook his hand and said to him â€˜ You are going to survive ! Herr Sattler reported that this experience in his dream gave him the spiritual power to survive everything . Those prisoners who managed to reach Gliwice/LOC â€“ amongst them Herr Sattler â€“ had to travel back to Buchenwald/CAMP KZ eight days and eight nights in an open coal wagon without any cover or food and drink as a result Herr Sattler was completely exhausted and could no longer move his feet . However thanks to his friends he could find a place in the sickbay of Buchenwald/CAMP KZ where he was able to remain until American troops on the 14th April 1945 liberated its surviving inmates . Before the liberation some hundreds of prisoners had yet to undertake a Todesmarsch/LOC . When Herr Sattler left there on the 7th May 1945 he was personally convinced that no member of his family was still living . But since he held it to be his duty and obligation to find out the exact facts he walked 500 kms in a group of three for 21 days in springtime on a long way round towards Krakow/GPE the three men only fed themselves underway on some lettuces and potatoes . From Kattowitz/LOC Herr Sattler was able to travel by train to Krakow/GPE when he arrived there he made his way to the cemetery the marble of the burial places had been stolen and as an aftermath of his suffering he was seized with a suicidal mood . Nevertheless he pulled himself together and recalled an address which a Pole had given him when he had suffered from a broken foot in Buchenwald/CAMP KZ . On the way there by chance he met a Polish slaughterer whom he told that he had met a Polish slaughterer in Buchenwald/CAMP KZ whereupon the Polish man invited him to his house where he stayed an hour and drank vodka . He found out that 31 members of his family â€“ amongst them his wife his mother his brother a nephew who was a doctor â€“ had been murdered by the Nazis . Herr Sattler then spent three years in Wroclaw/LOC which was under Polish rule where he founded a large metal ware shop which still exists today though in nationalised form . In 1947 he married again in Wroclaw/LOC his second wife nÃ©e Fass is a trained biologist . They had two sons Stephan and Albert . In 1949 Herr Sattler and his wife went to Vienna/GPE and from there after six months they emigrated to Melbourne/GPE Australia/GPE he arrived there on 3rd May 1950 and since then has run a restaurant in which his second wife works with him assiduously . I have checked the report prepared by Dr Fritz Friedlander on the basis of my communications and find it to be correct . Melbourne/GPE 22.9.1958Signed SALO S. SATTLER 
author witnessed the heartrending scenes during the selections for the mass deportations to DuenamÃ¼nde/LOC . In a poignant manner he describes how first the rumour of a new camp with good conditions was spread by the SS among the starving people of the Riga/GHETTO Ghetto . Then on 26 February 1942 a roll call of the entire population of the Ghetto was ordered and after repeated counts and hours of waiting in the freezing cold the Camp Commander whip in hand appears and tells the horror stricken crowd of the new camp and its excellent equipment . He then callously proceeds to select persons for DÃ¼namÃ¼nde/LOC . These are ordered to report the next morning . On 27 February 1942 early in the morning heavy lorries arrive and at great speed and with many brutalities the victims are loaded onto them . At the last moment the commander and his minions at random seize another 100 persons and push them on the lorries . Hardly an hour later the lorries return empty but for the clothing of the owners who have gone to their mass grave DÃ¼namÃ¼nde/LOC . DuenamÃ¼nde/LOC Yonder/LOC where the wide stream of the Duena/LOC flows into the waters of the North Sea like a cornucopia one finds on the flat beach and on the brim of spacious woodland that stretches down the cost many isolated farmhouses and small sttlements whose inhabitants mainly earn their livelihood by fishing and by cultivating the rich grassland and the fertile fields . The war brought many hardships to these people but at the time when our tragedy took place there they had not been troubled with actual combat scenes and the general horrors of war . Ships of the Battle Fleet cruised the sea and sometimes one could see speeding vessels in the distance whose grey or black smoke trail lingered on the horizon long after they had disappeared . Units of the German Navy were posted as sentries along the coast and frequently the sound of whistling shots could be heard which had been fired from machine guns and small cannons at enemy aircraft flying over the district . This took place from February 1942 until the end of 1943 on the soil of Latvia/GPE yonder where the Duena/LOC flows into the sea . The serene calm of this peaceful landstrip was at that time ingeniously used by the SS Command . They decided to propagate the idea Duenamuende . Cunningly they allowed rumours to spread that approximately 20 kilometres from the Ghetto of Riga/GHETTO lay the Port of Duenamuende and that there a few thousand people would be taken into newly errected comfortable camps . The Jewish orderlies appointed by the SS in the Riga/GHETTO Ghetto were instructed and ordered to mention Duenamuende/LOC to everyone in the Ghetto quarters Duenamuende/LOC was supposed to be a lovely spot on the coast . Many people were needed there for work in the Labour Unit Arbeitseinsatz . The new camp was said to be very clean and well planned much better conditions and less overcrowded than the narrow unhygienic quarters of the Ghetto . The inmates of the Ghetto needed more room and improved conditions and some relief measures were necessary . The rumours about Duenamuende rapidly went from mouth to mouth and whilst many unattached people had become familiar with the idea of 2 being transferred to another camp the majority of the Ghetto inmates trembled for their families and the idea of separation and goodbye . It is the 26th February 1942 . At 6 in the morning all the inmates of the Ghetto had to assemble . The house stewards group leaders the orderlies the leaders of labour units the leaders of columns and finally the camp eldest all were made responsible for everyone being present . This also included all sick people . Those unable to walk and serious hospital cases are to be listed by names . All children have to be present and next to them came the doctors and the medical service personnel . 30 degrees below zero . The hard frozen snow grates under the feet of many thousand people . An icy wind makes the eyes water and the cheeks are covered with layers of ice . Eyebrows and beards are covered with a crust of ice and seem snow bedecked . Most people are still hungry from the previous day . The orderlies race into every room and billet and press for extra speed . Frightened eyes and twitching faces show signs of fear and terror . Our instinct tells us to expect the worst . Slowly the quarters are emptied . The people move in groups along the main street of the Ghetto and it is difficult to move on as everywhere on the road there is nothing but pure slippery ice . Old parents are led by their children small kids cling to the hands and coats of their mother or father . Many people slip and fall expecially when the SS appears . Everyone is driven and chased to the greatest possible speed . Many are hit with butt ends or kicked . The main street can not hold the masses . Therefore a number of the people are assembled in side streets . It takes some time before the people are ordered into straight lines and in rows . Lists are produced . Names are read out . Everyone responsible is asked whether all are present . Then they count the people . One twice five times again eight times . The lists are compared and discussed . Several Scharfuehrer of the SS appear . They too want to know many things and begin to ask questions . Then they turn to the hospital doctors and instruct them which patients are to be got ready for the transport . Two hours have gone by since we were assembled . Men women children the frail and the sick . The cold cramps the bodies . Faces ears and feet hurt terribly . Children cry . Subdued soft moaning but audible nevertheless . A 3 woman falls down she has fainted . Another one over there and one just opposite . Now an elderly man falls and does not get up . He is shaken and pulled . A medical orderly races up . Dead ! he says . Put him in a ditch along the road . He can be removed later says a Schafuehrer . Many collapse owing to the cold . The feet seem to freeze off . Despite orders a general trampling and moving of feet begins because no one is able to stand still any longer . Many cry with cold . Stand still is being bellowed again and again . Faces are smacked and stomachs are punched . Three terrible hours have passed . It is 9 . At last the command is heard ... ! Stand straight . Stand still . A big saloon car passes the barrier at the entrance of the Ghetto . It is full of SS and slowly rolls along the main street . The car stops in front of the assembled Scharfuehrer who salute smartly . The commander is the first to alight from the car and to receive reports . All assembled and present . The commander and his officers salute their subalterns with Heil Hitler . The salute is repeated by the NCOs with arm raised stiffly . Then with half closed eyes the commander musters the long lines of unfortunate people . An officer takes snaps . He picks out types and lets them step forward old unshaven men in rags miserable starved women . A young girl with a lovely face and hair she is on the verge of collapse through the cold but has to smile invitingly . The officer demands it . The dead man lying in the ditch is also being photographed . In the meantime the commander confers with the other officers and the Scharfuehrer who have been called aside . At last he takes off one fur glove puts up the collar of his coat pulls his cap so that it forms a jaunty angle unfolds a piece of paper and speaks . Attention everybody . Pause . Then a few subdued followed by breath taking silence . The voice again . You have undoubtedly all heard of Duenamuende/LOC . A new camp is to be started there . You will have modern clean billets In Duenamuende/LOC . Much better than here in the Ghetto . Not so cramped much more comfrotable and cleaner . Many fishing nets need mending in Duenamuende/LOC and tins are to be manufactured there . The work in Duenamuend/GHETTO is easy and a sedantry one . I therefore mainly require elderly people who are unfit for heavy manual work . I shall supply you with doctors 4 nursing personnel medicine and dressing material . Of course everything else that goes with a camp will be given to you . Food will be sent to you from the Ghetto . Our lorry will call on you every day with provisions . You will find the new camp ready to receive you . No one is to take anything with him is that understood ? I do not mind if you take some food but nothing else is that clear ? Thus sounded the military curt words of our superior uttered in a rattling tone . Then with his staff he passed through the rows of people . How old ? Occupation ? Hm hm . Fall out to the left . You too and you and you and you . Then turning to one of the Scharfuehrer ...... and these entire two rows there . Come here Scharfuehrer Mueller . Over there those old women all of them . Mueller Certainly Sir . Commander Here the front row and at the back there this old man . Yes this one . And there on your right the one with the cheeky face let the blighter step forward . Then turning round How old are you doctor ? 69 Sir replied the man . Take him too says the commander . Scharfuehrer he yells . Yes Sir . Start counting them . Yes Sir . After a while . How many have you counted up to now ? Sir . Ah not nearly enough . I need many more for Duenamuende . What is the matter with you ? I work with Command Reichsbahn II Sir . Nonsense ! I shall give them a younger bloke ! Quick quick fall out to the left join the others . What are you doing you there at the back the one with the high head ! I am a butcher I work with the slaughterhouse command . Then your good days are over join the others quick march . And you Sarah you too are going to Duenamuende/LOC . Do pull such a stupid face . There are many more going there beside you . So do get excited . Among those selected for Duenamuende/LOC I see an old couple whom I know well . People from my native country . A young woman slips out of her group marching on the opposite side and joins the old couple . Glancing sideways the commander has noticed the incident . He plants himself infront of the Deserter and orders her back to your row at the same time he swings his riding whip . The young woman is the daughter of the 5 two old people and falling on her knees she implores the commander to send her to Duenamuende/LOC with her parents . The commander to her If you insist I do care but you are making the biggest mistake of your life . The young woman replies Please Sir I want to go . The commander thinks for a few seconds then Well my child if you must I wo stop you . At last even the gentlemen think it has lasted long enough . The commander and his retinue feel the cold too much and begin to feel uncomfortable . Now everything is done at the double . The commander in his nasal voice You you you you ..... this woman there that one that one and that ...... wherever his hand happens to point . In the end whole rows are selected out of the group of assembled people and destined for Duenamuende/LOC . Thus people are collected . An SS camp leader speaks Those selected for the transport to Duenamuende/LOC have to gather on the assembly place tomorrow early in the morning . Is that clear ? The exact time will be made known during the day . Have you understood ? ......... Then Fall out all of you back to your quarters ! ..... By now it is twelve noon . Fear worry and anxiety was in the hearts and showed on the faces of those who had not been selected . They could not show any emotion during the selection as the intense cold had frozen their features into immobility but now they slowly began to come to life . Silently they drag themselves back to the quarters . Soon the streets are empty and deserted . Those who were hungry forget about it .... A car is heard to start and the noice of the engine slowly dies down in the distance . Death at DUENAMUENDE/LOC . 27th February 1942 . For many the last day of their lives . It is less cold than on the previous day . Also the assembly time has been fixed for 8.30am . Even a pale morning sun greets the unfortunate ones who stand ready for the transport to Duenamuende/LOC . It has become very quiet in the Ghetto . All those employed have long ago left the camp with its barbed wire enclosure and in long columns led and guarded by armed sentries they have started their slave labour . For the time being they have escaped the selection for Duenamuende/LOC 6 They have said goodbye to their beloved ones to their friends and acquaintances those heart rending handshakes last embraces words of good luck glances trembling with fear worry and anxiety and in some cases even showing a spark of hope despite everything all this they have already left behind them . The command Duenamuende/LOC is awaiting collection . Excited murmurs go from one to the other eyes ask questions . We know what they are asking what they would like to kniw we know how they feel . Nobody can however give them the answer . Heavy lorries draw up . They wait . Their drivers and crew have been summoned to the commander . Doubtlessly they are receiving last minutes orders and instructions A messenger announces The commander is coming . Smoking a cigarette and apparently in excellent mood the mighty one arrives . He who loves to be called King of Judea/LOC during his carousels and when drunk appears with several SS Unterfuehrer . He enquires whether all are present and if verything is prepared for the trip . He does not even bother to glance at the waiting crows . Suddenly he decides to look personally into the quarters . Whip in hand he chases people before him whom he collected from working places rooms and even the street . Fifty in all . Following his example a few Scharfuehrer drive another hundred people together . They all have to join those already waiting . The engines of the transport lorries are started . It wo be long now . The first lorry pulls up . The first batch has to climb into it . In order to speed up matters the SS Men in TRUE SS fashion help the people by beating kicking and pushing them . Greatest speed has been ordered and stern discipline they say . Hardly half an hour has gone by and all the vehicles are filled with people . More than 2.6 human beings have been loaded into the lorry caravans and are being driven away .... Very soon the passengers to Duenamuende/LOC will have vanished from our sight . 27th February 1942 . Same morning . Hardly an hour later . All the vehicles which had just despatched more than people are back again on the car park of the Riga/GHETTO Ghetto . 7 They are loaded with coats frocks suits underwear and shoes . All these wear garments have a yellow star bearing the inscription JEW . There are also many handbags small parcels with bread and bottles filled with coffee among the things on the lorries . The owners of these articles are already in DUENAMUENDE/LOC . This is the name the SS gave to their massgrave . DUENAMUENDE/LOC ! DUENAMUENDE/LOC ! 
report written by an anonymous author obviously a German Jewess who returned from Holland/GPE to Germany/GPE on 1 Februry 1935 . She duly reported her return to the police and after about 3 weeks she was interrogated at the Stapo offices Alexanderplatz Berlin/GPE . She declared that in Holland/GPE she had neither engaged in any political activities nor kept contact with refugees . Under some pretext the interrogating official led her to the police prison for women where Assessor Allass the official in charge of Jewish emigration matters signed a warrant for her arrest . She was told that she would be kept in preventive custody until being transferred to the â€˜ educational camp Schulungslager Moringen/CAMP near Hanover/LOC . She was kept in a prison cell for 7 women all classified as political suspects . One of these women had returned from Brazil/GPE on doctor orders having contracted typhoid and yellow fever . The German consulate in Rio/GPE de/GPE Janeiro/GPE had paid half of her return passage . The police prison was clean the treatment decent . Short visits from outside were permitted after a week . Two days before the scheduled transfer to Moringen/LOC i.e. on 9 April 1935 the author mother succeeded in obtaining her release on the strength of a railway ticket to  Amsterdam/GPE on condition that the author would leave Germany/GPE within 3 days . On 12 April 1935 her passport was returned to her at Bentheim/LOC on the German Dutch frontier . Preventive Custody for a â€˜ Returnee 1935 On 1 February I went back to Germany/GPE via Zevesaar/LOC Cranenburg . After I had registered with the police on 8 February I was summoned to appear at the STAPO Staatspolizei police headquarters Alexanderplatz/LOC Berlin/GPE . I was informed that this had been common procedure for some time without any consequences . To be on the safe side I contacted Dr Kreuzberger once again before going to the STAPO but he had not heard anything about arrests or unpleasant consequences . I promised to let him know how things went . On 22 February the STAPO recorded in writing the statements I made on being interrogated by a detective superintendent . I stated that I had neither engaged in political activity abroad nor was I a member of any party whatsoever I had not contacted any refugees did not know of any places where refugees used to meet had not demanded any money from any committee for my journey home etc . They asked me what foreigners thought about Germany/GPE . I answered that I had never cared about politics and had never discussed such topics . To their question about whether I had ever been kept in preventive custody or in a concentration camp I answered â€˜ No . Meanwhile I could tell that they were asking various police stations in Berlin/GPE whether my passport was in order . Of course it was . Now I thought I would be allowed to go home but instead I was led by an official through a labyrinth of corridors and staircases and suddenly I read the words â€˜ police cell block . The official pretended to need a signature and told me to go with him . Assessor Allass the official in charge of Jewish emigration matters was just inspecting the women cell block and signed a warrant for my preventive custody . I was suddenly trapped . At my request to tell me why I was being arrested he only answered â€˜ You will be taken to the educational camp at Mooringen/GPE near Hanover/GPE and until then you will stay here . By entreating and begging him I managed with the help of a little trick to make him 2 at least inform my parents . After a thorough body search I was taken to a room shared by seven women . They were all political suspects so I knew straightaway that I was being treated as a political case . From the girls I learnt that in another room there was a Jewess who had been living in Palestine/GPE for two years had a Jewish husband and was now back in Berlin/GPE to visit her mother . As she had wanted to earn some money in Berlin/GPE for her journey home to Erez she had registered with the police who put her straight into preventive custody . In my room there was another Jewess who had gone to Brazil/GPE with her six year old son the year before as her husband had got a job there . She contracted typhoid and yellow fever spent six months in a Brazilian hospital and was strongly advised by the doctors to return to Europe . The German consulate in Rio/GPE offered to pay 50 per cent of her return passage . This woman was also kept in preventive custody although she required more medical treatment immediately . They wanted to put the child into an orphanage but he was allowed to stay with his grandparents . Our â€˜ cases were increasing from day to day until there were ten Jewesses together in a separate room . Everything was spotlessly clean . At first the female guards were distant with us but later when they learnt from us why we were imprisoned they were really nice and humane . We were allowed to send post once a week letters took one week within Berlin/GPE â€“ really strict censorship . For example I wrote to my parents that I had been arrested on the basis of a new regulation of 1 February 1935 which decreed that all Jewish emigrants returning from abroad were to be put into preventive custody . This sentence had been made illegible and the next one too in which I had written that we would be taken to Mooringen/GPE. After one week a first short visit of ten minutes was permitted . Meanwhile my parents had been to all the Jewish organisations in Berlin/GPE and had learnt that I was not the only who had been treated in this way . Then the woman from Palestine/GPE was released on condition that she would return to Erez/GPE within three days . Although my case was different â€“ people from Palestine/GPE are treated more generously in Germany/GPE â€“ I told my mother at the next visiting time that she should immediately try to obtain my release by arguing that I would leave Germany/GPE 3 within a given timespan . It would take too much time to describe all the ways my mother now went about this . All this happened on Saturday 9 March . On Monday 11 April we were to be transported to Mooringen/CAMP . I would like to point out that all these so called â€˜ educational camps and â€˜ community camps were nothing but ordinary concentration camps which had recently been given new names . By the Saturday my mother had succeeded in getting me out of prison supplied with a ticket to  Amsterdam/GPE . It was my last chance . It was completely uncertain how long I would have been in the camp . At worst one must reckon on a year . Obtaining release from a camp is much more difficult . I had to give back my warrant for the preventive custody and to sign another document which said that I would never be permitted to enter Germany/GPE again and that I would never make any claims on the Reich . Otherwise I would face preventive custody and a concentration camp . They held on to my passport . I had three days left before my departure . I had to collect my passport from a detective superintendent in Bentheim/GPE . On the morning of 12 April I crossed the German Dutch frontier so I had been kept in preventive custody for sixteen days . Those in custody who had money on them had to pay 1.5 RM per day . Of course board and lodging were not worth that much as we got the usual prison food breakfast 0.75 litres of acorn coffee without milk and sugar and for the first five days one slice of dry bread later bread and jam . Lunch dried vegetables made into soup or some other thick and very hot soup . In the evening soup again and for the first five days dry bread later bread and lard . Every day we were led along with the other prisoners around the prison courtyard for half an hour in single file keeping a distance of five feet apart . It was strictly forbidden to speak â€“ otherwise an isolation cell ! ! 
Eisenstaedt who had received the Cross of Honour for war widows the Cross of Merit and a diploma for social work in Stettin/GPE was managing her own factory at the beginning of the Nazi regime . As she was no longer allowed to sell her goods to German enterprises she was forced to sell her factory . She started a retail business but this too was destroyed by boycott . In 1937 Mrs Eisenstaedt emigrated to Sweden/GPE . Boycott against a Jewish War Widow in Stettin/GPE Ms EisenstÃ¤dt comes from Mecklenburg/LOC . After getting married she moved to Szczecin/GPE where she lived until her relocation to Stockholm/GPE . Ms EisenstÃ¤dt first husband Mr Brotzen died from complications caused by a war injury shortly after the end of the First World War and her second husband died at the start of Hitler rule . These misfortunes twice forced Ms EisenstÃ¤dt to earn her own income . In the report that follows she tells us about her experiences in Pomerania/CAMP . There was talk that intellectuals were joining associations affiliated with Hitler as far back as 1923 and in 1933 they were given key positions in the Hitler movement . Antisemitism became more noticeable then too . I remember making a journey in Pomerania/CAMP in 1929 and on the train hearing rumours about a Jew I knew â€“ the sort of sexual fables and fairy tales that would later appear in the newspaper Der StÃ¼rmer The Fighter . Hitler boycott in 1933 hit all Jews in the affected area hard as many had been in the same location for generations and had come to be highly respected . It was mostly factory cereal and banking businesses that suffered alongside doctors and lawyers who were very popular amongst the inhabitants of the relatively small towns . A cousin of mine ran a shop in his own property in Bergen/LOC on the island of RÃ¼gen/LOC . He had never suffered at the hands of Antisemitism and was highly regarded by the public . However a swastika flag was hoisted up at his home in conjunction with the boycott efforts and he committed suicide . At his funeral the local priest alluded very clearly to the regime in place at the time . As I was allowed to sell any goods to German companies from the factory I owned I started my own retail business . Of course I was soon boycotted as a StÃ¼rmer vendor stood on one side of the shop entrance and a photographer stood on the other side of the second entrance . A large number of passers by gradually gathered in front of the shop so I approached them and spoke to them . The public sympathised with me but they were afraid of the regime . I pointed out that I was a war widow that I had been awarded the Order of Merit by the Kaiser during the First World War 2 and the Cross of Honour for War Widows by Hindenburg and that I had been honoured for my own work during the war . I was also awarded a diploma by the city of Szczecin/GPE as a token of gratitude for my social work during the First World War . I had trained hundreds of soldiers wives and war widows to work to meet the army demands despite the fact that they had barely known what to do with a sewing needle . The company I had rented my shop from ended my rental agreement with three months notice because they were not allowed to have Jewish tenants . It was at that point that I realised that one Jewish business after the other was ending up in Aryan hands and I could come up with a long list of businesses in that situation . Most of my relatives had been transported to Theresienstadt/GHETTO and some had been sent to other concentration camps . They all died . Lots of my friends from Szczecin/CAMP had been deported to Poland/GPE and died in the ghettos that had been set up near Lublin/CAMP . As for me I managed to escape this horrifying fate thanks to my son forcing me to stay in Stockholm/LOC during a visit in 1937 as I had been completely broken . So I left everything in Szczecin/CAMP behind . 
Schoengut an Austrian Jew lived in Berlin/GPE and emigrated to Holland/GPE in 1933 . Until the Nazi invasion the Schoengut lived quite comfortably as the Dutch refugee committees and Jewish Community Council helped the refugees . When the Nazis invaded Holland/GPE in May 1940 Schoengut was at first allowed to continue working as an interior decorator . He worked for Alois Miedl a banker and friend of Goering for whom he re decorated Schloss Goudstikker . After the promulgation of the anti Jewish laws in May 1942 all Jews had to register with the Gestapo Judenamt at Euterpestraat/STREET and hand in all their assets and valuables . These were banked with the bank of Lippmann Rosenthal & amp Co. who had been dispossessed . The Judenamt was later bombed by the RAF . With the help of a Christian Dutchman non Jews helping Jews Mr Bennick Bolt Schoengut could hide his jewellery and another helped the Schoengut to go Underground Maarten Hulst . They found shelter with De Graan Orthelius Kade 75 and in particularly dangerous times and during the frequent raids they hid in a specially built coal bunker . Practically all the inhabitants of the Ghetto who had not gone into hiding were taken to the Schouburg/LOC and from there to Westerbork/CAMP . On 3 September 1944 the Frantic Tuesday it was erroneously rumoured that the Germans were fleeing and many Jews left their hide outs and were arrested . The winter of 1944 was the worst time due to strikes and the break down of rationing . But by then the Resistance distributed forged papers stolen ration cards and organised a warning system before raids . A Hungarian Jew Pollak initiated this but when he was arrested he turned traitor . He even betrayed his own friend Geza Weisz who died in Auschwitz/CAMP and the Swiss Dr. Rimatha who had sheltered Weisz and who was murdered in Buchenwald/CAMP . Pollak was later killed by a member of the Resistance . When  Amsterdam/GPE was liberated in May 1945 only out of Dutch Jews had survived . 9 . Further references Rienstra van Stuyvenzande Christian employer in  Amsterdam/GPE . Schouwburg/GPE  Amsterdam/GPE its fate after the war . Frantic Tuesday Herr Heinrich Schoengut an engineer and interior architect by trade graduated from the University of Vienna in 1915 and then moved to Berlin/GPE where he worked until 1933 . As an Austrian national he was considered an alien by the Nazis and treated accordingly . He could not however abide the nature of National Socialism and emigrated to Holland/GPE with his wife Maria in August 1933 . Like all refugees they were warmly received by the Dutch and received all sorts of willing offers of help . For the Dutch this help was of a purely humane kind and they did not see their mission as a specifically Jewish cause . Herr Schoengut was immediately able to practise his profession and Frau Schoengut also managed to find work as a designer after a short while . At that time there were Jewish and general committees for refugee aid . Debates were held at the Amsterdam Gemeinderat council allowing orthodox Jews who closed their shops on Saturdays to open them on Sundays . When the Dutch foreign envoys warned the Dutch about the Germans in 1939 even on 9th May 1940 the Dutch would not believe them . Even after the Germans had invaded Holland/GPE Herr Schoengut was able to carry on working until 1941 . One of his last jobs was for a banker Alois Miedl a friend of GÃ¶ring who was married to a Jewish woman and who knew that Herr Schoengut was Jewish . Herr Miedl had appropriated the castle owned by Goudstikker an art dealer and tasked Schoengut with its renovation . At the same time Herr S. was working for the director of the same bank Rienstra van Stuyvenzande who later also became a Nazi . His brother in law was a high ranking Nazi leader . When Herr Schoengut made a legitimate complaint about the doings of a Nazi company he was not only forced to stop working but was also threatened with the concentration camp . From 10th to 14th May the Dutch put all Germans under house arrest . On the 14th they were freed by the Germans and Herr and Frau Schoengut like all Jews immediately purchased some poison . They also hid their jewellery which a Christian Dutch notary Herr Bennink Bolt buried in his garden . This Herr B.B. was a wonderful person who risked his life to help the Jews . When dealing with transactions for Jewish people he refused to take money for his work . He documented against the Germans whatever was asked of him . He would visit those in hiding of his own accord in their hiding places . After the anti Jewish laws came into force on 1st May 1942 freedom of movement for Jewish people came completely to an end . The yellow badge had to be worn vehicles of any kind could not be used businesses could not be entered 2 and streets had to be cleared by 8 in the evening . Soon afterwards inventories of dwellings started to be compiled . This meant that officials would make a list of all the contents of a home . Jewellery also had to be handed in . All Jewish people had to make an official application to emigrate which was to be handed in at Euterpe Straat the headquarters of the Gestapo Judenamt . In 1943 or 44 the English deliberately bombed this school building in order to destroy all existing material . This was the building where people entire fortunes as well as jewellery and silver had to be handed in . Everything was taken to a bank the owners of which were Jewish but who of course were no longer at the bank . The name of this bank was Lippmann Rosenthal and this has been a notorious name ever since . There were no underground organisations yet at that time . Like others Herr and Frau Schoengut began looking for an underground hiding place . A foreign Dutchman a teacher called Maarten Hulst helped them to find such a hiding place he also provided Jewish people with ration cards and provided assistance wherever he was asked to help . He was later arrested for these actions but took up his aid work again immediately after his release . On 13th June 1942 he found a young married couple of low status â€“ they were from a working class family â€“ in  Amsterdam/GPE who offered them an empty room in their flat to hide in . Their name was De Graan Orthelius Kade 75 . This ordinary couple were of a nervous disposition . But their desire to help was so strong that they overcame their nerves . As with all people in hiding S. could not make themselves noticeable in any way . They could not speak loudly they could not go out their presence must not be revealed by anything or anyone . Half of those in hiding were exposed through carelessness . This young married couple were very poor and yet they consistently refused to take money from S. They must have been made to since they had to constantly spend money on feeding the family as well . When the labour service raids started in June 1942 S. were already in hiding but they returned to their own home after a few days . S. did not comply with a summons for labour service . On 7th August however such a major raid took place that Herr S. had to spend the night on his neighbours floor and they moved into their hiding place the next day . There they devised a place to hide which was necessary for when homes were being searched . They built a platform inside a deep wall cupboard which was used for storing coal by shovelling out the coal and creating a hollow space with boards â€“ big enough for 2 people to be able to lie inside â€“ and shovelled the coal back in . Then they spent a long time practising going to hide so that they could calculate to the second how long it would take in an emergency . Raids were a frequent event between 1942 and 44 mostly on Saturday evenings . Especially in the Jewish/GHETTO ghetto in east  Amsterdam/GPE . The entire Jewish proletariat was rounded up and exterminated . There were Jewish people who moved back there who had a special stamp and thought themselves to be safe . The Nazis however simply did not acknowledge the stamp and they were all sent to Westerbork/CAMP . They were all made to report at the Hollandsche Schouwburg a theatre which was being used as a transit stop . After the war the Dutch no longer wished to use this building as a place of entertainment because it was associated with too much horror . Non Jews bought the building and offered it as a gift to the/GPE State/GPE of/GPE Israel/GPE to create a sort of Jewish cultural centre there . 3 Israel/GPE had to refrain from accepting the gift as the expense of using and maintaining the building would be too great . At this time of large scale raids Herr Schoengut like so many other Jewish people kept watch the whole night so that he could alert people in good time . During these vigils at an open window he would often see the Nazis but they never stepped into his building . 3rd September 1944 was the date of so called Frantic Tuesday . It was believed that the Allies had advanced all the way to Rotterdam/LOC and both Dutch and German Nazis began to flee . The oppressed people breathed a sigh of relief and a large number of them came out of their hiding places . Unfortunately it had only been a rumour and several of those who had left their hideouts were now arrested . 17th September saw Montgomery failed airstrike on Arnhem/LOC . This was followed by the great general strike of the railways which led to the hardest winter of the whole war . There was nothing to eat . Even ration cards got people nothing because there was simply nothing left . The weekly ration was 400 g of bread and 1 kg of potatoes . Anyone who could get hold of tulip bulbs cooked those . Herr S. lost 40 pounds in weight that winter . He suffered swelling from malnutrition and temporary memory loss . Frau S. had gall bladder problems and was generally in a weak condition with high blood pressure and her memory was also debilitated . During this winter of starvation there was no fuel to be found either since all transport facilities had stopped . People would pull trees out of the streets at night . Houses in the Jewish quarter which were lying empty were looted and anything in them that was combustible was smashed into pieces and taken away . Dead bodies could not be transported and were piled up inside a church . Many families attempted to cross over to Friesland/GPE to get something to eat there . In February and March 45 Herr and Frau S. were in hiding in the building next to their old flat . They walked the considerable distance from one hiding place to the other at night . They managed to get to the new space without being challenged . Another time Frau S. was suffering from severe toothache and had to go to the dentist . A woman took her under a FALSE name to a dentist whom she could trust . Frau S. was terrified of what the cost would be as by then they had no money left . She was prepared for an extremely high bill and how she beamed when the dentist told her that she had nothing to pay and in fact would be getting 2.5 gulden out of it because there was a gold filling in the tooth she had pulled out . To procure identity documents during this period in hiding they first had to be stolen and edited to suit the Jewish people to whom they were given . Ration cards also had to be stolen from the offices . In 1942 these operations were all only half organised whereas later the resistance movement was large enough for them to be managed in a properly planned fashion . In March â€“ April 1945 the Germans allowed just once the Swedish Red Cross to drop bread and margarine from planes for the populace . A Hungarian Jew by the name of Pollak tried to organise a warning service . People warned each other in good time so that they could hide from the German raids . He also helped to find hiding places for Jews and sheltered his own friend Geza Weiss in a Swiss man home who kept him in his hideout . After some time Pollak was arrested by the Germans . On condition that 4 he carry out undercover operations and betray Jews for them he was released . Sadly he kept his promise and took his task of betraying Jews very seriously . He even exposed his own friend Geza Weiss . Weiss died in Auschwitz/CAMP and the Swiss Dr Rimatha was murdered in Buchenwald/CAMP . Pollak himself was killed in the street by a man from the underground during the occupation period . 4th May was the day of liberation . People could be heard in the evening calling out the good news in the street but no one dared leave their hiding places until they were sure that the curfew was still being ignored and everyone could run through the streets happy and free without coming to any harm . On 5th May the liberated people of  Amsterdam/GPE descended on the Royal Palace where people always congregate on happy occasions . The Germans were still occupying a building in the area and despite the war being over they again shot at the crowd of people from their windows . Out of the Jewish people once living in Holland/GPE survived . 
her husband deportation to Lublin/CAMP the authoress fled with her eleven year old son from Wrutky/GPE in Slovakia/GPE to Hungary/GPE at Galanta/GPE the man she had bribed to take them to Budapest/GPE took them to the Police instead . She had the choice to go into an Hungarian camp but preferred to be sent back . When they arrived in Slovakia/GPE they were immediately taken to the Camp at Szered/CAMP from where a selection of one thousand Jews were sent eastward every week . Being a good cook and working day and night the authoress could stay on for 1 Â½ years p.2 . In autumn 1943 the Germans took over from the Hlinka guards p.2 3 and terror began . In November the authoress was sent to Auschwitz/CAMP where she lost her mother at the arrival her son soon afterwards . During the humiliating and exciting mistranslation by original indexer agitating procedures the women had to go through many of them went into hysterics some neighbours asked the authoress to sing to the women so that they should not go mad all of them and she sang the melody of Ave Maria but without the words as she did not know them . The song did not only calm the upset detainees but pleased an SS woman so much that she let the singer come to her warm room where she enjoyed listening to many more songs then she sent her to join another bunch of internees so probably saving her life as she never saw her former companions again .
