In February or March 1944 the women were asked if they wanted to be sent to this or that labour camp in Germany/GPE the author chose Lippstadt/CAMP the transport comprehended about 300 women from Czechoslovakia/LOC 400 from Hungary/GPE 45 from Poland/GPE and some others it took a week and many died on the way p.6 . Work in factory of and metalware . Ill treatment . The camp was evacuated in spring 1945 . Completely exhausted and panicking again and again the women were driven in the direction of Buchenwald/CAMP . On Easter Sunday after a march of three days and nights they suddenly found themselves abandoned by their tormentors and spotted the approaching Americans who immediately gave chase to the fleeing SS detachment and succeeded in seizing them . Ave Maria at Auschwitz/CAMP At the beginning of 1942 I was living in the small Slovakian town of Wrutky/GPE Rutka/GPE in Hungarian near the railway junction of Zilina German Sillein Hungarian Zsolna with my first husband and our son who was then eleven years old My husband was a timber merchant . The Nazis deported him to Lublin/CAMP in March 1942 . To escape the same fate I decided to flee with my little boy across the nearby border to Hungary/GPE where conditions for Jews were supposed to be better . I sold everything I could for cash and then approached a railway official to see if he could smuggle us over the border for a large sum of money . At that time many Hungarian troops were being sent to the Russian front through Slovakia/GPE and the railway carriages were coming back empty . My son and I were hidden in one of these empty carriages and then taken over the border to Galanta/LOC where a second man who had also been bribed was supposed to collect us and take us to Budapest/GPE . But the second railway worker who was involved in the escape did not take us to the agreed destination but straightaway turned us over to the Hungarian police who gave him 30 pengoe as a fee for betrayal . In Galanta/LOC we were kept locked up in prison for three days by the Hungarian police . They especially tried to get information out of my son using physical violence to find out which route we had taken to get there . But they could not get anything out of him . He came back to me with his face full of blood and said proudly Mama I did tell them anything . Finally the police commanding officer asked me if I wanted to stay in Hungary/GPE in which case the two of us would be taken to an internment camp or whether I would prefer to be sent back to Slovakia/GPE . He left the choice between these two options up to me . Helpless and at a loss to know what to do I chose to go back to Slovakia/GPE but once I had arrived there we were interned again and this time in the infamous assembly camp in Szered/CAMP . At that time this camp was run by the Hlinka Guard . The camp was permanently occupied by several thousand Jews men women and children . New inhabitants arrived daily taken here from all parts of Slovakia/GPE . About once a week there was a selection that is to say that about 1000 of the inmates were selected to be put into railway carriages and transported to the East/LOC . Mostly it was not clear what the criteria for the selection were the interned inmates were assembled randomly and those destined for deportation were herded together into a particular barrack room which they were not allowed to leave until they were loaded onto the railway wagons . They were not even allowed out to go to the lavatory . The camp consisted of old military barrack buildings which had not been properly converted so that the inhabitants were exposed to the inclemency of the weather . The food rations were meagre and always the mostly potatoes and beans . There in the camp I was also reunited with my mother who had been brought to Szered/CAMP with a number of other Jewish women . The food for the interned prisoners was prepared in a central kitchen and apart from that there was a special kitchen for the Hlinka Guard . One day I was sitting in the kitchen with about 50 other women peeling potatoes when suddenly a Hlinka Guard came in to find two women to help in his own personal kitchen . A number of women volunteered including me . The guard led me to the other kitchen and showed me a large piece of meat that was completely burnt and charred and he asked me what I could make out it . Using thickeners flour and so on I made a kind of sour sauce as well as some dumplings and so made an edible meal out of it . He liked it so much that he ordered me to report to the Guards kitchen every day at 7 in the morning from then on . The fact that I had this regular job temporarily saved me and my relatives from being deported . Every day I cooked for 60 guards washed up and tidied the kitchen . I worked hard day and night and so for eighteen months I managed to spare us being deported . But in the autumn of 1943 things got much worse . The Hlinka Guards were replace by Germans and with this came a new wave of terror . The whole camp lived in increasing fear and despair . New people arrived every day even those Slovakian and Hungarian Jews who still had had work permits to live in Slovakian towns were now sent to the camp . There were horrific scenes in the camp itself . Day and night the Germans would herd the interned prisoners in and out of the barracks and would shoot into the crowd with revolvers and guns . Many people were killed in this way . The Rabbi from Nyitra/LOC was shot in a shed just next to the kitchen . There were more and more selections and deportations . In November 1943 my mother my son and I were selected and sent to Auschwitz/CAMP . We arrived in Auschwitz/CAMP after a terrible journey in an overcrowded carriage . When we arrived we were still together as a family . We owned two small cases with some clothes and underwear I carried one and my son carried the other . But he was exhausted . His little hands were bloody and blistered . I told him it would be better if he threw the suitcase away . And that what he did . It did make any difference anyway because they took everything away from us in Auschwitz/CAMP even the clothes that we were wearing . After we had arrived in Auschwitz/CAMP we were taken to the infamous camp doctor Mengele who then made his selection . Admittedly we did not know what it meant when he sent the old and weak to one side and the others to the other side . He asked me how old I was . I was confused and as I was used to speaking Hungarian in which in numbers the digits are said in the opposite way to German I made a mistake and instead of giving my age as 37 I said I was 73 . He looked at me puzzled and sent me to the side where my mother was . At that very moment I realised that I had said something wrong and I corrected myself out loud . He grabbed my arm angrily and pulled me over to the other side . I did know what it was all about and only realised much later . I never saw my mother again . I was with my son for a little while longer after that but then I also lost him . When we were taken to be tattooed I saw the SS soldiers leading him away with the other children I ran up to the gate after him but was held back by the sentry . I could still see my son turn around and wave to me . That was the last time I saw him . We women were then moved from one set of barracks to another . All our clothes and personal possessions were taken away from us we were tattooed our hair was cut off we driven around from place to place naked . Our body hair was shaved off supposedly to stop the spread of lice and all this in full view of the SS soldiers . Finally we were taken to a huge hall into which hundreds of women had been herded not just from our transportation but I also saw many other foreign women there All the women were in a state of total exhaustion and at the end of their tether . Some stood around apathetically some shouted or laughed hysterically many bickered and there were scuffles there were also some who sang . A neighbour who had accompanied me on the journey from Szered/CAMP and who knew that I loved music and had a good voice told me that I should sing something so that we did all go mad . Of course I did feel at all like singing but as time went on and as we had been standing there waiting for hours I began to sing the Ave Maria . I did know the words and sang only the melody . As I sang it grew quiet in the hall the screaming was silenced the women squabbling stopped berating each other . When I had finished one of the female SS overseers came in and asked Who was the singer ? I thought my time was up . But she led me out and into her own room where it was warm and where I was allowed to sit down . She ordered me to sing some songs and I sang a number of German and Hungarian songs . Finally she had had enough and took me back to the women but to quite another barracks . As a consequence of this incident I was separated from my former colleagues in fate and I met another group of people all strangers . I never saw the women and girls who had come with me from Szered/CAMP again and probably this incident had saved my life . Then we were given clothes that were just bits of rag . I was given a dress which must have previously belonged to a very fat woman as it hung off my body . One sleeve had a huge hole . Seemingly a rat had gnawed in it and you could see my naked flesh through the gap . It was a thin summer dress and I wore it throughout the harsh cold Auschwitz/CAMP winter . We did get any stockings at all . For my feet I got a pair of Dutch clogs which rubbed so badly that after only a short time my feet were bleeding . Given this situation I thought it preferable to throw the useless clogs away and decided I would prefer to go barefoot . In the bitterly cold winter that followed I walked barefoot in the snow and ice . We suffered terribly on the parade ground where we had to stand every morning sometimes for five or six hours . Sometimes to warm up our hands we used to put them in the armpits of the women prisoners standing in front of us or next to us . Once when we were standing like this a woman beside me collapsed completely exhausted . Another woman and I dragged her to one side and shortly afterwards she died right there in front of us . When we returned to the group and tried to stand in line as we had been ordered to we discovered that a selection had just taken place and I had now been placed in another barrack building . And so I had once again by a miracle cheated death . In the course of time I was allocated to five or six different barrack maybe even more . Any concept I had of time or space ceased to exist . We simply eked out an existence there and I can only remember fragments . I do remember that in the beginning of my miserable time in Auschwitz/CAMP I was in the so called Roma Gypsy barracks . I also remember that once when we were sent to fill up the straw sacks we went through a room where someone had drawn a fantastical fresco . It was of some kind of coal mine in which some miners were working . In the foreground there was a car and a German officer was getting out of it and he was being greeted by a soldier doing the Hitler salute . Apparently a painter who was imprisoned there had painted this . In the barracks we women slept in so called kojen bunks six eight or even more women packed tightly together like sardines . You could move . If one person wanted to move then the whole row had to get up to complete the manoeuvre . During the night no one was allowed to leave the barracks not even to answer the call of nature . The worst of this was that most of us suffered from diarrhoea and cystitis probably as a result of the terrible diet that mostly consisted of turnip soup or an indistinguishable porridge . Once in the middle of the night I tried to take an overflowing latrine bucket outside and I got beaten for that with a broom . We got beaten for anything at all by both the overseers and the SS personnel . I spent the long winter months in this hell . In February or March 1944 there were several work transportations of men and women to Germany/GPE . In the crowded barracks where we women a group of all different they called out where the transports were going and they asked us if any of us wanted to go there . Many volunteered because they thought that anywhere had to be better than this hellish place Auschwitz/CAMP . One day we were asked Who wants to go to Belsen/CAMP ? I did like the sound of this name it reminded me somehow of Beelzebub/LOC and I did volunteer . Then they asked Who wants to go to RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP ? and after that Who wants to go to Lippstadt/CAMP ? I liked the sound of the name RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP and I was about to volunteer when a woman standing next to me said Do go to RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP . It really bad there . Come to Lippstadt/CAMP with me instead . Once again chance had sealed my fate . I volunteered to go to Lippstadt/CAMP . The transport consisted only of women . As far as I remember there were 300 Czechoslovakians 400 Hungarians 45 Poles as well as a few Dutch French and Belgian women . Before the transport left we were given clothes . I got a coat a pair of stockings and a pair of shoes . Of course none of it fitted anymore . The shoes were far too big and wide for me but as time went on as a consequence of the strain and suffering I endured my feet became so swollen that the new shoes became too small again . At the end I got another pair of wooden clogs . Although we believed that there could not be any worse suffering than that which we had endured in Auschwitz/CAMP we were soon to experience new forms of anguish in the carriages on the journey from Auschwitz/CAMP to Lippstadt/CAMP . 70 women were herded into each truck . Originally they told us that the journey would last three days but in reality we travelled for a week . We did get anything to eat or drink the whole time . We wailed and pleaded in vain . Finally one German soldier took pity on us and gave us some of his own food but only a few women had some and then only a mouthful . A large number of women died during the journey and their corpses accompanied the living to Lippstadt/CAMP . When we arrived there the women who survived were starved to the bone and so weak that they could not climb out of the trucks . Lippstadt/LOC is a small industrial town in Westphalia/LOC and we were to work there in the Lippstadter and metal works factory . However our camp was outside the town and every morning we had to march from the camp to the factory . SS soldiers escorted us and they herded us with whips as if we were cattle . We had to march in rows of five across and naturally the people on the end of the row felt the whip more often than those in the middle . So of course everyone wanted to go in the middle as far away as possible from the SS soldiers who accompanied us on both sides . Finally we all agreed that we would alternate where we stood in the rows one day on the edge of the row and one day in the middle and so on . In spite of this every day we were beaten black and blue . There were other instances of mistreatment and torture . We would be punished for the slightest insubordination or alleged infringement . One day because of some apparently small crime we had to lie flat in the snow and stay there for hours on end . The SS went backward and forwards between the rows and if any of us dared to lift our heads or just move a little we got a kick from a heavy boot . I myself got a kick in the back and suffered an injury to my spine which I still have today and which has caused me constant pain . The food rations were very poor . Early in the morning there was an indistinguishable black drink and we never knew whether it was coffee or tea . For lunch we had mostly soup and turnips . Now and then we had some horsemeat . The food was not designed to help us regain our strength but nevertheless we had to do the heavy work in the factory . All kinds of machine parts were manufactured there and it was said also components for the V1 and V2s . Large numbers of forced labourers worked there not just we women from the concentration camp but also French and Italian workers Russian prisoners of war and other nationalities too . We had to carry heavy pieces of iron and work at the stamping machine and solder too . The overseers exhorted us to work harder . If we did work fast enough or when something went wrong the Germans threatened us and shouted at us You saboteurs ! We have you shot . This forced labour lasted more than a year . In the spring of 1945 there were increasing signs that we were soon to be liberated . The camp was cleared . Shortly before Easter we women were herded together and we were supposed to be transported to Buchenwald/CAMP . This time we were not to travel there in trucks but we were to walk there . Once again we were assembled in rows of five and we were escorted on the march by heavily armed soldiers . We walked for three long days and also for a large part of the night . One night we were driven into a barn filled with straw . Many feared that they would kill us all before we could be liberated and suddenly a rumour went around that the Germans intended to set the barn alight and burn us all to death . No one dared to go to sleep everyone wanted to be close to the door in order to be able to escape from danger . But this night passed . The next day we were made to continue . We were all nearly dead from exhaustion . And then after all that it began to rain . We covered our heads with our mess tins . Finally we arrived at a hill where we were told to stop . The German soldiers stood in the road and had set up their machine guns . Again there was great panic . Suddenly we heard the noise of aeroplanes and just above our heads an aerial battle began . We all threw ourselves onto the ground . When we looked up after some time all the Germans had disappeared . We women stood alone on the hill completely at a loss as to what to do . Suddenly a woman shouted The American tanks are coming . We were overcome with joy . At first the Americans did not know what to make of this large group of people and aimed their canons at us but that did last long . As I understood English I was singled out as the group interpreter and I explained the situation to the Americans . They were friendly and told us which way we needed to go as they had to keep on advancing so that they could capture the fleeing German and as we later found they managed to do this So we were liberated on that Easter Sunday . Elizabeth Lichtenstein/LOC .

Berlin/GPE 1949 The Russian zone stretches from central Germany/GPE to the Russian and Polish frontiers in the east and contains the cities of Erfurt/LOC Magdeburg/LOC and . In this large region which covers almost half of Germany/GPE there is Berlin/GPE but its situation is different it is not subject to the Russian regime but to all four occupying forces . Going to the city by plane is no problem and no special permission is needed from anyone . It is more difficult to go by train as it runs through the Russian zone for about 170 kilometres or more . I was not bothered by these limitations my journey was â€˜ sponsored by the Foreign Office and I travelled in the train of the CCG Control Commission Germany/GPE . From Hamburg/GPE we went first to Hannover/GPE . This is a long detour but the train runs from the west and not from Hamburg/GPE . From Hannover/GPE I travelled in the sleeping car . Obviously the trains of the CCG run through the Russian zone only at night . There is a notice saying that the windows must be closed and the curtains drawn . So you do see anything of the area not even a night time view . At one station the train stopped for over an hour . This was in Helmstedt/LOC a place often mentioned during the time of the Berlin/GPE blockade the place where the airlift had started . I arrived at the Zoologischer Garten Zoo station on the morning of 24 October . The first thing I heard when I stepped onto the street was one man asking another â€˜ Hast du Alexen I was back home . The destruction of Berlin/GPE is terrible really beyond description worse than in any other town I have seen during this journey . No part has been spared every one has suffered . The Reichstag Parliament is burnt out large parts of the walls are destroyed . The same is TRUE of the Fasanenstrasse/STREET synagogue . Both buildings had been burnt down by the Germans long before the war and are now monuments which bear witness to the fact that it was the Germans and not the enemy who started the destruction . If the two buildings had still been standing perhaps Berlin/GPE Germany/GPE and the world would have been spared all the other destruction . The Germans complaints about what happened to them and what the war had done to them are put into perspective by these two buildings . It is very difficult to point to certain parts of Berlin/GPE as more heavily destroyed than the rest because everywhere there is terrible destruction . The is a wasteland partly overgrown by weeds there are still some trees left and some parts have been made into allotments . The Siegesallee conveys a tragicomic impression . Large parts of the once splendid Unter den Linden have been destroyed and knocked down . The Unter den Linden / Friedrichstrasse/STREET intersection once a focus of traffic unparalleled in the world now looks like a track across fields but without any fields . The houses in both streets are completely demolished and so nothing on one side faces nothing on the other . In the Wilhelmstrasse/STREET the has disappeared . The last fighting took place here and afterwards the Russians cleared away the whole huge building . Today it is waste ground with one lonely stump sticking up into the air a remnant of Hitler huge bunker where he committed suicide . All over the city you are reminded of the splendour which once existed now gone . In front of the sad remains of a house you learn that Rudolf Mosse had lived there and in front of the even bigger ruins of the neighbouring house that Aloys Petschek had lived there . Behind these remains some ruins protrude and you are informed that lived there . His niece had married a Jew . I was told that she had insisted on bringing up her children as Jews during the Third Reich and her husband is now the Parnos Head of Community of the Jewish Community in Frankfurt/GPE am Main . On the Alexanderplatz I tried to find the house in which my parents had lived for years 49 Alexanderstrasse/STREET . It has disappeared and all the houses in the neighbourhood with it the large square is an empty desert . Not only is the destruction in Berlin/GPE more widespread it is also more thorough . The other towns I visited were only attacked by enemy bombers but in Berlin/GPE there was also close combat with tanks and artillery . The rubble has been cleared away in many places but in others the ruins remain and are a danger to traffic . There are still ruins waiting to be blown up . Then the police block off a wide area passers by have to wait around the next corner then there is an explosion followed by the loud thunder of the collapsing building a cloud of dust rises high into the sky and a group of workers appear to clear away the rubble . Reconstruction in Berlin/GPE is much slower than in other places . The Berliners tell stories of the Blockade which lasted almost a year during which time they were lacking the bare necessities of life . Only then and there do you fully understand the importance of the air lift the â€˜ air bridge as it is called in Berlin/GPE . The Allies used three airfields when supplying the city by air . I visited the southernmost one Tempelhof the Americans airfield . Its vast area is filled with hangars hangar after hangar . During the blockade a plane arrived every three minutes . It touched down the pilot was able to have a rest and something to eat in the nearby barracks while the plane was unloaded and made ready to take off again . Within a very short time it was flying west again to bring the next delivery to Berlin/GPE . The same thing happened at the British airfield in Gatow/GPE near Potsdam/GPE and at the northern airfield â€“ I think it was Tegel/LOC . That when you come to understand what â€˜ Cold War means and how great the victory was that the English and Americans won over the Russians though suffering heavy losses . And yet whatever was achieved Berlin/GPE could only be provided with the barest necessities . This lack of everything has lasted and is one reason why rebuilding Berlin/GPE takes so very long . There are also other factors which produce the same effect the division of Germany/GPE into zones the blockade between East/LOC and West/LOC which cuts Berlin/GPE off from West Germany/GPE without which the city can not survive and the fact that Berlin/GPE itself is chopped into sectors . There are four . They are from south to north the American the British and the French sectors . In the east all three border on the Russian sector . You must not confuse them with the zones they have nothing whatsoever to do with them . It is difficult to get into the Russian zone and perhaps even more difficult to leave it again but you can enter the Russian sector and leave it again without any . It is very different in the zones . On 12 October I went to a conference in Harzburg/LOC . Not far to the east of there is the Russian zone . Our driver took me and some colleagues along beautiful roads past hills and forests to show us the . It is now in the Soviet zone . The frontier is indicated by yellow stripes on the trees and across the road . But the driver may miss the signs and enter Russian territory without realising â€“ that makes him nervous and he turns back ten kilometres from the frontier . That can not happen to you in Berlin/GPE . The boundaries between the sectors are clearly marked Vous entrez le secteur franÃ§ais â€“ You are leaving the British you are entering the American sector . At the entrance to the Russian sector there are the corresponding inscriptions in Russian lettering . This division has far reaching consequences . The city is split into two halves which are separate from each other â€“ not so much geographically but in other decisive respects . There are two local authorities now instead of one . The town hall in the KÃ¶nigsstrasse is in the Russian sector . It is the seat of one local authority under Fritz Ebert the son of the former . Somewhere in the west is the local government of West/LOC Berlin/GPE under Lord Mayor Professor Reuter . Only a few institutions belong to the city as a whole . Among them is the Jewish Community which is based in Oranienburger Strasse in the Russian sector . There are big differences between the sectors . In the West the shops are well stocked in the East there is hardly anything . In the West there is an abundance of fruit in the shops and on the streets in the Russian sector there is no fruit at all . TRUE in the Russian sector there is Werder/LOC a small place the â€˜ orchard of Berlin/GPE but the Russians have bought up all the fruit to make jam which they send to Russia/GPE . The two zones have different economic systems . In the Russian sector there is the collective with numerous co operative shops as well as the â€˜ Handelsorganisation HO . This is a state owned nationalised trading association . Their shops are better stocked than the private ones the prices higher . You soon learn from little things what it means to have this single city divided into several sectors with different economic systems . I wandered around from the â€˜ Zoo station to â€˜ Under den Linden . When I had had enough I asked at the Friedrichstrasse/STREET station for a ticket to â€˜ Zoo station and wanted to pay twenty pfennigs . But I did not get a ticket . â€˜ Only Ostmarks the ticket office clerk said . So there are two currencies in Berlin/GPE Ostmarks in the Russian sector and Westmarks in the British sector . Despite all the money I had with me I could not buy anything . I walked to the â€˜ Potsdamer Platz station but it was the same there â€“ that station is also in the Russian sector . But a few steps further on there is the â€˜ Potsdamer Platz underground station in the British sector and I got my ticket there . In both sectors the currencies are relatively stable but one Westmark is worth six Ostmarks and is a very elite currency by comparison . A customer from the British sector can buy goods very cheaply in the Russian sector and indeed many people from the West shop there in the same way as foreigners went shopping in Germany/GPE during the period of inflation 1922 1923 . They buy Ostmarks with their Westmarks in the West . There is an extensive market in the streets where all sorts of goods are on offer American cigarettes English or Italian coffee dollars pounds and also Ostmarks and Westmarks . People buying Ostmarks will perhaps get only 5.5 Ostmarks for one Westmark and on the other hand will perhaps pay 6.5 Ostmarks for one Westmark . These differences in exchange rates are the basis of this trade . Here the visitor is confronted for the first time with the â€˜ black market in practice based on small sums but he will soon be faced with bigger problems . The difference between the currencies produces immense difficulties in many areas of life and is bringing about the radical separation of the Western from the Eastern sectors . There is no geographical frontier there are no guards to prevent people from entering the various sectors . The powers are invisible which prevent contacts and circulation between them . A few days before I came to Berlin/GPE the East German government had started operations . I was in NiederschÃ¶nhausen/LOC . There is a castle there where once a Prince of resided . Now this large area has been confiscated and cut off from the rest of the world by a massive wooden fence . Behind this barrier lives the President of the East German Republic GDR Wilhelm Pieck and some others of the hierarchy of the new state . Among them is Arnold Zweig . His wife was one of my pupils in the VII Religious School of the Jewish Community almost fifty years ago I accepted an invitation from her and thus was able for a short time to see the area behind the wooden fence . Zweig lives in the manor house which the government has granted to him . Once it had belonged to somebody else who is perhaps now wandering about as a DP displaced person without a home to go to . It is splendidly equipped with furniture belonging to the state . â€˜ It belongs to the state means it has been confiscated and stolen from its owner . Communism just like National Socialism and other revolutionary movements has its fellow travellers . But Zweig is proud that his books have earned him some furniture for his private use . He was in Israel/GPE in Haifa/LOC but a German writer an artist of the German language can not earn a living there . For him and others of his circle Communism is their religion . He speaks about dialectical materialism like an orthodox Jew about the Torah of Moses . He was about to travel to Warsaw/GPE as the representative of the â€˜ All German Democratic Government for Unity and Peace to attend the celebrations for the two hundredth anniversary of Goethe birth . The government he represented had been installed just a fortnight before . Joseph Stalin letter of congratulations to President Wilhelm Pieck had been posted on many walls in the Russian sector and the inaugural speech of Prime Minister Grotewohl was displayed on the advertising columns . He had spoken like all the heads of government everywhere in every country no matter which system they represent . â€˜ The most important means to achieve our aims is to improve productivity . The seat of this government is the former Ministry of Propaganda in the Wilhelmstrasse/STREET opposite the former Reichskanzlei . This was previously where Goebbels got up to his mischief . The former Reichskanzlei is flanked to the south by the former Ministry of Aviation GÃ¶ring creation once described as â€˜ megalomania in stone and to the north by Goebbels former Ministry the whole symbolising the crazy arrogance and complete collapse of the National Socialist state . The evidence of the defeat is even more impressive elsewhere in the Russian sector than in the three others . One symbol directly at the entrance is the Brandenburg Gate . It still exists but the four horsed chariot Quadriga is seriously damaged by gunfire only one of the four horses remains and three of its feet were shot away with only one still sticking up into the air . has disappeared in its place has been hoisted a large red flag . Like other monuments of Prussian grandeur the Neue Wache is burnt out and deserted . Across the gate there is a long banner on which is written â€˜ Let there be peace ! The arsenal with the Hall of Fame is burnt out and partly destroyed . The trophies which were kept there have disappeared . A notice states that this building is to become a â€˜ House of Soviet Culture . Russian propaganda is insistent and effective . The University is also partly burnt out and partly destroyed . Those rooms which can still be used have been turned to a large extent into co operative shops in some lecture halls however there are still lectures . The name of the University is no longer â€˜ KÃ¶nigliche UniversitÃ¤t Royal University as it was called fifty years ago when I was a student there it is now â€˜ Humboldt UniversitÃ¤t . Somewhere in the West a â€˜ Freie UniversitÃ¤t Free University has been founded which claims to be the genuine one . That is why there are large posters calling upon the students to defend the unity of their University just as their ancestors had done in 1848 the year of the German Revolution against that institution in the West which is splitting the University . In the building the propaganda for the Stakhanovite system is conspicuous . This is a new way of organising work . In the English press it is called a kind of modern slavery and the way in which the Soviets have brought back slavery in Europe/LOC . The posters in the University present a very different idea . Pictures and texts show how the miner Stakhanov had one day beaten the record of some face worker because of the special way he had gone about his work how he had consequently been entrusted with organising the work and how he had increased the productivity of mining and of the whole economy in Russia/GPE with it in a way unheard of before . They say his system will free the working masses from excessive work and will give them liberty at last . May workers and employers decide who is right . In any case it is surprising to see how the same management system is praised by one group as the way to paradise whereas others condemn it as the way to hell . I have not seen a lot of Russian military personnel in Berlin/GPE . As in the other sectors and in West/GPE Germany/GPE the occupation in the Russian sector is â€˜ invisible . Only the police among them a considerable number of females seem from their outward appearance and uniforms to be Russian . But they only look like Russians in reality they are Germans . There is greater poverty in Berlin/GPE than anywhere else . When you stop in the street you will be asked by well dressed men both young and old if you perhaps need a guide . I have received petitions and begging letters from persons unknown to me and I was told that people keep sending them in large quantities hoping to get some money from time to time . The defeat is also demonstrated in the names of streets . The former â€˜ Kronprinzenallee Crown Prince/STREET Avenue/STREET in GrÃ¼newald/LOC is now called Clay by West/LOC Berlin/GPE in grateful recognition of General Clay support . In the Russian sector one of the most beautiful streets is now called . Another street in the Tiergarten is now named Reichpietsch Ufer Reichpietsch Bank to commemorate the sailor Ernst Reichpietsch one of the leaders of the German navy rebellion in 1917 who was then shot . What will these streets be called in fifty or one hundred years I wonder . II Nowadays Jews live in Berlin/GPE . That is not many compared with the in 1925 . But Berlin/GPE is still by far the biggest Jewish Community in Germany/GPE a fact which is very important . In Berlin/GPE single Jews are not condemned to live an extremely lonely life in contrast to those in other places . Although the Jews live in very different districts all over the city they can meet those that they get on with . I was invited by Dr Rosenberg the senior consultant of the Jewish hospital . There were other guests there too . It was a pleasant evening with most interesting conversations which could have taken place anywhere . To that extent life for a German Jew is easier and less dreary than in other places . I was received by the Community leaders and learnt a lot . The gentlemen there are convinced that the number of Jews in their Community is fairly constant and will remain so or at least will not change greatly within the foreseeable future . They believe that on the whole migration has stopped most of those who now live here have a special relationship with Berlin/GPE many were born in Berlin/GPE . They will stay unless particular circumstances force them to emigrate . As everywhere else it is mostly the elderly who explain that they want to stay here where their jobs and pension are rather than live abroad as beggars . They certainly sense the impending danger in Germany/GPE and particularly in Berlin/GPE but they are resigned and say quite rightly that it is dangerous for them everywhere and that there is no security anywhere . But it is TRUE looking at the Community administration board you can see that there is a strong desire to emigrate . There are different members now from four years ago at the end of the war . The then Chairman Kammergerichtsrat Supreme Court Judge Dr Fabian has emigrated with his family to the USA/GPE probably because of his children . For it is generally agreed that the children must not stay in Germany/GPE but must be prepared for emigration to either Israel/GPE or elsewhere . Nobody thinks about life after the next two generations but they believe there will be a future within this time span . It seems that in Berlin/GPE comparatively more Jews are in employment than anywhere else . A register of the members of the Community drawn up according to their jobs was read out to me in the Community office but so quickly that I could not catch everything . The list comprises names of people who are in work . If I am not mistaken there are only four Jewish commercial travellers left . What is striking in Berlin/GPE as everywhere is the small number of doctors because they can work almost anywhere and so do not need to come back unlike those of other professions . The number of jurists however is relatively large as it is everywhere . In Berlin/GPE there are fifty one â€˜ juristische Personen jurists as they are called in the register . The list begins KammergerichtsprÃ¤sident President of the Supreme Court 1 SenatsprÃ¤sident President of the Senate 1 . In fact there are two supreme courts now one for the western sector and one for the Russian sector . The President of the eastern Supreme Court Dr Freund is a very active member of the Community . There are twenty seven lawyers . Whereas in other places there are few Jewish shops or none at all the Community administration board in Berlin/GPE has set up shops for a number of members who thus earn enough to live on although the legislative body and the administration try to replace the private shops with expropriated shops or those run by the co operative or the â€˜ Handelsorganisation and they try to make life pretty difficult for the private shop owners by not delivering enough goods and in other ways . As already mentioned the Jews in all four sectors form a single Community and they are proud of it . The occupying powers have introduced their special system of administration almost everywhere . Thus in the British sector the English have replaced the function of the Lord Mayor by appointing a British Mayor . Here the city is represented by a citizen who is elected for one year and has the title â€˜ Lord Mayor . But the head of the administration is a civil servant elected for twelve years whose title is â€˜ Oberstadtdirektor and who is in charge of the administration . The Russians have established something similar for the ecclesiastical administration a board with a central office which belongs to the municipal authorities and which consists of representatives of all the denominations and also of similar groups such as the Unions of Spiritualists or of Anthroposophists . The representative of the Jewish Community Sigmund Weltlinger is so pleased with his role and prides himself on the fact that the meetings of this body are the only occasion when the mayors of the two municipal authorities which govern Berlin/GPE meet and shake hands . But it is not definite that this arrangement will last and this gives cause for concern . It is the Communists in the Community who demand the partition of the one Community into two one for the Russian sector and one for the three Western sectors . The seat of the administration is in the Russian sector whereas the majority of the members live in the Western sectors . One synagogue â€“ in Pestalozzistrasse/STREET â€“ has not been damaged at all . Others were damaged and have been repaired while most of the synagogues were destroyed . New prayer rooms have been arranged for small groups one in Joachimsthaler Strasse and one in the office building of the Community . The synagogues are too big for the few people who wish to worship . On Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur there are services in the Rykestrasse/STREET synagogue and on these occasions the synagogue is fairly full . But the services on Pesach and Sukkot are not attended at all . Daily services as well as those on the Sabbath are held in a prayer room containing about eighty seats . I gave a lecture there and the room was quite full . In the Pestalozzistrasse/STREET synagogue I gave another lecture . There may have been about the same number of people as in the Rykestrasse/STREET but in that huge room they were lost a depressing sight and a painful reminder of the fact that the clothes have become too big for the Jews of . The same is TRUE of other Communities . In Hamburg/GPE services are held in the small but beautiful synagogue of the Oppenheim Old People Home . They were always quite well attended . The Community still owns the big temple but there are not enough members to fill it and so they have let it to the Nordwestdeutscher . In the big auditorium there I gave a lecture on the situation in Israel/GPE the room was full of music stands and instruments . Here too the clothes have become too big for the shrunken body . In the Pestalozzistrasse/STREET I heard a real chasan cantor again for the first time in Germany/GPE . His name is Nechama he is a Sephardic Jew from Salonika/LOC Thessaloniki/LOC spent a long time in a concentration camp KZ/CAMP afterwards came to Berlin/GPE and now all he wants is to emigrate to the USA/GPE because as he says his income in Berlin/GPE is too small . The way he led the prayers was most beautiful but his reading from the Torah left much to be desired . In Berlin/GPE as well as in Hamburg/GPE I also saw a few children two or three at the service . They get a special treat during the Kiddush blessing they walk up to the cantor and are allowed to drink what remains in the Kiddush cup . There are some teachers who give lessons only a few on the whole but at least the children get an idea of what Hebrew and Judaism mean . The Community has engaged one preacher Mr Riesenburger . He performs wedding ceremonies and funerals . About one year ago an American organisation appointed young Steven Schwarzschild as liberal rabbi in Berlin/GPE . He got married here and his wife obviously an excellent social worker manages the Berlin/GPE office of the Jewish Relief Unit . Schwarzschild belongs to the British or American administration and lives in the British sector in a house that the military government has requisitioned for British officers and civil servants . The furniture was provided by the occupying authorities . He the rabbi eats out with his wife and not kosher food . Apparently he is a good rabbi but he is faced with great difficulties . Not long before I came he had given a sermon against the black market whereupon some group â€“ I do know which â€“ had threatened to drag him out the pulpit next time . According to what I was told he had been intimidated by the threats and did not preach the next time . I was not able to get any further information . I spoke to him personally only once . On that occasion Hans Joachim Schoeps a professor of philosophy or theology â€“ I am not quite sure which â€“ in Erlangen/LOC was with him . Schoeps is a Jew and does not want to be anything else . It is a shame that my time in Berlin/GPE was so taken up and the whole stay was so short . I did not have a chance to look into many things which were important to me . Schwarzschild is going back to the USA/GPE in the spring . All the rabbis who so far have worked in West Germany/GPE Helfgott and Broch only stayed for a short time . Now the committee of the Community has again appointed Moritz Freier once the rabbi of the Jewish Community as the conservative and orthodox rabbi in Berlin/GPE . It will not be easy for him . The older generation still has some general knowledge about Judaism when I had finished my lecture â€“ stories from the Talmud â€“ in the prayer room in the Rykestrasse/STREET there was not only applause as usual but also one man from the audience stepped forward and said Rabbanan Kaddish . But a lot of aspects of Jewish life have disappeared almost completely . This is the case with Kashrut in particular . There is only one Jewish restaurant in the whole of Berlin/GPE in Schlachtensee/LOC . The food is good but expensive . One meal including a bottle of beer is twelve DM West German Marks . I asked them where their guests have their meals on Shabbos Sabbath the restaurant is so far away on the outskirts of the city that you can only get there by car . They explained to me that some guests stay overnight on Fridays and that those who can not do so are given packed lunches on Friday afternoon . On the whole Kashrut Kosher food is finished . The hospital of the Community which I will speak about later no longer observes the rules of Kosher life . Only a small percentage of the patients are still Jews . In Berlin/GPE just as everywhere else there is a lack of rabbis able to represent Judaism to the Community as well as to the outside world who are able to answer the many questions of Jews or who are the equals of the Christian theologians in the religious discussions which are now occurring . During a conversation with Sigmund Weltlinger I learnt what problems Jewish men are concerned with nowadays . He spent a long time in a KZ and studied the Bible thoroughly there . He now knows it very well . There is above all one disconcerting passage that he does not understand . In Samuel 1 2.25 it says of Eli sons â€˜ Notwithstanding they hearkened not unto the voice of their father because the LORD would slay . This passage shocked and worried him and he was at a loss for an answer . Apart from their synagogues the Community also has its own institutions . The biggest is the Jewish hospital in Iranische Strasse . Dr Rosenberg is the Director . He lost his wife Eugen Fuchs daughter in a KZ and has married again a nurse . His son a junior doctor works with him and under him . He showed me the hospital . In his view it is even today excellently equipped and can carry out the many different modern methods of treatment . I saw the newly fitted out rooms of children ward which came into use for the first time on that very day nicely decorated with characters from German fairy tales . Everything looked very cheerful . But the hospital gives the same impression as the synagogues it also is too big for the Jewish population that has shrunk so much . As already mentioned only a small number of the patients are Jews and this is one of the reasons why it is not run according to Jewish precepts . Another problem is how to get doctors . As I have already explained there are only a few Jewish doctors in Germany/GPE and in particular in Berlin/GPE . They can get jobs in many countries and so they are not as keen as for example the lawyers on returning to Germany/GPE . The management is seriously considering employing Jewish doctors from abroad on short term contracts . Linked to the hospital are two homes a children home and an old people home . I did not have enough time to see them but I had the chance to visit the home for old people and children in NiederschÃ¶nhausen/LOC in the Russian sector . I think in the children home there are eighteen children mostly from mixed . The education here is different from that in the English sector . From their earliest years the children learn to play chess . The Director Mr Baruch told me that there were some good players among them . He teaches Hebrew . On the walls there are Hebrew songs written in Roman not Hebrew letters . On the desk was a textbook of the Hebrew language â€“ judging by the pictures it was aimed at little children . Some days before after my lecture in the Rykestrasse/STREET a woman had told me about her troubles . Her husband living in the Russian sector was taken from their flat by the Russians in April and has been missing ever since . Enquiries with the authorities produced no result . The highest authority â€“ a general whose name I have forgotten â€“ says he know nothing of the case . This case is direct evidence that people really do vanish into thin air in the Russian sector . In the children home I learnt exactly the same thing . In a twelve year old girl room there were two photographs on the bedside table one of her deceased mother the other one of her father and herself . But the father was taken from their flat some weeks ago he had been employed as a civil servant by the authorities in the Russian sector and has been missing ever since . Nobody knows anything about this and that is why the little girl has been taken to the home . Under the same roof or next to it is one of the two old people homes . The rooms are nicely furnished and cosy . I asked one woman whether she liked it there . She said she did . But someone who must know about it the Director or someone I think told me that this was not possible . None of them has a room to themselves and people who live very close together soon get on one another nerves . Moreover the economic situations of the inmates vary widely some are poorer than others some get parcels some do . This leads to envy and you ca stop it . This bad situation does not even change for the better when the lucky ones share some of their riches with the others . Yet I had a lovely fifteen minutes in the old people home . The oldest male Jew in Berlin/GPE lives there Mr Falkenstein a former glazier in Schlochau/LOC . He is ninety nine years old . He was just sitting there with his kippah yarmulke or skullcap on his head and when he took it off you could see the most beautiful white hair full and thick . Beside him lay his he is a pious man . He puts them on every day and has his breakfast only when he has completed this . It takes him a long time now until ten or half past ten . My companion told him that at his age he did not have to be so careful about this and said that I was an expert . But the old man did not accept this explaining that he was almost one hundred years old and did not want to change the habits of a lifetime . But he too has joyful moments . Every afternoon at three he puts the radio on and then he can hear the voice of his grandson who is an announcer . There is a radio in every room . As in other old people homes the residents here who are not Jews are the non Jewish spouses in mixed marriages . Twice I have visited the cemetery in Weissensee/LOC in the Russian sector . It is beautifully kept the fighting in Berlin/GPE has not destroyed its peace . In the office I asked about a grave that I wanted to see . It was found in no time with the help of a file . My parents graves are situated in a place of honour . On both sides â€“ right and left â€“ many people are buried whom I knew very well and who were close to me . Thus the visits to the cemetery were something of a spiritual reunion . On 30 October two days before I had to return home I attended a meeting of Jewish lawyers and other jurists . They had been summoned by the Community administration board . The Community is claiming the restitution of a large amount of land which they lost under Hitler through confiscation or in other ways . But apart from that there are more claims for restitution in Berlin/GPE than anywhere else . The Community has taken these on too . In order to pursue and deal with them they have just set up a compensation commission . Its Chairman is Mr LÃ¶wenthal who also spoke at the meeting . The Jewish lawyers however are not happy with these activities on the part of the Community . They say it is their job to deal with these claims and they feel restricted by the actions of the Community and also of other interested people and in particular the big Jewish organisations abroad . These have founded their own institutions two other institutions JRSO the Jewish Restitution Successor Organisation and a bank for restitution both with their headquarters in Frankfurt/GPE am Main are pursuing the same aims . Many are hoping to work for this restitution and thus earn some money . The lawyers are embittered in particular by an article by Dr Strauss a colleague who claimed in a New/LOC York/LOC newspaper that restitution should be enforced in Germany/GPE by foreign lawyers either from England/GPE or from the United/GPE States/GPE . He said the moral standards of German lawyers had fallen they did not keep their clients informed by carbon copy of any changes in their legal matters as had been common practice previously allegedly because of a lack of paper . He admitted however that the lawyers were intimidated the Germans as well as the Jews in short one should not engage any lawyer in Germany/GPE not even a Jewish one . The discussion produced some important insights . There are still fundamental questions open to discussion . The argument about whether Jews should be judges in these in these trials is still going on . In Berlin/GPE about sites are claimed for restitution . Between and persons are said to be entitled to claim . A number of claimants are baptised Jews . The Community acts for them too . Lawyers complain about the difficulties they have with legal processes . The administrators of the sites do not provide any information to enquirers . There are high costs and many of those entitled to claim can not pay them . One lawyer called the briefs he has been given a collection of briefs of the poor . Another argued that these cases are not exclusively a matter of civil law . â€˜ The state has robbed us and the state has to make up for it . But that is not easy . Who is to make up for the losses ? One lawyer mentioned the fees for a certificate of inheritance . Another called it immoral that the state should demand a fee when they the state had murdered the person who left the inheritance . The meeting has given me a profound insight into the situation of the Russian as well as of the Western sectors . The underlying factors have become visible . On Shabbos Sabbath 29 October I took part in the service in the Pestalozzistrasse/STREET synagogue . The evening before I made a short speech on Neshamah Jethera the spirit of the Sabbath the other soul which usually sleeps and awakes on the Sabbath . The Sidrah weekly portion of the Torah was on the subject of Noah and so in my sermon I explained the idea of the Talmud that Noah had seen three worlds one flourishing one falling and one new born . Our generation understands even better than our ancestors the truth which is expressed in these words . On Friday evening I had been invited to a meal by Dr Rosenberg and his wife . Later some more guests arrived among them Sigmund Weltlinger and his wife . We had an extremely good conversation . On Monday I spent some time in the office the JRU Jewish Relief Unit . One man an electrical engineer was in absolute despair . He wanted to emigrate to Australia/GPE with his family but an entry permit was refused because he lived in East . Nobody knew what to do . These are the special problems of the people in the Russian zone . The next day Tuesday I returned home . Just as on my journey to Germany/GPE Mr Bruchheimer was travelling with me the most pleasant companion . I am sorry to say this was the last time I was to see him . Not long after our return he was knocked down by a car and died immediately . Between seven and eight we arrived in Vlissingen/LOC and at eight went on board . The sea was calm the night absolutely beautiful . Later there was fog which caused a delay . In the morning we arrived at Harwich/LOC . There was a big squadron of the British fleet in the harbour destroyers cruisers battleships a most impressive sight . The customs officers were very strict and it took a long time until the train was able to leave . But a few hours later we were at Liverpool/STREET Street/STREET station . Herbert was waiting for me . We had a shock because the customs officers in Harwich/LOC had stowed my luggage away so well that in London/GPE it could not be found straightaway . But soon we were able to relax and I was back in 18C Belsize Park grateful for an extraordinary journey which had taken me back for six weeks to my former profession and which brought me into contact with what was left of my former world in West Germany/GPE and in Berlin/GPE and also with a great deal of what has come back into being . 1 Translator note there was no common frontier between the Russian zone and Russia/GPE 2 â€˜ Have you seen / met Alex ? â€“ Alexen is dialect 3 Translator note the Reichstag was destroyed in an arson attack on 27 February 1933 a welcome pretext for Hitler and other leading Nazis to rid themselves of their political enemies eg communists socialists etc immediately and to annul almost all fundamental rights eg habeas corpus etc . The Reichstag building survived the heavy bombing of Berlin/GPE but the fighting between the Soviets and Germans ended almost at the same time as the Reichstag was taken and heavily damaged and burnt by Soviet soldiers â€“ there is a famous photo of a Soviet soldier hoisting the Soviet flag on the Reichstag . her father and mother side Mrs Privat ancestors were baptised since the years 1859 and 1823 respectively . When she had to declare her origin to the Reichsschrifttumskammer her Aryan husband divorced her on 2 June 1938 in order to remain in the position of earning her and their daughter subsistence . Although her Jewish descent was known to every neighbour at Lankwitz/GPE near Berlin/GPE where they lived as well as to the police and Gestapo she was not called up to do forced labour nor was she deported . She never knew if it was due to a mistake of the Gestapo or to the secret help of a kindly police officer that she has been spared p.2 4 . Exempt From Deportation due to a Gestapo Error or Secret Help of a Non Jew ? I am the daughter of Dr. phil . Robert Hirsch and his wife Anna nÃ©e Lehmann . My father parents were General Medical Adviser Prof. Dr. August Hirsch and his wife Pauline nÃ©e Friedlaender . These grandparents of mine had themselves and their 3 children baptized in 1859 at the Dorotheenstaedtish Church in Berlin/GPE . My mother family was of Jewish descent but my grandfather Dr. Emil Lehmann in Hamburg/GPE had already been baptized in 1823 as a child even before his parents . From this entire background it followed that I had no relationship with the Jewish religion . After the Abitur A level exam I studied Classical Philology and Archaeology in Goettingen/LOC Berlin/GPE and Marburg/LOC from 1917 â€“ 1922 achieved my higher degree in Marburg/LOC in 1933 and my PhD at the end of the same year in Berlin/GPE . After a brief professional employment at the Thesaurus Linguae Latinae in Munich/GPE I married Dr. phil . Karl Privat Frankfurt/GPE on 17 April 1924 . My husband was an Aryan and worked as editor at the publishing firm of Ullstein in Berlin/GPE later German Publishing House . Consequently my daughter and I were initially not affected by the actions against the Jews by the Nazi government . We were living in Lankwitz/GPE an area entirely well disposed towards Hitler . My circle of acquaintances consisted mainly of Christian families who despite certain reservations were not particularly negatively inclined towards National Socialism . Nevertheless not one person out of this circle withdrew from us limited contact with us or hurt me with insensitive remarks quite the opposite when my husband was unemployed through the limitation of production at Ullstein publishers between 1932 and the end of 1934 we received the kindliest help . This although it was widely known that I was of Jewish extraction . In all political discussions the National Socialist actions against the Jewish population were condemned emphatically from the very start . The only two incidents from these early days of National Socialism that I can recall are 1 that the mother of a classmate of my daughter prevented my daughter from appearing as a Christmas Angel in the Christmas production at her school and 2 that in February 1936 an official of the NSDAP occasionally appeared at our flat and demanded we retract the flag . The National Socialist race laws only began to play a noticeable part in my life when my husband was asked at the end of 1937 to present his and my proof of descent at the National Documentation Chamber . In order to avoid endangering his position at the German Publishing House and thus his ability to support me and my daughter he divorced me on 2 June 1938 . I was the innocent party as at that time the Jewish descent of one partner was no reason for a divorce . However immediately after the divorce my situation as a Jewess worsened because on 17 July 1938 the order was given that required every Jew in Germany/GPE to hand in their passports to request an ID card marked J and to inform by the end of the year three registry offices that they i.e. the women would have the additional name Sara from 1 January 1939 . I believed that I still had a small chance of avoiding this requirement . But when I obtained my grandfather certificate of baptism from Hamburg/GPE this showed clearly that he was the son of two Jewish parents . This was not evident from my maternal grandmother certificate of baptism . Of course I was not able to conceal the Jewish descent of my paternal grandparents as they had been baptized as adults . In addition the church authorities had noted on the extract from the church records which we had requested This baptism is considered in form and content a baptism of Jews . As three Jewish grandparents were sufficient to make me count as fully Jewish I consequently came into the category of this order . In 1937 I had already once been summoned to the Gestapo to make declarations about my descent . I had deliberately left open the question as to whether I was fully or half Jewish in order not to endanger my sister emigration as half Jewish . At the start of 1939 I again received a request from the Gestapo to present my papers which I did immediately . When I enquired in May I was told that they were being examined at a very high authority . In July the police in Lankwitz/GPE informed me that the papers had been returned with the notification that I was half Jewish . This declaration must of course have been based on an error which was never cleared up . The police officer in Lankwitz/GPE who had issued my J ID card very kindly made sure that it would be taken back . Right until the end of the war I never possessed a normal ID card as I did not want to go as far as to sign against my better knowledge that I was not of full Jewish descent . Seen from the outside I was now relatively safe . However I had certainly put myself into a dangerous situation because it was well known that the most severe punishments were given for keeping one Jewish descent secret and I knew perfectly well what would happen if this deception was ever discovered . I might therefore say that I felt under extraordinary threat for the entire period of time until the end of National Socialism . Above all I had to prevent my papers from being examined again by any official organization . For this reason it was impossible for me take a job in as far as I was even allowed to work as a half Jewess . Far more important than for me was the decision about our descent for my daughter who was now considered of mixed race II which enabled her to stay at her school and take the Abitur A level exam whereas she would have had to leave if of mixed race I . However the situation became rather critical when I learnt from a neighbour in our building that the security department of a branch of Siemens in Marienfelde/LOC where her husband had intended to install my daughter as an apprentice had been informed by the Gestapo that I was fully Jewish and had to adopt the name Sara . Roughly at the same time the Party in Lankwitz/GPE had begun a campaign against me â€“ something I did not find out until after the war . My flat had already been allocated to someone else without my knowledge and my removal was about to happen when the house Lankwitz/GPE Muehlstrasse/STREET 39 a was destroyed by a bomb on 24 August 1943 which made the impending orders and void . My neighbours told me after the war that â€“ whilst I still had great illusions about the safety of my situation â€“ they had expected night after night that I would be arrested . As I was convinced that the Lankwitz/GPE police had me registered as mixed race I I avoided for as long as possible registering with the police elsewhere . For a few months I therefore lived illegally at various addresses until I left Berlin/GPE eventually and took on the position of housekeeper with the actress Brigitte Horney in Babelsberg/LOC . At her house I experienced the collapse and the occupation by the Russians . Naturally my worries had increased greatly when towards the end of 1943 the privileges for divorcees from mixed marriages were cancelled because now I had to be aware that even though one department had me registered as half Jewish another might take a closer look and initiate my deportation to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . Luckily this did not happen . Equally I was never obliged to do forced labour which was the rule for half Jews because the police in Lankwitz/GPE had transferred my details to the police in Potsdam/GPE without the annotation Half Jew or mixed race I . I never found out with any certainty whether my salvation was due to the humanity of the police officer in Lankwitz/GPE who had always been helpful or whether this was an error by the Gestapo . In fact after the war I had repeated difficulties in convincing official institutions of the truthfulness of my fantastical story as they called it . Grotesquely I had to present the documents of my descent in order to prove that my statements were the truth .

Mrs Schneider a Brave Old Lady from Potsdam/GPE In July 1944 I met an extraordinarily brave woman Muttchen Old Lady Schneider who lived at Wielandstr . 22 Potsdam/GPE . I had just escaped Gestapo custody and had been given her address by Dr Harald PÃ¶lchau a chaplain at PlÃ¶tzensee Prison . Mrs Schneider was a chaplain widow . In the years that followed 1933 she herself would tell you she was a devoted Hitler supporter living in what was then the Warthegau/LOC . She and her small daughter obeyed her FÃ¼hrer when he set out his Heim ins Reich back home to the Reich/LOC foreign policy . She slowly began to open her eyes here and the devoted Nazi supporter became a passionate opponent of the criminal regime . She joined the Confessing Church and raised her daughter in the way she thought was right . But this was soon not enough for the brave woman . From 1942 onwards she constantly hid destitute illegal Jews in her home . One of them was Ms Latte from WrocÅ‚aw/LOC whose son is still alive . She did this out of a sense of justice humanity and to make some amends for her earlier support for Hitler which made her feel like she was partly to blame . When Dr PÃ¶lchau told her about my situation she took it a step further and actively helped the political resistance movement by hiding a fleeing prisoner for the Baum Group a Communist resistance movement in her home . She clearly understood the consequences of getting caught which could only mean death . She offered me shelter shared her food rations with me and showed me human kindness . She did not have it easy with me . Night after night when I first escaped I would wake up screaming and the walls of this new build apartment were thin . The one week I was supposed to stay with her became five long weeks which must have got on her nerves . But she never made those feelings known to me . Then Dr Harald PÃ¶lchau 2 surprised me with some forged documents and a new place to live in Anklam/LOC . At the time the trains to Anklam/LOC departed from Oranienburg/CAMP and I had to get there on the S Bahn commuter train from Potsdam/GPE . I needed to change trains at Gesundbrunnen/LOC station/LOC near where I used to live . I was really well known to the Gestapo informants and I was now really scared of taking this journey . So the brave lady did one last thing for me she came with me to Oranienburg/CAMP and disguised me as a typical Potsdam/GPE local . I later found out that she sheltered more HerzblÃ¤ttchen little sweethearts as she called the illegals . When I went back to find her in autumn 1945 she was so weak as a result of the years of hunger she had always shared her food rations from 1942 onwards . Despite the fact that we took care of her she wasted away and passed away part way through 1946 . 
personal report of a young girl who was deported from Stettin/GPE to Poland/GPE . Stating many details she describes the unbelievable sufferings she has witnessed and gone through herself in twelve camps . Before crematoriums were built people were suffocated in disinfecting stoves p.2 . Aktion the shooting of Jewish men and women at Majdanek/CAMP from 6 am to 9 pm on 30 November 1943 p.4 . people were marched to Gross/CAMP Rosen/CAMP through the cold of January 1945 for eight days the way was shown through thousands of corpses lying on both sides on the road no food then they continued the journey by train for another week without food finally there were fifty dead in each wagon . And for the next fortnight they had to live under circumstances which made the women kill each other p.5 6 . Typhoid fever p.5 6 . Together with six boys and three girls the author succeeded to rescue fifty sick internees from being burnt by the Nazis at the approach of the Americans . Three cyclists pretending to belong to the American Red Cross followed by others with machine guns p.7 definitive escape . youth transport to Switzerland/GPE . 9 . Experiences in Twelve/CAMP Concentration Camps I Irmgard Berger born on 11.09.1927 in Stettin/GPE have experienced the following We my mother and 5 children were deported from Germany/GPE to Poland/GPE in 1938 my father was forcibly detained in Germany/GPE and on 9.09 . 1939 he was taken to the Sachsenhausen/CAMP concentration camp . We lived in groups homeless until 1940 then we were sent to the forced labour camp in Radom/GPE that was under the leadership of and Polizeifuehrer Dr. Boettcher . His deputy was Untersturmfuehrer Hans Schippers . We worked in a weapons factory and in workshops and the people in charge of the work were Haupsturmfuehrer Blum and Weinreich . The Exekutionsfuehrer who arranged the shootings with the Ukranians was called Kapke . Boettcher arranged an Aktion during Purim at which everyone who was interested in the trip to Palestine/GPE was to come forward . Matters were dealt with as if they really were preparing for a trip abroad but on the very day when they were due to depart two cars with Ukrainians under the leadership of Untersturmfuehrer Kapke stood ready behind the camp and they drove the cars containing the travellers en route to Palestine/GPE to the cemetery in Schydlowce/LOC where 150 people had to dig their own graves were stripped naked and were then shot dead . My girl friend who was actually there reported this to me and she was fortunate enough to be able to save herself . There was an expulsion in Radom on 13th January 1942 a so called deportation . Of Jews were selected and the rest were sent to Treblinka/CAMP . This was a camp that had been in existence since 1942 and where thousands of people were killed on a daily basis . As far as I know people were taken there in wagons the floor of the wagon opened up the people fell into ditches and there they were gassed and burnt . I saw with my own eyes how during this deportation small children were grabbed by the legs and flung head first against the wall so that their skulls shattered and their brains gushed out . Women who were expecting had their stomachs slit open with swords . Those who were somewhat frail or sick were pushed to the ground and immediately shot dead . Families were forcibly torn apart . This all happened under the leadership of Boettcher Blum and Weinreich . Those who were left over after the deportation were taken to a concentration camp on the Szkollna/LOC . Selections took place there time and time again . Children old people frail people were selected based on their previous ordeals and they were shot and killed . On 3rd of March 1942 we were transported to Maidanek/CAMP Lublin/CAMP on the pretence that we were being taken to a better camp . Meanwhile my elder brother had emigrated in 1940 he had managed to travel to Berlin/GPE and to emigrate to America/GPE . We were separated from my brothers in Maidanek/GPE my sister my mother and I remained together . When we reached Maidanek/LOC we had to undress fully in front of Obersturmfuehrer Dr. Blanke senior doctor in Maidanek/LOC and the Oberaufseherin Elfriede Schroeder the latter certainly had the deaths of around 2 children on her hands various valuables were taken from us we were inspected from top to toe in case we had any hidden valuables . Any rings on fingers which could not be pulled off were removed with shears . If anyone had earrings then the earlobe was simply cut off it made no difference at all . We were then bundled into a bathing area where there was hardly enough water to make us wet then we were bundled out into a cold room where we had to wait for hours on end until each of us received a torn and flea ridden shirt that was completely the wrong size some clothes and heavy clogs . It all happened terribly quickly . If anyone was unable to get dressed in a hurry they were beaten and then we were bundled in front of the orderly room where we had to wait all day long until we had been registered . We each received our own completed records and a death sentence to sign . On arrival at the camp we were separated from the men from the transport and we had no opportunity to speak to them ever again . If we happened to meet the men on the way to work we were not allowed to look at them otherwise we would be beaten . Some female supervisors battered the women obsessively these were Luise Danz Erna Ehlert Alice Orlowska Meier Ruth Haselow and Mrs Weber . We also had prisoner capos women who were previous society misfits and who were the most despicable people imaginable . The death angel of Maidanek the murderer of 1942 was called Obersturmfuehrer Tuman . Whenever he crossed the street with his dog you knew that he himself was going to shoot and kill some victims that same day . Up until 1943 people were suffocated in disinfection ovens after that crematoriums were built . Various small children were escorted to the ovens by Oberaufseherin Schroeder herself with promises of chocolate . The men principally the Jewish men had a terrible time . German career criminals who were mainly dressed as hangman capos in red hangman outfits took charge of the internal administration of the male camps . Whenever a detachment whether male or female went out to work they received orders to bring back only 100 of the 300 . The capos had to kill these people with their bare hands they were given any guns for this purpose and the survivors were made to drag the dead all the way back after their hard labour . The capos carried out their executions with glee . The SS men and women roared with laughter as the bone weary people towed the corpses back . At the start of 1943 those people who were deemed to be strong were transported to Plaszow/CAMP near Cracow/GPE . This was a camp where nearly all the women worked in the stone quarry and where the standards of hygiene were particularly atrocious . Dr. Blanke and Elfriede Schroeder also came to Plasznow/CAMP together with their staff and carried on with the same rigmarole as they had in Maidanek/CAMP . In June at the height of summer we were deprived 3 of water for 4 days . People who were working in the stone quarry under the hot sun had to swelter without water . I was made to work in a brickyard and had to carry out heavy duties on three machines all at the same time without any eye protection or anything similar and I had to work 12 hours a day . Hauptsturmfuehrer Gett was the camp commandant who derived particular pleasure from frequently having 20 men strangled and thousands of prisoners were made to watch this spectacle . It was impossible to stay alive for more than 3 months with the provisions they gave us there . The work shift leader was Untersturmfuehrer Mueller . He had the habit of walking between the workers with his large dog and letting the dog molest anybody who was slacking and in so doing these people were mauled and lacerated . I witnessed this happening . Camp commandant Gett and his staff lived in a splendid palace which Jews had built for him . They allowed Jews to cook their meals and wait upon them whilst at the same time allowing others to be trampled by horses or to be killed with revolvers . In August we were then transported from there and taken to a camp in Wilhemsburg/CAMP which had been rebuilt and where 700 women and men were made to work in salt mines . The work the women had to do was terrible and not one woman was able to cope with it . The SS Untersturmfuehrers who supervised the work laid explosives in these mines i.e. at the work sites they then hounded the unsuspecting girls and women into them and thereby killed a very large number of them on a daily basis and then they boasted about their heroic exploits in the evenings . We were sent to Plaszow/CAMP again 3 months later where we worked in a laundry and then after a short period of time we were sent to Auschwitz/CAMP . On arriving in Auschwitz/CAMP as a result of a three year spell in concentration camps we were given the privilege of being the first to be selected for a bath .
