I was able to thank him from a deeply moved heart now with the words of Hans Sachs Euch macht leicht mir macht Ihr schwer gebt ihr mir Armen zu viel Ehr . 63 You make it easy for yourself you make it difficult for me you do me a poor man too much honour . Attempt to quote the character Hans Sachs in Wagner opera Die Meistersinger von NÃ¼rnberg . . Truly the gratitude of these good people for showing them understanding and standing side by side with them when help is needed is indescribable . Their farewell cries Do not forget us help us ! are deeply embedded in my heart . Like the dove from Noah ark I was set free . But oh I found no country for the poorest that I had to leave behind with sadness and concern . Immediately after my arrival in Stockholm/LOC I did make contact with the Joint in the U.S.A./GPE in order to make the donations flow again . But it was only possible to dispatch from there for a short time and not sufficient resources by far . In addition a big relief operation was required which I endeavoured again and again to instigate . With the entry of America/GPE into the war the transfers were soon made impossible anyway . For my fellow countrymen I organised fundraising with the help of my friends in Stockholm/LOC which in accordance with their private nature and my unfamiliarity and uncertainty on foreign soil had been more through the others than through me quite successful which however could of course not remotely satisfy the great need for help . And again I laid myself open to the accusation of only helping some and not all . For still one saw in me the person who had cared for all equally . For all my efforts not only the deportees still stood before my eyes however but the entire unfortunate Polish Jewry . It has taken a long time before my spirit could overcome the depression about this failure of my mission . I had the shameful feeling of having no entitlement to a life in peace and freedom when I had to disappoint the hope of so many unfortunate people . In the car which the Judenrat provided laden with flowers so that I could not hold them in my arm I drove in the brightest sunshine back down the road to the railway station which once my poor husband had had to walk along in stockinged feet . Everything was so unreal so incredible like a dream . At the station the dear wife of the Advokat said goodbye to me as she was not permitted to go onto the platform . She promised to lay my flowers as a final farewell on the grave of my husband whom I now had to leave behind in foreign soil but cared for by friendship . How much would the woman so admired because of her courage have liked to be â€˜ die Kleine the little one again ! To return alone to Germany/GPE what an adventure ! On the platform I was called back by a guard . However I calmly produced my pass apparently unconcerned that my armband which admittedly had been beautifully embroidered in silk by the Judenrat with the Star of David had been presented to me must however reveal the pariah to my fellow passengers . The proceeds from my wedding ring had after paying for the travel expenses still a small sum left over which I really wanted to send from the first station Warsaw/GPE to my sister . However the train was very late so that I found no other opportunity and despite the insignificance of the sum looked anxiously towards the checkpoint . But the German officer dismissed my explanation with a wave of the hand and went on . At that one said opposite me If it is inconvenient for Madam to travel to Berlin/GPE with foreign currency then I will gladly exchange it for you as soon as we are across the border . It is all the same to my firm whether I settle in Zloty or Marks . But when I had left the compartment for a short time I realised from the chillier atmosphere that one had probably only now discovered my armband which showed up against the light coat . When we had passed the border I wanted to give the young man the foreign currency . Forgive me I did not know that you are a Jewess now I can not do it he said to me sullenly . As quick as lightning the thought flashed through my mind why should I trust him not to denounce me on arrival ? Who will believe that the Jewess had shown the officer on duty the notes ? Could I have made difficulties for myself in the last hour ? And so I tore the banknotes and let them fly out . I sat at the window and stared out sleepless into the nocturnal darkness . Sweden/GPE Sweden/GPE Sweden/GPE sang the wheels . Is it possible that I am travelling to Sweden/GPE ? Like dull listlessness it lay on my brain . But then I travelled into the well known Berlin/GPE station . I had been able to telegraph my arrival to the Reichsvertretung and despite the early morning hour I was met by colleagues and friends . As if in a dream without seeing to left or right I travelled to the acquaintance who wanted to put me up for the two nights of my stay . I had scarcely freshened up when the telephone call came that one was expecting me immediately in the office . There the colleagues greeted me with roses . Everyone had gathered and a member of the Vorstand that brave man who let his family travel alone to England/GPE because he believed he would not be able to answer for it if he left his work and who has since met his death in the concentration camp welcomed me with undeserved words of praise about the work I had done and brave conduct . I then reported back about the conditions in Lublin/CAMP until one urged me to go to the Swedish consulate for a visa . There one was enormously kind to me . One knew my fate and although my passport was not a proper passport one still granted me a visa . My colleagues in the Hilfsverein Hilfsverein der deutschen Juden â€˜ Aid Association of German Jews provided financial and practical assistance to Jews seeking to tried to absolutely insist that I demand a German passport from the appropriate authorities but now I roused myself from my lethargy and resisted . I wanted to have nothing more to do with the German authorities . I was entirely convinced that one would make difficulties for me at the last moment . The colleagues stood stunned before my outburst she whom they only knew as self controlled . However I was no longer a brave woman but an emigrant gripped by the usual psychosis . The two days of my stay in Berlin/GPE were filled to the brim with talks . Also despite the size of the city the news of my arrival had spread like wildfire and I was assailed by relatives of the deportees by representatives of associations had to work with the excellent case worker in the Reichsvertretung through our documents that had reached them in order to demonstrate opportunities for my fellow countrymen to emigrate . One was convinced like me that I formed only the start of a mass onward migration from Poland/GPE . The meeting with the leadership of the Reichsvertretung which had the unthinkable burden of representing the Jews in Germany/GPE I will never forget . I was welcomed in the most affectionate way and gave a report which concerned principally the organisational questions for the necessary assistance . I later reproached myself for having reported so much of the harrowing details and thereby perhaps to have caused alarm . There is certainly a big difference whether like us one is suddenly placed before unknown conditions from which one hopes to return or whether like the poor Jews later one must wait for the dreadful and inescapable fate . But my information has then been after all the reason for different organisational measures so that e.g. no other transport departed without appropriate leadership something that is of greatest importance not least from the psychological point of view of the poor victims . One did now have time to prepare oneself as the transports were â€˜ vorbestellt ordered in advance i.e. the Reichsvertretung was notified and the information and leave taking of the unfortunate people ranked surely among the most heartbreaking tasks of those charged with it . The strain and agitation to which the turmoil of these two days brought me left me quite suddenly listless . I was hugely ashamed of myself for during the whole time of the deportation such a thing had not happened to me . And it was good for me that the curfew for Jews was so early that the stream of visitors who were waiting for me when I came home could not stay too long . The least time ebbed away for the members of my family . Both sides were accustomed to me belonging predominantly â€˜ to the others . However I still think about it with a guilty conscience . The next morning it was then alone to the airport for no one was permitted to accompany me there and I was more anxiously afraid than ever before . The flight to Sweden/GPE had been given to me and booked in advance by the Reichsvertretung . The customs check passed off very quickly but when I wanted to go through the barrier a Zollbeamter customs officer detained me and demanded the handing over of my fur . As I produced the permit from the Devisenstelle in Lublin/CAMP he ordered instead the detailed examination of the seams and a body search . The aeroplane was delayed by this unnecessary hold up . That was my last meeting with a German official . As I took my seat by the window I thought Just do not see anything of the country that I loved so fervently and that now does not know me anymore . And the weather god granted my request and sent us towards thick grey clouds through which the aeroplane had to battle . The rain beat monotonously and gave the exhausted woman sleep . When I awoke it was light again . We were already flying over land and I caught sight of little red houses . I am flying over Sweden/GPE I thought incredulously as if in a dream . Sweden/GPE Sweden/GPE Sweden/GPE beat my heart . Slowly the great bird glided to earth . I was the first to stand at the door . Am I dreaming did I not see this in a film ? I was already on the steps and looking around expectantly for the friends whom I had been able to notify by telegram of my arrival . I did not know that no one was permitted to enter the airport . Something or other will still happen to me it said fearfully inside me . As if in a dream I went into the hall to complete the formalities . As if in a dream I climbed into the waiting omnibus . There oh terror my name was called out . Now something dreadful is going to happen and no one knows where I am ! A car from the city is waiting for you the voice continued . As if in a dream I climbed out again . There stood a beautiful taxi that seemed splendid to me like a Rolls Royce . In the back of the car lay a big bouquet of roses . I climbed in the car rolled slowly out of the unfenced area . Outside friends freedom were waiting for me ! The miracle had happened the dream had become reality . I had been saved ! ! And I sensed a new mission . 1 â€˜ untersteuzt in original . â€˜ unterstuezt is intended . 2 Gudrun Maierhof â€˜ Central Organizations of Jews in Germany/GPE 1933 1943 Jewish Womens Archive Encyclopedia last accessed 17th November 2016 . 3 Presumably headquarters of the Reichsvertretung . Schoenewald describes in detail the work done by the Jewish Women Guild at Bochum/GPE between the years 1934 1938 . In particular she speaks of the measures to assist the stateless Eastern Jews who were deported from Germany/GPE in October 1938 . Polenaktion . She praises the work of the Joodse Vrouwenraad in Holland/GPE with whom she worked together on various occasions . Holidays for Jewish children in Holland/GPE placing of women and girls with Dutch families etc . . 7 . References Bertha Pappenheim the brilliant complex personality founder of the Juedische Frauenbund Hannah Karminski her devoted much younger disciple who considered it her duty to remain in Germany/GPE to the last Rabbiner Dr. Leo Baeck on Hannah Karminski still unexplained death . Aus der Arbeit des Juedischen Frauenbundes in Boghum/LOC 1934 1938 It may be more tempting to describe dramatic events but small and seemingly insignificant occurrences are often more illuminating and give a clearer picture of the problems with which we had to do battle in our daily lives i.e. every day . Nowadays one often hears It is impossible that this or that person who was so close to these events did not know about them or gave such a FALSE report . Here is an illustration of this I was living in Bochum/GPE and one day I was invited to a general assembly of the local group of the Union of Jewish Women in Gelsenkirchen/CAMP which incorporated several neighbouring communities . As the president of the Union I would usually be met at the railway station on such occasions but as a precaution I had noted the address of the new Jewish Community Centre because almost everywhere we were no longer permitted the use of public localities . I took a cab and was most surprised when I was questioned with expressions of consternation and astonishment as to how I had managed to find my way when I had not met their representative . My reply that I had taken a cab was met with general disbelief especially when I replied to their dismayed questions that I had given the address of the Jewish Community Centre . The answer to the puzzle In Gelsenkirchen/CAMP it was strictly forbidden to accept a Jewish passenger or for a Jew to take a cab under the threat of punishment for both parties . We who lived in the neighbouring town had no idea of this incisive measure . Had anyone asked me about it I would have simply denied it although I must have known as it was a neighbouring community . Another incident on the same day one of the greatest difficulties for all our organisations consisted of the rule that we had to submit the details of every meeting and that we were not permitted to alter the slightest detail such as agenda location time speakers topic . The registration had to arrive at the relevant authority by post at the agreed time not earlier not later so that any irregularity 2 in the delivery could be disastrous for the respective organisation not only through the cancellation of the meeting but the dissolution of the organisation . Usually two representatives of the Gestapo were present at each session to supervise it . On this particular day in Gelsenkirchen/CAMP it happened that the main speaker a rabbi was telegraphically recalled through the sudden illness of his wife . I was asked to come to the rescue and to give an account of the Union of Jewish Women . The venerable gentlemen of the Gestapo two youngsters gave their permission with the warning that they would keep a strict eye on this unforeseen speech . I still remember expressing my satisfaction with it and promising them that they would hear many things that they had previously not known . In this way I could be certain to have at least two attentive listeners a positive outcome for any speaker!There were no consequences so that I ca comment on the effect ! 3 The expulsion of the Eastern Jews Ostjuden 1938 . Why am I so frightened merely to write about this event why does my heart beat so hard as to take my breath away even today as soon as I think about it ? Events that directly threatened my own fate and life occurred before then and afterwards but this day lives in my memory like an abyss a tear that can never close a wound that will never heal . And yet it all happened so calmly so organised no murder no manslaughter no torture I almost wrote . But that was exactly what it was a long drawn out cold cruel torture . One did not need to have the imagination of a poet to be a Dante to think of the lower circles of hell ! I thought that I would not forget the smallest detail of that day but the date has escaped me completely . I only know it was a bitterly cold October day in 1938 . According to Jewish tradition it all began on the evening before or rather the afternoon . The doorbell rang continuously soon a whole circle of Jewish people known and unknown a cross section of the entire community was seated in our large sitting room library . The tangle of voices made me realise that something was up but at first it was difficult to extract the facts from the contradictory rumours . All the Eastern Jews have been arrested No only the Poles Quite the opposite they are still free only the Stateless ! The community secretary came to her boss that was my husband and reported at last reasonably authentically so far nobody had been arrested but the stateless Eastern Jews had been banished and had to leave town early the next morning together with their families . What advice should we give them passive resistance appeal for postponement acceptance of the expulsion ? This depended on the circumstances whether it was a local measure in which case the community or the Jewish general organisation could possibly protest to the Party Leadership and at least try to achieve a postponement or if it was a general order from Berlin/GPE . I therefore telephoned the Jewish communities of Essen/CAMP and/CAMP Dortmund/CAMP and despite the overlapping confirmations also the Central Council of Jews in Berlin/GPE . After a discussion with Dr. Leo Baeck and his council we had no choice but to accept the tough fact and to help the poor expelled people as much as possible . After I had called the office of the Jewish Women Union in Berlin/GPE and after discussions with Hannah Karminski in my capacity as Union President 4 in order to find means and ways to organise care stations at the most important railway junctions we began the immediate local tasks . Firstly we needed to solicit the help of the few Jewish car owners which was not difficult as most of them were gathered in our home . They immediately began to collect suitcases to enable the banished people to take as many of their possessions as possible . Each time the doorbell rang another stressful message arrived All the men concerned have been taken to prison . At 8 in the morning the women and children must be at the railway station but they are completely helpless and need support . So personal assistance was required . â€“ The men are refusing the food in the prison they only want to eat kosher food . What was to be done ? The motorcade drove to all the Jewish butchers to buy all their kosher sausages then to the bakers who promised to reserve several hundred fresh bread rolls in the morning . We quickly recruited help with the scouring of the large copper washing kettle and so we were able to appear at the prison at the crack of dawn with ample hot food . Brushing aside the astonished guards we arrived at the inner courtyard just as the pathetic little heap of Jews was lined up straight . The supervisor in charge who was known to me indicated that we should deal with the meal at the railway station and even offered his car for transporting the steaming cauldron . So far it all seemed quite humane as in general constant activity helps to overcome inner agitation . This only proved partly TRUE on that day ... At the railway station a teaming mass of agitated weeping and screaming women and children had gathered and ever more lorries drove up and as it were discharged their pitiful load on the forecourt . Bochum/GPE was the collection place for the surrounding small and larger localities with a population mainly of workers . I should take this opportunity to explain why there was such a concentration of Eastern Jews in the Ruhr/LOC area . During WWI when Germany/GPE occupied Polish lands Polish men partly with their families were forced to move to the Ruhr/LOC area to work in the mines which had been denuded of men . There were so many of them that the communities concerned opened Jewish job centres to look after these involuntary immigrants . Already during WWI or shortly afterwards the mine authorities took a survey amongst these institutions to establish the contribution of the Jewish foreigners . I read the results myself at the time which were throughout satisfactory and partly outstanding . After the war these people opted 5 to remain in Germany/GPE where they returned to their previous occupations in business etc . thereby losing their Polish nationality and being regarded as deserters in Poland/GPE . For them a return to Poland/GPE would have meant the death penalty . This made their expulsion so very tragic . Those who had been brought to Germany/GPE as children and those who had been born in Germany/GPE knew nothing of Poland/GPE had no relationship with it and neither spoke nor understood the language . On the day of the expulsion and banishment there were more pressing needs to be dealt with . Through negotiations with the supervising Gestapo officer my acquaintance from the prison yard and from the children holiday transport to Holland/GPE I had succeeded in reserving the 3rd class waiting room for the women and children so that the newly mobilised Jewish Women Union and â€“ club were able to begin an extensive programme of food distribution . The well known kind Jewish heart exhausted itself in cheese sandwiches cake and coffee . The sausages had been exclusively served to the starving men . It was not difficult to conclude that in some communities the women and children had been fetched from their beds . All of them were only too ready and keen to relate their troubles . After I had telephoned Herr Parnes to elicit his permission to charge the costs to the Bochum/GPE community we activated the motorcade again in order to collect woollen blankets and warm underwear from the Jewish shops that were still available . The continuously renewing line of recipients did not come to an end but humanity in all its manifestations merely appeared tragic not repulsive . Only when the same face appeared again and again in the queue and the competitors became rebellious justice and necessity had to take precedence over the heart . The stationmaster had disclosed to me that it would be impossible to organise a special train before 11 p.m. At the same time he promised to add a luggage compartment so that the passengers would be able to sleep in their seats . This offered us the opportunity to drive some of the men for whom I had given a guarantee back home where they were able to pack bigger cases and thus take some of their belongings with them especially children things and warm clothes . On listening to the men one could hear again and again how very worried they were about the fate of their businesses . Because of this I quickly returned home to get my husband who was a lawyer to issue forms for powers of attorney specifically for this purpose . With these people were able to nominate relatives or the Jewish Community to represent their interests . Even then faith in the efficacy of German justice and business dealings was as great as before . I do not know if this measure had any practical value after the 6 events of the 9th November 1938 but no other measure no food distribution not even the permission to come out of the icy cold evening air into the warmth of the waiting room and to join their wives and children caused even a fraction of the reassurance that the issuing of the Powers of Attorney had produced which were pressed into my hands at times with words of prayer . Other details ? There were dozens that could be related . E.g. there was the 14year old boy an apprentice who had been collected from his business . His parents lived in Essen/CAMP and I asked that he should be sent there . When the official made a call it turned out that the Essen/CAMP transport had already left and so one could only hope that the child would somehow meet his parents at the border . We were told that the transports would be joined together at one point which happened in fact in that these helpless people were abandoned in the no land between the German and Polish borders on the open fields . We dressed the boy in warm clothing and gave him a small travelling case and nightwear . Never before or after have I seen such a beaming proud face . My little friend did not move from my side all day and later sent me faithfully the ready addressed postcard which was also in his travelling case saying that he had not found his parents ! I did not learn anything further 9 November occurred in the meantime . I had long since noticed an ancient paralysed man he and an evidently highly feverish young girl were definitely not fit to be transported . Even the Nazi doctor we summoned had to agree but both of them refused to go to the hospital and insisted on staying with their people . The explosion of anger on the part of the young doctor â€“ incidentally the only such occurrence of the day â€“ expressed itself in the sense I ca remember the exact words that one should not have bothered him concerning the Jew Rabble . In response I told him again in the sense of that I was responsible for his inconveniencing because I had assumed that this was an expulsion of undesirable Jews but not a death sentence but if these people wanted to go voluntarily as they preferred death to remaining in Germany/GPE then I could fully understand them . I can still see his surprised stupid expression with which he handed me his referral to the hospital . Then he whispered with the supervisor surreptitiously indicating me and then departed muttering and shrugging his shoulders . I think this was the only moment of satisfaction and even fleeting humour for the observers of this scene . However nobody succeeded in changing the minds of those two patients . The paralysed ancient man calmly allowed himself to be tied to his chair in order to be fit for transport . 7 Expulsion of the Stateless Eastern Jews from Nazi Germany/GPE November 1938 This has turned into a lengthy report but it was a long day packed with tragic individual scenes which left me with the memory of a tangled confusion . Every individual fate was certainly tragic but over everything hovered the threat to the total fate of all the Jews in Germany/GPE . Fortunately human nature has a regulating power sensitivity increases up to a certain climax â€“ and then becomes dulled . Thus with the arrival of an early dusk a kind of paralysing sluggishness descended on the teaming mass of people . The last woollens had been distributed hunger and thirst had been quenched the good fairies of the women club and also the selfless drivers had returned home . The children had found peace in the protective arms of their mothers slept on their laps or at their feet and probably gave off a little of their trusting confidence to their surroundings . However when they were told at 10.3 Everyone to the platform we experienced a mass psychosis of the purest form everybody rushed pushed although nobody had longed for this moment . The mothers cried out for their children who were holding their hand or their skirt whilst the children cried for their mothers any attempt to create order in this chaos was prone to failure . But in the end everybody was on the platform with sack and pack as it is said so accurately where huge piles of woollen blankets were arranged for distribution . This made a troop of the H.J. Hitler the opposite platform very envious . I hope that the ensuing conversation between us developed in them the recognition that this was not a joy ride or a night exercise but that the recipients of these woollen blankets depended on them for their very lives . The excitement rose to a climax when a distant signal announced the arrival of the train . It arose like a moan and a sob from one single large body and at the same time the hands of the surrounding women and children clung to us as we seemed to them to be a solid support . I remember precisely that I told them It may not be much longer that you outside in a foreign country will perhaps say Nebbich pity those poor things who are still in Germany/GPE now . They will have nobody to support them when their transport comes about ! At least you have someone to wish you Masseltoff good luck and Shalom peace be with you . A handshake and the storming of the seats on the train began . Here once again the natural safety valve the physical wishes and needs of the moment displace the awareness of destiny . 8 One scene which throws a bright light on the situation in Nazi Germany/GPE must be recorded here when the afore mentioned old venerable Jew in his Kaftan and with his round hat tied to his chair was carried into the train I heard a young man in a small group of three Nazi youths say to his mates Hey just look at this clown you simply have to make a sketch of him in your pad . Whereupon I in my fury turned on them and added not very gently Yes you do that and then never forget what you are witnessing here . In all your dreams it should appear to you until the end of days ! Again this astonished embarrassed smile . Whoever spoke like that could not be one of us ? Maybe a Nazi Women representative ? In any case prudence was the better part of valour in this case and so the heroes slunk away without a sketch!Who does not know the feeling of being totally abandoned when a normal train has just left the platform and instead of the former hustle and bustle one is surrounded by silence and emptiness . In that fateful night this was heightened into something almost unbearable so that I rejected the comforting words of the station master and the supervisor in my first emotional reaction . But for the sake of justice I must mention in this report how they carried out an inhuman order in a humane and much milder manner . They too were Germans . Postscript Through a report by the Office of the Jewish Women Union I later learned that in most collection places the transports had happened more quickly that this made the setting up of food distribution on the transit stations impossible that the tragic trains had been diverted onto inaccessible sidings . In Germany/GPE very little could be found out about the fate of those who had been abandoned in no land . This cutting off all connections this division of the Jewish community into helpless little parts was one of the most effective tactics to induce a feeling of helplessness and abandonment . The Jewish organisations tried to fight against this by grasping every possibility of staying connected but their fate was overshadowed by the feared suspicion of spreading horror propaganda . I particularly recall a personal experience at the advisory council of the Reichsvertretung National Jewish Representative Council in 1934 or 1935 . I shall try to find other witnesses still alive . 9 As far as the expulsion campaign is concerned it is to be noted that each person was only permitted to take RM 10 . Because many of them were wealthy individuals the consequence of a warning by the supervising official in Bochum/GPE was that many of the intimidated men entrusted me with Thousands naturally against a receipt and an indication where the money was to be delivered . Others who had been snatched without warning asked for a loan which in each case was promptly repaid by their telephonically contacted friends . The highest amount was RM 50 . Of the fate of the people in no man â€“ land I only learned for the first time after my emigration to Holland/GPE March 1939 where I was recruited to help with a collection of funds for these victims of Nazi persecution . It was a useful learning process to be transferred from the green table to the group of anonymous helpers . Since then I regard such a collection activity as the most difficult task of any emergency campaign having always valued it as the backbone of it . I never found out how much money was collected and how it was applied as we already had to emigrate further to England/GPE at the end of August 1939 three days before the start of the other hand I was able to succeed in a different action in favour of Jewish women who were willing to work and who were looking for a possibility of emigration from Germany/GPE with the encouragement and help from Hannah Karminski and the Joodsche Frouwenrad Jewish Women Council in Holland/GPE . If the recording of my memories is to give an explanation and illumination not only to me but also to those who were not present then I will have to widen my account and give a more detailed description of the participants as well as the why and how of the task and its solution . Hannah Karminski was for many years the General Secretary and Director of the Union Office in Berlin/GPE and as such also member and secretary of the higher management whether this was since the foundation of the Jewish Women Union in Germany/GPE is not known to me as I became the founder of the local branch in Bochum/GPE and its leader only in 1926 . As favourite child and devoted friend of Bertha Pappenheim she lived entirely in the spiritual realm of this outstanding brilliant personality with all the advantages and disadvantages of such an exceptional position . Without a doubt in her thoughts and feelings stamped by the contact with such an idol despite her enthusiasm and empathy it was 10 inevitable that her own line of thought was sometimes hidden especially when decisions had to be made where the difference in age and generation played a part . Bertha Pappenheim once said to me regarding H.K. This is the young person that I have formed and she spoke justifiably regarding the result full of pride ! From the remarks above it will not be difficult for the outsider to conclude that the voluntary submission of the General Secretary to the brilliant but dominating will of a personality who at times had no responsibilities within the Union could and did lead to problems in her collaboration with the responsible union leadership especially in the prone and dangerous period from 1934 â€“ 1939 . It is particularly because of this that I can state with greater joy and satisfaction and provide documents and letters as proof that both of us regarded our co operation as harmonious with the same purpose and fruitful in its conclusion . Hannah K. who was unmarried was taken over by the Reichsvertretung after the Jewish Women Union was dissolved . She surely represented a women union in herself . I am certain that in whatever position she found herself she always remained the representative of the interests of all women even when unsupported by a large organisation . She the beautiful imposing energetic woman was surely for any artist eye the type of Old Testament Jewish Womanhood and eternal Motherhood . She childless herself carried in her heart the destiny of all children . She refused to use the emigration visa in her passport as a means of escape . She remained in her post and died as a martyr . I generally hate the devaluation of this word for involuntary victims of inhumanity but in this case it was a voluntary offering of her own life for something she recognised as bigger and more important . Nobody can give any definite evidence for Hannah Karminski final fate . Dr. Leo Baeck told me shortly after his liberation from Theresienstadt/GHETTO Terezin/CAMP that one day the Gestapo showed him a picture of Hannah Karminski and asked Do you know this woman ? She died last night of pneumonia . It seems that she had been arrested but where and when and of what she really died Dr. Baeck never found out . A question to this effect was not harmless and simple in those days . I possess a beautiful large picture of Hannah which she gave to me before my emigration but she becomes most alive to me through her many letters suggestions and publications . 11 Particularly characteristic of her personality and method of work is a letter ostensibly addressed to me which I received in Holland/GPE 1939 . Memories of People and Events in Jewish Social Work in Hitler Germany/GPE The Jewish Women Union was forced to dissolve H.K. worked on Women Affairs within the Reichsvereinigung . She was personally in touch with many of the former colleagues in Germany/GPE and abroad collected all notifications and data and reported them to me in such a manner so as to make it an ideal circular for all concerned even though in its appearance it was a personal letter addressed to me . By repeating any information I had given her earlier she included this in her report . My husband called this document a masterpiece which militated effectively against the devilish plan of atomising our community . Then I received a request from the Reichsvertretung der Juden in Deutschland Representative Organisation of the Jews in Germany/GPE written on 4/14/1939 and signed by Prof. Cora Berliner our former vice president and Hannah Karminski to make myself available to the Jewish Women Union in Holland/GPE  Amsterdam/GPE in order to assist with the placing of 50 Jewish women and girls as domestic help in Dutch families . The Women Union had achieved the permission for immigration and work permits from the Dutch Government . This campaign naturally required thorough organisational preparation in Germany/GPE whereby the knowledge of and personal relations with our women were especially useful to the organs of the Reichsvertretung . It was important not only to consider social aspects but to examine the girls objectively for their suitability as the Jewish Women Union had had to supply certain guarantees and the failure of a single one could endanger the entire emergency action . Unfortunately this occasioned certain restrictions concerning nationality age etc . e.g. stateless persons were not admitted . The entire correspondence together with other documents from my social work in Holland/GPE which mostly relate to questions on emigration are contained in one of my files . As far as I remember there is also correspondence with Lily Montagu . Another instance of the Dutch Jewish Women Union willingness to help It was in the summer of 1934 or 1935 that we i.e. the Jewish Women Union in Germany/GPE expressed the wish to bring Jewish children of school age to Holland/GPE during the holidays for recuperation both physical and psychological . The Dutch Union declared itself willing to accommodate 250 children in families 12 or homes . For reasons of comfortable and shorter journey times and the very limited possibilities of recovery in the industrial region we decided to choose children from the Rhineland/CAMP and Westphalia/CAMP from Koblenz/CAMP to Dortmund/CAMP . We had complete freedom of choice the only thing required was a medical certificate that there was no infectious illness present . Of course we had to take into consideration requests by the host families as to gender age religious affiliation to ensure the necessary match with the individual household . Together with a representative of the Dutch Union who met with our committee at my house we dealt with all the organisational prerequisites . Interestingly the railway authorities provided a special train for us whose three wagons came together in Duisburg/LOC and that the passport office in Bochum/GPE issued a collective passport for my group whereupon the groups in the other towns had no problems in obtaining similar collective passports . I myself accompanied the transport across the border where the representatives of the Dutch Union took over the protection of the children and a representative of the government welcomed them in the name of the Queen . The joy was merely diminished by the disappointment that the Queen crown on her head was not there in person . It is tempting to lose oneself in reminiscences of many a touching or even amusing incident however in this context the only fact of interest is that such a project was only possible through the cooperation of the authorities or individual officials . The only not so pleasant corollary concerned me however with a happy end . One day at the end of the holidays I was called home from the weekly market by a breathless pointy nosed employee of my husband with the horror message The Gestapo has come to arrest you ! In reality it was an official from the passport office who rather angrily accosted me You really landed me in the soup but you can eat it yourself ! I replied that I was not fond of soup of any kind and asked him for an explanation for this scene . What had happened ? He had been criticised from above because the children holiday had not been permitted officially as I had claimed . Fortunately I was able to offer for his inspection the original permission stamped with the swastika which had been sent to our Berlin/GPE offices . Peacefully we went to my home which however did not prevent that the rumour of my arrest spread through the town with the speed of wind . After examining the document thoroughly and muttering a curse on the busybodies in 13 Berlin/GPE my friend even became interested in the outcome of the transport and I rewarded him by telling him that not one of the children gained less than 3 lb but some a lot more . Later on as expulsions continued apace it happened that some of the host families took in their children . So it came about that e.g. the son of friends of mine who both perished afterwards was saved by his former hosts . He now lives in America/GPE after learning to grind optical lenses in Holland/GPE . 14 A memory from the time of my activity as a member of the Legal Committee of the Prussian Association of Jewish Communities in Germany/GPE I must state in advance that I was the only woman on this committee which naturally consisted mostly of lawyers . The Prussian government had tasked the Association with the drawing up of guidelines for Jewish prison chaplains and this task had been passed on to the committee . As I in my capacity as member of the town council in my home town of Bochum/GPE had been involved in the local committee for prison aid and not only had worked practically as such but had also taken part in a course of specific questions of prison care and social prison aid which had equally involved the local prison chaplains the committee of the Prussian Association of Jewish Communities entrusted me with the responsibility of formulating the guidelines that were to be newly issued . There may have been guidelines for Protestant and Catholic priests before but never for rabbis . After my report it was decided to create an editing committee . I suggested a female highly suitable lawyer who lived in Berlin/GPE as did the other committee members . In response a new but very old ! member of our committee questioned why there had to be a woman on it and how it came about in the first place that a woman and to boot a non lawyer was part of the Legal Committee and in addition writing the report whereupon I replied calmly and modestly Dear Privy Counsellor that was his title I represent simple common sense . Hearty laughter from the lawyers .... and unanimous acceptance of my suggestions . P.S. Later it turned out that this Privy Counsellor Goldfeld was the father of a Frau Wachsmann nee Goldfeld Breslau/GPE who was known to me and who was a capable socially active person . He took great care to clarify that his remarks were in no way an expression of his opposition to the participation of women but that he was merely expressing his amazement . Therefore quasi a compliment ! 
personal report by Mrs Kafka formerly from Prague/GPE who was deported to the Lodz/GHETTO Litzmannstadt/GHETTO Ghetto on 19 October 1941 . Her husband Dr. jr . Emil Kafka former Kultuspraesident of the Jewish community in Prague/GPE and Grossmeister odd fellows had gone to Paris/GPE in spring 1939 in order to discuss with the American Joint a systematic Jewish emigration from Czechoslovakia/GPE . As he could not stay any longer in Prague/GPE he went via Paris/GPE to London/GPE . His wife in return had to suffer from the growing chicanes of the Gestapo and was finally sent to Lodz/GHETTO the Litzmannstadt/GHETTO Ghetto . The report includes a description of Ghetto life and management the grosse sperre before the selections for the transports took place when nobody was supposed to move from the barracks the liquidation of the Ghetto because of the approaching Russians from people in the beginning only were still alive when most people were sent to extermination camps Mrs Kafka to Auschwitz/CAMP . 8 . P.III.h . Lodz/GHETTO Litzmannstandt/GHETTO No . 30 At the time when Hitler invaded Prague/GPE 3/15/1939 Elsa Kafka husband Dr. jur . Emil Kafka was the President of KultusprÃ¤sident and Grand Master of â€˜ Odd Fellows . The Jewish City Hall was searched only a few days later . They took the passports away from Dr Kafka . The Germans demanded foreign currency for each emigrating Jew . This foreign currency was urgently needed that is why they allowed Dr Kafka to go to Paris/GPE in order to negotiate there with the American Joint . From there the foreign currency was directly sent to Germany/GPE to enable the Jews to emigrate . To create a job opportunity for Jewish emigrants Dr Kafka also had successful talks in Paris/GPE with Rothschild . He returned home on 6 August and went back to Paris/GPE on 19-Aug and from there went on to London/GPE . He did not go back to Prague/GPE . Elsa Kafka was called to see the Gestapo was called again and again and questioned . She was prohibited from leaving Prague/GPE . The Kommandant who managed the Jewish issue was called Eichmann a cruel and hard man . Mrs Kafka read in an English newspaper two or three years ago that Eichmann is in Egypt/GPE where he continued in his evil ways . Eichmann successor was Kommandant GÃ¼nther . It was from him that Frau Kafka received the order to vacate her apartment as the house was confiscated for the Hitler Youth . Mrs Kafka was forced to move in with friends where she stayed for four weeks . On 19 October 41 she was sent to Lodz/GHETTO into the Ghetto . She was allowed to take 50 kilos of luggage partially walked on foot until she arrived there during a blizzard . This Ghetto Litzmannstadt/GHETTO was the former criminal quarter where Polish Jews had already been accommodated for two years completely starved and ragged figures . This Ghetto was like a small town consisting of so many wooden huts without windows and without sewerage . More than 80 people dwelt in a normal sized room . These huts were often far apart sometimes one had to walk for a while 15 minutes over a field to get to the other hut . There was also an old people home and an orphanage . The old people home consisted of six huts . There the beds were placed closely together everyone had a bed of their own . In the orphanage too each child had their own bed . They died like flies of hunger and cold . Mrs Kafka was given oversight of the old people home and then of the orphanage . She had to rise at 5 am make the coffee crossed out one was called early to the roll call then the plank beds had to be put in order and the rooms tidied up . One queued for hours to get the rations . Potato peels were a luxury . Vegetables were cooked out of beetroot peels . Mrs Kafka had to wash and mend all of the laundry . Everyone was so occupied that 2 there was no time nor energy nor sense for possible friendships . One was far too undernourished and exhausted . Mrs Kafka often worked until 12 at night . People worked hard in the Ghetto . Only the old were exempt from this . The children had to be at the workplace at 7 am already the girls in the sewing rooms the boys in a mechanical engineering workshop . There were countless factories . All kinds of things were made furniture fake flowers clothes shoes undergarments artisanal crafts and so on . One worked from 7 am to 7 pm . The cold in winter was so great that the breath from one mouth turned into icicles and lay on the neck and chin and shirt . The block eldest Chaim Rumkowsky was a clever but sadistically disposed man . He was the Ghetto absolute ruler . He thought that as long as the Jews could productively work for the Germans they would be preserved . Transports arrived incessantly . The criminal police were in the Ghetto and collected Jews who lived in Lodz/LOC on a daily basis . They were beaten terribly . The food rations which were meant to last for 14 days arrived very irregularly sometimes only after 4 weeks . They consisted of the following margarine or oil â€“ 2 ounces sugar â€“ 4 ounces flour â€“ 1 pound . cabbage â€“ 2 pounds potatoes â€“ 1 pound . bread â€“ 2 pounds per week . There was only horse meat â€“ once every 6 weeks â€“ 2 ounces . Potatoes were rare . Later there were none at all . One cooked soup from grass in Lodz/LOC until that too was forbidden because the grass was needed for the animals . For their work the Jews received Ghetto money which was only valid in the Ghetto . Mrs Kafka had not seen any coins but possessed a slip of paper which counted for 10 Marks it was later taken away from her at Auschwitz/CAMP . The Polish Jews who had been in the Ghetto since 1939 smuggled in goods from Lodz/LOC . One could buy all sorts of things for example food potatoes were 400 Marks per 1 pound . 200 Marks had to be paid for 2 pounds of bread . Mrs Kafka income however was 110 marks per month . In March â€˜ 44 one could suddenly be sent 4 pound parcels . The bread arrived completely mouldy but was still eaten one put the bread into water for a few hours and then the mould floated on top of the water . Mrs Kafka was grasped by horror when she spoke about the transports . At first one knew early on when a transport was being assembled but later the Nazis came suddenly in the night and took people from their beds . One night they came and took the sick out of the hospital they were gassed in the train carriages or in Auschwitz/CAMP . The great curfew was horrible . Everyone had to remain at home all streets in the ghetto were cordoned off . Then the Germans came selected people and took them away on vehicles . One day they took children 3 who were unable to work another time old people . Some transports went to the Czenstochau Labour Camp most however to Auschwitz/CAMP . Those with transmittable diseases dysentery typhoid were put into an isolation hospital . This hospital was run by one Dr MÃ¼ller . Before the liberation through the Russians Dr MÃ¼ller was forced to set the hospital with all its inhabitants alight and finally he was thrown into the burning building himself . On one day in the Ghetto 7 men were hanged for a minor offence . Everyone including the children had to assemble in the courtyard and watch the procedure . The children screamed and many women fainted . During one of the great curfews one woman did not want to give them her child . It was torn from her arms taken by its tiny feet smashed with the head against the wall and thereby murdered . Thus there was always made space for newly arriving transports . When the Russians had come close to Lodz/GHETTO the ghetto was disbanded and the survivors taken to Auschwitz/CAMP . At the start there were at the time of the disbandment only were alive . All others had perished . Before this ghetto was disbanded the mayor of Lodz/GHETTO came and gave a speech The Jews are now going to the bombed out areas and must take with them everything they own . Mrs Kafka and two gentlemen belonged to the transport management . In view of what Dr Kafka had done for the Jews Chaim Rumkowsky the leader protected her . The German Camp director was called Herr von Bibow . He wanted to confuse the prisoners by giving them a letter on their way which were addressed to all German authorities in Aussig . The German authorities ought to be of assistance â€¦ . But the route led to Auschwitz/CAMP into the concentration camp . They were put into cattle waggons and arrived there at 2 am . Women and men and children . All luggage had to be left in the waggons . SS men separated the men the women and the children . Then they were chased across the Camp/STREET Street/STREET ./STREET The/CAMP concentration camp consisted of so many blocks with a courtyard each . No tree no single blade of grass anywhere . One saw nothing but emaciated figures . Some were kneeling others were leaning against the wall . They wore rags as clothes . The newly arrived were herded past them into a building . There the order came Undress ! . The clothes were thrown onto a heap and the women were led away by SS women . Stark naked . Then they came into a different block for a medical examination . Next to Mrs Kafka stood a young 23 year old girl with rather weak legs . Although she assured the doctor in return to his questions that she could work â€“ stating that she had proven this in Lodz/GHETTO â€“ she was declared unfit and was chased with a column of other women into the gas chambers . The others were placed under a shower and after their hair had been shorn off they were thrown some dirty rags as clothing . 4 By now it was evening and again they were herded into a different block which was built out of wood and had gates at both ends . In the middle a kind of brick bench ran from one gate to the other with troughs and taps . The female camp eldest stood up on that bench she wore a silk nightgown and spoke to them You are now in an extermination camp . Early in the mornings and in the evenings you will be called to roll call . You must stand there for many hours . Sometimes from 3 pm to midnight sometimes early from 3 am . When someone drops dead you are not allowed to stir . The female block eldest more or less had privileges . She had a small shed for herself whereas the others lay or kneeled on the concrete floor . When later plank beds were given out to sleep in 6 women lay on one plank bed feet head â€“ feet head â€“ feet . One lay pressed together like sardines . Sometimes one had to stand at roll call on naked clay earth . The arms lifted high and a brick in each hand . On the third day there was a special roll call . The female block eldest walked up and down saw Mrs Kafka stand at the corner or a row she walked close up to her and gave her an imperceptible push . A sign . Mrs Kafka completely instinctively ran back into the block was not noticed and thus escaped the gas chamber . The female German camp commander was called Grese a cruel beautiful woman with an angelic face . She wore a becoming grey uniform with a blue blouse . She always had a whip in her hand and hit at whomever she could reach . Mrs Kafka witnessed how she hit an older woman so much that the blood just splashed everywhere . It was a horrible experience to once watch a young woman who was highly expectant and went into labour during roll call . She stood there immovable for 3 to 4 hours in spite of the pain . She then got into the hospital but the newly born child a little boy was gassed immediately . Early at roll call one often saw the chimneys of the gas chambers smoking and it smelt of human bones . Mrs Kafka has blond hair . She assumes that this was the reason why her head was not as with most of the other women shaved completely but only cut short . She sometimes had it a little better because she did not look very Jewish . The female camp eldest even gave her a shirt as a gift . She was beaten twice . She got ill had a fever of 42 degrees but she did not call in sick but rather dragged herself on for fear of the gas chamber . After 6 weeks she came into the Bernsdorf/CAMP Labour Camp near Auschwitz/CAMP . Again only such women were selected who had not been completely shaven . In this labour camp gasmasks were made and iron traverses carried these are heavy polls with which buildings are supported when they are being built . At Auschwitz/CAMP the rags often fell from the women bodies and they had to walk around naked . It happened that when they 5 received their rations sometimes a dozen potatoes were left over . The SS women threw these potatoes randomly into the crowd these starved people grappled scratched beat each other for a potato . Then the SS shot into the crowd . Blood flowed and there again were dead people . There was no water closet but a block with latrines made of stone . Often when the rations were being handed out the jam was put onto the open hand only then came the bread and before they could eat they were chased into the latrine block . Mrs Kafka sometimes stole away at night to wash herself . One morning a doctor came selected 30 women among them Mrs Kafka they were herded into a small shower room . 20 remained there the other ten came into a small room next to it . For moment the door was opened and Mrs Kafka could see with horror that there on benches placed on top of each other naked women sat awaiting their fate . It was a gas chamber . The director of the factory in Bernsdorf/CAMP was called Schlechta he had a spinning workshop and a weaving workshop gas masks and munition were made there . In the Bernsdorf/CAMP Labour Camp were 311 female Jews . They all had to work in the different areas . Schlechta treated them decently . He even sometimes whispered to them news about the state of the war . In Bernsdorf/CAMP there was a Jewish and an Aryan dining hall in the latter were Poles French people Belgians and others who had been sent for forced labour . The director sometimes smuggled a piece of pork from the Aryan kitchen to the female Jews and each received a small piece . He was not a Nazi . For Christmas he gave all 311 women a small parcel as a present . In it were 5 small pieces of marzipan as well as a pocket mirror and a comb . These were all valuables . Schlechta had work suits made for them because it was so terribly cold there . He had even been allowed to buy clothes that had been handed over at Auschwitz/CAMP he officially bought coats for them for all 311 women . When they wanted to herd them into the country interior at the end of the war â€“ these was known as the death marches because they died on the way from weakness or were shot â€“ he negotiated with the SS women . In vain . At that time by chance the male Kommandant came by bike . He spoke with him for a long time and effected that the women remained where they were . He invited Mrs Kafka and her fellow sufferers to his villa in Trautenau/LOC where they were cared for and nursed by him and his wife for 4 weeks . Whether he did this to escape punishment â€“ she could not say . He got 18 months in prison because he was in the SS . He claimed he had been coerced . 6 A small episode is still to be mentioned When Mrs Kafka one day was sitting on the balcony in Trautenau/LOC the previous workshop master of the Labour Camp came . He was called Wolf . In the camp he addressed them as follows Jewesses go over there go over here â€¦ . . Now however he said Good day madam Austrian phrasing now we are rid of the gang ! After four weeks Mrs Kafka Aryan brother in law came and took her back to Prague/GPE . When after the war Benes and his entourage left England/GPE and returned to Prague/GPE Dr Emil Kafka went too . Hence the two were reunited . But only two years later Dr Kafka died . 
description of conditions for Jews in the various places visited immediately following the liberation . The author states all the information he has gathered regarding the fate of the Jewish communities data of deportations the extent of destruction of Synagogues and cemeteries . At Gross Gerau the new Burgermaster has made the local Nazis rebuild the destroyed Jewish cemetery in the course of the Sunday morning forced labour scheme introduced by him . At the same place a returning Jew was received back royally by his former fellow members of the Reichsbanner who insisted that he should stay there . A Jew in Hamburg/GPE has told him a deportation story with a difference his was the last wedding in Hamburg/GPE before the deportations started . In 1943 the couple was taken to Theresienstadt/GHETTO where it was prohibited to have babies . Yet the woman had her baby born there and as she had scarlet fever at the time she was allowed to have it and got away with it . The husband was taken first to Dachau/CAMP and then to Auschwitz/CAMP was included with one of the notorious death marches survived and returned to Hamburg/GPE . Only a few days later his wife turned up with the baby boy by then a year old . Theirs was now the first circumcision ceremony held in Hamburg/GPE again . From his observations the author has come to the conclusion that on the whole the smaller the town the better the Jews there are now looked after because there is the personal touch about it and those in office now are usually those who were friendly to the Jews before . See related testimony P.IV.b . No . 568 for further information . Fate of Surviving Jews in some German Communities Visited by Sgt . K. Ambrose in August 1945 frankfurt/GPE A.M. Of a community of about pre war there are some 300 to 500 left including about 10 children ! . Those who have returned from various camps get the heavy workers ration allowance as in other parts of the country and all Jews I believe have received an allocation of wood for the winter . But those seem to be about the only privileges they get . The Synagogue in the Friedrichstrasse/STREET which only suffered interior damage when the Nazis burnt it in 1938 and has not suffered bomb damage has been redecorated simply and was used again for the Festivals when about 1500 American and other servicemen attended as well as all the available civilians . This I understand is the only synagogue in use in Frankfurt/GPE . The secular matters of the community are managed from the offices adjoining the synagogue . Rabbi Dr. Neuhaus who has returned from Theresienstadt/GHETTO is managing both secular and religious affairs . The community is frequently visited by ex refugee American soldiers . PFUNGSTADT . nr . Darmstadt/CAMP This little town of about 8000 or so inhabitants used to have about 10 to 20 Jewish families . There are of course none there now . However I happened to hear about there still being a synagogue so I went to investigate . I did indeed find the building which used to be the synagogue . But it showed no signs on the outside which might betray its original purpose . It had been given a large iron door on the street front to admit farm wagons as it had been used as a vegetable distributing centre . It is now locked up altogether and as I was only in the town for a few hours I could pursue the matter any further . There was a stone lying by the side wall with the year â€˜ 1922 on it . Presumably that was the year the synagogue was built or inaugurated . I took two photographs of the building which I will send on when they are developed . GROSS/LOC GERAU/GPE nr . Frankfurt/GPE a./GPE M. This little town of about the same size as Pfungstadt/GPE is supposed to have had quite a flourishing Jewish community of 50 to 60 families . When we arrived in the town a few weeks ago only one Jew was left there and this was a half wit who was in an institution . The synagogue was entirely demolished by the Nazis in 1938 . The cemetery was badly knocked about by them but the new burgomaster is making the local Nazis put it back into shape in the course of the Sunday morning forced labour scheme which he has started there . Rather a remarkable little incident occurred in this town there were two young brothers Goldberger here before the war . One emigrated to America/GPE and just recently passed through the town as a lieutenant . The father was shot in Berlin/GPE and the mother died in a concentration camp . The other son who is now 26 was sent to Buchenwald/CAMP I believe in November 1938 . However he managed to escape later and got to Jugoslavia/CAMP . He was there caught by the Italians and interned in Italy/GPE . When the Allies marched in he was liberated got the status of a Displaced Person and served as Batman in the South African Army until recently his 1a unit was posted back to the Union of S. Africa . As he was only a civilian D.P. by status he could not go with them and asked to return to his home town of Gross/CAMP Gerau/CAMP which he did just while we happened to be there . According to his own account he was received â€˜ royally by his old friends i.e. his former fellow members of the â€˜ Reichsbanner etc . and they insisted that he should stay there . He asked to join the police force which consists of about 9 persons so that he could settle up with a few outstanding Nazis who had been dealt with yet . This was granted at once and he is now apparently happy in his job . When the present police chief retires which should be in a few years he hopes to become chief in his place and he considers that a satisfactory position as he is not ambitious . Meanwhile he is living with some friends of his where he is being treated like their own son this is again in his own words and he draws on his farmer friends in the neighbourhood for food . Apart from that the new burgomaster is a good friend of his and fixes him up with anything else he needs . He even had a house offered himself which he refused for the time being as he is better off where he is now . Sounds rather like a â€˜ local boy made good story but is nevertheless TRUE . 2 WUERZBURG/CAMP There are about 50 Jews here at present of whom only 14 are ex â€” Wuerzburgians of an original 1500 the remainder being Poles and other Displaced Persons . The 14 are all I believe â€˜ returnees from Theresienstadt/GHETTO and other camps and include the two families who were and are now again caretakers of the Jewish Cemetery . I am getting a complete list of names which will be forwarded to the Association of Jewish Refugees as soon as possible . The caretakers of the cemetary are living at the cemetary a Mr. Max Fechenbach and his whole family grandmother aged over 70 wife son of 17 and daughter of 13 years all ex Theresienstadt/GHETTO are living in the Gauleiter Rottendorfer Str . 26 where Jewish Services are also held . All the reminder I believe are living together in the Jewish hospital . There are a fair number of Jewish American soldiers including officers stationed in this town and these are looking after the community quite nicely . Nothing much is done for them officially but they seem to be getting quite reasonable assistance from these servicemen . Mr. Fechenbach is in charge of the communal affairs and is working for the Military Government . One of his tasks there is rather amusing he has to check up on the people who have suddenly discovered that they had a Jewish grandmother or even father . Among all those Jews there are only one child of 2 one . girl of 13 and a boy of 17 the latter two being Mr. Fechenbach the others being grown ups . Wuerzburg Synagogue was completely destroyed by the Nazis and a workshop erected on its site . This in turn was completely bombed out so perhaps we can build another synagogue there . Meanwhile Mr. Fechenbach is collecting money for a memorial for Jews murdered by the Fascists I am enclosing a specimen receipt . In the suburb of Heidingsfeld/LOC there is only one complete â€˜ Non Aryan of Christian faith I believe left . He is Dr. Igenberg who is practising again now as a doctor and is fairly well looked after by the local authorities most of whom he knew personally before the Nazi period . It does seem on the whole that the smaller the town and the Jewish community the better the Jews there are now looked after because there is the personal touch about it and those in office now are usually those who were friendly to the Jews before . In a large town like Hamburg/GPE or Frankfurt/GPE nothing short of official regualtions will make life more pleasant for any surviving Jews and such official regulations are not usually forthcoming . I am told that the Jewish Cemetary in Heidingsfeld/CAMP was one of the oldest in Germany/GPE . It had been out of use for some years all funerals having recently taken place in Wuerzburg/CAMP itself . It is very derelict and grown over and a large number of stones are still where the Nazi hooligans left them in 1938 . However it is now being cleared up . DEPORTATION STORY WITH A DIFFERENCE I spoke to a Jew in Hamburg/GPE whose name I did not ask and who might have been 30 to 35 years old although the marks of what he had been through made him appear rather older . His was the last wedding in Hamburg Synagogue before the deportations . He and his young wife were taken to Theresienstadt/GHETTO in 1943 . It was prohibited in that camp to have children . However this couple had a baby there and somehow because the woman happened to have scarlet fever at the time and was in hospital she was allowed to have the baby and got away with it . But the husband was sent to Dachau/CAMP . From Dachau/CAMP he was sent to Auschwitz/CAMP . From there when the Allies approached they were sent on one of those death â€” marches which started with 7000 and finished with 2000 . Then they were liberated . 2a The man_returned to Hamburg/GPE where he found his parents in law and lived with them . He had not been there more than a few days when his wife turned up with the baby now a year old ! So going to be the first ceremony of Circumcision there . Incidentally the rescue of the whole complete family of Fechenbach mentioned above under â€˜ Wuerzburg/CAMP is also quite remarkable especially as it included the old lady and since the 17 year old son served a spell at Auschwitz/CAMP towards the end where he only escaped the gas chambers by hiding in the bunkers . Dr. Igenberg also mentioned above under â€˜ Wuerzburg/CAMP maintains that he owes his life to an Allied raid on Nuremberg/LOC . His being a mixed marriage his number was up until quite late in the war . Just when matters became critical we raided Nuremberg/LOC and amongst many other good jobs there destroyed the Gestapo records . Since Nuremberg/LOC Gestapo covered the Wuerzburg/CAMP area Dr. Igenberg was not thereafter troubled . 
personal report on his experiences at Dachau/CAMP and Buchenwald/CAMP June 1938 January 1939 . Interesting and detailed description of life in both concentration camps . 4 . Date October 1955 . 5 . Number of pages 4 1-Feb . 6 . Author or Source Mr H. Hager formerly of Vienna/GPE . 7 . Recorded by Dr. W. Berent . 8 . Further References a Places Vienna/GPE Buchenwald/CAMP Dachau/CAMP . b Individuals Kerll Lagerkommandant at Dachau/CAMP Wagner Sturmfuehrer at Dachau/CAMP Koch Kommandant at Buchenwald/CAMP Ilse Koch at Buchenwald/CAMP . The experiences and observations of Mr H. Hager under the National Socialists I lived in Vienna/GPE as an employee in a business . My father was a rabbi who owned a large property in Vienna/GPE which he himself administered . The builder had built into the front of the building a decoration with a large Star of David in glass . Two days later after the 11th of March 1938 when the Germans moved into Vienna/GPE a squad of SS people appeared in front of our house and smashed the glass pane with the Star of David on it . There was a lady who lived in our house who was known as a shoplifter . This woman son wore a Nazi badge although on his father side he was not a pure Aryan . One day he stood in front of our house with a rifle and said that he wanted to shoot the landlord my father . As a consequence I wrote a note to the SS and objected that young Jewish persons were running around with a rifle threatening others . The upshot was that an SS squad appeared took the rifle from him and tore off the Nazi badge . Apparently later he was recognised as Aryan and as a Nazi again . Soon after we heard that my father who was considered to be wealthy was in danger of being arrested . As a result my father went to a hiding place where he could evade the enquiries of the Nazis . As so many other Jews my mother brother and I were often conscripted to clean the streets . The deportation of Jews to concentration camps began at this time . To this end those Jews who had ever come into conflict with the law were particularly singled out . Once in 1930 without thinking I had used the discounted return ticket of another on the train . As a result of this I was prosecuted at the time but I was not fined . This affair was still in the memory of the police inspector in charge of our area . He summoned me and for no other reason I was sent to Dachau/CAMP . The same happened to a friend upon whom a very minor bicycle transgression had been imposed some time past . In the first transport to Dachau/CAMP there were a lot of prominent people ministers senior civil servants and doctors etc . I was taken on the second transport on the 2nd of June 1938 to Dachau/CAMP . The journey there was extremely unpleasant . Our custody was assigned to Bavarian SS people who hit out in the roughest manner at every opportunity . On either side of every compartment 6 prisoners sat in the 4 places . We were required to look at the ceiling light the whole time . Anyone who did not do that was beaten . We were not allowed during the whole journey of 26 hours to go to the toilet . Also it was worse because we had no idea where we were going . In Munich/GPE we were loaded into cattle waggons . During the difficult climb into the waggons which were later sealed many of us were beaten . As a result some suffered leg fractures . A certain Walter Hand who was hard of hearing was shot when he misunderstood an order and carried it out incorrectly . After our arrival at Dachau/CAMP we had to go through a column of SS men armed with rifles and machine guns who shot into the air as part of the process of intimidating us . As a result some of us received grazes from shots . Even an SS man was accidentally shot during this affair . The next day was a day of rest for us because the SS had to attend the funeral of their comrade who was shot . On the day after we all had to strip naked and were then led to the showers . When I attempted to grasp the soap in order to use it I was hit because I wanted to use it . After I had washed without the soap I was beaten again because I did not use it . In this way everything occurred as a pretence in order to torment us . SturmfÃ¼hrer Wagner behaved especially badly in this . After the shower our heads were shorn and we received camp clothes with certain badges . I had to wear on my items of clothing the red yellow Jewish badge . Then the camp commander Kerll gave us a speech in which he said nothing would happen to those who behaved properly but those who did anything wrong would be severely punished . Afterwards we were lined up in rows of 6 and it was announced that every thirtieth person would be shot . We were counted and every thirtieth man was pulled out . The men who were withdrawn were led to a field nearby . As it later transpired it was again only an attempt to intimidate us . After that the people came back to us without anything happening to them . The barracks in which we were accommodated comprised two sections . One part served as a dining room whilst the other was the sleeping area . There were bunk beds in the latter and there were 60 prisoners in my room . We were wakened at 5 in the morning and had to be out of bed in seconds in order to avoid being reported by the SS guard . Making the bed was an especially difficult affair . The blankets had to be dead straight and lying without any creases . Generally you could see a lot of cleanliness and order . Every prisoner had to shave daily . After making the bed we had to march off in strict military fashion to get some coffee . There was a weekly bread ration . The rest of the food was bearable . At 6 there was the register and count on the assembly ground . The individual sections were reported by their Kapos . After this followed the marching off to work . In the main the work consisted of road building . We participated in the extension of a motorway . If there was no work to hand they had us carry stones to make a pile and after we had to carry them back again . The other works to which I was consigned were sweeping the courtyard with a brush and planting flowers and then watering them from a can which was very heavy to carry . The treatment meted out by the SS guards during this to keep us on our toes varied . We were often beaten during the work . To go to the toilet you had to report in a special manner . It was prescribed for this purpose that we may not come closer than 6 metres to an SS man . A well known businessman who contravened this regulation was shot by an SS guard . The entire camp was constructed as a large square . First of all it was protected by a ditch then by an electrified barbed wire fence and finally by a wall upon which there were a number of machine gun tours . It was a rule that anyone who was spotted in the ditch would be shot . One day I was working with others about 1 metre away from the ditch . We had to bring a wheel barrow full of gravel to the ditch and unload it . By and by a hillock of gravel developed which in the end was overlain with planks which we had to go up with our wheel barrow in order to unload it . In doing this a prisoner fell over with his wheel barrow and pushed me into the ditch . At any moment I expected that I would be shot at . The SS man in charge had apparently given a sign not to shoot at me . I was pulled out of the ditch with help from a rope and because I was half unconscious through fear taken away in a wheel barrow . I stayed for 4 months in Dachau/CAMP . Then we all were to be transferred . We had to give up the clothing which we wore and we were supplied in return with completely torn clothing . Wearing this we marched off . We were all very depressed because during our stay we had become used to Dachau/CAMP and did not know what was going to happen to us . We were loaded onto the railway and arrived in Weimar/CAMP via Jena/LOC . Here we had to get out and we were marched through the city accompanied by SS men with drawn revolvers to buses which took us to the Buchenwald/CAMP concentration camp . From the beginning Buchenwald/CAMP made a very poor impression on us . They camp was not completely built and it was extremely dirty . In every respect it was much worse than Dachau/CAMP . In the barracks there were three beds one upon the other and the rooms were extremely crowded . The food was in no way sufficient and the cutlery was rusty . Water was scarce and there were only open latrines there . In addition proper supervision did not exist . Common criminals who had been imprisoned as such were appointed as Kapos in the individual barracks . They treated Jewish prisoners very badly and often doled out beatings . It became especially bad after Kristallnacht on the 10th of November 1938 when around 13000 Jews were brought into the camp . Many of these came in already badly beaten up and were further mistreated in the camp . The crowding in the camp now became terrible and also the food was scarcer than before . The guards here also tormented us to extremes . They always sought out new things to make our lives unbearable . For example they forced us to ride piggy back and chivvied the pairs against each other . The consequences for us were often bloody heads and other injuries . Once two prisoners escaped . One was caught soon after and immediately hanged . The second succeeded in fleeing to Czechoslovakia/GPE . Later he was brought back from there and likewise hanged . On the occasion when the two prisoners escaped we all had to report in the evening to the parade ground and stand outside the entire night in a temperature of minus 32 degrees . 33 prisoners died the next day from exhaustion . Later the number of the dead increased . The commander of the camp was the infamous Koch . I had nothing to do with him and so I can not report anything about him . However I was once commanded to carry out cleaning work in his villa which lay 10 minutes from the camp and whilst doing this met his wife Ilse Koch .
