I can not say that she treated badly either me or those colleagues with whom I carried out the work . Worth mentioning though is that an orchestra was formed from prisoners who had to play marches soldiers songs and other pieces as prisoners went off to work and when they returned . The which was the internee Rainer Huppert poem set to music by Leopoldi another internee was especially popular . The camp commandant himself always wanted to hear that song . I include a copy of the song and one of another song from a different camp . I would like to state an opinion contrary to that expressed by some former inmates of Dachau/CAMP and Buchenwald/CAMP that it had not been so bad there like it was claimed by an 80 year old man who was incarcerated with me . This man enjoyed special treatment because of his age treatment not granted to anyone else . He was in a barrack which was under the command of the Kapo Brandel who was formerly a communist member of parliament . Brandel looked after the man and arranged that he was released from any work and also organised a collection of money for him . My stay in Buchenwald/CAMP ended on the 13th of January 1939 . In response to my request I had received an entry visa for England/GPE and as a consequence I received my release from the camp . With a group of others who were equally fortunate I left there and reached England/GPE without any further mishaps . 1 Buchenwald/CAMP song 
personal report by Mrs L. Picker on her experiences first in Vienna/GPE 1938 1942 and later in Eastern/CAMP Concentration Camps where she was separated from both her husband and daughter of whom she never heard again . 4 . Received 17 August 1955 . 5 . Number of pages 6 . Language German . 6 . Author or source as above . 7 . Recorded by Dr. W. Berent . 8 . References Guttava Riga/GHETTO Ghetto Kaiserwald/CAMP Spilve hut camp Stutthof/CAMP Tambo Russian Hospital . murder of children p.4 . 9 . Remarks Mrs Picker owes her life to the Russians not on account of the liberation itself but because of the wonderful treatment by their doctors and nurses . She spent a whole year in the Russian hospital . Erlebnisse und Erfahrungen unter Nationalsozialistischer Herrschaft I am an Austrian citizen and lived in Vienna/GPE together with my family . My husband had been an employee of the Laenderbank state bank in Vienna/GPE and received a state pension from the bank . With the support of my husband I ran a textile manufactory and purchased the produced goods to resellers . When the German troops occupied Vienna/GPE in 1938 restrictive regulations for the Viennese Jews were legislated very soon after . They were only allowed to show themselves publicly in the streets until 4 in the afternoon they were not allowed to visit theatres cinemas or cafÃ©s . Especially from 1940 onwards the regulations against the Jews were intensifying . They were forced to wear the Judenstern yellow star badge and to give up their homes if they were not in the vicinity of the/LOC Second/LOC Viennese/LOC District/LOC and to move to this District/LOC . The vast number of Jews living there were coerced into providing rooms in their own homes to their coreligionists from other districts . It was often the case that Jews regardless of their age or social standing were forced out of their accommodations to carry out road cleaning works . At the same time they boycott of Jewish businesses began . Until 1940 our personal situation as well as the situation of our business had been halfway bearable . Then one day some people appeared who told us that they allegedly were ordered to scrutinize our firm books of account . Some days later they declared to us that they had received the order to take over our business . We had to give them the keys and were coerced into surrendering our business including the available goods in stock all of the machines cutting tables etc . to them . They claimed that we were to receive a compensation . However we never got anything . Fortunately my husband still had his state pension which he was receiving at least temporarily since the Laenderbank was a French business . We were subsisting solely on that pension . The small apartment in the/LOC Second/LOC District/LOC which we had to move in to was conducive to minimizing the living expenses . Apart from that there was not much available for us to buy anyway . Jews did not receive Kleiderkarten ration cards for clothing hence we were denied the chance of complementing our wardrobe by necessary clothes and pieces of laundry . In 1940 the deportation of the Viennese Jews began . The first transports went to Poland/GPE . Usually the deportees were notified one week in advance . Sometimes they were also taken out of their homes without prior notification . Every person was allowed to take 50 kg of luggage with them . One was granted permission to carry valuable items such as money and jewelry but it was taken from the owners in the Sammellager/LOC transit camp in exchange for a certificate which contained the promise of return upon arrival at the destination . However this promise was never kept . In the winter of 1942 our fate was sealed . We were living together with our 22 year old daughter . We had been able to send our son to England/GPE before . One day three Gestapo men came to our apartment . They informed us that were to be deported and helped us pack the necessary things . I had to organize a vehicle for the transport of the luggage and then the three men escorted us to the Sammellager . We stayed there for a week without coming to know anything about where we were going to be brought . The Jewish community provided us as well as many of our fellow sufferers with food for the coming transport . After one week we were taken to the train in trucks . Having arrived there we were loaded on to cattle cars under strict surveillance and departed for a destiny unknown to us . Our travel time amounted to five days and four nights and we did not receive water or food during that time . We had to make due with the food we had gotten from the Jewish community . At last and in an indescribable condition we arrived in Riga/GHETTO . In Riga/GHETTO we were handed over to the Latvian Police who treated us in an extremely brutal way . After we had gotten off the train we firstly had to surrender all of our hand luggage and in case we had some left our food . Our bigger items of luggage which as we had been told would be packed into baggage cars had remained in Vienna/GPE . Next we were ordered to walk to the Riga/GHETTO ghetto near the city boundary . The route led through deep snow and took us more than four hours . The guarding Latvian police officers were equipped with rubber truncheons and pressured us mercilessly . Many of us were incapable of enduring the march . The ones who could not walk on were left lying in the snow . We were prohibited to help the ones left behind . I do not know what happened to them . We had been robbed of our entire clothes beforehand . In Riga/GHETTO they had guarded us to a bath where we had to undress . Nazimaedels Nazi girls were standing there and took our clothes . We received old worn out rags in exchange which we had to put on . The particular district which had been modified as a ghetto had been the residential area of wealthy Jews from Riga/GHETTO . I learned that two to three days prior to our arrival the Latvians had slew those inhabitants who had not fled . All of the apartments were standing open and had been looted . A large number of furniture was standing in the streets . We set up in the apartments as good as possible . A high fence surrounded the whole district holding about 1000 internees . SS men guarded the entrance area of the ghetto . A SS officer was the commandant of the ghetto . During the first days we did not receive any food until a committee of internees formed and organized some bread coffee and sugar . Then we were divided up for work . The daily schedule was as follows we were woken up at four o clock in the morning . The roll call started at half past 6 . Afterwards we got our breakfast black coffee substitute and a ration of bread with which we had to make due for the entire day . Later the SS men brought us to our working place . The work we had to do was extremely hard . Regardless of the weather we had to carry bricks cement and boards . We also had to carry out work for the construction of airfields trenches and bunkers as well as cutting trees . At about six we were brought back into the ghetto . There we usually got a bowl of potato soup which rarely contained a potato and sometimes some margarine . There was a strict code of discipline . Sometimes compassionate passers by would try to give us money or bread during our marches . It was strictly forbidden to accept what was offered . We were searched for possible goods of that kind each time we arrived at the ghetto . Every person carrying money or food was severely punished . Obviously For that reason some of the men were hanged . Their bodies were presented publicly for everybody to see for three days . Every one of them carried a piece of cardboard around the neck which read This is what will happen to anybody who hides money or food . We were also threatened that ten of us would be shot should anybody try to escape . When half a year was over all of the men first the older ones and later on the younger ones were removed from the ghetto . It was said that they were to work in a remote area for six weeks . My husband was among the men . Since then I have never again heard anything from him . Some months later the older women were transferred I was among them . I had to leave my daughter in the ghetto which as I learned was closed sometime after that . Since then her whereabouts have remained unknown to me . I was sent to the concentration camp Kaiserwald/CAMP . The circumstances in that camp were similar to those in Riga/GHETTO . We had to work very hard which among other things involved carrying bricks lime slaking digging trenches and sorting potatoes . We also had to transfer heaps of sand but due to a lack of tools we were forced to shovel the sand into linen sheets with our bare hands and to carry the full sheets over our shoulders to the place directed . Our guards were women imprisoned for murder or other severe criminal offences they were very cruel to us . The food was comparable to what we got in Riga/GHETTO but here we sometimes received boiled fish heads in addition . Like in Riga/GHETTO people were shot as a punishment . Other punishments especially for stealing potatoes were pouring cold water over an inmate outside in the winter cold cutting of their hair or having them sleep on the bare stone floor during the winter . Apart from that we had old mattresses to sleep on and a blanket for two to three people . After some time I was sent to the concentration camp Stutthof/CAMP . An electric barbed wire fence surrounded this camp . SS men beat us up a lot there but we did not have to work . During the four weeks that I was in this camp a great number of old people was taken away no one found out anything about their remain . My next station was the barrack camp Spilve . I had to work very hard again dig trenches and work on turnip and potato fields . One day when the women were at work outside of the camp all of the children who until then had been accompanied by the women of the camp and who stayed in the camp while their mothers were at work were seized and taken away . About three months later I was sent to Guttava/LOC which I suppose lies in the/LOC Polish/LOC Corridor/LOC because Polish inhabitants lived in the villages nearby . It consisted of ten big barracks and about one thousand female inmates . The barracks stood on the bare ground the floor was meagerly covered with straw and there were no heating systems . We neither had the possibility to wash nor clean ourselves . The work was about the same as before . Many of us internees became ill and died many suffered from typhus . Those women lived in a special barrack which was never entered by the SS people . There was no doctor sick people were left to fate . One of the interned women regularly brought some coffee into the barrack . I caught typhus too and came into the barrack I lay there for a while without receiving any sort of treatment . One day we noticed that the women who had provided us with coffee did not come anymore . Although we looked for her we could not locate her or any of her moves in the camp . Meanwhile some Poles from the village came to us and told us that the SS had left the camp with the remaining internees and that it was completely empty . They expected the arrival of the Russians any day this was in the spring of 1944 . The village people were very nice to us they brought us coffee and invited us to their houses if we were capable of leaving the barrack . Then the Russians came . They were shocked to find us in the given condition and appalled by the situation in the camp . They told us that they had never seen anything like that in their lives . From then on they made sure that we got the best treatment and care . We were taken out of the barracks and brought to the houses of nearby farmers . Russian nurses came bathed the very sick cut off their hair and truly cared for them . From the Russian field kitchens we got only the best food which we had not had for such a long time and meat we had had to do without for years . We were in constant medical care of doctors who made sure that we lived in warm rooms . Russian officers of higher rank were also eager to help . I can only say that the Russians saved my life . After some weeks I was brought to the hospital of Tarnow/GPE Russia/GPE . I stayed there for one year and enjoyed the luxury of sleeping in a decent bed and of being served marvelous food . The Russians issued us papers of legitimation and gave us clothes and shoes as well . After some time we were eventually allowed to return to the places that we had come from . I went back to Vienna/GPE where I spent one year attempting to find my son in England/GPE . I finally located him with the help of the Joint . I had my son request me and immigrated to England/GPE in 1946/47 . 
author of the report a Dutch political prisoner arrived in Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP on 10 February 1945 with a transport of about prisoners from Sachsenhausen/CAMP . He was to be executed because the SS had found out that as head of the Political Department in Sachsenhausen/CAMP which had the task to register newly arrived prisoners he had saved many prisoners from execution by substituting their names for others who were already dead . Of the prisoners the SS had singled out for execution most had been shot in Sachsenhausen/CAMP in the Industriehof . But the executions were interrupted by an air raid alarm and the last group of 21 whose hames began with one of the last letters of the alphabet were sent by Erdmann the commander of Sachsenhausen/CAMP with other prisoners to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP to be executed there . The German journalist Rudolf Kuestermeyer was a member of this group . In Belsen/CAMP typhus was rampant . The SS therefore confined itself to guarding the camp but did not enter it . The registration of new arrivals was done by prisoners . Some knew Zwart who had helped them in Sachsenhausen/CAMP . In return they arranged for Zwart group to be administratively dead by listing them as having died on the transport while giving them names of prisoners who had really died . Most of the prisoners died from typhus or starvation prisoners who were allowed to get parcels were often murdered by the block elders who then kept the parcels . There were cases of cannibalism . Shortly before the Allies arrived when the SS regime was already disintegrating Zwart was elected senior camp leader . When the British arrived on 15 April he asked them to feed the prisoners with boiled rice . Instead they got corned beef and some prisoners slaughtered the pigs of the SS and distributed the meat . As a result prisoners died from overeating during the first days after the liberation . More over the British left the Hungarian SS who had guarded the camp on duty with their arms for three days . Not until they had killed 41 people by firing into the camp could the British be persuaded to disarm them . Neither the British with the exception of Derrick Sington nor an American film team which arrived soon afterwards had any idea about the nature of the SS and the National Socialist regime . The Last Days of Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP Joop Zwart imprisoned for political reasons was during the last couple of years of his stay in Sachsenhausen/CAMP the Vorarbeiter of the Politische Abteilung . This Abteilung consisted of prisoners only . They had to register the prisoners when brought in and had access to all the files of the prisoners . With the influx of prisoners this department worked in and night shifts . In his capacity as head of it Zwart had managed in the course of years to manipulate a number of things . So for instance whenever a prisoner was brought in the camp and his file contained a death warrant resp . at a later date the order was received by the Reichssicherheits Hauptamt that the prisoner had to be executed Zwart tried as often as possible to prevent the actual killing of the prisoner involved by writing that he had already died because of typhus or an accident whatever cause of death the Political Department had at that moment available . Now at the end of January 1945 with the Soviet troops in full offensive and rumoured to be in Frankfort/LOC at the Oder there came an order from the Reichsfuehrer SS Himmler and the Reichssicherheitshauptamt that in the CC Sachsemhausen/CAMP as a measure of intimidation a number of prisoners were to be shot . Among them was a large group of policemen from Luxemburg/GPE the British of the command raid at Rjukan/CAMP in Norway/GPE French officers etc . This special committee of the RSHA installed itself in the room of the Politische Abteilung and went through the files . The members of the commando were not allowed to enter . Apparently this committee found out that there had been quite a lot of swindling fake correspondence destroying of death warrants and other manipulations been done and for that reason put Zwart on the list of those to be shot as well as his brother who had not anything to do with it and the Dutch professor Telders who was a close friend of Zwart and working with him at the political department and since he was a renowned jurist helping to clean files . Zwart name however starts with a Z so he was one of the last persons on the list . When all night through various groups always consisting of 26 prisoners had been brought to the Industriehof to be shot shortly before the group in which Zwart was the last batch were to be brought through the gate to the execution stand the Royal Air Force raided Berlin/GPE . So there was air raid warning and the shooting stopped . The raid took a very long time . It seems that then the commando in charge of the execution started deliberating and apparently the commander of Sachsemhausem camp Erdmann who did not like this affair fearing the Russians who were 2 advancing rapidly would make him responsible managed to convince this special commission that it would be better to have the remaing death candidates transported to another camp . So they were put in the bunker stayed there for a few days . It was intended to send them to Buchenwald/CAMP this was changed into an order to send them to Belsen/CAMP with the explicit order for Kramer to have them executed there . This was also the reason why this small group to which belonged a British officer Keith Williams under special . guards was with the transport Mr Zwart has described in the following statement . In this transport there was a.o . also Mr Rudolf KÃ¼stermeyer now correspondent of D.P.A. in Israel . Of these 21 persons only a few survived . Professor Telders died a few days before liberation of Belsen/CAMP due to typhus Keith Williams likewise . 3 In the early morning hours of February 10th 1945 a freight train entered the small station of Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP . The trip from Oranienburg/CAMP near Berlin/GPE to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP about 200 km to the west had taken two days . The Belsen camp was to the memory and partly hearsay knowledge of a large number of my fellow inmates a much better camp for they thought it to be an internment camp from which groups of internees got permission from the Third Reich authorities to go abroad especially to Portugal/GPE . Among the large group of prisoners who arrived at the Bergenstation that morning there were a few who knwe Belsen by own experience . They had been there earlier and many of the prisoners who during the as a group of prisoners usually was called had listened enviously to their tales of those days about the circumstances there were happy at the prospect of going for the last part of the war to a camp where the conditions seemed to be bearable . I myself was not convinced of these so called advantages of Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP for during my work at the Politische Abteilung Political Department i.e. Registration Dept of the Sachsenhausen/CAMP Concentration Camp I had found out repreatedly that Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP was considered as a genuine concentration camp and that the conditions there were accordingly . This notwithstanding I was happy that the transport went to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP instead of going to Buchenwald/CAMP which was its original destination . Compared with Buchenwald/CAMP the Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP camp had at least the advantage of being nearer to the Dutch frontier . 4 Immediately after arrival we had to get out and form rows of four prisoners illegible . After some quarrelling and ado finally a column of about a thousand prisoners was formed all coming from the Sachsenhausen/CAMP concentration camp . In this column of a thousand people our group the one I was belonging to was a special group . It consisted of 21 prisoners . We were specially guarded during the trip as well . This privilege was due to the fact that our group of 21 men from the Sacnhsehausen/CAMP camp had escaped imminent execution because during the night 196 previous executions took place and while we were waiting to be brought to the Industriehof to be shot the Royal Air Force made an air raid over Berlin/GPE . Consequently the executions were stopped . Our group of 21 was so to say the last page of the order for special treatment consisting of six pages which meant death for those concerned . With the typical German orderliness our names had been typed alphabetically on those six pages and so it happened that those whose names begin with the last characters of the alphabet escaped the bullets at that time . After this airaid the Sachsenhausen/CAMP camp and the nearby village Oranienburg/CAMP was full of rumours that Russian tanks had been seen near KÃ¼strin/CAMP . These rumours caused the highest SS officers to withdraw from Sachsenhausen/CAMP to Berlin/GPE whereas the remaining SS officers of the lower charges just did not have the courage to finish the last page of this special order . So with a special instruction of the commander of the CC Sachsenhausen/CAMP to the commander of the CC which was our destination we were sort of distinguished and it was 5 quite certain to all of us that this special advice would have the saddest consequences for all of us . Our group consisted of three Norwegians three Dutchmen four Italians two Frenchmen one Englishman two Ozechs and six Poles . We were awaiting execution if not something would happen . On arrival at the station we got special guarding but during our march to the camp it became clear to us that the guards who were marching with us were worrying about other things than giving all their attention to guarding us . After having marched about five quarters of an hour I sniffed the air rather deeply for my nose had been warning me already for some time that there was a peculiar smell around . This smell reminded me of an episode at the front during the Spanish Civil War . It was that peculiar sweetish smell of decaying corpses . To the Dutch professor B.M. Telders walking next to me I muttered I do think it looks a bit well for I smell death and corpses . On which remark Professor Telders sniffed himself deeply and answered Yes indeed the smell is most atrocious quite some stink . After more than twenty minutes marching illegible we arrived at a cluster of nice looking barracks . They were situated at the grounds just outside the camp . We walked on to the entrance and the whole transport was admitted to the camp surrounded by the high barbed wired walls so typical for the German concentration camp system . The moment however our column had entered the camp it somehow all of a sudden disintegrated . The SS guards accompanied our column to the main campstreet the Lagerstrasse/STREET from there large contingents of our transport were directed to the entrance of another barbed wired compound . Within this wired enclosure we were at home according to SS ideas . 6 There were two camps next to another . A little farther on there were another two camps called as we learnt later the Hungarian camps still being considered as the original internment camps . In the latter two camps there were Hungarians Slowaks Dutchmen Poles and Frenchmen housed that is to say that these camps only differed in so far from the genuine camp that the prisoners in the internment camp were housed much worse than those in the real camp if that was possible at all . Especially in the second Hungarian camp the situation was most dreadful here there was a lack of barracks so the prisoners were lodged in tents . On the opposite side of the main street the barbed wirefences of the two women camps began . These women camps were a wee bit better as far as the equipment was concerned than the mens camps . The barracks were as a whole a little better However for all who had thought that Belsen/CAMP would be much better than the previous camps they had gone through Belsen/CAMP was a terrible disappointment . At arrival with in the fenced compounds we had to be registered anew . This was a procedure that was repeated with every new transport of prisoners . There were prisoners who had been in twenty different camps so they had been registered twenty times . Based on this registration the various offices within the camp made a new file so that every prisoner appeared on card indexes and lists at least eighty times . The disintegration of the SS apparatus caused by the military dissolution made the number of registrations the prisoners were submitted diminish rapidly so during the last weeks in Belsen/CAMP it was even possible to escape registration altogether . With our transport however the serious attempt was made to put all of us on a file . This gave us the unique chance that eventually saved the life of a few us . In the 7 department prisoners were employed . The Belsen registration dept . consisted of prisoners only for the SS had already at that time withdrawn from the camp registration and administration to a large extent . Not because this registration could do without the SS control but because of the danger that the SS guards would catch lice a danger which was so great that a categorical order was issued by the camp commander that SS guards should keep a distance of at least 5 meters from the prisoners because of the dangers of contamination . In the camp there was a typhus epidemic The whole Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP complex consisting of six departments in fact was inhabited by millions of lice living on a diet consisting of about prisoners . The accomodation in the camp however was planned for a population of . Although regular roll calls were held nobody neither the prisoners nor the SS were able to say how many prisoners exactly were in the camp . Of course there existed administrative estimates and statistics but insiders knew that no figure whatsoever was correct . Between the real number of inmates of a concentration camp and the official figures even in more orderly camps such as Sachsenhausen/CAMP Buchenwald/CAMP and Dachau/CAMP there were differences and discrepancies as a result of irregularities in the administration . In the Belsen/CAMP camp the difference was figured out at being a couple of hundred . This now was our chance . I knew that our little group was destined to be shot . Frank to the circumstance that I found in the registration department some fellow prisoners whom I previously in Sachsenhausen/CAMP had been able to help I succeeded in making a deal with them that they would administratively let die the members of our group . 8 Of the approximately thousand men who had left the CC Sachsenhausen/CAMP at the beginning of our journey to Belsen/CAMP about 40 had succumbed during the trainride and the march to the camp . This now made it possible to use the numbers of these succumbed prisoners as well as their names since ascertaining the identity of the prisoners who had died was wholly left to the prisoners working in the registration department . So by and by the members of our group were given in the card index and files of the camp other names and numbers namely those of the deceased prisoners . Although the prisoners who knew me and were aware that we were designed to be shot somehow were suprised that the execution was not performed we could not divulge to them the secret of our still living . So I for instance lived during the last months of the camp officially under the name of Leo Verdonschot and was wearing his prisoner number whereas my friends called me with my own name . They suspected something but for tactical reasons nobody asked or talked about the matter . Officially I as I could ascertain from documents found years after the liberation died at March 6 1945 due to typhus . The difference between the date I was inscribed in the files as having died and the date we decided to let me die must be explained . Due to the disastrous conditions in the camp every night about 500 to 600 prisoners died . That does not mean they died indeed during the night they just were found dead in the morning . However there was already during some time a large scale swindling as far as the reporting to the SS was concerned . A of the barrack who had at night roll call still 300 living prisoners in his block could reckon for the morning roll call at as many portions of bread as he had living prisoners then . For the senior it was also under certain circumstances a good thing to manipulate the number of deceased . This was done on a large scale . For those who died after 9 rollcall one portion of food could be obtained during the very day . That was the reason that in the camps in the Third Reich and this even happened in some jails there was a comparatively large group of dead who were counted as living beings . Of course these dead could could not appear at roll call so they were reported as being seriously ill and it all depended whether the medical control was defunct enough to manage to go through with this manipulation . In Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP the number of dead souls amounted to appr . 600 that is at the moment that I got insight in the administrative affairs this number kept growing . The prisoners working at the registration department knew very well that more than 600 portions of food were being distributed for people who were not alive but they themselves profited from this circumstance for they got their share of these portions so it was in their own interest to let these dead souls exist as long as was possible . With the deterioration of the situation and the increase of the number of deaths all sorts of mistakes occurred at the identification of the deceased so that the administration at last had chosen to wait a bit with reporting somebody as having died so that corrections could take place . For it happened too often that somebody was reported having died who just had not yet though he was in coma . Then reports had to be changed again and such correction caused a lot of red tape . So with silent consent pf the SS due to this system of FALSE system a born . That is why I could officially illegible being reported dead on March 6th though we had decided that I should be dead as from February 18 on . Once installed in the camp and freed of the worry that we still could be fetched for shooting I got more opportunity to look into the affairs of my prisoners . I had come 10 as a prominent prisoner from Sachsenhausen/CAMP and some sort of a camp codex was that then you were treated as such in the other camps as well . This meant certain privileges . Though I was ill when I left Sachsenhausen/CAMP jaundice I did not feel terribly bad when I came to Belsen/CAMP . Nevertheless the Camp senior Lageraelteste had white bread brought to me and I accepted it . It was quite certain that other prisoners needed this more than I but in the camps the conditions there could not be measured with the moral standards of a free society . I knew that if I had refused the white bread this would not have gone to prisoners needing it more . In each camp especially in Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP the rule governed first me and then the others . Nobody could afford to help first somebody else with a thing he himself needed most . Still with more solidarity among the prisoners it is my conviction that many more thousands could have been saved . But it seemed as if the people in the camps did their very best to shed their best qualities as quickly as possible for their very worst qualities . So not only envy but betrayal and worse reigned . In Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP there were a few hundred internees who simply by administrative measure had been put in the camp . The Gestapo however intended to put them in an internment camp not in a regular concentration camp . Since these camps in the course of time got so mixed up that in practice they were all considered as belonging to the same type it did not make much difference in which department one was put . Formally however there was some difference as to the rights and privileges of the internees . In reality all of them just were submitted to the same conditions and suffering . Of these some hundred internees however during my stay in 11 Belsen thirty and more were killed by their fellow prisoners . These internees were allowed to receive parcels . Whenever a parcel for an internee illegible arrived in camp the block senior or his assistant had to fetch the parcel hand it out to the prisoner involved and deliver the signed receipt at the postal department . Only in case the addressee had died the very day the parcel was received the block senior of his assistant was allowed to keep the parcel for himself resp . decide what to do with it . The consequence of this rule was however that those entitled to receive a parcel were murdered in cold blood . Because of their special powerful position the Blockaeltesten had in a concentration camp these murders could be committed without punishment . The education was being done by the block seniors or their assistant or help who simply made certain that a prisoner had died . Then the corpse was without any ceremonies put on a cart and brought to the cemetery . The crematorium could not due to too large influx take care of all the bodies so that it was decided to dig large pits called mass graves . However the burying of the dead could not keep up with the tempo . When I entered Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP the capacity was 300 to 400 corpses a day . However there often ocurred 500 deaths a day . The result was that in all the parts of the camp huge piles of corpses lay about . In the first week of April 1945 before liberation a Strafkompagnie of the Wehrmacht was mobilised and had to dig enormous graves . At a certain moment there were 2000 corpses lying around . Everything in the camp smelled of corpses the bread the blankets the indescribable stench penetrated everything . Most of the prisoners succumbed due to typhus . Also until the very last moment large groups of prisoners were put on transport to another camp . Many of these groups did not reach their destination . A few were liberated by 12 allied troops others liquidated by the SS . The number of inmates of the camp varying between and remain rather constant since for those who left other groups came from other camps . From Sachsenhausen/CAMP only during February 1945 prisoners were sent to Belsen/CAMP . Later the commanders of other camps such as Neuengamme/CAMP and Buchenwald/CAMP send large groups of prisoners to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP whereas only small groups left Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP . A steady contingency of leaving prisoners however were those 500 prisoners who died due to exhaustion and illness . On the evening of April 10th 1945 we saw that there were changes in the system of the SS guarding . A rumour had it that a transport from Dora/CAMP an annex camp of the CC Buchenwald/CAMP at the last moment had been redirected and housed in Wehrmachtbarracks near the Belsen/CAMP camp . Also a group of jewish prisoners who had been put on transport that morning returned since apparently communications had been broken . This of course resulted in a feeling of alarm . In the early morning hours of April 11 1945 a meeting was held in the camp of those prisoners fit enough to keep themselves on feet . It was no must to attend the meeting he who wanted to come could come others stayed away . In this consisting of about 60 prisoners it was discussed which measures we should take if the SS would decide to stage a Bartholomews Night . We decided to build hiding places in the barracks under the cots . For that the floor of the barracks had to be torn apart and a sort of shallow foxholes could be dug . At our first attempts to do so however we found out that such work was too much for our weak forces . During another gathering later in the morning we concluded that the SS at the utmost could try to put fire to the camp by shooting for the millions of lice reigning in the camp 13 formed a sanitary cordon . The SS would not dare to penetrate the camp . At this meeting I was elected general senior camp leader with the order to deal with the Allies whose arrival we were awaiting daily . It was significant for the situation in the camp that the senior prisoner officially appointed by the SS a professional criminal accepted my election to senior prisoner and declared that he would loyally cooperate . We were not very happy about this statement however we could not risk offering him at that moment which we would have done if we had declared that as far as we were concerned he could go and beat it . On the contrary during the first days after my election it seemed necessary to ask his advice etc . About noon on April 11 1945 after we had ascertained more information about the position of the SS I proposed an experiment in order to find out to what extent the SS still possessed absolute powers and wanted to apply these . For this I suggested to go with an Hungarian boy whom we had caught several times committing cannibalism to the officer in charge and to tell that officer that this boy had cut parts from corpses . It was an experiment for usually the verdict was beating until death . However it was my opinion which was confirmed by other prisoners that we should risk this experiment . So I went with the boy who was wholly out of his mind and had not the slightest idea what was happening to the officer SS in charge . At a distance of five meters from the barbed wire with this secure fence between us the SS officer listened to my tale . Then he asked what I wanted . I replied I want to know what to do with this boy . The SS officer replied thereupon Do what you like with him . That nothing of my concern . 14 At that moment I could have jumped with joy for this meant that the SS did not have absolute power any more and could not use it according to their illegible . I controlled myself however and slowly walked away with the boy . My friends were waiting impatiently and full of tension but when I told them what the officer had replied there was a timid hurrah . The others as well understood imediately that the Reich of the SS was finished . The days that now followed were fraught with tension . We felt liberated already but still the barbed wire was there and on the watch towers the SS guards were heavily armed yet we felt strong enough to request from the SS that the camp doctor the man who previously had decided and committed selection at Auschwitz/CAMP issued extra food portions especially for the children . What we expected happened indeed . Two days previously this would have been impossible . The camp doctor complied with our request and ordered the issue of condensed milk . That settled things . We knew that the SS only was prepared to do this because it did not have power any more thus there was a higher power and that only the allies our allies could be . On April 15 1945 a British armoured car drove in . On this there was a loudspeaker from which a warm voice speaking German slowly with a heavy British accent told us that we were liberated by the allied troops that immediately aid would be organised and that the SS had to obey orders in this case from the British units . As previously agreed I stepped forward and out of the comfound surrounded by the fence and walked unto the armoured car . The car came to a standstill and out stepped a man in a British uniform who stretched out his hand and said my name is Derrick Sington . He said a lot more 15 however I did not understand it at that moment for I was very moved and could not bring out a word . After a few moments I had myself under control and told him with a few words that this was a concentration camp and that we all were very hungry . He invited me to come to the barrack of the camp conmmander and to tell everything . Moreover he asked my assistance in maintaining order . Of course I promised my assistance however all promises could not prevent that within half an hour after his arrival a real liberation celebration broke out during which the most incredible things happened . The Russian and Polish prisoners broke open the pigsty of the SS in which about 50 fat pigs were being kept . They were slaughtered right away . Within two hours after Sington had come and left fresh fried pork chops were offered . At his arrival Sington had driven with me through the camp and asked the prisoners to remain calm until vehicles were brought to the camp . He came back with a team and we had a long talk about what was to be done . The first sanitary unit arrived and a supply unit and a field kitchen which brew an extra fat soup for the starved prisoners . I had refused to eat any of the pork meat my endeavours however to convince the British who were prepared to do everything not to make a fat soup were fruitless . They just did not understand me we were hungry were we . I had said that myself . I patiently explained that my greatest wish was a little rice boiled in water from which one could eat a spoonful every half hour and this I wanted for the whole camp . 16 They listened politely to my stammering and looked at me with friendly eyes but went on frying very thick slices of corned beef and probably thought that I just was out of my mind asking for a bit of watery rice whereas they offered such delightful corned beef . The results of this liberation celebration were disastrous . On the day of the liberation and the night following on it four thousand up to five thousand persons died in the camp most of them because of eating too heavy food . It has taken us days to convince the British that a lean diet really was the best thing for the inmates of the camp . Finally they agreed but then the catastrophe already had happened . We found young Ukrainians dead with a pork chop in their hands . Others had not been able to walk more than twenty meters away from the kitchen where they ate their too savoury meal . They died in the main street of the camp . A special tragic circumstance of the now liberated camp was that in the first days the SS guards were still armed at the watch towers overlooking the camp and doing service . Service consisting of controlling the camp . The SS guards still obeyed an SS order stating that when there was rioting or irregularities they had to shoot into the camp . Now the British had supposed that the SS had laid down their arms and that the guards at least would not use their firearms . But in the first night of the liberation prisoners found their death because of the shooting by the Hungarian SS men . Though the next day we went to the British commander to request removal of the SS guards from the towers the Hungarian SS men were kept on duty . So the next night again the SS shot into the camp and when a third night there had been salvos the British commander finally consented 17 and agreed to our statement that this was a most unbearable situation and ordered the towers to be cleared . It was remarkable that the British who had not been aware of the existence of the concentration camp complex at the Luneburgheath/LOC when they occupied it considered and treated the SS guards as prisoners of war . The SS officers remained armed and although I had warned the British right from the start not to leave the camp population behind without leaving a British post as a control authority the British simply did not understand how dangerous their refusal made the situation . The only person among the Brtish with whom one could talk in a sensible way was Lt . Derrick Sington who showed because he understood German much more insigiht for the difficulties and worries of the inmates . In the three nights of this reign of terror by the Hungarian SS from April 15 till April 18 1945 41 prisoners were shot by the SS and died . The SS excused this shooting with the argument that hey had received order to use arms when there were riots and that they were under the impression that the British commander had ordered them to continue service as previously . It cost the deaths of 41 persons before the British were convinced that the SS troops . due to their mentality really could not be considered as and compared with regular troops . On the contrary the whole criminal mentality of the SS system showed itself very clearly during the last few days . Kramer the camp commander was formally arrested on the second day after liberation but when the armoured car entered the camp he had still mobilised a SS command and given orders to shoot if the prisoners would endeavour a break out of the camp . 18 After the British had taken command of the camp a penal unit of the German Wehrmacht had to bury at least corpses who had been lying in piles when the British entered the camp . After six days an American film team arrived to make a film of Belsen . I had a conversation with the cameramen who became very much shocked at what they saw . I was shocked and surprised about their ignorance of the situation under National Socialist reign . I told them that not in all their pictures they would be able to bring out the smell of the dead and this was during the last months of the existence of this camp the most characteristic thing .

Stargardter Meyer Koplowitz ZÃ¶llner Blond Goldstein may have collaborated with the Nazis more closely than necessary p.6 . 1 The Emigration at Grosse Hamburger Str . 26 in Berlin/GPE The former Berlin/GPE Jewish Community in Berlin/GPE ran an old people home at Grosse Hamburger Str . 26 ! The courtyard of this old people home adjoined the earliest Berlin/GPE Jewish cemetery ! It is the resting place of the famous Jewish philosopher Moses Mendelssohn ! In April 1942 the Gestapo of the time made up the first Berlin/GPE old people transport to Theresienstadt/GHETTO from the home residents ! Once the first transport of inmates had vacated the building further transports were assembled initially from other Jewish old people homes and taken off to Theresienstadt/GHETTO ! This soon became standard practice with what were called one hundred transports leaving Berlin/GPE for the same destination every day ! The Gestapo Division IV D I Berlin/GPE C 2 Burgstr . 28/30 and those heading the Jewish affairs section SS HauptsturmfÃ¼hrer and Detective Inspector PrÃ¼fer now systematically turned the former old people home into an assembly camp for those scheduled for immediate deportation from Berlin/GPE ! The people deported from this building were over 63 and up to 70 or in some cases 90 ! Presumably with the aim of making the deportation rather more palatable to the people concerned they were handed wholly mendacious so called home purchase contracts for signature ! The guileless might reasonably infer from this that in spite of the signs of extermination plans there was after all perhaps still a glimmer of hope for survival ! Many people felt that their sense of what was right had not been disappointed because one surely could not give credence to the rumours of extermination that were circulating ! One had been born and brought up in Germany/GPE after all and so in many cases people simply could not believe that every last vestige of government protection for them had ceased to exist ! However most people did gradually begin to sense uneasily that everything â€“ literally everything â€“ that was going on in the building was purposeful done with exploitation and extermination in mind ! Every single possession was searched through even though the rooms people had lived in had been sealed up together with their contents whether movable or not ! On top of that a whole squad of Gestapo officials carried out further extraordinarily minute body searches using the most sophisticated methods ! Initially these physical examinations were conducted separately by male and female Gestapo personnel ! Later on and I shall return to this point practices of an entirely different order took place ! In the as they called it where everyone already searched was kept on the building second storey â€“ they all remained segregated 2 pending deportation during the following night ! The transports would set off at 3.15 in the morning initially on foot as far as Monbijou/LOC Platz/LOC ! Here 2 special trams would be waiting with members of the GÃ¶ring police battalion on board . The transport now proceeded to the Anhalter Station and at 5.58 every morning two coaches with the prisoners on board would be attached to the Dresden/CAMP train ! The route was Tetschen/LOC Bodenbach/LOC â€“/LOC Aussig/LOC â€“/LOC Rations available for the prisoners at that stage were still relatively speaking very good ! This was because prospective deportees took perishable foodstuffs along to the pre departure holding camp and used them for the general good ! Thus the people were relatively well fed as they travelled to their deaths ! The Reich Federation of Jews in Germany/GPE had appointed Gerichtsassessor Werner as Jewish camp leader ! It was then Simon responsibility imposed by the Stapo to provide several detachments of Jewish assistants known as Ordner â€“ administrative assistants . Initially these people played a subordinate role ! They were expected to assist the people due for collection going to their homes to help pack linen clothing roll up blankets etc . ! ! Gestapo officials turned everything in the apartments upside down searching for valuables gold etc . A pre eminent figure in this work was a certain de BÃ¼hl BÃ¼hlei ! He made the Jewish helpers even lift out the ashes from the floors of the heating stoves searching for supposed valuables ! The actual collection of deportees was carried out by SS men from Burgstr . IV D I wearing civilian clothes ! They carried out their other duties there at the Burgstr . HQ in the department of Jewish affairs ! SS ScharfÃ¼hrer sergeants Lachmuth Schneider de BÃ¼hl mentioned above Sasse Wenzel Bolz Heimbach Dobberke always went in pairs to fetch the old people out of their homes . In the emigration camp at Grosse Hamburger Str . 26 as it was now called three groups of Ordner had their so called WachrÃ¤ume duty stations ! It was their task to shift the people possessions after searching from one place to another in the building then load them on horse drawn carts for the early morning departures and transportation to the Anhalter Station and on to the train ! Also stationed at Grosse Hamburger Strasse 26 were two doctors and two nurses to care for the deportees ! There were many suicides and attempted suicides ! The doctors tried every means available to keep the people alive as they had orders to deliver the stipulated number of people for transportation in the morning ! Nevertheless sometimes they would fail to prevent a suicide . In that case unsuspecting further individuals would be hauled from their beds in the middle of the night to make up the numbers ! ! Dr. med . Fritz Sternberg who has now died in the eastern sector of Berlin/GPE is thought to have gone far beyond what he as a doctor could rightfully do in his efforts to supply the Stapo with human material ! But the other doctor Dr. med . Salomon was reluctant to comply with the demands made of him and as a result became one of those despatched with me on 1 July 1943 to Theresienstadt/GHETTO ! Here I would also like to record that â€“ irrespective of the norm of 63 as the minimum age for Theresienstadt/GHETTO â€“ it was quite possible for Jewish Community office holders front line veterans from the First World War etc . to be taken off to Theresienstadt/GHETTO ! ! This allegedly conferred advantage but here in Berlin/GPE nobody knew that from there depending on circumstances 3 they might be taken straight on to Auschwitz/CAMP and the gas chambers . And that is why it was rare for an inmate of Theresienstadt/GHETTO to survive most of them were taken further east to the extermination camps ! ! At this time â€“ before Brunner from Vienna/GPE â€“ the Jewish camp leader had only administrative responsibilities ! He supervised the kitchen and its staff for instance â€“ two cooks and the necessary underlings on kitchen duties . He also drew up the duty rosters for the Ordner . All the employees worked under Stapo pressure and the ever present threat that if something was not as it should be they would find themselves on a transport ! ! Back in the early days some of the basement space had been divided up into compartments used as punishment cells for any prisoners who offered resistance â€“ beginning with a spell of solitary ! Some â€“ if they became compliant â€“ were then deployed by the Stapo to round up further deportees ! In this way they could postpone their own deportation remain in Berlin/GPE for the time being and attempt to save themselves and their dependents from deportation ! On such matters the Jewish camp leader of course could exert no influence at all but there were certain matters on which Dobberke would call him in to provide advice . Every now and again for instance there might be the chance of wangling a later deportation date ! This might even mean a life saved ! If there is talk today of Werner Simon having worked hand in glove with the Stapo I must refute this outright ! The prevailing ethos of the camp was such that even Simon could not entirely avoid picking up some of the tone ! Everything was conducted in a suitably military style if a ScharfÃ¼hrer let alone a passed along the corridor there would always be a sharp command of Achtung Attention ! â€“ this had been done since the beginning by order of the Stapo post ! The idea may well have been to prepare the old people for what was still to come ! I must here make it absolutely clear that all this amounted to no more than a very minor relatively trivial prelude to what came later for on 11 . 11 . 1942 HauptsturmfÃ¼hrer Brunner arrived from Vienna/GPE and ensured that all who entered this building would suffer a martyrdom of a very special order ! II . Emigration Camp Berlin/GPE N 24 Grosse Hamburger Str . 26 Report on the Brunner period ! On 11 November 1942 the Vienna/GPE Gestapo men suddenly appeared at the emigration camp bringing with them a staff of Viennese assistants ! Of these some were uniformed Waffen SS others wore civilian clothes ! The arrivals were HauptsturmfÃ¼hrer Brunner HauptscharfÃ¼hrer Weisl HauptscharfÃ¼hrer Krell and about six others whose names were not disclosed ! The retinue also included a number of gentlemen from the Vienna Jewish Community ! Only very gradually did it emerge that the last named individuals were not in fact Aryans . 4 A key figure among these people was a certain GerÃ¶ ! This man was important in that he was found later to have been instrumental working on commission from the Stapo and in extremely close collusion with the Vienna/GPE SS people in the hunt for Jews ! What happened first was a situation review conducted with the Prussian Stapo based at the Burgstrasse/STREET . I was in the building at the time and soon learned the decisions as they filtered through ! The entire building was now put on a major operations footing ! The first step was to clear out all remaining furnishings from the individual rooms of the former old people home leaving behind only the mattresses on the bare floors ! A large number of other rooms had no mattresses and these were furnished with a loosely thrown down layer of straw ! Next the kitchen services that had been provided hitherto were abruptly terminated ! For people being processed on to the transports from then on the only provision made was from food containers brought by cart from the Jewish People Kitchen Berlin/GPE C 2 at Gormanstrasse/STREET ! A second measure was removal of the doors from lavatories throughout the building use of lavatories whether by men or by women now had to be in public view ! When these measures began to be introduced the aforementioned Werner Simon still held the post of Jewish camp leader ! Brunner paraded all the building Jewish assistants soon to be known as Ordner in the now partly disused former kitchen ! Speaking with undisguised arrogance Brunner made it clear that the last Jews would soon leave Berlin/GPE ! Anyone guilty of the slightest shortcomings in the execution of assistants tasks would be on a transport forthwith ! Then came the question who among those present had seen frontline service in the first world war and had furthermore led a charge ? Max Reschke a retired headmaster and qualified teacher of commercial subjects was appointed on the spot as the second Jewish camp leader because he met the required criteria ! Perhaps the star by this time was already sinking â€“ I mean it could be that this choice had some connection with Werner Simon â€“ I just do not know ! But the thing was done besides Werner Simon who had been appointed to this post by the Reich Security Main Office KurfÃ¼rstenstrasse 126 Eichmann acting through the IVDI in Burgstrasse/STREET there was now a second Jewish camp leader ! I must add right away that a few days later still almost immediately after Brunner had assumed command Assessor Werner Simon was placed under house arrest and was kept in a room guarded by an SS sentry ! Meantime the mass deportations of Jews from Berlin/GPE were increasing in volume ! While previously the practice had been to take away Jewish workers from businesses factories etc . radically new methods now began to be employed ! The new procedures involved cleansing the city tenement by tenement by removing the Jews ! And now the SS men â€“ directed by the gentlemen of the Jewish Community who had been brought from Vienna/GPE three in number plus GerÃ¶ began to work wholly systematically â€“ as they presumably already had done in Vienna/GPE earlier ! And every day every 24 hours precisely one thousand Jewish people left Berlin/GPE on their way east ! Departures from the Grunewald goods station but mostly from the goods station 5 at Quitzowstr . Beusselstr . ! . When the tenement cleansing raids became less successful new arrangements were suddenly decreed as follows All the cartage firms engaged on the Jew programmes i.e. those that provided transport to the goods stations â€“ the people involved were Preiss Scheffler and Degen â€“ were ordered to bring their large lorries empty to the Hamburger Strasse ! Here each lorry was boarded by 2 SS men with an Alsatian dog 2 Stapo men and an Ordner ! The vehicles now cruised slowly along the Berlin/GPE streets ! East west north south ! ! When a Stapo man spotted someone who looked Jewish he jumped off with his dog and gave chase ! Then he would demand to see the person papers there on the street in case of any doubt i.e. if the papers were not one hundred per cent in order the persons detained would be manhandled on to the lorry ! On this day in particular there were enormous crowds of people on the KurfÃ¼rstendamm and Tauentzienstrasse/STREET and there were very vocal protests especially when the public realised just what was going on . The haul from these raids was extremely meagre and I still believe that the Viennese people here landed themselves with a major fiasco in Berlin/GPE ! On the same day the Vienna SS also carried out a search of a major photographic studio on the KurfÃ¼rstendamm the proprietor of which was allegedly Jewish and took away three full lorry loads of valuable antiques quality foodstuffs furniture etc . etc . to IV DI in Burgstrasse/STREET . Unloading these articles took the entire night . And everything presumably went to the Berlin Stapo for the time being ! Arrests were made in a wholly draconian way . Pregnant women might find walking or climbing up on the waiting lorries difficult old people likewise but it made no difference everything was done under the eyes of the German public and on the public streets sometimes there was even applause for the SS men ! However there were also other people who went silently round the next street corner so as not to have to see it all ! It was the rifle butts that enjoyed the greatest triumph near Spandauer BrÃ¼cke when the wife of a Jewish dentist was to be collected she was shot dead getting out of the bath because in the SS men opinion she did not get out of it quickly enough ! The building progressively acquired the character of a prison ! The Jewish Ordner had to submit to a prescribed duty roster with three groups on guard for 8 hours each ! They were required to patrol the building all of whose windows were now barred to prevent escape attempts ! A police guard was installed but in practical terms this step was almost meaningless as the actual business of monitoring the Jews etc . was in the hands of the SS ! If occasionally a younger person attempted to escape from a departing transport the Ordner were responsible for sounding the alarm with the police guard ! Any further response measures following successful or unsuccessful escapes were implemented by the SS . The special importance 6 that this emigration camp had for the SS is best attested by the fact that until summer 1943 the camp had external lighting on the windows . By order these lights had to be kept on even during air raid alerts because of possible escape attempts ! The emigration camp had now converted the entire basement space for use as a punishment bunker ! Supervisory personnel there included a certain Koplowitz a ZÃ¶llner and others . These people in effect provided a full prison warden service ! The SS put in an appearance only if there was some special reason ! It will surely be obvious that these individuals were hated by the Jewish people imprisoned for purposes of extermination . It may well be that sometimes wrong things were done and sometimes justified incidents were recorded ! As for the Ordner proper it is important to distinguish clearly between those who carried out genuine assistant duties and those who to retain their lives and their freedom readily sold themselves to the SS as informers ! For all and any Ordner not prepared to serve in this way as informers the response was inexorable they would be on one of the next few transports ! ! In February 1943 the guest performance by the Vienna Gestapo came to an end and from that point on the same Berlin/GPE Stapo people as before â€“ Dobberke Stock PrÃ¼fer â€“ were once more in charge ! By that time however probably all that was still required was the work of tracing Jews who had gone underground and were living illegally ! Initially certain factory operations concerning Jews now released did Daily transports to Theresienstadt/GHETTO carrying 100 people at a time continued as before likewise transports to the east carrying many hundreds ! The operation against mixed marriages at Rosenstrasse/STREET 2-Apr on 27 . 2 . 1943 Hitherto exempted from the collection operations mixed marriages were first attacked by the Nazis on this date ! The Jewish partners in the marriages were removed from their workplaces and assembled in the 2nd administrative block of the Jewish Community . It is a fact that in this case once all the men and women concerned were in the building the Aryan spouses made a weak attempt to demonstrate on the street outside ! It would of course have taken no more than a clear instruction from the police patrols to disperse the assembled people ! Yet this was surely the first time serious protests were made on a public street against the regime of the Nazis . In my view it was only in a vanishingly small number of cases that people involved in this protest were subsequently deported to extermination camps nearly all those arrested were quickly released to return to their families !
