Steinharter was the wife of a well to do Munich/GPE lawyer . With the economic elimination of the Jews the Steinharter moved to Garmisch/CAMP Partenkirchen/CAMP and lived there unmolested until 1939 . On 9 November they were taken to the town hall and with a gun on the desk had to sign an undertaking that they were leaving voluntarily the same day . Under SS guard they packed and settled all the formalities and left for Munich/GPE . Their flat was sealed . While living in a Munich/GPE hotel Mrs Steinharter accompanied by her former landlady who was a member of the Party went secretly to the flat and packed some of her belongings . In endless negotiations for papers and visas the Steinharter tried to emigrate Switzerland/GPE refused a visa their quota number for USA/GPE was too high but finally in August 1939 they could go to England/GPE due to the generous help of an English Jew . They were given a house rent free and lived on their money in Switzerland/GPE . Mr Steinharter soon found office work and after 5 years they were naturalized . Mr Steinharter died in 1948 and Mrs Steinharter took up nursing . During this difficult period she received much kindness and help from English people . She now lives at the Otto Schiff House . In her restitution claim the former Gauleiter HausbÃ¶ck proved a most helpful witness . Emigration Obstacles Ida Eva Steinharter nÃ©e Hechinger . Born 12 October 1881 in Nuremberg/LOC . Religion Jewish . Married 1900 widowed in 1914 . Married her second husband Dr Steinharter a legal adviser and state prosecutor in Munich/GPE in 1919 . He died in London/GPE in 1948 . They had no children . Parents father was a merchant . Both parents came from Buchau/CAMP near Ulm/LOC in WÃ¼rttemberg/LOC . When she was married Mrs Steinharter lived in Munich/GPE where her husband took a very prestigious job . They lived comfortably . When her husband was stripped of his position at the beginning of the Hitler regime and was no longer allowed to perform any legal duties the Steinharters decided to move away from Munich/GPE . They moved to Garmisch/CAMP Partenkirchen/CAMP in 1934 as they thought the opportunity to do sports would be a distraction for a very depressed man . They initially lived in a furnished room . However they soon got the chance to rent a little house that was still being built . The owners of the house lived in northern Germany/CAMP Wilhelmshaven/CAMP and did not want to move into it just yet . These owners â€“ Aryans â€“ were extremely accommodating and drew up a very fair contract with the Steinharters . The Steinharters had their furniture shipped from Munich/GPE and felt at home in this beautiful modern apartment . However after almost five years 1939 a Jewish ban was issued in Garmisch/CAMP Partenkirchen/CAMP â€“ the place was to be cleansed of the Jews immediately . But all their neighbours and the locals who knew them said Oh they do mean you by that . The people living in the town were not really aware of what was going on in the outside world . At 9 am on 9 November local men came to take them to the town hall . A revolver was kept on the desk throughout the hearing that followed . The officer on duty apparently told them that all Jews had to leave town by 6 pm . If you sign this to say that you will leave town 2 voluntarily with your money and personal possessions by 6 pm tonight then the FÃ¼hrer has stipulated that you may leave the country without your passport . Their passports had already been confiscated . You can hand in your luggage when you book your tickets to a destination outside of Germany/GPE . All Jews were supervised by an SS officer when packing their belongings and arranging their most important personal matters as well as when they were taken to the train station . Once vacated their homes were sealed by the SS officers . One of the Steinharters neighbours a Christian doctor issued a medical certificate to state that Mrs Steinharter was unwell . This enabled them to keep their car and use it to drive to the station . Mrs/STREET St./STREET was in fact healthy ! But Mr Steinharter seized the opportunity and played along with the whole eviction . And so they drove to the station handed in their baggage to be sent to Switzerland/GPE after purchasing a ticket to Zurich/GPE but then got in the car and drove to Munich/GPE . One of Mrs Steinharter brothers who had recently been living with them went with them on their dangerous journey home . It was dark and dense fog closed in so they drove very slowly and only arrived late in the night of 10 November . This was their saviour as they were not caught and they also escaped the arrests of all Jews that were made the day before . It was difficult to find accommodation but they ended up in the Regina Palast Hotel . They remained in their room while in the hotel and then drove to the Consulate General of Switzerland/GPE where they found out that everything the Nazis told them was a scam and you could not get into Switzerland/GPE without a passport . In actual fact all the Jews from Garmisch/CAMP Partenkirchen/CAMP who tried to cross the border were arrested upon arrival . Mrs Steinharter made one more clandestine trip back to Garmisch/CAMP Partenkirchen/CAMP . 3 Even her husband was unaware of her plans . She was accompanied by the owner of the house in which they lived in Garmisch/CAMP Partenkirchen/CAMP . She came along to help the Steinharters once she heard about the eviction of the Jews that had taken place . It is worth mentioning that this woman was a member of the Nazi Party and her son was in the Gestapo in Berlin/GPE . As the landlady of this house she could not be refused entry to the sealed building and Mrs Steinharter was allowed in with her . They both packed everything they could take with them and ended up leaving the building with 11 suitcases shipping everything as registered luggage to Munich/GPE . However the furniture large rugs and various valuables were left behind . The Steinharters were in contact with a cousin in Zurich/GPE who made every effort to ensure their lawful entry to Switzerland/GPE by issuing a guarantee for them . However there were long delays at the Consulate General of Switzerland/GPE in Munich/GPE and their emigration to Switzerland/GPE was ultimately rejected . In the meantime Mr Steinharter had received his exit permit due to his social status so they attempted to get to the U.S.A./GPE They received three visas but their waiting numbers within the quota were not due to be called for at least another 4 years . Shortly afterwards a new regulation came into force men over the age of 60 and their wives would be allowed a transit stay in England/GPE . But they needed either a guarantee or to be in possession of a certain amount of money otherwise the women would have to go as domestic staff . Although the Steinharters had money in Switzerland/GPE it was not enough for the period of time they were expecting to stay in England/GPE . Transferring the money from Switzerland/GPE would have been possible . One of their lawyer friends living in England/GPE â€“ a Jew from Germany/GPE â€“ wanted to help them and came up with an idea to get them what they wanted . He simply turned to a Jewish diamond merchant 4 who was known for being very wealthy but was not a personal acquaintance . He told him what had happened and asked for either money or a guarantee for his persecuted Jewish friends . Mr and Mrs Steinharter received the guarantee from him and were subsequently able to travel to England/GPE . However Mrs Steinharter brother was not able to emigrate with them as he was not yet 60 years old . He ultimately managed to illegally cross the border to Luxembourg/GPE . They arrived in England/GPE on 27 August 1939 . Getting out of Munich/GPE was very risky right up to the last minute the British Consulate General in Munich/GPE was about to close as relations had broken down as a result of the impending war . They must have been so happy when they received the permit for England/GPE in time . It needed to be entered on their Jewish identity card otherwise it would not have been valid . No flights were departing at this time but they managed to book themselves on to the last ship for England/GPE . So they travelled via Frankfurt/GPE to the Hook of Holland and crossed the sea on their rescue journey . The overcrowded train was the unpleasant end to the gruelling frightening and hounded chapter of their lives in Germany/GPE . There were civil servants from the Consulate travelling with them to England/GPE on the ship . Mrs Steinharter said it was like being on an emigration ship . The Steinharters settled in London/GPE where they were initially able to live on the money that they wired from Switzerland/GPE . They took a room in a boarding house but they were soon able to upgrade their apartment through their ties with an English Jew a childhood friend of Mr Steinharter . This lady husband was the Chairman of 5 Bloomsbury House and the owner of an unoccupied house in London/GPE . They gave the Steinharters this house fully furnished and rent free . They were finally at peace after the multitude of experiences and the turmoil of the past few years that culminated in their emigration . Mr Steinharter soon found work in a factory office where he was treated very kindly by the English boss who was a Christian and his work colleagues . He died in 1948 . The owner of the house that the Steinharters had been living in had also died and it was now being used for other purposes . It would have been too large for Mrs Steinharter as a widow anyway . So she moved out initially living with a neighbour . Immediately after her husband death Mrs Steinharter received great support and kindness from her neighbours and she could not be more thankful even today . All of the people who were so keen to help her were English . Shortly after this she moved away to a boarding house in Belsize/LOC Park/LOC where she lived for seven years . Five years of that until she fell ill she worked as a private nurse . Despite having never worked in that kind of role before she made the most of her new life . She was called on by various doctors so she always had plenty to do . Mrs Steinharter now lives in Otto Schiff House London/GPE . The Steinharters had quickly decided against emigrating to the USA/GPE given their satisfactory circumstances in London/GPE and their receipt of a residence permit . Five years in they became British citizens . 6 The following may be of interest When Mrs Steinharter claimed compensation as part of the reparations process for the possessions left behind in the house in Garmisch/CAMP Partenkirchen/CAMP her representative a lawyer in Munich/GPE contacted several witnesses . Former Nazi party regional leader HausbÃ¶ck was summoned as a key witness . He confirmed all of Mrs Steinharters claims but then stated that all Jewish possessions had been publicly auctioned . Until the auction the sealed houses were guarded by SS officers to prevent looting . Based on this statement which did not need to be reviewed further Mrs Steinharter received confirmation of her compensation claim . 
Durlacher Cohen a Dutch Jewess by birth married a German Jew in Baden/CAMP . When the Nazis came to power they emigrated to Holland/GPE where Mrs Durlacher Cohen tried to assist as many people as possible . She always acted on intuition asking for the co operation of people whom she had not met before and was never mistaken in her judgment . In this way she secured the help of Mr Stroes secretary at the municipality of Oosterbeck/LOC who provided her with forged papers in order to â€˜ legalize 6 Jewish children . Forged papers were also procured for the Durlacher family but they proved to be insufficient . In a very complicated way the couple was able to get into possession of the birth certificates in photostatic of a Dutch couple Mr and Mrs Zeller who had emigrated to the USA/GPE . years ago . As Mr and Mrs Zeller they asked permission to settle down in Holland/GPE again pretending that their passports were lost during a raid in France/GPE . The permit was granted and they rented a house in Heelsum/LOC near Arnheim/GPE in autumn 1943 their two sons lived â€˜ underground with them . Mrs Durlacher Cohen describes the many ways in which the Dutch people private persons as well as officials assisted the Jews . Our Illegal Life in Holland Mrs Henriette Durlacher Cohen was born in Holland/GPE illegible and married a German Jew with whom she lived in Baden/CAMP Baden/CAMP Germany/GPE . When the National Socialist laws made life too hard in Germany/GPE they emigrated to Holland/GPE and tried to help as many people as they could throughout the war years . Mrs Durlacher took a 14 year old cousin to a hiding spot for example as the girl was living all by herself . Her parents had been deported . As long as the child â€“ like any other child in hiding â€“ did not have a personal identity card she was forced to live in hiding without being able to access normal education or participate in any of the activities children normally do . Personal identity cards were only issued once young people reached the age of 15 . Mrs Durlacher therefore went to the local council secretariat of the town of Oosterbeek/LOC using a FALSE name and presenting herself as being non Jewish . She approached the office manager a Mr Stroes whom she asked to show her how to obtain a FALSE personal identity card without having to steal one . He gave sympathetic advice . Mrs Durlacher had not known that official . There were no rules which she could have used for guidance { illegible } as to which officials could be trusted and which not . That was something she therefore always decided based on her gut feeling . Thinking back she believes that sometimes the way people expressed themselves played a role and that sometimes 2 she could see that they would be able to trust each other just by looking into people eyes . Mr Stroes informed her that a written application needed to be made to obtain an ID card and that the personal details of both the child and the parents needed to be enclosed with the application . Then an ID card would simply be issued . As the cousin lived in hiding and was Jewish neither her own papers nor those of her parents could be used and therefore personal details needed to be found . Mr Stroes stole a blank marriage certificate from the civil registry which they completed with two random names as the married couple . They retained the child first name but used the married name of the fictitious couple as the surname and predated the child date of birth by one year so that she would be entitled to have an ID card . They falsified the document without any difficulty and following this success Mrs Durlacher legalised five other children in collaboration with Mr Stroes . This not only ensured that the children were able to lead normal lives but they could also legally obtain food cards and other ration coupons for people living in hiding these papers could often only be obtained by stealing them and the risk of being found was reduced to a minimum for both the children and the people posing as their parents . The rescue of these six children was a total success . Many of those living in hiding tried to get rid of their own ID cards which were marked with a J and to get normal ID cards instead . To achieve this Christian Dutch officials proceeded as follows to steal papers from the various authorities issuing these cards . They took a few blank cards every day or every week which were then completed with FALSE names and stamps by the organisation of Illegals } . The officials who stole the papers took a great risk 3 as did the people who completed them with names and stamps but the risk was greatest for those who used them . In Holland/GPE people needed to be registered not only with the residents registration office at their place of residence but also with the central people registry BevolkingsbÃ¼ro in The/GPE Hague/GPE . In very few cases it was possible to have stolen original cards registered with the central registry in The/GPE Hague/GPE . It was possible to carry out only so few of these manipulations because the office was under German supervision . If an ID card was not registered in The/GPE Hague/GPE there was a risk of being found out in case of a thorough check . The checks were generally not that thorough on trains and in the streets as long as people did not look Jewish . But when searches were conducted in people homes officers checked very carefully and it was likely that people would be found out . From 1942 onwards it was often the case that entire streets were blocked off and then all homes in these streets were searched . Around 1943 the Durlacher family lived with such falsified but inadequate papers under the name of Dubois in the town of Benekom/LOC near Arnheim/CAMP . They urgently needed good papers because their son had escaped from the Westerbork/CAMP camp . They thought that they might be able to repatriate { illegible } coming back to Holland/GPE from abroad . However putting this idea into practice required enormous preparatory work and it took 5 months just to obtain the tickets for Mr and Mrs Durlacher . Mrs Durlacher again approached Mr Stroes who still thought of her 4 as being non Jewish . She asked him how she could obtain approval for a Dutch family wanting to migrate back to Holland/GPE from southern France/GPE in order to settle in Holland/GPE . She chose southern France/GPE because it was beyond the demarcation line and not occupied and the Germans were therefore unable to make any enquiries there . Mr Stroes told her that these people should simply come they would only need to show their passports to be approved for settlement in Holland/GPE by the central registry in The/GPE Hague/GPE . Knowing these facts she went home and the family â€“ the sons were 17 and 19 years old â€“ worked out the following plan as they would be unable to immigrate again under the name of Durlacher . They tracked down a family where both the husband and wife had been born in Holland/GPE but had emigrated to America/GPE long before the war . These people had last visited Holland/GPE in about 1935 when they lived in Wageningen/CAMP near Arnheim/CAMP . The plan hatched out by the family was carried out by Mrs D. alone because she was the one looking least Jewish . Mrs Durlacher called the residents registration office in Wageningen/CAMP and asked for all of the personal details of the Zeller family from the USA/GPE who had stayed in Wageningen/CAMP for a three month visit in 1935 . Everybody was free to ask for this kind of information . She agreed that she would call again the following day and she was provided with the requested information in all available detail . Mr Zeller had been born in Enkhuizen/LOC in northern Holland/GPE and Mrs Zeller in Rotterdam/LOC . Mrs Durlacher then wrote to the civil registries in Enkhuizen/LOC and Rotterdam/LOC asking for copies of the birth certificates purportedly on behalf of the Zeller family in the USA/GPE . After 5 days she had photocopies of the birth certificates . Armed with these papers 5 she then went to Zeist near Utrecht/LOC presenting herself as Mrs Zeller asking for permission to resettle in Holland/GPE . When she was asked to submit her passport and that of her husband she explained that these had been lost during a bomb raid on Strasbourg/CAMP and that she had been unable to rescue anything but their birth certificates of which she showed the photocopies . Her story was believed and she was given the necessary forms which she completed and which the local council in Zeist/LOC then forwarded to the central registry in The/GPE Hague/GPE . 48 hours later the local council in Zeist/LOC was given approval for the Zeller family to settle in the town . They were able to pick up their papers on the following day and Mr Durlacher now had legal papers in the name of Zeller and Mrs Durlacher had papers in the name of Zeller Selbach . They stated that they were living in a guest house in Zeist/LOC but gave a FALSE address . Now they were able to obtain food cards and other ration coupons from the competent authorities . Nobody thought or suspected that the papers were falsified as they only used original papers . After a few weeks they found a furnished house in Hoelsum/LOC also near Arnheim/GPE which they rented officially and then moved in on l October 1943 . They were able to have their two sons with them but only in secret . The sons needed to be legalised differently as they would have otherwise have been recruited for labour service or defence services by the Germans . This is why they did not want to become fully official and legal . 6 Their son Leofried was the one who had managed to escape from Westerbork/CAMP . All German authorities had been informed of the incident and he would have been executed on the spot had he been found . Leofried was studying textile chemistry at the time . All students were at a risk of being abducted to Germany/GPE and to prevent that from happening the Durlacher family thought that Leofried should write to various factories and dye works in southern Germany/GPE that they were aware of under the alias of Leonardo Maduro from Curacao West/GPE Indies/GPE . He asked the companies whether they were looking for a good worker and he received responses from almost all of them . Some asked him for further details and information as they would like to hire him while others wrote back saying they were interested and would be in touch soon . These letters were very important as during raids it was important to be able to show that one was looking for work in Germany/GPE . Also one needed to be very persuasive with the SS to convince them that it would be better for the German economy to keep businesses running rather than have young men sent off to do forestry or similar labour . Of course he never had any intention of taking a position in Germany/GPE it was enough to be able to show that he wished to work in Germany/GPE . Mrs Durlacher can not remember what they did to save their other son Evan . She believes that they used a similar approach with Dutch companies . 7 In about summer 1944 all 1000 guilder notes were cancelled and people could exchange them for different bank notes of the same value . But there was a set date which Mrs D. can not remember after which the exchange rate for 1000 guilder notes varied between 400 and 600 guilders and an official exchange was no longer possible . People forced to live in secrecy and hiding had little opportunity to exchange their money in time and they suffered huge losses . Mrs Durlacher had become friends with an older lady who was a member of the council of Gelderland/LOC province she can not recall her name . This lady introduced Mrs D. to some Christians who were sufficiently wealthy and prepared to exchange 1000 guilders for l000 guilder notes even after the deadline had expired . With these transactions people living in hiding probably entered a moral obligation to pay back the money if they survived the war . However it was assumed even then that they would themselves get the money back from the Dutch government provided they were able to demonstrate that it had been impossible to exchange the notes in time . Through her contacts Mrs Durlacher managed to help a number of people living in hiding in this way . To do this she had to travel by train to Rotterdam/LOC  Amsterdam/GPE Arnheim/GPE and other destinations sometimes several times a week sometimes every day . Jews were not allowed to use any means of transport . During these trips she was often asked to show her papers but never had any difficulties . Mrs Durlacher said that 60 % of the officials at the 8 public authorities in Oosterbeek/LOC Renkum/LOC and Ede/LOC near Arnheim/GPE were good and provided assistance as did the officials in Zeist/LOC near Utrecht/LOC . They stole falsified and helped in other ways .

Frustrated Emigration to Cuba/GPE Throughout all of 1937 we were preoccupied with the question of our emigration and when the horrible wave of arrests of Jews began at the end of 1938 this problem became even more urgent for us even though we were spared this wave because of our particular circumstances . Thus the years 1937 and 1938 were a time of great difficulties for us of agitation and sometimes of despair until we finally saw a silver lining on the horizon . We finally remembered that we had first cousins in New/GPE York/GPE with whom we had corresponded until the outbreak of World War 1 . But as often happens in such cases the correspondence was revived the old letters had gotten lost and the contact was completely broken off . How could one find the address after a space of time of more than 20 years . I contacted every possible Jewish organization in New/LOC York/LOC . It took about 9 months until it was determined that It was all in vain ! By chance but with a good feeling I turned for advice to the American Jewish statesman Herbert Lehmann who was governor of the/LOC State/LOC of/LOC New/LOC York/LOC at the time and described our situation to him . I received a very kind response immediately . He told me that he had asked the New/LOC York/LOC Chief of Police to do everything he could to find our relatives . Caught in the continental view that it must be a minor matter for a Chief of Police to find residents in his city and unaware of the fact that over there there is no requirement to register with the local police there was great joy in our halls in response to this letter from Herbert Lehmann . But this feeling of being on top of the world was soon followed by the depths of despair when the Chief of Police informed us much later that his attempts had been in vain and would remain so unless I was in a position to specify the last address I knew of my relatives . But this was possible for us . In our despair I wrote again to Herbert Lehmann who answered me immediately that he had assigned the investigation to a special office . And lo and behold ! Less than 14 days later I received word from this 2 office of their success . On the basis of the documents provided the oldest member of the American family had come forward and acknowledged their relationship . A few weeks later our son received an affidavit for the U.S.A./GPE on the basis of which he was then later accepted into the Kitchener Camp in England/GPE since in the meantime the German quota for immigrating to the U.S.A./GPE had been closed . Precisely on New Year Day 1938 the liberating telegram arrived for my wife and me informing us that our relatives had made available to us a large amount of dollars at the HICEM in Paris/GPE the representative of the Jewish Aid Society in Berlin/GPE which after consultation with the Aid Society we were supposed to use for emigration . At this time the opportunity arose to get a permit for Cuba/GPE for a sum of money of several hundred dollars . We took advantage of this opportunity and received from the agent who handled these matters the news that our permit was approved and that we should take care of the immediate transfer of the sum of money from Paris/GPE . We immediately did what was necessary at the Aid Society and waited with excitement for the permit until one day to our great horror we received a telegram from Cuba/GPE that the money transfer had not arrived and that our acceptance by Cuba/GPE could only be valid for another 48 hours . The transfer from Paris/GPE had apparently been forgotten whether it was due to the fault of HICEM or the Jewish Aid Society remains an open question . Through an exchange of telegrams and a telephone call with Paris/GPE I finally still managed to get the transfer to Cuba/GPE done in time and we promptly received the permit . Booking the berths also did proceed without difficulties . Hapag Hamburg America/GPE Line had commissioned a special ship the largest diesel motor ship the St. Louis for 1000 passengers who all had the same permit to Cuba/GPE . When I arrived at the Berlin/GPE office of Hapag in order to reserve two berths the official told me that everything was sold out . Thereupon I asked him if it might not be possible to get berths if I paid the fee in American currency which I had available in Paris/GPE . The official promised me that he would immediately contact the headquarters in Hamburg and would let me know the next day . 3 But I learned the same day that the Aid Society had reserved berths on this ship which could not all be fully used by it and the Aid Society gave me permission to demand two of these reserved berths for myself . When I arrived again at the Hapag office on the next day and the official beaming said that I could get two more berths in exchange for payment in currency I explained to him that I could no longer honor my offer on this matter because he had given me FALSE information and I demanded two of the berths that had been reserved by the Aid Society to which the official had to express his agreement under these circumstances whether he liked it or not . So we left from Hamburg/GPE on May 13 1939 on the St. Louis to Cuba/GPE though we could only take with us two suitcases with things for four weeks because the currency exchange supposedly had been able to complete their examination of our baggage lists in time . A shipping agent we had contracted was supposed to forward all of our luggage to Cuba/GPE after examining our lists of the contents . After a wonderful trip in very beautiful weather across the Atlantic/LOC we arrived in Havana/GPE in good spirits . When all the passengers had already made preparations to disembark the catastrophic message came that the President of Havana/GPE had forbidden our landing at the last moment and Cuban police came on board to watch over us . We were never told the reasons for this prohibition . The American Joint American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee immediately took on the matter prominent public figures flew over from New/LOC York/LOC but all attempts were in vain and even Joint offer to pay half a million dollars for permission for this case was rejected . Thus the St Louis had to leave Havana/GPE for Hamburg/GPE with all the Jewish emigrants after the captain received from Hamburg/GPE per telegram the instructions Head back to Hamburg/GPE . The mood on board was one of desperation . Through Joint mediation world opinion now stepped into action and when this became known the initial shock subsided . News arrived daily about the efforts to save us and depending on how the news sounded the mood on board would naturally change . The optimist saw one night between two days the pessimist saw one day between two nights . By and large however the mood remained calm and composed and there was any panic in large part due to the conduct of Captain SchrÃ¶der a TRUE 4 human being whom all the passengers could thank enough . Finally Mr. Tropper the representative of the American Joint in Paris/GPE succeeded in getting Belgium/GPE England/GPE France/GPE and Holland/GPE to each take in one quarter of the passengers in exchange for the amount of money that the Cuban President had offered . We ended up on the English list and landed in June 1939 in Southampton/LOC we were saved . There was another epilogue for us . Because it had become known throughout all of Germany/GPE through the press and radio that we had been forbidden to land all of the shipping agents who were supposed to forward our luggage had failed to forward it and were waiting for further news from their clients . Only our shipping agent did wait he forwarded all of our luggage to Cuba/GPE although he as we later determined knew full well about the ban against landing . So we arrived here in light summer clothes in part even wearing tropical clothes without any stuff for winter . Because we were successful at getting our luggage returned to London/GPE within two months of our arrival in London/GPE and the war broke out in the meantime we had to fight for more than a year until we got our luggage back and this happened only after our relatives in New/LOC York/LOC agreed to pay 165 dollars for storage fees in Cuba/GPE . The amount of approximately 400 dollars that had been transferred from Paris/GPE to Cuba/GPE for the permit remained lost . 
report by a Jewish woman who lived in Berlin/GPE with her paralysed husband until his death in September 1942 . She describes the deportation of her Jewish friends and her relatives . Her family was deported from Breslau/CAMP her sister in November 1941 and her parents some months later to the camp Riebnig near Brieg/CAMP . Mrs Veit records numerous cases of kindness shown to her and help given to her and other Jews at considerable risk by non Jewish friends and even strangers . They visited them gave them food and ration cards provided illegal billets and warned them of impending arrests . Among those she mentioned as particularly helpful are Heinz Hilpert director of the Deutsche Theater Karchow the actor and film director Fritz Clemens a businessman and his employee Kleinjung who was jailed for having given ration cards to Jews the literary historian Paul Wiegler the editor of the Berliner Illustrierte Dr. Wuesten Gotthard Schuh of the Meue Zuercher Zeitung Harold Lechenperg also of the Illustrierte the cartoonist Theo Matejko ? then with the periodical Die Wehrmacht . 9 . Remarks See related report P.III.d . No.536 also written by Mrs Susanne Veit . Non Jews Helping Jews Our emigration failed because my late first husband Wilhelm Meyer suffered a stroke because of the anxiety with complete paralysation of the left hand side . We had to stay in Berlin/GPE only our son came to England/GPE before the start of the war aged 13 years old . My husband died in autumn 1942 and I went into hiding in order to live illegally until the end of the war . Most depressing was not this illegal living but rather the time beforehand in which the Nazi government measures became more and more grotesque and wicked . One after the other our relatives and acquaintances disappeared one way or another and I was unable to keep any of this hidden from my husband . Rather being completely fit mentally until his death he was needed by Jewish friends as an advisor by the Aryans as a confidant for their outbursts of disapproval and desperation and witnessed it all from his bed possibly even more intensively . We received an evacuation summons twice and both times we were delayed after a medical examination because he was unfit for travel . But from his bed he said goodbye first to many who robbed of everything completely legally could still travel out to America/GPE after the start of the war and then those who had to go on the transport . I helped one elderly lady whose children were in France/GPE Mrs Danziger with her packing . I then heard that she was struck by a blow at a Berlin/GPE railway station during the loading for Poland/GPE . My husband had to hear everything from one collection as an elderly woman two doors away from us in a home with five tenants in which we had been temporarily housed was taken away by police early at 5 o clock . One of our acquaintances a bachelor Rudolf Kahn was recognised without his star from someone in a cinema and denounced â€“ this diversion was allowed as settlement for his forced labour from time to time â€“ he immediately hung himself in the police cell even before the Gestapo arrived . One acquaintance Bruno Goldberg his brother is in the USA/GPE and previously was an editor at Felix Bloch Erben said goodbye to us . He was in forced labour and learned in autumn 1942 that he was threatened with collection . He no longer went to his work and wanted to cross the/LOC GrÃ¼ne/LOC Grenze/LOC into Switzerland/GPE . His reception by Swiss friends and also the route there where possible was prepared with the help of a good Aryan friend in Berlin/GPE . But he seems to never have reached his destination . Miss Berend a sister of the Jean Paul researcher Dr. Eduard Berend who at the time had gone to Genf/LOC was collected here and already at the collecting point on Levetzowstrasse/STREET . Her employer â€“ the boss of a small private enterprise who had received her as an allocated forced labourer â€“ was still able to reclaim her from here and 2 get her out again . The only time I heard of someone being able to get back out of there . But unfortunately a few months later she was collected for good . I personally was released from forced labour due to my husband need for care however my school friend Alice Schnell who worked in the Jewish department at Siemens visited us every week and from her we learned how there and in the Jewish community everything was heading step by step towards complete liquidation and extermination . She still had a long time I think until the introduction of the Jewish star she worked illegally as a secretary for authors and screenwriters . These were put into contact with her partly by the long time secretary of the German Theatre where under Hilpert as director there was a particularly good and civil atmosphere . E.g. I remember that she â€“ I believe still around 1940 â€“ wrote a manuscript for the actor and director Karchow in her home in Westend/LOC . The forced labourers thought they were protected through their work . But she got a warning on the back of which she â€“ I think on the 26th February 1943 â€“ did not go to work and in fact on that day the workers were collected directly from the department at Siemens . She went into hiding and after a time of vagabondage a friend of ours a particularly good civil person who also supported me during my illegal time Fritz Clemens provided her with a hiding place at the residence of one of his customers . And that was in fact a Spanish diplomat who had brought his German wife and children to Spain/GPE and was very glad that his home in Halensee/LOC did not remain empty . He visited his family in Spain/GPE and there tried to obtain FALSE papers so that she could go to his wife . In doing so without realising he got mixed up with Gestapo agents and so to his horror he himself was the cause of her arrest from his home . Mr Clemens has a shop on Olivaer Platz and his vendor at the time Mr Kleinjung for his part created aid initiatives for Jews of his own accord . A school friend of mine Hilde Bielschowski went into hiding in the summer of 42 together with her brother and mother very difficult for three people together at the start and Mr Kleinjung made ration cards for them . The three Bielschowskis got snatched as we matter of factly and unpleasantly called it back then and during interrogation they were blackmailed into giving the name of the supplier of the ration cards . Mr Kl . was arrested and put into jail so survived the war which otherwise in Russia/GPE would have been very doubtful . The conduct of our Aryan friends was for us the positive aspect of that time with only two exceptions which I want to forget today they are both head editors incidentally . Colleagues who were not so close 3 also expressed their sympathy . The literary historian Paul Wiegler with whom we had never kept company wrote to us in 1938 asking us to visit him . Dr. WÃ¼sten head of the Berliner Illustrierten until the war end but I believe not a PG told us about his family and then apologised in a manner of speaking for the fact that he is the only one of his siblings who is not in jail has not emigrated or is not politically disreputable in some other way . The Zurich/LOC photographer Gotthard Schuh â€“ today editor of the Neuen ZÃ¼richer Zeitung â€“ visited us after the start of the war . When he went to Ullsteinhaus an editor there asked him You are living with these Meyers or going there are you ? You ca keep an honest relationship with Jews they just as much enemies of the state as Poles . Schuh angrily told this to the head editor of the Illustrierten at the time Harald Lechenpegg who having never visited us before asked to also be brought to us as a demonstration and he sat for two hours at my husband bedside . The very well known newspaper cartoonist Theo Matejko who had been employed at the publishers Die Wehrmacht a conservative but not very Hitler friendly publishers since 1938 also regularly visited us during the war brought us many expensive and for us unobtainable groceries and told us a lot of confidential news from the army from the base and the front and also from the Reich Chancellery . Before I went into hiding I visited him and his wife in order to say goodbye . There I learned the following An animal painter he had previously known had lost his work permit because he was non Aryan . First of all Matejko had tried to sell his pictures for him . Then because he no longer felt safe from persecution he let him use his studio so that he could work there in peace . Finally because he no longer felt safe in his own home he provided him with a room in his house . But finally it was no longer possible for the man to hide and avoid collection and he procured himself veronal . When I arrived at the house he had been on his deathbed for a day in other words unconscious . Because he was an especially strong healthy person he did not die quickly and everybody was now fearing that perhaps the Gestapo could come before he was released . Because being called back to life and then evacuated was what you were especially scared of . My husband also had to hear by letter about the evacuation of my relatives in Breslau/GPE in great detail . People in Breslau/GPE â€“ unlike in the initially rigorously bureaucratic system in Berlin/GPE â€“ were mainly evacuated as soon as a Nazi needed their apartment or house . These transports then initially went to three 4 camps in Schlesien/CAMP itself I also remember GrÃ¼ssau/CAMP and Riebnig near Brieg/CAMP where Jews could even have a camp organisation and where we could send letters and packages . As was soon exposed they were only meant as transition camps for the full evacuation . My sister who lived with my parents was very suddenly collected without prior notice . My parents were not allowed to bring her food and warm clothes at the collection point . She probably went to the Baltic/LOC we have not heard anything more from her . That was in November 1941 and the elderly people now lived without her for five or six more months in their home . They were given a few days notice of the evacuation of their home . This took place in the usual thuggish way . They had to take good clothes back off which those collecting them immediately packed for themselves and they instead had to put on old things etc . etc . Good friends of my sister Dr. Laubhardt a teacher at the Victoriaschule and his wife who I am still friends with today were with them until the end . My parents went to the Riebnig camp . My father died there from pneumonia after two months . My sister friends had the courage to write long and wonderful letters of condolence to my mother there . The coffin was driven out of the camp on a horse wagon and is supposed to have been buried at the Jewish cemetery in Brieg/CAMP . My mother was not allowed out of the camp . You soon began to tell from the letters coming from these camps that once again packing rearranging and gloomy leave taking was beginning . I do not know how long this camp continued to exist . After a few months my mother was taken away I hope to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . That was the last news we got from her . After hearing these pieces of news my husband who up until now had very bravely battled his heavy grievances aware that it meant protection for me lost the will to live . In September 1942 he died and my illegal time began . My experiences after I went into hiding were more serious and were mostly more dramatic than how it sounds in the following accounts and the danger which all those who helped me placed themselves into was very great . That my current husband came through it so unhurt is still a wonder today . Aside from my life I myself certainly did not have much to risk . When I went into hiding my son had been rescued in England/GPE my husband was dead and my relatives were already collected and missing . My only concern 5 was to always handle myself in such a way that I put those who were helping me in as little danger as possible . For me the time before going into hiding was the truly grim part when we lived in the ghetto so to speak in Berlin/GPE and learned of the full extent of the evil and corruption portrayed through the reports from various circles of acquaintances and the dramas which took place as the Berlin/GPE Jews were taken away both very completely as most Germans did not learn until after the war . There were our friends who partly belonged to the opposition or passive resistance . We Jews were the only ones who they could pour their hearts out to without fear . There were also the Jewish friends who witnessed the operations in the Jewish community and in the places of forced labour and then those who we witnessed saying their goodbyes before evacuation . I myself am one of those children of fortune who came through and who came through very leniently at that . There were definitely people who â€“ mostly because they had lots of money â€“ came through implausibly pleasantly and safely but on the other hand some had to pass from hiding place to hiding place and deception to deception with far more difficulty and uncertainty than me . 

winter of 1940 the author a Polish Christian fled with her husband from the Russians to Wilno/GHETTO . Mr Zadarnowska who had been a forester on an estate near Lida/GHETTO East Poland/GPE became a labourer while the author worked as stage designer at a theatre . Here she met a Jewish prompter Masza Perewoska . After the German occupation of Wilno/GHETTO the Zadarnowska decided to return to their home and Mrs Zadarnowska went to say farewell to the Perewoskas . She found the whole family in a state of upheaval as the Germans had ordered all Jews to move into the ghetto . Nobody at the time knew of the subsequent mass murders in Ponary/LOC forest but on her return home the author felt compelled to save Masza and her daughter Lilka . In November 1941 she returned to Wilno/GHETTO . Ill though she was she faced the inclement weather and considerable danger to establish contact with Masza . Finally she found a workman willing to take a message into the Ghetto and the women met at the house of a mutual friend . Meanwhile the author sold Masza valuables in order to finance the purchase of forged papers a certificate of baptism and travel permits . At one of the selections Masza and her family had been included for the transport to Ponary/LOC and in a desperate effort to save her friend the author prevailed upon Professor Kola Taranowski to give her shelter so that she and her child did not have to return to the Ghetto . The next day Masza escaped to Lida/GHETTO . Encouraged by this success the author applied for her own travel paper and at the psychological moment asked for the inclusion of a child and followed Masza to Lida/GHETTO . After days of frantic search and with the help of a parson she located Masza and in spite of the great dangers involved travelled with her and the child to her home . Her husband soon agreed to keep mother and child . Dangerous nerve racking months followed during which the author tried to ward off the constant danger of detection by making Masza look more Aryan and by teaching the child the Polish language and Christian prayers . In the following summer frequent Russian partisans ambushes added to their anguish and finally forced the Zadarnowska to move to Lida/GHETTO . They took Masza and Lilka with them but a few weeks later somebody asked for Masza on the telephone by her proper name . Undeterred by the danger and the proximity of Gestapo headquarters the author helped Masza and the child to flee to a farm the commandant of the Polish Resistance having provided forged papers . A period of constant moves followed and in the end the author had to take them back as nobody else was brave enough to shelter them . Later Masza decided to volunteer for work in Germany/GPE Konstanz/LOC . The Zadarnowska were forced by the constant Russian air attacks to move to Warsaw/GPE where the couple got separated during the insurrection . Mrs Zadarnowska was taken to Breslau/CAMP as a slave labourer Mr Zadarnowska was sent to Dachau/CAMP where he perished . Mrs Zadarnowska managed to flee to Konstanz/CAMP and join Masza . Both had to work hard and when at the end of the war Switzerland/GPE opened her frontiers they went there . Mrs Zadarnowska now works as a designer at the Polish museum in Rapperswi/LOC the Jewish family she saved live in Israel/GPE . Rescue of a Jewish family by a Polish Non Jewess I met Masza Perewoska in Wilno/GHETTO back in the winter of 1940 . In September my husband and I had to flee our home near Lida/GHETTO in the east of Poland/GPE and leave behind all our belongings . My husband had been working as a forester there . In all the awful chaos caused by the immense floods of refugees on all sides we finally ended up in Wilno/GHETTO where the Russians were â€“ for the time being â€“ not generally deporting people . In the east of Poland/GPE by contrast the mass deportation of the Polish population continued in earnest . My mother and brother were among those deported and my mother sadly died somewhere in the depths of â€“ most likely from hunger . My husband got a job as a railway worker not far from Kaunas/CAMP whilst I found an opening for a stage designer at a travelling theatre which attracted mostly amateurs who had previously practised intellectual careers . The Russian NKVD People Commissariat for Internal Affairs had an extremely poor opinion of intellectuals so they had to assume a cover activity . It was in this very theatre that Masza Perewoska was working as a prompter her husband Lazarz was a trader and together they had an 8 year old daughter called Lilka . Masza was a good colleague â€“ I went to see her at her house once but our friendship developed any further than that . Just before the outbreak of the war between Germany/GPE and Russia/GPE the Russians started with their abominable deportations of the Polish population from Wilno/GHETTO too . This was followed by the German occupation . My husband made the decision at this point to return to our home to resume his work as a forester . The plan was that I be far behind travelling in a truck from Lida/GHETTO as you needed to have a special permit to be able to travel by train . In the next few days I was on my way to see the seamstress when I passed Masza apartment . I thought I would just pop in quickly to say goodbye . I found the whole family busy packing as an order had been issued for all Jews to move into the ghetto . There was a lot of commotion but not a hint of panic since at this stage nobody knew that all of the Jews who were moved to the ghetto would be condemned to extermination . Even later on the Jews in the ghetto believe that this was the case but it was common knowledge in the town that the Jews being transported en masse away from the ghetto in trucks were being taken to Ponary/LOC a wooded area of Wilno/GHETTO where they would be shot dead . As we said our goodbyes Masza husband jokingly said to me want to get some forged Aryan papers for Masza and Lilka . If we did manage to do that you could then take both of them home with you. I laughed along to be polite and went on my way . I finally arrived home sick and tired having travelled there from Lida/GHETTO on a truck that belonged to the mayor who was an acquaintance of ours . 2 Our lovely little home that we had lovingly set up as our own just before the war had been completely ransacked . We had to borrow flour for bread and other food from the farmers we knew . I stayed in bed for weeks on end and stop thinking about Masza . I slowly reached the decision that I had to rescue Masza and Lilka from the ghetto . I know why but I simply shake the idea that they were worth risking our lives for . When I first mentioned it to my husband he thought it was nothing more than a pipe dream and he take me seriously at all . As I was still ill I travelled to Wilno/GHETTO in November to see a doctor . While I was there I was also going to collect someone we knew to come and help us around the house â€“ we had promised them this beforehand . The doctor prescribed me more bed rest but instead I spent days walking around the town trying to find Masza despite the cold and wet weather conditions . I heard that she was working in the kitchen at the Gestapo building . So then I spent a few days watching the groups of Jews that left the ghetto every day to go to work but Masza was not among them . In the end I decided to simply go to the Gestapo building even though just walking past it was enough to give me goose bumps . I stopped a young Jewish girl working there and asked after Masza . She thought I was mad and with fear in her eyes quickly whispered that I should leave right away . But I carried on looking for Masza . I paid a visit to a student I knew who now worked in a factory . When I was there I saw a Jew who went to this same factory every day to work . I finally had a way to reach Masza ! This factory worker agreed to take my letter to Masza in the ghetto . Masza and I were able to meet up several times at the home of some German railway workers who were staying in Masza friend apartment and who were often able to pull her out of the ghetto under the pretext that they needed her to help them out around the house . I was feverish â€“ all I could think about was how I would now be able to pull off my plan . I had to source the Aryan papers baptism certificates and travel permits all myself . I have any experience of this sort of thing at all and I certainly have the money for it . My main strategy was to sell some of Masza jewellery â€“ on the black market of course . I then spent days talking to all sorts of people to make all the necessary arrangements . During this time I came across some real idealists as well as some genuine scoundrels but it was mostly just young . Obviously these people had risked their lives and sometimes they also had to off the Germans . A group of these young men that I was meeting up with on an almost daily basis one day suddenly stopped showing up . It turned out that they had actually been murdered by the Germans ... Eventually I had my hands on the forged baptism certificates . However when collecting the travel permits that I had been promised and had already paid for I was told that Masza would have to go to the police in person for the collection . This was absolutely out of the question as she clearly looked Jewish . Even Jews that had a very appearance would generally not dare do this and understandably so . I was in despair . One day I found out from Masza friend that the night before there had been a big selection at the ghetto . Masza and her family had actually been among those chosen to be sent to Ponary but at the last minute a Gestapo chief had decided to keep back his workers . Every single day there was 3 a chance that this could happen again . I had run out of strength and had no idea what I should do next . I got in touch with a young geography professor Mr Kola Taranowski who agreed that Lilka could stay with him for a few days until I had managed to get hold of the travel permits . However there was simply nowhere to get forged permits from and the truck from Lida/GHETTO materialise either . Suddenly events moved forward at such a speed that it seemed to me that I had lost all control of the situation and was somehow stuck on a mill wheel . I found Masza at her friend apartment filled with despair and desperation because they were expecting another at the ghetto the following night . This meant that she could not go back there . The professor who had already taken in Lilka and a few other Jews agreed to offer Masza a safe haven for a few hours . Poor Professor Taranowski and his beautiful young wife were later killed by the Germans because of the help he offered to the Jews . Physically exhausted I ran to see various acquaintances and begged them to give Masza somewhere to stay for one night . But I had no luck whatsoever . Tears were frozen to my face as I went back to the professor home that night having failed in my mission . That kind brave man agreed to let Masza stay with him until the next day . In the morning I continued with my pilgrimage with a heavy heart . However this time some friends of my husband said they were willing to take Masza in for a few days . In the meantime Masza actually had the opportunity to travel to Lida/GHETTO illegally . I was due to find her there where she would be staying with a Jew who was living at the rectory and working there as a gardener . So at this stage the situation got a little bit easier . I plucked up the courage to go to the German railway official to get myself a travel permit . Luckily for me he spoke French as I still speak a word of German back then . I explained to him that I needed to return to my husband who was a head forester and he issued a permit in my name without any trouble at all . When I reached the door I turned around and casually said with a smile on my face I almost forgot ! Could you add plus child please? Without any hesitation he wrote child on the slip and that was that . Now I would be able to take Lilka to Lida/GHETTO with me ! The very next day the two of us boarded the train . I was incredibly nervous . Would the three of us manage to be reunited in the home we longed to reach ? Or would we be caught and shot ? Would we find Masza in Lida/GHETTO ? What would my husband say when I arrived home with a Jewish woman and girl rather than Ms B. who I had promised to collect ? These questions just kept going round and round in my head . Luckily Lilka followed my advice on the train and spoke to the other people on board as little as possible . They would have undoubtedly recognised her Jewish accent immediately . Once we reached Lida/GHETTO I again found myself looking for Masza and it took hours . It transpired that the Jewish live at the rectory at all and then had been too scared to let Masza stay with him so she was forced to go to the ghetto in Lida/GHETTO . When she was there she was given the address of a midwife who offered her a place to stay in the end . That was where we found Masza . She was very distressed having lost almost all hope of seeing us again . Not to mention that there was a huge risk of being betrayed on either the Christian or Jewish side . Lilka and I spent the night at the rectory and the next 4 day Masza joined us so we could all travel back home together in a truck . The priests were privy to everything that was happening and were nothing but friendly and kind . Lilka slept closely by my side and I felt like a second mother to her given that I wanted to give her back the gift of life . The next day I had to continue to fight for our lives . I had found out from the priests that the Germans would be searching every single vehicle on the roads thoroughly since you needed a permit if you wished to travel . But of course Masza did not have one . They also told me that on several occasions the Germans had found Jews and then shot all of the passengers in the vehicle without a second thought . The priests prepared a wonderful feast ready for when Masza arrived wrapped up in a huge piece of cloth like a peasant . Masza who had spent the past few months of her life feeling like a deer being hunted now felt as though she had stepped right into a dream as she sat down at the beautifully laid table and joined in conversations with her fellow companions ... The truck arrived later that afternoon and Masza said goodbye to those lovely priests . Outwardly I was silent but this was because the me was stuck in a trance . I had spotted the mayor driver out in the courtyard and kept a close eye on everything that was playing out in front of me . When he saw Masza and Lilka near the truck his eyes widened . But before he had time to utter a single word I had slipped a litre bottle of vodka which I had prepared for precisely this situation into his pocket and called to Masza to hurry up . I joined them in the truck and introduced Masza as my friend to a few people I knew . I then instinctively hid her back in the dark corner so she be easy to spot . Every time the truck stopped even for a split second I thought that must be it â€“ the Germans would be there to check and it would all be over . The truck came to a halt and I stared as though hypnotised into the tarpaulin that was now being lifted up . To my relief I saw that it was the mayor â€“ the owner of the truck . He said hello to me and then looked surprised when he spotted Masza and Lilka . Before he could speak though I quickly began to tell him â€“ in great detail â€“ all about what it was like in Wilno/GHETTO and I explained that I had just brought my friend back home with me . He said he knew about this and had promised my husband that he would give me a ride . But he then went on to point out that I in fact had two women with me . I quickly replied countering his point with a laugh and by saying that there was indeed just one woman and the other was no more than a child . He finished by asking whether he was right to assume that we all had our travel permits with us . I confirmed immediately that of course that was the case . The mayor went back to the driver at that point and to my relief we started moving again . My nerves still let up for a single second . I kept the people I knew in the truck busy by talking to them a lot so they have chance to concern themselves with Masza and Lilka . The police commandant who was heading in the same direction as us did start to talk to Lilka however . Masza and I were absolutely petrified because Lilka speak very good Polish she went to a Jewish school but that poor little girl carefully considered every word and make a single mistake . The journey seemed to us to be lasting forever . The truck stopped frequently almost making my heart stop every time but we were lucky enough to avoid checks by the Germans . We finally arrived at the destination we were so desperate to reach late at night and it took us 10 minutes to get home from there . My husband was thrilled to see me again . To start with he 5 notice anything in particular about Masza because it was dark . He just thought that brought someone else I knew back with me instead . It until after had supper that he came to speak to me in the kitchen . With a look of fear on his face he said to me a Jew she? I stayed calm and collected replying with a simple yes . My husband soon accepted the situation and welcomed Masza in as part of the family . I was so grateful to him for his reaction and I had already decided that if the Germans found out about what we were doing I would say that my husband had no idea that Masza was Jewish . The first few months were extremely challenging . We spent hours trying to come up with ways we could make Masza face hairstyle and clothing as Aryan as possible but we have much luck . Whenever I introduced her to people I could see it in their eyes straight away that they knew the truth ... It was even worse because our house seemed to be full of all kinds of people all day long . The table was more or less set constantly . We were in a very dangerous situation now as word had gotten around that a Jewish woman was living with the head forester our friends had discussed it amongst themselves and decided that we had been given a lot of gold for what we were doing . In many other cases the Germans had heard rumours of this kind and started investigations which had led them to visit houses under suspicion and kill everyone living there without any further consideration . The woman living in our house with her posed a huge risk too . Lilka had not had a very good education and it was hard work for me to get her to learn anything during her Polish lessons â€“ she simply want to follow them . Afterwards she was an extremely kind hearted and well behaved girl . I must have a sixth sense as the first thing I did was teach her the Maria . I also told her that if anyone ever asked her how she knew the prayer she should tell them that her grandmother taught her it when she was just a little girl . It just so happened that a few days later our neighbour children asked her whether she knew this very prayer . Lilka was able to recite it and the children then went on to ask her how she knew it . And Lilka knew exactly what to say . But this just went to show that people had their suspicions about our house . At least the neighbours had been reassured that Lilka was in fact a Christian child . Common folk on the whole posed less of a threat since they so sensitive to people being different or not having a pure accent given that they had their own ways and mannerisms . There certainly were some people though who noticed even the slightest of nuances in speech and behaviour . These were the ones who could soon turn into enemies ... The winter passed by and Masza worked really hard on running the household . By the time summer arrived we had a little more to eat but we were living in truly turbulent times . During the day we had to fear the Germans who were making all sorts of arrests . When night fell the Russian partisans went on a rampage killing people at random and burning houses down to the ground . For weeks my husband either slept in the or stayed with friends and people we knew . I never went to bed without a revolver a garden shovel and a kitchen knife so I had a chance of defending myself if it came to it . In the middle of 6 August my husband was arrested with a group of people . A Gestapo inspector we knew intervened and my husband was released together with a few others in other areas everyone that was arrested was shot without exception . Even in the face of all of this danger there was still no question in my mind that Masza and Lilka should continue to stay with us . The overnight raids by the Russian partisans had become so frequent by this point that I was a complete nervous wreck . We decided to move to Lida/GHETTO for a while so we would have to be worried about the Germans and the bombings . We managed to find two tiny little rooms in the suburbs . Masza carried on working temporarily as an office assistant to the second head forester but a few weeks later she got a phone call and the person on the other end of the line asked for her by her real name ... She had no choice but to leave immediately . The place we were staying in Lida/GHETTO was around 100 m away from the Gestapo building and there was a steady stream of strangers at our home . Full of despair I turned to the commander of the Polish resistance movement for help . He was in fact able to offer his assistance and arranged for Masza to live on a farm pretending to be the wife of a Polish officer . However it long before she and Lilka had to be moved to another farm . When it work out there either they both came back to me in Lida/GHETTO . After another few weeks we managed to place her still in the guise of a Polish officer wife with Lilka in a large home as a gardener . She stayed there for a few months sharing a large room with Lilka and having plenty to eat . She even travelled to Lida/GHETTO once all alone on a horse and cart to visit me . Unfortunately our luck last long and rumours soon started to spread around the area that Masza was a Jew . As far as I was concerned we had no choice but to have them stay with us in our two little rooms again . The situation we were in now was enormously dangerous . The Gestapo was very close by my husband had a lot of people visit him for business including Germans and we still had a large number of strangers coming to our home . But I still just send Masza and Lilka away . And so they stayed with us until the very end . The ghettos in all of the towns in the local area were in . We could hear nothing but gunshots from every direction . Everyone who came to visit us filled us in on the details ... We were all shocked and upset but we had to keep playing the part convincingly and seem to the outside world that we were indifferent so as to mitigate any suspicion we may have been under . As I had done many times before I had to brush off the comments of all the people who would say is a Jew she? with a laugh as if they had told a funny joke . With a view to wiping out all suspicion entirely Masza spoke really angrily about these comments the next day at the table forcing some of the men there to apologise to her . Masza had decided to travel to Germany/GPE with Lilka as a voluntary worker as she would be able to get by more easily there . Her husband who had been rescued when the ghetto in Wilno/GHETTO was liquidated and was now living in hiding had agreed to this new plan . So Masza and Lilka travelled to Konstanz/CAMP meaning they were closer to the Swiss border . Two weeks later Lida/GHETTO was bombed very heavily by the Russians . Going 7 back to our house in the country an option for us as the Gestapo was searching for my husband . Our response was to flee to Warsaw/GPE and we were taken in by some friends living near to the city . I had ventured into the city at the moment that the insurrection broke out and I turn back . I see my husband again . I was taken from Warsaw/GPE to Breslau/GPE as a slave labourer . I fled from there and made my way to Konstanz/LOC where I hoped to find Masza and Lilka . Masza was working very hard for a gardener in Konstanz/LOC and I had no choice but to work in a factory . I got an extremely serious case of pleurisy but I still had to go to work despite suffering from a fever with a temperature of 39 degrees . The German doctor give me any medicine either so I believed I was going to die . I had no strength left in me . Luckily in spring with the French very close Switzerland/GPE opened its borders meaning we were able to leave Germany/GPE . Once we were in Switzerland/GPE I was detained in the same camp as Masza and Lilka to start with but then I was moved to a different one . I then managed to get a temporary job as a graphic designer at the Polish museum in Rapperswil/LOC . I suffered through many difficult years after this . My poor health stopped me from taking on any arduous work and this is still the case now . I tried to look for my husband when I was still in Germany/GPE and then from Switzerland/GPE but I had no luck whatsoever . It was only two years later that I heard from the Red Cross that he had died in Dachau/CAMP . In the meantime Masza had decided to return to her husband who had since turned up in Prague/GPE . All three of them subsequently emigrated to Israel/GPE . Masza and Lazarz now work in office jobs whilst Lilka is happily married to a doctor as of this year . 1 It has been assumed that â€˜ Fernrussland/LOC is a description of the general location within Russia/GPE rather than an official place name . 2 It has been assumed that Masza/LOC and Lilka/LOC are being referred to here and that â€˜ mit ihren Kindern in the plural should actually be in the singular . 3 It has been assumed that â€˜ Scheine is a typographical error in the original source document and should instead read â€˜ Scheune barn . 
Samuel his parents sister and brother Werner were deported from Krefeld/CAMP to the ghetto in Riga/GHETTO on 15 December 1941 . Two days before their arrival there Latvian Jews had been slaughtered in the same rooms now occupied by the new arrivals . After a week in Riga/CAMP the brothers Heinz and Werner were sent to Salaspils/CAMP camp for 8 months there Jews out of had been murdered . A notorious mass murderer in the Riga/GHETTO Ghetto was Oberstf . Krause November 1943 . Werner and Heinz were transported to Camp Dondangen/CAMP Vernichtungslager/CAMP . Heinz worked for the Armee Bekleidungsamt . SS Dr. Krebsbach selected the inmates for the annihilation camp Stutthof/CAMP only 200 out of inmates remained in the camp of the Armee Bekleidungsamt .
