Heinz Samuel Experiences in Concentration Camps in Latvia/GPE On the 11th of December 1941 we were deported from Krefeld/CAMP to Riga/GHETTO . Our luggage which we had with us was completely taken away . Two days before our arrival in the ghetto something dreadful had taken place . Out of Latvian Jews only 5000 were left there . All the others were executed by the governing authorities with the help of the Latvian SS . We found the apartments in a devastated condition and had to wade through the blood of those murdered . To report on all of this is too much . Before we had settled into the ghetto there were still more victims . At the beginning there were 17 of us accommodated in a small room . The question of food gave us a lot of concern . We received rations for 14 days which only sufficed for two . We attempted through bartering to obtain a bit more . But for bartering stood the death penalty . Numerous people were hanged or shot for this offense . We men had to make a 7 hour march to the port in snow and ice and carry out heavy work there . Our food was frozen turnips which we found . When we returned from work hungry children stood at the fence and waited for a piece of bread or turnip which perhaps would be taken into the ghetto at the risk of one life . Our dear father who was suffering from severe heart problems did not have to work . On the 22nd of December 1941 Werner and I went with a large transport of men into the well known death camp Salaspils/CAMP 17 kilometres from Riga/GHETTO . We took our leave from our relatives with heavy hearts . The majority marched unsuspectingly to their deaths . Of people met their deaths in a mass grave . Vermin the lack of any possibility to wash and completely inadequate nutrition were the causes of numerous hangings and shootings . On the 11th of April 1942 even our Werner was sentenced to hang because he had money with him at a control check but thank God he was reprieved at the last minute because we were liked by the camp leadership . Our boxing gloves which we always carried with us brought us some advantage . This hell without any news of our loved ones lasted for 8 months . Then the rest of us returned half dead to the ghetto . Meanwhile our dear father had died through starvation . Our mother and younger sister were very thin the hunger was too great . Many of our friends never found their relatives they had been dragged off by the SS and eliminated . Mother had also been selected but was released . Many transports which came to us were led directly from the tracks to the woods and disposed of in a mass grave by machine guns and hand grenades . Our friends had to dig out the mass grave the day before under tight security . In the ghetto there were people from Cologne/LOC Dusseldorf/LOC Prague/GPE Vienna/GPE Berlin/GPE etc . men and women went in columns to individual SS and military units for heavy work . There were daily shootings and hangings . Mother worked in the ghetto and took care of the household of 8 people amongst whom were also Mally Kaufman Paula Davids and Julius Winter 3 . Sister Ruth worked in a big scrapyard and had to unload heavy iron parts . She requested that I go there and I was put to use there as a welder . Above all the possibility existed of a piece of bread or other food which I received in recognition for my work from the Latvian workers and took home to our loved ones . The joy was great but even greater was the danger bringing it into the ghetto . Our mother and sister recovered again very well and they lived very happily together apart from the anxiety which they had daily when ObersturmfÃ¼hrer simply took innocent people mainly mothers who had to feed their children to the cemetery and shot them because of food abuse . At the beginning of June 1943 a lot of Jews were sent to Torf . Even Ruth had to go . I was reclaimed as a skilled worker and was able to remain with my mother and sister . At this time a new concentration camp was constructed in Riga/GHETTO Kaiserwald/CAMP . Bit by bit the ghetto was shut down . It was the first time that we lads were split up . I would have liked to have gone with him voluntarily but on the other hand I also did not want to leave my mother and sister alone . We took our leave with heavy hearts and cried like children . Even Werner had luck this time and was the camp eldest in the death camp Dondangen/CAMP . My â€˜ command was also disbanded and I had luck I was assigned to the Military Clothing Authority as a plumber . This department stayed to the last in the ghetto and so I was able to continue with our life together . Only through my job was I able to manage to release my mother and sister from the horrible camp . Kaiserwald/CAMP . We often had to unload quarantine trains day and night . Ruth came back from Torf/CAMP with a septic leg on the 24th of October 1943 . In the meantime her parents were no longer here . She brought food with her which she had earned after work through tailoring for the director of the Torf factory . In between that our little sister went by command to the military hospital . It was 4 hours walking but she came home proudly in the evening with bread and potatoes in her rucksack which she received as a present there and felt like the â€˜ bread winner of the family . It is terrible what that child had to do through those horrible years . After I was sick in January with diphtheria it went well with us until the dreadful November of 1943 . When I came home from work I found a deadly silence in the ghetto instead of happy children greeting their parents and brother and sisters from work . Here and there was a light burning and I heard horrible weeping and howling . When I entered our flat I discovered it in the same circumstances as we found it in December 1941 but mother and sister were not there . I ran round the entire house and looked but in vain . After a long time I found Ruth again . She had sought accommodation with Mendel from Kempen/CAMP who was a witness to the events of the day . At 8 in the morning there came the order for all children and old people to report . After that the entire ghetto had to fall in . The people were driven from the houses by the SS with revolvers drawn . They had to go to the muster place for â€˜ selection by the murderer Krause . The fate of these poor people was decided by a nod of the head of this criminal . They had to immediately climb in to large vehicles and were loaded into train wagons . From there there was no trace . Many young mothers hid their children and gave them sleeping powder to avoid any screaming or crying but most of them were discovered by the criminals . The general mood in the ghetto was now terrible . The few people who remained had lost almost all of their relatives . We remained in the ghetto until the 6th of November 1943 and then were quartered at the Military Clothing Authority . People who had children under 10 had to remain in the ghetto and in a repeat action went the same way as our loved ones . We who were assigned to the Military Clothing Department had to all be registered via the Kaiserwald/CAMP Camp . There many of us were retained and badgered by the murderers . We arrived in the camp of the Military Clothing Authority . The work was very difficult and rations were scarce . We bartered the clothes of our loved ones in order not to die of hunger . We put on very thin prisoner uniforms . Both men and women had their hair cut off completely . Ruth went twice to the military hospital with a high fever and came home . I secretly left camp and begged in a neighbouring house for medicine and food . I wanted to give the good lady the shirt that I still wore but she said that the Lord would reward her for it . Then another bad day came . The last children who were still with us were fetched by the SS . There were terrible scenes . The parents had to hand over to the SS their own children . Small children who were sometimes smuggled illegally and with difficulty from the ghetto into the camp now ended up in the wood where so many of our fellow Jews found their death . When the Russians came once again an â€˜ Action took place and 76 people from our camp found their death . This selection was done by SS Doctor KrÃ¤bsbach . After this our camp was reduced from 1500 to 200 people . All the rest were sent to the well known death camp Stutthof/CAMP . Again most relatives were snatched away . However through satisfactory work which pleased the criminals Ruth and I managed to be one of the last selected . 140 people went by boat to Libau/LOC also Ruth had to go . 50 men and 10 women remained behind . After 14 days we also went to Libau/LOC and joined again with the 140 people . Our commander now was HauptscharfÃ¼hrer BrÃ¼ner who also had a lot of people on his conscience . By now there were heavy air raids by the Russians . Half of Ruth face was burnt by an incendiary bomb which fell in the slit trench . After an operation on my hand I was assigned as a heating engineer and often had to work through the night . We stayed in Libau/LOC until the 19th of February 1945 and then we were transported by ship to Hamburg/CAMP . After we were transferred by the SS to the prison of the Concentration Camp FÃ¼hlsbÃ¼ttel . We stayed for 7 weeks in this hell . Our strength ebbed away from day to day . 60 of our comrades were sent to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP . On the 14th of April 1945 we had to fall in . We were given 750 grams of bread and 100 grams of margarine which had to last for 4 days . Immediately after that we marched 100 kilometres to Kiel/LOC supervised by the SS . The first day we walked 30 kilometres . We could barely move because our bodies were already too weak from previous exertions . We fed ourselves only on turnips which we found and even for that there were kicks and blows . We arrived there after 4 days . We were greeted with the words from the SS FÃ¼hrer and camp commander You synagogue servants will have it good with me . We had to undertake exhumation work in bomb damaged house in the city of Kiel/LOC and during it we were treated disgracefully . Every evening SS â€“ FÃ¼hrer Baumann displayed his shooting ability and as a result 30 camp inmates had to die . The camp inmates were now only skeletons and we were so far gone that our legs could hardly carry us . Our legs and feet were badly swollen with water . On the 30th of April we had to put on the dirty and blood stained clothing of those who had been shot the previous evening . With this action we did not see anything good for us because many comrades had already had to take their last walk in torn clothes . We were already too indifferent to think . We had no strength left for life or death . Then an unbelievable miracle happened for us . The Danish Red Cross fetched us the next day the 1st of May 1945 out of the hell the memory of which will be with us for the rest of our lives and took us to a priceless freedom . This report is only a fraction of our frightful experiences . 
the author and his two brothers tried to escape from the unbearable conditions in the KZ Kaiserwald/CAMP and their work in the Ortskommadantur they were caught and sent to ABA 701 forced labour . There they had to suffer cruel punishments and sadistic atrocities the author accuses the Unteroffiziere MÃ¼ller and Schwellenbach . Dr. Josef Lagerarzt would warn Schwellenbach in vain of the possibly fatal consequences of his cruelty . The author declares himself ready to repeat his statement under oath before any magistrate . Evidence Against Unteroffizier Franz Schwellenbach Stockholm/LOC 3 September 1947 . Regarding Testifying against former Unteroffizier Franz Schwellenbach when he served in Riga/LOC . The signatory hereby states that he has provided a truthful report on Schwellenbach character as evidence of how the latter behaved in an inhumane manner . The signatory had to experience first hand the disgraceful deeds that Schwellenbach was capable of . I am ready to repeat this statement under oath before any magistrate at any time . At the time in question my two brothers and I were taken from Kaiserwald/CAMP Concentration Camp near Riga/LOC every day to work in the Ortskommandantur . Life in the concentration camp and where we worked was unbearable . This prompted us to put an end to this once and for all by escaping from this degrading life . Unfortunately our attempt was unsuccessful and we were sent to the Army Clothing Centre 701 which was also in Riga/LOC for forced labour . Once they had brought us to the Clothing Centre the commandant of this camp Unteroffizier Mueller gave us 25 lashes each and then continued to strike us . We were then sent to the forced labour group Schwellenbach was the head of this unit . Despite receiving our punishments from the commandant this did not seem to be enough for Schwellenbach and he set about persecuting us in dreadful ways . He tortured us using every trick in the book including making us carry a large stack of wood beams which were 5 metres in length for approx . 500 metres at a run . At this stage I would like to emphasise that this was not work that needed to be done â€“ its sole purpose was to torture us . We were working in 30 degree heat and { we } were close to collapsing . If we were unable to keep up with the pace at any point through no fault of our own as we were weak Schwellenbach would relentlessly beat us with a truncheon . The less we could stand the pace as time went by the more Schwellenbach would beat us . This ended with us fainting and collapsing covered in blood . You would have thought that this would be the end of it . 2 On the contrary our Lagerarzt camp doctor Dr Josef came and could see Schwellenbach knelt over us after we had collapsed punching us etc . in an effort to bring us round to consciousness . Dr Josef told him that our lives were at risk so Schwellenbach then threw buckets of water over us . The doctor was not able to attend to us at all as Schwellenbach could not be deterred from his actions in any way . Schwellenbach sprained his foot when he kicked us â€“ this was the only thing we have to thank for this procedure being brought to an end . On the many occasions that we lay there unconscious Schwellenbach would use water to try and bring us round . It actually worked but each time it indicated to him that he should start beating us again . Once it got to the point where nobody would have believed we were still alive Schwellenbach dragged us into a dark basement where we had to lie in the most awful conditions . We were forbidden from having any medical assistance whatsoever . Although I laid there for a while with a high fever and continued to be persecuted by Schwellenbach in every way imaginable I believe it was down to fate that I am still here today to testify against him . My case and that of my brothers is not an isolated incident . There is evidence that Schwellenbach without any authorisation treated us Jews in such an inhumane manner out of pure personal pleasure . I hope that Schwellenbach receives just punishment . Signed JAKOB GALANTER . I herewith certify that the above is a correct copy of the German original . FOR THE PUBLIC RELATIONS SUB COMMITTEE . My Experience in the Concentration Camps Dachau/CAMP And Buchenwald/CAMP A short extract of my martyrdom and of my frightful experiences in the hell of the concentration camps Dachau/CAMP and Buchenwald/CAMP in which I was nine months long a prisoner . I will begin with my arrest in Vienna/GPE on 28th May 1938 . This was in the early morning when a man in plain clothes sought me out in my parents home and summoned me in a friendly tone to accompany him telling me it was a question of supplying a little information and I should return home in about half an hour . He brought me to the police station where I was only asked if I were a Jew and on saying Yes was thrown into prison where there were already several hundreds who knew no more than I. But we had no longer to wait the first transport was soon sent off in which I found myself . There were about 700 of us driven in armoured cars to the otherwise peaceful West/LOC Station/LOC . The next picture was one of the most terrible . We were crowded in the cars like animals and placed round the Station were S.S./LOC men armed with machine guns who now set about us with their hand weapons until they had established a blood bath . When more than half experienced wounding and several were dead the death train left the Station . This found me with a broken finger and four teeth missing . As yet however the worst was to come when later the beasts started on us in the train itself . We were ordered by the sodden barbarians to gaze in the glaring light sun during the whole journey . Obviously this was impossible and we were then treated to blows kicks and shots until we were almost insane . However we got to Munich/GPE is still a puzzle to me today . Yet it was so . As we alighted we were treated much about the same as we were when on the Station at Vienna/GPE . From Munich/GPE to Dachau/CAMP we were dispatched in cattle trucks . We were lucky to have such gloomy trucks as these for not one of the cowardly hounds would enter . We were choked with blood and sweat and nearly unconscious from thirst when we reached this hell . It was almost like a funeral for as we marched to the gates of Dachau/CAMP Camp we carried the dead bodies of those who had suffered at the 2 Murderers hands at the head of the procession . After a short call of the murdered Grunewald the Camp commandant addressed us wherein he intimated that the guns of the beasts of guard go off quite easily . We were shorn bald and brought into barracks . We then received rough convict uniform and at last after more than 40 hours torture were given food and drink and the opportunity to lie down on straw . A short sleep and then off to work . Work is a fine word . Off on a torture trip . We each carried a stone block of 30 40 4 stones and a half to five stones weight which we had to carry the whole day long on dusty roads temperature often 40 deg Centigrade about 110 deg . Farenheit and without hats so that we all suffered a sunstroke . Numbers fell unconscious together . They were roughly brought round with water and must continue to walk . Bad enough this torture but this was yet the worst . One day we marched out and formed a parade ground in which was set up a block or post . The guards in full equipment arrived at this place and we saw a terrible picture public whipping . With animal strength they threshed helpless men whose groans were heart rending . After this devlish game the Death Head S.S. guards were grinning like devils . Such an unhappy experience as this torture happened to me when after gruelling work I fell unconscious . I was brought before the dog Grunewald commandant and asked why I had refused to work . To this nonsensical question I could give no answer and so he pronounced sentence Treehanging . My hands were bound with chains and I was placed backwards to a tree trunk and bound so high that my feet could not reach the ground . I held this out for roughly 20 minutes and then cried out . This was a bad move for I was whipped and placed higher on the tree and not released until 12 1-Feb hours on the torture stake . To come out of this witches cauldron alive was quite exclusive but besides these tortures a little example of some of the other fine things this mob did . On one occasion a small piece of bread was found lying in a barrack . Punishment twelve days Torstehen for all prisoners living in the vicinity . There were 2000 of us affected . By Torstehen the following 3 is meant . After tiring work and with hungry stomachs and thirsty throats remain standing to attention until sufficiently punished and that was roughly three hours . So our food was delayed and shortened with 30 days on half bread I can forget this but when I think of the punishment exercises I still cry out hopping jumping running knees bend creeping on the floor until we were exhausted . Anyone must see that not a day passed without many deaths . And now a trifle about the good watchmen . Some of these tyrants had hardly passed their 18th year . I was working in a pit which was already over 4 metres 4 yards and a half deep . When I stopped to wipe the sweat from my forehead I heard a command which ordered me to report to one of such youth . As quick as I could I jumped out of the pit grave and reported myself to himj Jew in protective custody reports obediently to Herr Wachtmeister I said . This I had to repeat until I was even hotter ? but it was still too soft for him . After this fine performance he asked me why I had come to him . Because you called me was my answer . You lie he said and gave me a blow which knocked me backwards into the pit . Now out of it he bellowed . I sprang out in haste . What I could have done to him then would have cost my life for I was at the end of my nerves . Yet this performance was put about ten times like a fool I jumped in and out and this hound grinned . I can still remember that malevolent grin today exactly . Another case which did not concern me but cost a dear friend of mine his life . We were stone breaking when he was ordered by a headman to run to him . What he asked him I could not hear but I heard his bellowing command March march . My friend obeyed the command and the cowardly dog shot a bullet into his head . The excuse attempting to escape Comment superfluous . Of such episodes I could write books but I will leave Dachau/CAMP and write about the many fine â€˜ goings on at Buchenwald/CAMP and about its commandant because there can remain no secretabout the brutality which helpless people are subjected to in present Germany/GPE . BUCHENWALD/CAMP may well be termed the worst camp in Germany/GPE because the brutality and 4 ness which are meted out there are not easily depicted in empty words . The criminal system on which it is built can he seen and judged on entering the camp . This transcription is written over the entrance Right or Wrong My Fatherland . Horrible the first impression . There one saw a half dead man before the commandant REDI whipped on the post two gigantic demons thrashing the poor fellow frightful to behold it . Yet a stroke and yet another but no sound came from the helpless one no movement to be seen . He is dead . Only then do they yield to the corpse no pity no compassion . They bellow for two prisoners it is carried away . Yet another horrible sight is to be seen . A column passes by broken men they carry a band on the arm on which is written bloed insane . They carry a heavy burden of stone one follows the other they can hardly move it . No pity a Beath Head moves amongst them and cruelly whips them forward . Gan one liken these dogs to men ? No and again No . And this is where we must live . We have had already some experience and were quite apathetic I reckoned no more with my life because after human estimates it was impossible . Little to eat no drinking water it was infected no water in general we could only wash once a week . Five men had to sleep on two straw sacks . Lousy blankets so that nearly all of us suffered from an eruption . And on top of this the work until late in the evening with no Sunday rest . Thus one day passed the same as the next ? work blows work blows . We were already used to it and feared only more horrible surprises . And what we feared promptly turned up . It was on November 3rd when a frightful order reached us half rations no medical facilities no smoking no letters . Buried alive . Every day we carried bodies from the rooms . I was unfortunately in the body carrying column . I carried many friends out on my shoulder thinking One day I also shall be carried out I am nearing my end . Yet the foregoing account is nothing to the unbelievable brutalities of 11th November 1938 and the following weeks . It was the great round up of prisoners after the attempt on Rath in Paris/GPE . The bloodhounds arrested men cripples and even children of 11 and 12 years and brought them to the camp . How they attacked them is unbelievable . There was 5 not one of the more than in the camp who had at least a hole in his scalp . The roll call place where they mustered ressembled a veritable blood bath . They were placed in provisional barracks where 200 had previously been 200 were packed . No taking off clothes no washing the food that was thrown to them eaten with the hands picked from the filthy floor . In these conditions they lived for weeks . There was no lavatory accommodation for them and one just let nature take its course . An epidemic was unavoidable and it came in truth typhoid was rife in the camp . It sounds terrible and so it was indeed . Hundreds who became insane we had later to carry as corpses from the washrooms where we had put them . When children erred in the camp the Death â€” Heads did their duty . The whip did not rest they were pitilessly whipped thrashed murdered they had never asked for it . And in conclusion of my TRUE pictures of the brutalities which are perpetrated in the present day Germany/GPE I will yet open the eyes of the British people and tell of the execution of a man in the presence of more than prisoners . Two prisoners broke out one was quickly recaptured the other fled to Chechoslovakia/GPE . The other after short proceedings in Weimar/CAMP which is in the neighbourhood of the concentration camp was condemned to death and this the Gestapo determined to carry out in the camp itself . It was the day before Christmas 1938 . At 8 a.m. the signal went and a parading of prisoners took place in deep snow at 30 degrees Cels about 90 Farenehit under zero we had to watch the horrible end to which one of our friends was to come . At attention in the piercing cold we stood waiting for the next terrible minutes in our lives . We were so many yet we could not help him . The threatening machine guns were trained on us and one move from any other of us would have cost many lives . The searchlights also pla yed on us and in the middle of all this the gallows stood out . Soon we heard the words of the gangsters March him to the gallows . And with sallow face and raised head with quick steps went our friend Forster . Yet he greeted us with a laught while the Leath Heads threatened us . The hangman shaking put the noose around the neck of the unfortunate indeed the hangman shook for he was one of us a 6 prisoner and had to do the infamous act under the threats of the beasts . Let him go was intoned and a few minutes later there dangled an innocent sacrifice of the German barbarian tyranny . March â€” march bellowed the beasts and the death struggle continued .

Police p.6 . The Rescue of Jewish Children in Belgium/GPE AndrÃ©e Geulen Herscovici is a social worker in the Belgian Ministry of Labour . During the years 1943 44 she took part in the rescue operation for Jewish children within the framework of the â€˜ ComitÃ© de dÃ©fense des Juifs . 1 â€˜ CDJ organisation ComitÃ© de dÃ©fense des Juifs 2 Personal responsibilities Reception and placement of the children Concealment of the illegal addresses even when it came to the parents 2 et seq . Episodes of Resistance work 3 et seqq . Attempt by the adoptive to prevent the return of the child 5 et seqq . Further episodes Rescue of the children in the Franciscan convent Heroic conduct of the Ovart family Evacuation of the children Help from Belgian during the acquisition of ration cards . Early in 1943 at the time when the roundups of the Jews where increasing by the day I met whilst at the home of some mutual friends a social worker who asked me if I wanted to help hide Jewish children . I said yes right away and that is how I ended up being part of the main aid organisation for Jews in Belgium/GPE during the last war the CDJ ComitÃ© de dÃ©fense des Juifs . Within this organisation there were two sections the â€˜ Adults section and the â€˜ Children section the latter dealing exclusively with the placement of children . The work was divided into three groups . The 1st group directed by Madame Jospa was tasked with searching for places either through official charities Å’uvre Nationale de JOC Aide Paysanne aux enfants des villes Foyers Leopold III etc â€¦ or with families preferably far from the cities . That is how many children were taken in by The 2nd group the placement centre directed by Ida Sterno was responsible for visiting the Jewish families who were still at their official addresses and who were appealing for our help to take away as soon as possible their children who risked every day being rounded up . These appeals reached the placement centre through various Jewish organisations the Zionist groups des Juifs de an organisation under German control but where we had allies . After visiting the family in order to determine the age of the children and their physical traits very important we would place them as and when places were found for us by the 1st group . The 3rd group carried out the administrative work . For each child it would create a FALSE identity after having noted down by means of a code the child TRUE identity as well as the address of the parents locking everything in a strongbox and a FALSE ration card noting the address of the caretakers or of the establishment where the child was hidden . A team of young girls would go visit the caretakers every month to bring ration stamps and to pay for the children keep . I worked in the 2nd group and it was my duty to go see the families who were asking for our help . I used to learn the names and addresses by heart in order to not make the Gestapo work easier were I to be arrested and searched by giving them a list of addresses . We would ask the parents to prepare the children suitcases and to keep them ready . In some cases the parents were asked to contribute financially . We would come by to pick up the children several days later and we were to take them either to convents to Homes in the country or to Belgian families who had willingly accepted to hide the persecuted children . We never placed Jewish children who had strong Semitic traits in communal institutions this so as to prevent them from being noticed too easily amongst the other children . When we took the children away we never used to tell the parents where we were hiding them . I realise how cruel it could be for the parents to entrust their children to an unknown woman we obviously could not say who we were we introduced ourselves in the name of the Resistance who would not even say where she was taking them . But this was an indispensable precautionary measure since experience had taught us that when we gave the addresses after forcing the parents to formally promise not to go see them they could not stop themselves from going and by doing so compromised the security of the children . Our organisation worked mainly in Brussels/GPEbut we also managed to hide children from Antwerp/LOC where a group had been formed under the direction of Mr Certain memorable episodes from this period . One day I was to take a two year old child Charles S. to stay with some peasants in Two children were already hidden there . I was to pick them up again so as to take them to another Home . When I arrived there I noticed that they both had scabies . Clearly I did not leave the little Charles and took him to the where I was staying so that I could find him another place . The pensionnat was raided that very night and the child was taken to Malines/LOC . The orphaned children were not sent to the camps but were placed in officially recognised Jewish Homes . Maurice Heiber who at the time was in Malines/LOC was able to help us retrieve the child whom we then placed in the HÃ´pital St. Pierre under the pretext that he had diphtheria . There he was made to â€˜ die . Then he was placed with some gardeners under a FALSE name â€¦ Today he is a big fifteen year old boy who is studying to become a dental technician . â€¦ After the liberation all the children whose parents had not been deported were returned to their families . This went smoothly except for one boy whose mother almost never saw him again . But the circumstances surrounding his placement had been particularly difficult so instead just listen this child who was one year old had been taken out of the camp in Malines/LOC being entirely without a family the mother had jumped from the Gestapo lorry that was taking her to the camp and placed in a Home for Jewish children that was under German control . No one knew his TRUE identity and he was given his first new name . The director of the Home Mr Tiefenbrunner passed the child on to our clandestine organisation . Every now and then that was how a child could avoid detection twenty nine children would be declared to the Germans when in reality there were thirty and the thirtieth would be smuggled out . We placed the child under a second new name this one more French sounding with a notaire from Brussels/GPEwho asking for neither ration stamps nor money explicitly requested that the child was never visited . After the liberation the mother who had managed to stay hidden throughout the war came to claim the child from us â€¦ she had found out that he had never been deported from Malines and had been hidden by the clandestine organisation but she knew nothing ever since he had left Malines/LOC . She gave us the TRUE name of the child which was neither the first nor the second one he had received . Whence our first difficulty for nowhere in our files figured the TRUE name of the child . Essentially through the help of multiple photos and due to the fact that the child had been operated on for an inguinal hernia we realised that this was the unknown child whom we had taken from the Home of Mr Tiefenbrunner and placed with the notaire . We went with the mother to where this notaire was living and there we heard that the notaire had in fact had the child with him but had only kept him for several months and afterwards had given him back to the organisation . To whom ? He could not give a name â€¦ he had not asked for it when the child was brought to him he still had not asked for it when the child was taken away from him . The mother was desperate ! No one within our organisation remembered having been to take back the child but many were those amongst us who had been deported . How were we to know ? The notaire had asked for neither stamps nor money none of the â€˜ had gone to see the child since his placement . What were we to do ? We placed a photo in the papers and made a public appeal whilst indicating the last known address in other words that of the notaire . The response was not long in coming we received a telephone call from the notaire furious who begged us to stop our searches since the Fifth Column was still around and he did not want a bomb being placed where he lived because he had kept a Jewish child during the occupation . At the same time he pointed out to us that he himself had lost a child during the war that he had well had to console himself and that the mother of our little missing boy just had to do the same . This last remark immediately roused our suspicions and gave us the keen conviction that the child was still with the notaire . Meanwhile we had found out that the notaire had a child staying with him who was the same age as the one whom we were searching for a child whom he had adopted following the death of the parents during a bombing . Despite our requests he refused to show us the child . At this point we decided to file a complaint and place the case in the hands of Justice . The judiciary police carried out a long inquiry questioning us all in turn time passed the mother began to despair of ever seeing her child again . Finally the police carried out a raid on the same day at the same time on all the properties belonging to the notaire and the child was found again â€¦ three years had gone by . The notaire and his wife had grown extremely attached to this little boy but who shall ever deny the cruelty of not returning a child to his TRUE mother especially after the suffering that she had endured during the war . â€¦ In/STREET Place/STREET Bara there was a back room in a cafÃ© where all the Jews used to hide during roundups . There was a denunciation and everyone was arrested . The patronne of the cafÃ© managed to save a little girl of about three or four . I was made responsible at the time for picking up this child . As she was on the first floor I first took down her suitcase . Having reached the corridor I found myself face to face with three men in civilian clothes one of whom had his arm in a sling . They asked for my papers which I immediately handed over . I pretended that I had to make a telephone call and found out that the man with his arm in a sling was the terrible Jacques . He had been injured by one of the men arrested in the cafÃ© who had escaped from the transport and sworn to avenge himself . In the cafÃ© there was unfortunately a couple that had also been able to escape from the transport but they too had been arrested again . The woman had just enough time to give me the address of her little boy in Deux/LOC Acren/LOC . What is more I had just been to see this child eight days earlier . This woman never came back . I was interrogated for two hours they wanted to know if I regularly went to see the Jews and if I had any addresses to give them . Finally they let me leave . They did not find the child who had been safely taken to a woman next door through the garden and we went to pick her up later â€¦ On avenue ClÃ©menceau there was a group of French nuns who also used to shelter every now and then children whose parents had been arrested . At any given time there were about a dozen children who shared the life of the religious community . Following a denunciation the Gestapo came but the Mother Superior managed to mollify them by promising to dress the children to have them ready the following day . She immediately alerted the Resistance the partisans came to pick up the children and they staged a scene gagged the nuns cut the telephone line . That evening when the Gestapo returned the nuns were calling for help â€¦ â€¦ An act of heroism . In the pensionnat Gaty de Gamont there were 17 hidden children and 13 adults in the attic . Following a denunciation everyone was arrested . The directeur the and their daughter were put in prison Mr and Mme Ovart were deported to Germany/GPE and never came back . Their daughter was herself in prison for more than a year . â€¦ One day we received news from Malines informing us that Frank who was head of the camp had received a telegram ordering him to empty all the Homes of the AJB . It was nearly the end of the occupation . We accomplished the tour de force of clearing out the children from all the Homes in one day . When the German lorries arrived they found the houses empty . â€¦ The children who were taken in by the organisation for the most part did not have ration cards . They needed an attestation de to receive a new card . I was made responsible for obtaining these attestations for about fifty children from Antwerp/LOC . Everything was going well when one day during one of my excursions I had to grapple with an overzealous commissaire de police who interrogated me and I had a hard time escaping from his clutches . I left this police station and sensed that I was being As it turned out a police officer who had witnessed the scene with the commissaire de police approached me held out his card and asked me to come see him the following day at the Palais de Justice . I went feeling rather uneasy all the same having already been arrested twice . This officer told me that he was on friendly terms with the head of rationing and suggested that we went together to see him so as to take care of all the papers which I needed . No list necessary ! How many do you need a hundred ? You will put the names yourself . And that is how I came to acquire the precious cards by the sheerest of luck . What is more I found out after the war that the head of rationing had also been providing cards to a whole series of people in hiding . â€¦ Very often whilst visiting the Jewish families we would be caught in roundups streets blocked off soldiers at every corner with lorries to transfer the product of their hunt . on the boycott day in Berlin/GPE the decision to emigrate and leave everything behind by well to do people the hope of the discontented that the time for revenge was near . Mr and Mrs Beck left their most comfortable flat to their old friend the well known actress Ida WÃ¼st . Her brother a Nazi in uniform who would protest his lasting friendship for them was trusted with the sale of the remaining valuables worth about RM 100 0 as stated in a contract they never received a word or a penny from Mr WÃ¼st after their departure . Although already 65 years of age when he first came to London/GPE Mr Beck worked from 1933 until his death in 1944 indefatigably and successfully in spite of the handicaps which the economic difficulties of those years put in his way again and again . His wife too worked from her arrival in this country and that as a secretary and lady clerk until her health broke down and she retired aged 74 . Emigrants Frau BECK now 80 years old recounts When we were at Eibsee/LOC in Upper/LOC Bavaria/LOC in the winter of 1927 we used to see young people every once in a while with a swastika on their jacket . This displeased one man who was clearly a regular at Eibsee/LOC he placed himself before the entrance of the Schwemme where they usually stopped intercepted the youths one by one and declared Whoever wears such a badge does not come in here ! They simply turned around left the place and are said to have headed towards Badersee/LOC which is situated nearby . On 1 April 1933 Frau Beck had her habitual meeting with her married daughter at a hairdresser in Wittenbergplaz/CAMP in Charlottenburg/LOC . Along the way she saw the smashed in windows of the Kaufhaus des Westens and completely understood when her daughter declared that she wanted to leave the country with her family as soon as possible and on no account wanted to have her child grow up in this poisoned atmosphere . She begged the mother to persuade the father to do the same . Once home she spoke with her husband and found that he had already deliberated the problem thoroughly . He said to her When you have read the book Mein Kampf you know that you can no longer delude yourself . Herr Beck was a very rich man owner of a considerable cardboard factory with 80 employees and accustomed to living in utmost luxury with his family . The decision to leave everything behind and emigrate into the complete unknown could not have been easy for him especially since he was then already 65 years old . It had always been Herr Beck principle to lend an ear to every reasonable request from his employees but when someone had gone on strike once they had to know that under no circumstances would they be hired again . The daughter of the first foreman Liepe by name who had also worked in the factory belonged to a trade union she had taken part in a strike at the end of the 20s and he had remained firm in his refusal to admit her again . Now one day in the middle of April the second foreman declared to Frau Beck that he considered it his duty to let her know that Foreman Liege had said to him The first who will hang on the next tree is old Beck . Frau Beck told her husband nothing of this short but informative discussion since he was already negotiating the sale of the factory . The prospects deteriorated however with increasing rapidity . The buyer who had at first agreed to pay Â¼ million RM just for the company goodwill ultimately received it for the current price of the machines and inventory he accepted though the provided conditions 1 that the employees would not be dismissed and 2 that he would pay the price in cash which was crucial under the threatening circumstances . Admittedly the money received then soon went missing in other ways . At that time the Becks were living at Innsbrucker Strasse 14 that is opposite the CafÃ© Meran a central meeting place for the Nazis . A giant swastika flag hung on the frontage of the building and constituted an incessantly irritating strain on Frau Beck nerves but when at last the big lifts which were to take her belongings to England/GPE then stood on the street they were not The household staff as well as the people in the factory apart from the one exception also remained loyal to the end . Customs clearance was at the Anhalter Bahnhof . Their numerous suitcases were not searched unopened just marked with chalk . They had left their apartment to an old friend the well known actress Ida WÃ¼st . She wanted to know whether she had to give the apartment back if the Becks did not like life abroad . The reply However we shall be never are we coming back to this country again . Ida WÃ¼st brother who at the time was wearing the SA uniform used to still assure her even then of his sincere friendship . He was an auctioneer and it seemed natural to entrust him with the sale of a number of assets which had to be left behind . He felt certain that he would obtain the best prices . It concerned a valuable BlÃ¼thner piano a large car and a yacht together with a sales value of RM . Herr Beck made a contract at his lawyer with Herr WÃ¼st in which he left him the objects for sale with the guarantee of a corresponding commission . He never saw anything of the money and only learnt that the lawyer had left the country in connection with the emigrations . Trying to get something back by way of compensation proved to be unfeasible . In England/GPE Herr Beck visited the companies from which he had obtained the cardboard for his factory . They entrusted him with their representation and from 1933 to 1939 he worked for them with the greatest success and sold their products to wholesalers and factories in Germany/GPE Austria/GPE Czechoslovakia/GPE and Belgium/GPE . The outbreak of the war put an end to this work . Herr Beck now began to build trade relations in Canada/GPE and by doing so soon established a new field of work for himself . Then came the requisition of cardboard by the government in connection with wartime economic measures which no longer left much freedom of movement for a job capable of supporting a by then over 70 year old man . Based on a newspaper advertisement he nevertheless secured work as the representative of a company in the provinces producing lining silk for leather bags and had hardly settled in when the lining of leather bags was forbidden . Herr Beck travelled to the factory in Manchester/GPE and suggested offering the silk in future as coat lining for which its good quality wholly justified its use . He operated sales successfully even on this basis with again entirely new clients and was hindered only by the need to observe the extent to which the material could be made available . Herr Beck died in 1944 . Through all these years his wife had been the secretary bookkeeper and maid of all work in the small companies . Even now 64 years old she still could and would not go into retirement . She obtained an appointment as secretary and bookkeeper in a company where she remained four years . Even later into her 74th year she was working and letting rooms at the same time then ill health forced her to retire . 1 Although the personal pronoun they in the text most logically refers to Frau Beck nerves the overall meaning of the sentence remains slightly unclear . 

tells the story of a young Jewish girl who at the beginning of the war worked secretly for a Jewish furrier in Berlin/GPE until she was denounced arrested and deported to Auschwitz/CAMP . When in 1944 the Russian Army was approaching she and other prisoners were taken away in a goods train . During a halt the girl escaped and with the help of a German soldier and an old woman made her way to Berlin/GPE . After a doctor had removed the Auschwitz/CAMP number with which she had been branded she found employment in a military clothing depot in Stassfurt/CAMP . Escape From a Concentration Camp Transport With the Help of a German Soldier In autumn or winter 1944 I visited old friends â€“ Mr Alfred Nomis his wife and 12 year old daughter he was Jewish his wife was a Christian â€“ at Schivelbeinerstr . 31 Berlin/GPE . He worked as a furrier and after initially being made to do forced labour somewhere he was released and made to do furrier work for the military in his little flat . He had to supply a certain amount of fur waistcoats etc . every day . A young Jewish girl worked for him . When the Jews were being deported in Berlin/GPE she did not return home to her flat at night because she was scared . She stayed somewhere at night and worked at my friend place during the day as she was destitute and needed to earn money . One day despite all warnings she decided to go to the birthday party of a Christian friend who had let her store a few things at her place . Her friend aunty was also at the party . She had nothing better to do than to notify the police . The girl was immediately arrested and deported to Auschwitz/CAMP . That was the last we heard of her . When I visited in 1944 my friends asked if I wanted to see an old acquaintance again . They opened a room that had been locked and in the bed lay the aforementioned girl with her hair cut off . She looked emaciated you could see her bones . Once I reassured her again and again that I would not betray her she told me her story In autumn 1944 prisoners of Auschwitz/CAMP were transported to other camps because the Russians were advancing . She spent two days and a night in a goods wagon with no food . One evening the train stopped at a small station and the poor people were allowed to relieve themselves . This young woman plucked up the courage to go around the small building in the darkness and climb into the brakeman cabin of a freight wagon waiting at the opposite platform of course without knowing where the train was going . Once the train had set off a soldier climbed the steps up to her . He had watched her and asked her what was the meaning of all of this . He told her she was in a train heading for the front but the train would stop at the next station and she would need to vanish there no matter what . After she told him her story he told her he wanted to help . He was born in Switzerland/GPE married a German and took German citizenship for his wife sake so he was forced to go to war . He gave her money and a handkerchief so that she could wash under the nearby fountain . He agreed to meet her in the station bar which was open until 11 . He said he would come and get her there and find her somewhere to stay . Where ? Not even he knew yet . He said she was not to stay on the street under any circumstances â€“ she would be immediately 2 arrested there . She followed all of his orders . The Red Cross were set up in the train station . They gave her hot food and she waited here for her saviour . He needed to slip away without permission . He met her and told her she had to tell everybody she was a refugee on the way to the West . She had lost her baggage and could no longer find the group of refugees she had been with up until this point . He walked with her along the streets of this tiny place and knocked at a small house where a shimmer of light could be seen . An old woman opened the door . The soldier told his made up story again and the old lady took the girl in . She could sleep in a bed for the first time again . At 5 am somebody banged loudly on the front door . The little town had to be evacuated within 2 hours because the front was approaching . All residents had to make their way to the train station . The old lady gave her a coat and she carried the baggage . Both women travelled to Frankfurt/GPE an/LOC der/LOC Oder/LOC where the old lady went to stay with relatives . The young girl bought a ticket to Berlin/GPE and headed to my friends place late in the evening . Once she had started to recover they wondered what to do with her . She could not stay in a Jewish person flat especially as she had her Auschwitz/CAMP identification number emblazoned on her arm . They found a doctor who removed the tattoo . He handed her the piece of skin in a glass filled with alcohol and said Keep it in a safe place you may still need it . Then my friends contacted a good friend who was a Feldwebel sergeant in a military uniform store in StaÃŸfurt/LOC . They told him about the young woman who he used to know . After a few days she travelled to StaÃŸfurt/LOC with a new identity card to work in the uniform store in StaÃŸfurt/LOC until the end of the War when she ran into the arms of the first Americans to arrive . She went to Sweden/GPE to rest then emigrated to America/GPE where she is happily married . I have saved myself the trouble of reporting on her experiences in Auschwitz/CAMP . The things that happened there are well known . I can get her name and address through my friends who now live in Buenos Aires . report on organisation and conditions in Theresienstadt/GHETTO by a member of the Jewish Ghetto Guard Willy Goerner . The first ghetto guard was dissolved in June 1943 and most of its members perished in Auschwitz/CAMP . After that only men over ? ? were employed in the ghetto guard . In April 1944 Goerner was transferred to the Aussenarbeitsgruppe Wulkow a working party of over 200 inmates of Theresienstadt/GHETTO who had to construct a future emergency HQ for the Berlin/GPE Gestapo in the woods . Goerner was put in charge of the camp but because of his lenient treatment of the inmates he was replaced by another Jew Rafaelsohn who ill treated the prisoners and was executed in Prague/GPE 1947 . Goerner was sent to a different working party the Z Baustelle which prepared a future HQ for Hitler . The prisoners employed there were guarded by police men from Berlin/GPE who behaved decently . The working groups were sent back to Theresienstadt/GHETTO in February 1945 . Goerner gives instances of sadism existed by Obersturmfuehrer Stuczka but also mentions that SS Oberscharfuehrer Hanke treated the prisoners more decently . Goerner gives also dates of transports from Berlin/GPE to Theresienstadt/GHETTO and from Theresienstadt/GHETTO to Auschwitz/CAMP . Every two to three months about people were sent to Auschwitz/CAMP . He estimates the total between 1941 and 1944 at . 9 .
