Theresienstadt/GHETTO Concentration Camp Ghetto The position of the Camp Theresienstadt/GHETTO which was a fortress until 1882 is situated in the Bohemian area of Leitmeritz/CAMP where the Eger/LOC and Elbe/LOC rivers converge some 50 kilometres north of Prague/GPE . Theresienstadt/GHETTO had around inhabitants until 1941 . The area of the fortress encompasses around square meters . The barracks and living blocks were built in square formations as the plan shows . The old houses of the town are only one floor high in contrast the new houses are two to three floors high . The Czech inhabitants of the town had already been evacuated to the interior of the country on the orders of the German Gestapo in the autumn of 1941 . The moveable inventory in the houses as well as portable ovens and stoves were cleared out at the same time . So only empty rooms remained . Organisation of the Camp The SS Camp Leadership The official rooms of the SS Command were in the street Q 4 /14 and 16 . The living quarters of the Commanders and the other administrative officials were in the street L Mar-24 Names of the Commanders 1941/43 SS Commander Dr Seidel Senior teacher from Vienna/GPE 1943/44 SS Commander Burger Manufacturer from Vienna/GPE 1944/45 SS Commander Rahm Metal worker from Vienna/GPE SS Commander Bergel Permanent representative of the camp commander manufacturer from Vienna/GPE The most well known and most feared other SS member there is SS Lieutenant Heindl a procurer from Vienna/GPE who was well known to some Jewish fellow sufferers from Vienna/GPE . The Jewish Self Administration The Jewish Self Administration comprised a Council of Elders with a Jewish Elder . The heads of the individual branches of the administration belonged to the Council of Elders . The SS Commander at any given time appointed the Jewish Elder . The Jewish Elder could himself choose his closest colleagues and had to present the list of these colleagues to the Commandant for approval . The Jewish Elder held the position like a mayor of a German town with the same departments and appropriate offices . So there were the following in Theresienstadt/GHETTO Central administration with card files Finance administration with a banking institution Commercial office with a central administration for goods Food department with kitchen administration Work department Culture and sports office Health office with corresponding hospital administration Building office Police station with economic criminal and street Police The following Jewish elders held office from 1941 until 1945 1941/43 Jakob Edelstein 1943/44 Dr Eppstein 1944/45 Dr Murmelstein All the departments needed for the administration were based in the Magdeburg/LOC barracks . In the same house more comfortable quarters were made available for the Jewish Elder and for those running the various departments . In the Fortification A IV there was the bakery with eight ovens in which bread for the inmates was baked by inmates . Bread rolls etc . were also baked for the SS in this bakery . Matzah for the Passover Festival was also baked in the bakery under the supervision of Rabbis . But this Matzah was only distributed to those who were strictly observant because there was so little available . The central storage area was also in the Fortification A IV . This is where there were very large supplies of all possible items from the smallest shoe nails nail files paint and coatings brushes and brooms etc . as well as the most expensive medications and surgical items . Even on the day when Theresienstadt/GHETTO was liberated there were still supplies of food etc . for another six months or so . From 1942 the Head of Police was Dr Karl LÃ¶wenstein a former lieutenant commander in the German marines . Through his energetic interventions with the Commandants he had been able to implement improvements for those living in Theresienstadt/GHETTO . On 17th May 1942 Dr LÃ¶wenstein created a Ghetto Watch as the street police for Theresienstadt/GHETTO . This was based in Barracks L Mar-13 and comprised three Watch Groups totalling 150 police . Jews taken on to the role of Ghetto Watch men were former soldiers and could not be younger than 22 or older than 35 years old . The privilege of being taken on as a member of the Ghetto Watch was given to members of the A. K. Transports . So the Ghetto Watch initially comprised only Czech Jews . The first Ghetto Watch had the privilege of being able to protect their family members in each transport . This privilege was taken away by the Commandants in June 1943 . At first there no uniforms . The police officers wore caps similar to those of the French Army made from black material with a protective flap and a narrow yellow stripe on the upper edges . Above the protective flap were insignia denoting rank on small metal badges with the letters G.W. The Watch Group leaders had two wide yellow vertical stripes fixed above the flaps of the caps whereas the train leaders had just the one stripe . The Corporal leaders wore two narrow yellow stripes and their deputies just the one . Each police officer wore a number on the left side of his suit while performing duties . White linen belts were worn around their waist over their civilian jackets while train and group leaders also wore white straps . With the exception of the ranked officers every G.W. man carried a wooden truncheon whereas the German Police carried rubber truncheons . In addition to the regular squad of 350 men young and inexperienced Jews aged between 21 and 30 were trained in courses lasting eight weeks to become additional police reserves . The person who ran these courses was the Austrian General Staff Captain Reich Weichsel who was assisted by former non commissioned officer SchÃ¼ler and Sergeant Willy GÃ¶rner as instructors . In May 1943 the G.W. was supplied with a grey uniform manufactured from dyed linen material . On 17 May 1943 the first anniversary of G.W. time was ceremoniously marked in the area of the Dresden Barrack . The formal swearing in of the G.W. men and of the reservists took place at am . This was followed by a march past by the G.W. in group formation in front of the Council of Elders . Those watching were unguarded Czechs some SS men in civilian clothes and a large number of inmates . The subsequent march past of the G.W. in goose step had left such an impression that the uniforms had to be handed over as early as the afternoon of 17th May 1943 . The order by the SS Commanders to dissolve the G.W. with immediate effect was given on 1 June 1943 and a new G.W. comprising only men over 45 years old was put into place . Those who were higher ranked remained with the Police . In the late summer of 1943 those G.W. men whose services were dispensed with were deported to Auschwitz/CAMP together with their relatives . The Council of Elders stated that these men would be Watch men again in Auschwitz/CAMP . I do not know that more than eight persons of the first G.W. survived . Even the second rate G.W. men were all taken to Auschwitz/CAMP in the autumn of 1944 because they were involved in smuggling with outside groups and illegal exchange of letters which had involved the Czechs and the outside groups . Some of the Czechs who were involved were punished and transferred to the small fortress . The police had the task of keeping order in the streets and above all in ensuring that there was no paper in the streets and that the prisoners did not spit onto the ground . The illegal task meant one had to be really careful when the S.S. came into the town and to report this immediately to the O.D. security staff and inform the house and the room Elder . The police dealing with criminal and business matters was under Dr LÃ¶wenstein as well . The crime police had the same tasks to perform as the Berlin/GPE crime police . The business police carried out checks in the kitchen and the business camps . The security staff called O.D i.e. Ordnungsdienst was part of the police . It was under the central administration . Only men above 45 were used as security staff as they would have to do light work . These men had to ensure that peace and order were maintained in the living blocks and the barracks . When working at night they had to check that only those who could show written proof of permission to go to work could leave their accommodation . There was a large hospital in the High Elbe Hohenelbe Barracks equipped with a modern operating room . The lives of many prisoners were saved here by the most capable of Jewish doctors . Beyond this in these barracks was a large shower room with baths which could be used by the prisoners . In the Gnie Barracks there was a TB hospital and areas for the special treatment of eye ear etc . illnesses . The very best doctors were to be found working here . In Fortification H.II there was a construction yard . Car repairs were carried out here . A special carpentry department had to produce the finest items of furniture for the commandants . Toy and ink production was also based in H.II both intended for German customers . The proceeds of this work were credited to the procuring funds of the commandants . In L May-21 and 24 the former riding stables was the big machine carpentry department which constructed parts of barracks for the German army as ordered by the SS Command . In the autumn of 1943 a big machine was also introduced for the manufacture of clogs and shoes for the prisoners . The Sudeten Barracks housed around prisoners until the summer of 1943 . The barracks were cleared out and then the entire European personnel file indexes were placed here . Only German police officials under the supervision of the SS worked here . These file indexes were burned by the fire brigade in the first half of April 1945 on the orders of the SS and under the supervision of the SS and the Czechs in work that took days and nights to complete . The Aussiger Barracks was the depository for clothes . Prisoners in each incoming transport were registered in these barracks and liberated from their most valuable possessions in terms of clothes etc . Every now and then these items were particularly sought and taken to Germany/GPE by the truckload . The Bodenbach Barracks with its armoury was the home for Jews until the autumn of 1943 . After it was emptied the officials who had worked in the Sudeten Barracks were accommodated there . Block D II â€“ Kasino/LOC â€“ was where the Czech police force was quartered . The police officers were called â€˜ Tschetniks for short . They were brought in to guard Theresienstadt/GHETTO and they were stationed at posts by the exits of the fortress and by the ramparts . The Czech Jews would talk and exchange news in a lively way sometimes with old acquaintances and at other times with other trustworthy Czechs . Cigarettes as well as other tobacco goods and also money were brought to Theresienstadt/GHETTO through these contacts . The Tschechniks brought in large amounts of money for Jews that they had befriended . Their commission was anything up to 50 % of the money they brought in . But overall the Tschechniks behaved decently towards the Jews . There were some amongst them who were guilty of violently hitting prisoners . Of particular note in this connection was Janischeck the Commandant of the Tschechniks . In recognition of his poor treatment of both prisoners and also his own police officers he was awarded the epaulettes of a German captain . The Tschechniks also had the task of leading and looking after those work groups who were deployed outside Theresienstadt/GHETTO . The fire brigade was accommodated in L 5-Feb . Its leader was the Jewish fire engineer Leo Holzer from Vienna/GPE . The fire brigade consisted of three groups keeping watch comprising 50 men who were initially trained by Holzer . A fire engine of the oldest type with a motorised spray and a lot of hoses and a mechanical ladder was the extent of the technical equipment . The entire crew of the fire brigade was deported to Auschwitz/CAMP in March 1944 . The leader Leo Holzer was removed from the group of deportees because the SS Command did want to be left without a single fireman . None of those deported came back . The frequent fires in the ash bunkers and chimneys meant that the fire brigade had enough calls into action . There were also bigger fires . In February 1945 a shoe making barracks in the area of the Southern barracks went up in flames . As a result Leo Holzer was struck so hard by an SS officer that two of his back teeth were knocked out because in the opinion of the officer the fire brigade had not showed up quick enough at the scene . In March 1945 an area of approximately 600 square metres burned where a roof of the Hamburger Barracks was being constructed . In this instance the professional Bauschowitz/CAMP fire brigade had offered to come but were not required . The speedy and courageous fight against this large fire had resulted in the praiseworthy recognition of Superior Officer Rahm in the form of a small container of liver sausage and 100 grammes of margarine . The fire brigade fought their last big fire at am on 9 May 1945 . In the Southern barracks the area for uniform materials had gone up in flames . It was around midday when the superior officer came to the site of the fire tapped Leo Holzer in a jovial way on his shoulder saying Well Holzer we wo be reconstructing these barracks anymore . Rahm lingered for a short while at the site of the fire and then returned to the Commandants area . It was later that said by a Tschetnik that the fire was started by Squad Leader Heindl . A large number of the camp prisoners were alerted to the fire by the noise of the fire brigade and in curiosity they came to the southern gate to watch the work of the fire being extinguished . At this time the rest of the SS occupation force left the town to go in a north western direction . It was during the previous night from 8 to 9 May 1945 that the bulk of the SS occupation force had moved out so the Tschechniks had told us . The agricultural team were based in D I and they managed several hundred acres of land together with a haulage area and a lot of agricultural equipment . In addition there was the entire livestock that had come from the area of Lidice/LOC taken by the SS . The leader of the agriculture section was the Czech Cursavy a member of the Nazi Party . There were only a few occasions when Cursavy hit his Jewish workers and only then when the controlling SS made him do this . Blocks E Iva and E IVb were intended for the accommodation of children . Only Czech children were in E IVb . There was another children home in L Apr-19 . The church that was situated between these two blocks stayed closed the whole time . In the corner house L 4-Sep Apr-15 there was a shop for ladies and gents ready made clothes . With their coupons the inmates could acquire clothing which they now needed but only after receiving the prior permission of the business office . The stocks were replenished by the items left by prisoners who had died or had been deported . On the plot of land there was a coffee house in the Viennese style . Every visitor received a cup of coffee no coffee beans and a lump of sugar for the payment of two Ghetto Kronen . The famous composer TranslatÃ¤r played the piano in the coffee house until he starved to death . In the autumn of 1943 and the spring of 1944 the market place of the small town was completely dug up and converted into a lawn area complete with large borders of flowers . There were even benches placed on the edges of the square . A music pavilion was built in the corner L4 / Q4 opposite the coffee house as the high point of the publicity for those from the outside . A band played here every lunch time and evening . The pieces of music to be played were prescribed by the SS command . Concerts and plays were performed in the Sokolowna formerly the Sokol Club house situated on the street which runs south west between and Sudeten barracks . There was also a small theatre area built by the inmates on the floor of the Magdeburger barracks . Concerts and plays were performed by the many artists Jewish artists who found themselves in Theresienstadt/GHETTO but only after receiving permission from the SS command . In L Apr-16 and 18 there was a watch repair workshop and a shop for spectacles . The watch repair workshop mainly carried out tasks for the SS Command . Only the heads of the main administration and the police received repair permission documents through the business office in the case of spectacles receipts were handed out and repairs were carried out with the express permission of the business office . The butcher shop was in area L Apr-13 . This supplied horse meat for the big kitchens . In general this butcher shop situated on the street was empty . It was only on the days when commissions arrived in Theresienstadt/GHETTO for the purposes of inspecting that good meat and sausage products were displayed . A grocery shop was established in the house on L 4-Nov . Here one could buy a great choice of herbal teas mustard and tomato puree with a coupon and in exchange for Ghetto Kronen . This occurred on average at 3 monthly intervals for the inmates . Mustard and tomato puree were very popular as spreads for bread . The bank which supplied the Ghetto money had its rooms on the ground floor of Q Apr-14 . Altogether around 5 million Ghetto Kronen notes were printed made up of 1 2 5 10 20 50 and 100 Kronen notes . This money was handed out as payment for work undertaken and was the official currency of Theresienstadt/GHETTO . The possession of other forms of money was forbidden . The laundry was sited on the street which leads via square C to the small fortress . This central laundry had been set up by the Jews and was operating in three shifts . Each prisoner received on average one washing permission document every three months which allowed him / her to use the facilities to wash 3 kgs of clothes . The columbarium was on the left side of the L2 street which runs through the map squares II and III . The columbarium was the place where the deceased were remembered and where their ashes were stored . On the other side of the street opposite the columbarium was the mortuary with its small space where funeral ceremonies could take place in all solemnity . The deceased were placed in simple boxes comprising lengths of bare wood and carried in the chapel . Following a short funeral ceremony the boxes containing the deceased were loaded onto a carriage pulled by two horses to be driven to the crematorium . Those who were left behind were allowed to follow the carriage as far as the exit of the fortress . In the months September to October 1944 many thousands of urns cardboard cartons containing the ashes of those who had died up to that date were transported to the Eger/LOC on the orders of the Command and under the supervision of the SS and then shaken into the river . Even children under 14 were called upon to do this work . The homes for the sick and infirm were in the block D VI and F III . All the very sick prisoners who were not expected to live were housed here . Many of the extremely sick prisoners owe their lives to skills of the predominantly Jewish doctors present in Theresienstadt/GHETTO if they were not to eventually die in Auschwitz/CAMP . The Small Fortress The small fortress was a precursor to the fortress of Theresienstadt/GHETTO and was situated one kilometre north east of Theresienstadt/GHETTO . Jews who had been severely punished in Theresienstadt/GHETTO by the SS Command were brought here . Czechs and Tschetniks as well as Germans who were guilty of collaborating with the Jews were likewise brought here . The small fortress was the nearest extermination camp to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . Only a small number of prisoners were able to survive this hell . Those prisoners who were guilty of further punishable offences were selected for shooting practice on the shooting range . These living people were used as targets for shooting on the shooting range . As Hans Wagner a fellow sufferer in the small fortress told me the commandant â€˜ Pinja and his daughter had taken part in these shootings with great pleasure â€“ and even his daughter had distinguished herself in this . The Wulkow Outside Work Group In the first days of March 1944 a work group comprising 235 men were sent to Wulkow/LOC in the region of Trebnitz/LOC some 55 kms from Berlin/GPE in order to build barracks . The work group were mainly volunteers . These men were promised by the SS Headquarters that they and their families would be exempt from any transportation . This promise was kept . The Jewish lead worker was the Czech engineer Cosinier and he had with him other engineers Schindler Eckstein Wassermann Mukden and others . The SS leadership and supervising officers were SS Senior Sergeant Franz Stuczka clothing manufacturer from Vienna/GPE SS Senior Sergeant Czasny cab driver from Vienna/GPE SS Senior Sergeant Hanke bricklayer foreman from Vienna/GPE SS Senior Sergeant Proschek bank messenger from Vienna/GPE In addition there was an SS Guards Group comprising ten SS men with Lance Corporal Schmidt as commander . The specialist work force had a roofer a well digger and experts in electricity telephone plumbing and painting . These men were not on the building site the whole day but their role was to give instructions regarding the individual tasks . These specialists were all German . In the summer of 1944 the 235 men were joined by 25 women from Theresienstadt/GHETTO whose job it was to keep the barracks in a good state of order as well as to clean the clothes of the men . The work force was involved with 110 building projects in the woods on Wulkow/LOC . These comprised building living barracks work and kitchen barracks as well as bunkers for files pools of water for extinguishing fires vehicle workshops and a bunker for coal . Complete systems for sewage and wells with modern automatic pumps were created for this small town of barracks . This camp was the alternative place for the headquarters of the Berlin/GPE Gestapo and was partly adopted for this purpose in the autumn of 1944 and was carefully watched over by a group of SS guards . In the first days of August 1944 a new building site was started at a distance of around 2 kms from the main camp . This building site was named the Z building site . This was built as the private chancellery of the FÃ¼hrer . It consisted of living working and kitchen barracks a bunker for files was part of this as was a pool of water for extinguishing fires a vehicle workshop and a shed for coal . The construction of a bunker for receiving news made entirely from concrete was also started . A modern system including piping intended for extracting water was likewise part of this . The hours of work for the work groups were am to pm in the summer months and am to dusk in the winter months . There was a one hour midday break . Every second Sunday was given as a work free day . In this connection Stuczka had thought of special forms of amusement at least for the mornings . He then often played a game of so called â€˜ HÃ¤ufchenmachen â€˜ piling up . All members of the work group had to come for a roll call and then for reasons that were impossible to establish Stuczka would select the most varied persons and make them come together in small piles . And then the group leaders were asked by the senior lieutenant about their diligence mental attitude etc . Sometimes Stuczka left having issued an order that no one was to leave their place . After one or two hours he either returned to continue the game or broke it up . A particular sport of Stuczka on the free Sundays was for the men to carry tree trunks from one place in the camp to another . For the women â€˜ dragging stones was the order of the day . On one day in October Stuczka managed a quite special orgy . In the previous days there had been a lot of rain which had very much softened up the ground and created a large puddle in front of the living barracks . Stuczka summoned a roll call on this Sunday . He selected his special favourites from amongst the women and ordered them to sit down on the ground and to use their behinds to push the resulting mud to a place indicated by him . So the women had to lift up their clothes high so that they were in effect clothed only in their knickers . In similar fashion the men had to remove their upper clothes leaving just their shirts and stand by to watch the women . The two women by the name of Schlesinger and Thomas had to bathe in the puddle firstly immersing the front sides of their bodies fully into the puddle and then the back sides . Then Stuczka trod on their upper bodies then their lower bodies so that they were then completely covered in mud . And each time these procedures were accompanied by Stuczka laughing in a devilish way . After five hours this roll call ended and this Sunday had been ruined . Stuczka was very unpopular amongst his subordinates . He was also extraordinarily untrusting . With even the slightest suspicion of a perhaps unintended instance of untruthfulness on the part of the workmen he would react immediately with the cruellest methods of beating . The SS squad leaders were likewise no angels . I can however maintain that they were very restrained in the matter of beating the work men . Senior SS squad leader Hanke very often even acted in contradiction to the orders of the Senior Assault Leader by caring well for those workers who had been beaten by Stuczka and placed in close detention . The Z building site work groups were led and watched by four SS men in the first week . On 1 October 1944 the supervision of this work group and the guarding of the building site were taken over by a group of police from Berlin/GPE comprising twelve policemen with a main guarding officer even during the nights . The Z work group lived in the greatest harmony with this group of police . Theresienstadt/GHETTO cared for the food requirements of the work group . Every fourteen days a carriage of food would come from Theresienstadt/GHETTO . The rations were 10 % more than in Theresienstadt/GHETTO itself . These comparatively good rations were very frequently significantly reduced by the senior squad leader for some or other reasons that were not transparent and were often completely non existent . Then it was the young pods of the acacia trees that made up the meagre nourishment for the work men . In the first week a camp guard group comprising six men was formed from the workers under the supervision of Georg Einstein grandson of Professor Dr Einstein . On 26 April 1944 a guard group of the Ghetto Watch comprising six men and under the orders of Guard Commandant Willy GÃ¶rner was ordered to go to Wulkow/CAMP . GÃ¶rner then assumed control of the camp as Chief of Police but then had this role removed from him due to his laxness towards his fellow sufferers and he took over supervision of the new Z building works . The leadership role in terms of the entire camp was then handed over to fellow sufferer Rafaelsohn . In the time prior to this change of leadership the Senior Assault Leader ObersturmfÃ¼hrer had conducted himself in a relatively normal way but thereafter began to use the most terrible methods of beating and Rafaelsohn often supported him with this . As a result Rafaelsohn was sentenced to death and hanged in 1947 in Prague/GPE . In the night of 2 3 February 1945 the working group marched to Trebnitz/CAMP and were then loaded into four cattle trucks and their journey to Theresienstadt/GHETTO ended around p.m. on 10 February 1945 having passed through Berlin/GPE Luckenwalde/LOC JÃ¼terbog/LOC Halle/LOC Merseburg/LOC WÃ¼rzburg/LOC and Prague/GPE . III . The Prisoners of the Ghetto . Jews in Theresienstadt/GHETTO had to wear a Star of David which had been made a legal requirement from 19 September 1941 . The residents of Theresienstadt/GHETTO had not all yet been evacuated when the first transports arrived in the late summer of 1941 . At first it was just Jews from Czechoslovakia/GPE . These transports had the designation A.K.I II etc . Construction Commando . The transport of Jews from Berlin/GPE was designated I / B 90 10990 . So this was the 90th transport from Berlin/GPE with the 10990th Jew from Berlin/GPE . The transports from the other German towns had other Roman first digits . The Jews transported to Theresienstadt/GHETTO from all the countries that had been occupied by the Germans had met certain conditions . These conditions were Married couple had to have a combined age of 130 . War wounded from 1914 1918 who had been at the front for a certain time . Those who had fought in the war who had the various insignia the least being the EK II given to the wounded . Those awarded the EK I who had fought at the front in the war for a certain time . Those who were married whose spouse had to be Aryan and who have children brought up as Christians . Jews who had been in the service of the Gestapo for a considerable time or who had demonstrated special merit . In this context the individual Jewish communities were given the task of encouraging their members to purchase enough to last their lifetimes for their stays in Theresienstadt/GHETTO . They had to pay a large amount of money to the Gestapo for this . These Jews were then transported to Theresienstadt/GHETTO but then had no advantages over the others . There were even prominent Jews amongst the others in Theresienstadt/GHETTO . These were high government officials and high officers and scientists from the occupied countries . They were particularly sought by the notorious SS Senior Assault Leader SS ObersturmfÃ¼hrer Eichmann . One of the most prominent personalities was the widow of the General von Falkenhain . The AK Transportees had to construct the empty structures in the barracks from untreated and un planed boards . They made beds which were 180 cm long and 60 cm wide and were triple bunk beds . The beds were supplied with paper bags that were filled with wood wool . The prisoners had to bring their own sheets etc . There were no tables chairs or cupboards there at all . General Matters There were approximately 14 large kitchens that supplied food for the prisoners on a community wide basis . The food served would alternate between millet gruel and turnip or potato meals . The order of the days was Mornings coffee but of course not ground coffee Midday Extract of Lentil Soup with a potato dish . Evening Coffee or Extract of Lentil Soup Lunch comprised 250 gr . raw weight potatoes millet gruel etc . 100 gr standard sauce Â¼ litre soup With this meal there was also 750 gr . bread to last 3 days in addition to last for 10 days 90 gr . sugar and 50 gr . margarine Every second day there was also â€˜ 50 gr . meat raw weight for lunch . Those who had to undertake heavy labour received 900 gr . bread and 50 % extra in terms of the standard lunch ration . Children received 50 gr . more food for lunch than the adults and their food came from special kitchens . Instead of coffee in the evenings they received comparatively well cooked semolina soup etc . Some of the prisoners received parcels from their relatives and friends . Parcels weighing 250 gr . to 25 kilos were permitted . Before being handed to the recipients the contents of these parcels were checked by the Tschekniks together with the SS Command . The recipients then received confirmation cards which each contained additional five hand written words . All men and women under 65 who were capable of working were registered in the work offices and divided up into the most different branches of work . Anyone over 65 did not need to work . There were special barracks in which only men lived and also some in which women with children lived . Married couples over 65 could live together in special living quarters but not together in one room . There was always plenty of different kinds of work to do in Theresienstadt/GHETTO . There was the inner construction of the sleeping quarters the creation of a good system of piping making provision for a supply of fresh water for the Ghetto from outside Theresienstadt/GHETTO construction and upgrading of the streets around Theresienstadt/GHETTO and the construction of the tram line from Bauschowitz/CAMP to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . All these projects involved the labour of many thousands of prisoners . It is worth mentioning at this point the large work group called â€˜ Kameik which built a large shooting range in the mountains of Leitmeritz/LOC for the army . Those prisoners who worked outside Theresienstadt/GHETTO had the big advantage of better portions of food . In addition they had the possibility of coming into contact with the population . This meant that these workers had been able to smuggle fruit vegetables tobacco items and other goods that were unknown delicacies and this smuggling was often quietly tolerated by the Tschetniks . These goods were then partly exchanged for others with their friends or relatives and partly sold to them or simply given . With this smuggling it often happened that everything went smoothly as far as the entrance to the camp but then the SS appeared and undertook a close inspection . Anyone caught would have had to expect a lengthy spell in prison . In particularly serious cases they were ordered to be taken into the small fortress . In the South Barracks which were outside Theresienstadt/GHETTO a large industry was started . Here was a big building for making Mica splitters and a workshop for shoes and clothes . The prisoners worked in these barracks in three shifts . After their work and other matters were done the prisoners could go to their overnight accommodation . Finishing time was pm in the summer and pm in the winter . Warnings were sounded in Theresienstadt/GHETTO whenever Allied planes approached . The occupants of their accommodation stayed where they were . The police then had to undertake special patrols to check that the black out regulations were being observed . In the living quarters and in the barracks were hairdressing rooms and sick bays for the outpatient treatment of those who were not seriously ill . There were shower rooms in the Hohenelbe/LOC barracks and in Block D VI . There used to be spacious brewery in D VI . The shower rooms generally enjoyed great popularity yet permission passes to use these shower rooms could only be given by the Block Elder . Theresienstadt/LOC was the show camp of the Gestapo . Almost at 3 month intervals Theresienstadt/GHETTO was visited by international commissions accompanied by high ranking SS Gestapo and army officers . The prisoners were not allowed to speak with the members of these commissions . These commissions were always a bad portent of coming events for the prisoners . Consistently large deportations to Auschwitz/CAMP Birkenau/CAMP followed a few days after such visits . In addition every two or three months large transportations to Auschwitz/CAMP regularly took place and these would decimate the camp by people on average each time . In the winter half year of 1943 44 the most people ever lived in Theresienstadt/GHETTO . At this time there were around people in this small town . The number of daily deaths rose to 350 400 at this time . The bodies to brought into the mortuary and after a brief ceremony were taken into the crematorium nearby . In the autumn months of 1944 there were larger deportations to Auschwitz/CAMP . On 25 April 1944 when I left Theresienstadt/GHETTO there were around people there . When I returned at the beginning of February 1945 there were barely still present there . In effect it seemed that Theresienstadt/GHETTO had almost died out . Between 1941 and 1944 around people had been funnelled through Theresienstadt/GHETTO to Auschwitz/CAMP . In the first days of April 1945 a convoys of 20 cars bearing the national emblem of Denmark/GPE appeared . The few Jews of Danish nationality were taken out of Theresienstadt/GHETTO in these cars . As these people were loaded into these cars there were some comical scenes . The accompanying staff gave cigarettes to the prisoners who were looking on with interest . Senior Storm Leader ObersturmfÃ¼hrer Rahm and Squad Leader ScharfÃ¼hrer Heindl who happened to be present wanted to stop the Danes giving these out but could not prevent this as the Danes were steadfast . Rahm even tried to climb into one of these cars but was prevented from doing so by the accompanying staff in a polite but energetic manner he was told that such entry into Danish territory was forbidden to him . In that period of time it was also revealing that neither Heindl nor Rahm put right or struck any of the smoking Jews . Smoking was banned in Theresienstadt/GHETTO with the threat of the most severe sanctions for anyone who was caught . The convoy of cars left Theresienstadt/GHETTO amidst the cheering of the prisoners who remained behind and it did in fact reach the intended destination in Denmark/GPE despite the ongoing and unresolved war negotiations that were taking place . There were spaces constructed for religious services in the attics of the Hamburger and Genie barracks as well as in corresponding spaces in the C IV sleeping quarters and these were used by practising Christians and Jews on an alternate basis . In Theresienstadt/GHETTO there were not only those of Jewish faith but also baptised Jews of the Christian faith . It was through this that for example in the fire brigade I got to know and value a man called Tabaksblatt . He had been an evangelical missionary in Holland/GPE and his father was a senior rabbi in Lodz/GHETTO . I also came to know a â€˜ designated Jew â€˜ Geltungsjude in Theresienstadt/GHETTO who had been an evangelical priest in a German town . On 11th November 1943 a count of all the people was made in the/LOC â€˜/LOC Bauschowitzer/LOC Basin/LOC a valley between Theresienstadt/GHETTO and Bauschowitz/LOC . Only those who were confined to bed were allowed to stay in the town . From 6 in the morning the entire population of Theresienstadt/GHETTO â€“ in groups arranged according to their accommodation blocks â€“ moved to the roll call area . They marched there until around midday . The entire area was blocked off by order of the Tschetniks . The SS members now let off steam by hitting the prisoners . Old people and children were not spared . There was no chance of answering calls of nature . At around Senior Storm Leader ObersturmfÃ¼hrer Burger the camp leader decided to allow the prisoners back into Theresienstadt/GHETTO . But now sad events played out . Old people who could no longer walk called to passers by to support them and children who had become lost called for their mothers . In addition people found themselves mixed up with others with everyone looking to find their own which was hardly possible in the darkness . It was long past midnight when the inmates managed to regain their sense of peace . Seeing the packed mass of people in this small space on the road from Theresienstadt/GHETTO to Bauschowitz/CAMP the passing Czech population had gained the impression that the Jews would be annihilated here through bombs dropped by planes . This view was also stated on 12 November 1943 in Theresienstadt/GHETTO . This was confirmed to us in reports by outside work groups and members of police patrols who has picked up on the very strong movement of bicycles pedestrians and cars on the road from Theresienstadt/GHETTO to Bauschowitz/CAMP . The sport and culture office had the nice task of offering a diversion for the prisoners . And so football and other ball sport competitions were organised on the bastion . The bastion was a large area of lawn between the fortification walls behind the JÃ¤ger barracks . Opera and operetta events and concerts gave the many Jewish artists a wholesome nourishment and the prisoners a beneficial diversion for a few hours â€¦â€¦ from the thoughts that were constantly circling inside their heads about the Sword of Damocles of further deportations . These events even sometimes silenced the stomachs that were grumbling in hunger for a few hours . In March 1945 the children operetta â€˜ Brautschky â€˜ Little Glow Worm was performed but this only involved the Czech children of prisoners who were three years or older . One of the main performers was a girl of barely four years of age . This operetta enthused both old and young and was performed around eight times . The members of the SS Command were present at one of the last performances . In their inner excitement these gentlemen did not smoke cigarettes during the entire performance but they puffed at them instead . I was on fire brigade duty in Sokolowna/LOC and so I could see at close hand the constantly changing expressions on the faces of these criminals and the way they were racked by their consciences . When they were looking at these charming little children they probably must have been recalling how many such children had been deported to their deaths in Auschwitz/CAMP . Apart from the constant hunger and the uncertainly about the imminent deportations to Auschwitz/CAMP the prisoners were also tormented by huge plagues of bugs and fleas . These tiny creatures were present in unimaginable numbers and could not be eradicated by the constant fumigations of the living quarters . Marriages were not possible in Theresienstadt/GHETTO . For example whenever two person became attached to each other they could have the words â€˜ life companion written into their central ID cards as an appropriate term . If they so wished a ritual wedding would take place but one without any legal validity . Any consequential actions within the community of â€˜ life companions and also in interactions with legally married people were not allowed to be made apparent . Otherwise this would definitely result in deportations to Auschwitz/CAMP . In July 1944 the film â€˜ Theresienstadt/GHETTO was made . The only prisoners to be filmed were those who had a certain Jewish appearance . The Jewish Elder was also to drive around in the town and he received a cigar which was taken from him once the filming was over . In January 1945 the Command put together a transport of around 1000 people destined for Switzerland/GPE . Volunteers were also allowed to join this transport . Those taking part were dressed and equipped in their finest . The transport left Theresienstadt/GHETTO and arrived in Switzerland/GPE in modern train carriages . From the end of March 1945 transports of Jewish prisoners arrived almost daily from other camps which had to be emptied as the Russian Army in the east was approaching . Some of these transports arrived in Theresienstadt/GHETTO on foot others in cattle trucks . These poor people were completely exhausted and for the most part were accommodated in the hospitals . Those Jewish prisoners who had arrived in the trucks had to be literally unloaded as if they were freight . These people found that they had become unbelievably weakened . These returnees brought us the first news of the hitherto unknown conditions inside the Auschwitz/CAMP extermination camp . Dr Schnurmacher Dr Winternitz Heinrich Jokel and Leo Kaufmann my comrades in the first Ghetto Watch all of whom were amongst the returnees provided me with detailed and thorough descriptions of Auschwitz/CAMP . I can clearly offer one example of the decimation of the Jewish people and I take it from a specific transport to Theresienstadt/GHETTO from Berlin/GPE . This was Transport I/90 which was brought to Theresienstadt/GHETTO on 17 March 1943 . This transport arrived with 1350 people in Theresienstadt/GHETTO on 18 March 1943 . 49 of these people were still alive on 15 May 1945 . In the days between 22 and 26 April 1945 a Commission of the Swiss Red Cross appeared in Theresienstadt/GHETTO in six cars . After briefly consulting with the SS Command they declared the entire camp and the small fortress to be international territory . A Red Cross flag was raised on the church tower . The inmates of Theresienstadt/GHETTO were very excited yet peace was maintained . After the Commission had arrived the destruction of the records began . The fire brigade had to work for many days in day shifts and night shifts under the supervision of the SS and the police force . The liberation of the prisoners of Theresienstadt/GHETTO by Russian forces followed on 9 May 1945 at around pm . A Russian major with his staff took over the leadership . Official closing time was set for pm . Infringements did not occur . After a quarantine period lasting three weeks the prisoners were officially discharged with repatriation ID documents . On 10 June 1945 I left Theresienstadt/GHETTO with my family and our friends Ernst Werner and his mother as well as Erwin Diettrich . We travelled by train from Bauschowitz/CAMP to Dresden/LOC . From there we walked to Berlin/GPE where we arrived in Berlin/GPE Marienfelde/LOC on 26 June 1945 . 
record of an interview with a gypsy from Burgenland/CAMP . The report illustrates the similarity between the treatment of Jews and that of gypsies . Racial persecution of the gypsies of the Burgenland/CAMP started soon after the annexation of Austria/GPE . To escape persecution Mr Hodosi like many others volunteered for army service but was expelled because of his race in spite of Goering consent to an exception being made in his case . He and his wife were arrested by the Gestapo in 1941 and brought to the Lackenbach/CAMP camp in the Burgenland/CAMP . They escaped but after a period of illegal life he was arrested again and together with his wife and 2 children brought to Auschwitz/CAMP Birkenau/CAMP ./CAMP His description of conditions there corresponds with the many Jewish accounts of the subject . His children were starved to death . He states that in 1944 particularly dark skinned gypsies were selected for experiments on human beings at Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP . Towards the end of the year a number of young men and women volunteered for sterilization experiments however the promise that they would be released afterwards was not kept . Mr Hodosi was allocated to the so called BewÃ¤hrungstruppe Probationary Unit which was forced to fight against the Russians in the Kottbus/LOC sector and suffered extremely high losses . Most of those who were not killed in action were murdered by the SS . Mr Hodosi himself was lucky enough to be made a prisoner of war by the Russians . 8 . Further References Schreiner Gestapo official Vienna/GPE . .... Jews and Gypsies What is written down here was experienced by Mr Julius Hodosi now living in Vienna/GPE IX . It was the hardest time of my life . It hard for me to remember I would like to forget â€¦ My home is in Burgenland/CAMP where the majority of the Austrian Gypsies lived . After the annexation of Austria/GPE we heard different things about the Nazis racial persecution . A lot of people believed they could escape this fate by registering voluntarily for the German army . Me too . The captain of my air force unit liked me . When the order came to expel all Gypsies from the army he wrote to Goering . He got the response that I could stay if the captain thinks it justifiable . But for the local group of my hometown it was shameful to have a Gypsy in the army . They complained about it so the captain wrote to Hitler . Hitler answered briefly When it the local NSDAP group wish you have to expel him . So I took off the uniform and went back to my hometown . One night the came into the village . They came with trucks and randomly loaded entire families . That why almost all the Gypsies hastily left the village . I moved to GisshÃ¼bel/LOC near Vienna/GPE and lived there in a subtenancy . My little brother who still went to school was expelled . A Gypsy was an adequate member of society . In 1941 my wife and I were arrested by the in GisshÃ¼bel/LOC . We went to the Lackenbach/CAMP reception camp in Burgenland/LOC . In this camp we got a foretaste of what was in store for us . The SS beat us . The food was horrible . I did the only thing possible and tried to flee . In fact my wife and I were able to escape . Together we hid in Vienna/GPE and lived as so called submarine boats . We were not registered and did get food cards . Because we had no money I had to look for a job . That was very dangerous but I had no choice . A coal trader was happy to get me as a delivery man because it was difficult to get male employees at this time . But it happened as I had foreseen . My cover was blown and I was arrested by the Gestapo again . Three weeks I was in RossauerlÃ¤nde/LOC prison . During a hearing the Gestapo official Schreiner said literally We will destroy you like cats ! At home I had a wife and two little children . Two girls aged one and two years . I did know if I would see them again . But when I was on the transport to Ausschwitz/CAMP the Gestapo brought my wife and the children to the station too . Together we rode to the Birkenau/CAMP extermination camp . The transport was an agony . Penned up without food without water without light we rode into the unknown . Finally when the waggons opened the SS received us with blows and bloodhounds we were at our destination . In this moment we stopped being humans . We were just numbers . All that we had was taken from us . All of us the women and children too had our heads shaved . All of us my little girls too were tattooed with a number . â€“ Then we came into the so called entrance barrack . We were in this barack about one week until we were called to different commandos On the 5th day we saw that there are more terrible things than getting almost nothing to eat . 300 people from Burgenland/CAMP were selected for the gasification and immediately gassed . The SS visibly revelled in the agony of the people . I came with my wife to the commando earthworks . Amongst other places we laid rails to the crematories . Every day from 9 â€“ 10 there was the so called punishment work . In this hour we had to do work on the double . When someone fell down with a heavy barrow or tippler they battered him to death immediately . So we lost 50 â€“ 60 people daily . In the morning the SS whispered to the the number of people who should not come back anymore . And the Capo tried to fulfill this order . For all children the camp was certain death . There was no nourishing food no milk nothing a child needs for the development of the body . In addition to that the uncertain life . No minute were you safe . We had to muster in the night for hours little children too â€“ which made hounded tortured beings of us . Very often the drunken SS made fun of us . They lined us up and selected those who had to go to the gas . Sometimes it was TRUE sometimes not . During this time I lost my two young children . They literally died of hunger . The food was the following 5 people got daily 1 army bread . Every prisoner got also 1 spoon marmalade Â½ kg swede and sometimes 50 grammes of ham and 20 grammes of margarine . There were extra portions too but always for a special purpose . The result of the distribution led very often to affrays . There were always people killed . The hunger was big . In addition to that came epidemics of typhus malaria mange etc . The sick people were gassed . So they reduced our number from to within one year . 1944 in Birkenau/CAMP and as I heard in Lackenbach/CAMP Burgenland/CAMP too they selected especially dark skinned Gypsies men and women for transports to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP . They did experiments with them to find out how long a man can survive without food and drink . At the end of this year they organised further transports . They seperated people who were fit for the military and such young women and men who agreed to be part of sterilisation experiments in the hope of freedom . They were promised release from the camp but the truth was very different . 8 days after such an operation which was done without anaesthetic they had to go back to work . Many perished because of that . I became part of the so called BewÃ¤hrungstruppe and was installed at the front near Cottbus/LOC on 12th April 1945 . Those who did die during the fighting were killed by the SS from behind . From men just 700 survived . We were happy to get into Russian imprisonment . Later I heard that none of the who stood in Birkenau/CAMP lived anymore . They were all gassed . 5 Addition to report of Mr Hodosi I managed the escape from the reception camp Lackenbach/CAMP as follows I worked on road building . We took breakfast next to a forest . Once the opportunity was good and I fled into the forest . After about 3 minutes they noticed that I was missing . They followed me but I could cover my tracks . During my escape I came into a Hungarian area . At Ã–denburg/LOC I entered Austrian land again and went to Mattersburg/LOC . From there I took the train to Vienna/GPE illegally of course . Yes my wife was a Gypsy too . The 300 BurgenlÃ¤nder who were gassed were all Gypsies . The reduction from to concerned only Gypsies . In Birkenau/CAMP we were in a part of the camp which was managed as a family camp and which got the name Gypsy camp . The who did military service were made up from all kinds of prisoners . So they were all Gypsies . All 700 who were left were rescued because they went into Russian imprisonment . 1 Nationalsozialistische Deutsche Arbeiterpartei engl .
