Singer lived with husband and two daughters in Barduwitz/CAMP Czechoslovakia/GPE . After the German invasion they sent one girl to England/GPE with a children transport . The couple and the second daughter were sent to Theresienstadt/CAMP in 1942 . Czech Jews had been prepared for the life in the ghetto by information spread by members of the Prague Kultusgemeinde and the Czech guards of the Ghetto . Yet on arrival Mrs Singer was struck by the spirit of desolation and apathy amongst the inmates . Even her own mother and sister showed no signs of joy at being reunited with her . Mrs Singer had had some nursing experience and volunteered for this type of work . She knew that it might give her some protection from deportation the fear of which overshadowed the whole life of the prisoners . In the first very cold winter typhoid broke out . The patients were crammed into attics without the most elementary necessities . Later a hospital was equipped and conditions improved a little . Mrs Singer was infected and after her recovery was ordered to nurse the typhoid patients . Her girl had been sent to a children home run by Dr. Groak who maintained a certain ethical standard among the children . The girl joined a Zionist Group and the special protection of one of the Ghetto Elders himself a Zionist might have saved her from deportation . Quite a lot of bitterness and ill will was caused by the Elders favouring members of their own nationality religious or political group . Mrs Singer husband mother and sister were deported . Mrs Singer was saved by a miracle . She was already standing at the train when she was sent back for no apparent reason . As discipline had crumbled by that time nobody noticed that she did not report back on her return and soon afterwards Theresienstadt/CAMP was liberated . 9 . Further References Dr. Teweles and wife kind doctors in the hospital . Dr. Epstein a Ghetto Elder who was arrested and shot . Dr. Leo Baeck visited patients of Mrs Singer . 10 . Remarks In her account Mrs Singer denies the statements made by Dr. H.E. Bach in the West London Synagogue Review . These were repeated later on by the Dean of St. Paul Matthews . Ghetto Life in Constant Fear of Deportation Mrs. Singer is a Czech Jewess who lived with her husband and two daughters in Barduwitz/CAMP . After the German invasion they still managed to send one of the children with a Kindertransport to England/GPE . In the winter of 1942 she herself together with her husband and the other child was sent to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . Mrs. S. emphasized how much better prepared physically and mentally the Czech Jews arrived at the grey fortress . For a start they were a great deal better nourished because the Czech population was much more well disposed towards Jews than the Germans slipping them whatever food they could spare at all . Mrs. S. is also aware of several cases where Czechs offered to hide Jewish children in safe places to protect them from the worst . Furthermore the Czech policemen guarding Theresienstadt/GHETTO had circulated reports about the conditions there and the Prague Jewish sent its employees out to individual Jewish congregations with instructions to prepare themselves for a life of poverty and work . For that reason the Czechs did not arrive in Theresienstadt/GHETTO as completely unprepared as the German Jews whose luggage contained high heeled shoes and evening cloaks . From Leitmeritz/CAMP onwards the prisoners had to walk and carry their heavy luggage . Upon their arrival in Theresienstadt/GHETTO they immediately gained an impression of the oppressive atmosphere of fear desperation and apathy . At the arrival of a new transport there was always a curfew and no one was allowed to be out on the street . However from their windows people looked down upon the new arrivals . No one nodded at them waved or smiled . Mrs. Singer sister and her 80 year old mother were already in Theresienstadt/GHETTO but even the reunion of family members did not bring a moment of joy . Mrs. S. found her mother in a bare room which she shared with 18 other women lying on the floor . There were no beds . The old lady began to cry bitterly when she saw her daughter and granddaughter again . She was unable to help them help for her had become identical with food old people getting the most meagre rations of all . Upon arriving the newcomers had first to pass through a German sluice gate where they were assigned work . Mrs. S. had had some training in nursing care and immediately applied for care work . She already knew that this would provide her with special protection from being sent to one of the extermination camps . She was immediately separated from her husband . Men were mostly housed in the old barracks 80 to 100 to a room three bunk beds one above the other . During the first very cold winter of 1942 a typhoid epidemic broke out and Mrs. S. worked from morning until night . The sick were placed in attic rooms where it was particularly cold lying on the floor in their totally soiled clothes without bedclothes . There were no medicines to help the sick not even towels to wash them with . All patients were covered in lice but it was not possible to send them for delousing because of the risk of infection . At the start of her shift in the morning Mrs. S. had to inspect the closely crammed together bodies to establish who was still alive and who had died during the night . Often it was barely possible to tell as the people lying there on the floor were totally starved and lifeless . After two months Mrs. S. too contracted typhoid fever . Meanwhile a gymnasium had been converted into a hospital as the Germans fearful the epidemic would spread insisted on isolating those infected with typhoid fever . There were however still no medicines the food was just about sufficient to avoid starvation and although there were many doctors available only nature could help the individual . At that time a couple who were both doctors Drs . Teweles worked at the hospital looking after the sick with great dedication . Their 16 year old girl had also been infected and died owing to the lack of medicines . Later the two doctors were taken to one of the extermination camps . As surviving the illness had left Mrs. immune to typhoid fever she was chosen especially and ordered to care for those infected with typhoid fever . Slowly conditions improved slightly medicines arrived at the camp the constant transports of people to the extermination camps created more space for those left behind and the total apathy that gradually took hold of people did of course help them bear the terrible conditions . One could perhaps even have accustomed oneself to a certain structure of ghetto life if only the fear of the transports and the constant farewells had not continually reignited the sense of terror and agitation . The worst was when the children were deported . Although Mrs. Singer daughter was spared her husband her mother and her sister had to make the journey to death . The daughter had been discharged from hospital by her mother and was sent to one of the children homes that was under the direction of Dr. Groak . He is said to have exerted a very good influence which meant that decent standards prevailed at the home . For inexplicable reasons a number of furniture deliveries arrived at the ghetto as a result of which a few decent pieces of furniture and even a piano found their way to the children home . Here the young girl joined a Zionist group and as the then ghetto Elder was also a Zionist these young people were under his special protection and were therefore saved from deportation . He not only took care of the young people physical welfare by finding them for example gardening work but also saw to it that they did not degenerate completely morally and spiritually . This preferential treatment by whoever was the ghetto Elder at the time based on religious attitude and even more so on nationality had of course considerable disadvantages and created much bitterness and discord . If you wanted to survive Theresienstadt/GHETTO it was eventually said you needed to have four P.G.s â€“ not Parteigenossen party but Polish grandmothers . Ultimately the ghetto Elders decided who would live and who would die . Although the Gestapo ordered that so and so many people were to make up a specific transport the selection of the individuals to be sent was decided by the ghetto Elders and one knew with cynical certainty depending on the relevant Elder nationality who would constitute the majority of that particular transport . Incidentally none of these Elders survived Theresienstadt/GHETTO because they knew too much they were systematically deported to the East/LOC . Just before the and the Russians were approaching the camp the Elder at that time Dr. Epstein gave an address to the effect that he was now the helmsman and would bring his ship safely to harbour . The following day the Germans came for him . When asked about the attitude of non Jews to the internees Mrs. Singer replied that she had had hardly any contact with non Jews . Everything was handled by the Council of Elders individual prisoners did not come into contact with their non Jewish oppressors at all . Some among the prisoners were Christians who had only been made aware of their Jewish ancestry by the Hitler . In Czechoslovakia/GPE only those who had been baptised lying were considered Christians . There were two Viennese women among Mrs. Singer colleagues at the hospital who had never known of their Jewish blood . They were self sacrificing nurses and as Mrs. Singer frankly admitted some of the few who practiced their profession because they loved to help and not because it would protect them from deportation . Altruism and ethical principles could not flourish in the atmosphere of Theresienstadt/GHETTO where at the end of the day everyone had to fend for themselves and self preservation became the supreme law . Mrs. Singer stressed repeatedly that no one who has not been through this kind of camp could possibly understand how the experience deadened every human emotion . Even today she feels that there are no words that can truly reach and get through to the others . As if by a miracle Mrs. Singer was saved from death . She had already been selected for a transport standing with her rucksack at the so called sluice by the train when she was called back . Her daughter had been protected by her gardening work though she did assist together with other young Zionist people with the transports and had promised her mother to jump on to the train at the very last moment so they would stay together . As she did not see her mother she stayed behind . In fact Mrs. Singer should have been issued with a rejection note to continue receiving accommodation and food in the ghetto . However by this time organization in the camp was no longer that tight and no one bothered with these formalities . Many who were summoned for a transport simply did report for the transport and saved their lives that way . After the liberation of Theresienstadt/GHETTO Mrs. Singer lived in Czechoslovakia/GPE until 1949 then went to join the daughter who had emigrated to Israel/GPE from where she came to England/GPE . Mrs. Singer recalls that Dr. Baeck came to visit some of her patients although she is unable to remember that his presence left much of an impression on the patients . Mrs. S. stresses repeatedly how cynical and apathetic life in Theresienstadt/GHETTO had left the prisoners so that the presence of a rabbi no longer made an impression . She herself as a Czech and not much involved with Judaism had never heard of Dr. Baeck so his visits did not mean anything to her . She now thinks that the legend Baeck in Theresienstadt/GHETTO has been retrospectively idealised . Neither had Dr. Baeck been sentenced to death as death sentences did not exist in Theresienstadt/GHETTO nor does the claim that he was saved from death by the Russians correspond to the facts . During the final weeks the Red Cross handled the administration of the camp so there was no need for liberation by the Russians to prevent a death sentence . Had there been any intention of getting Dr. Baeck out of the way at an earlier date the frequent deportations would have provided ample opportunity to do so . 1 Kultusgemeinde and Prager Kultusgemeinde are synonymous with the term JÃ¼dische Gemeinde i.e. the Jewish Congregation . 2 Springer in the German text is obviously a typographical error here . 3 i.e. party members of the NSDAP 4 In German texts of this period British is virtually always referred to as Englisch . 
Neumann an orphan was only 14 years old when in September 1942 she and her aunt had to follow her grandmother to Theresienstadt/GHETTO who was already among the first deportees from Vienna/GPE . The report includes details about the German speaking Kinderheim there modern pedagogical methods a kind of Kibbutz/CAMP where the children were happy in spite of everything . When later her aunt and grandmother were taken to Auschwitz/CAMP she voluntarily followed them with the next transport and met them there . Soon the grandmother was gassed and Edith and her aunt were moved to Hamburg/CAMP for forced labour . Terrible housing conditions Lagerhaus lack of food heavy airraids . The kind Italian Prisoner of War who looked after Edith and the Wehrmachtssoldat one of the guards who wanted to hide Edith with his wife she refusing because of her aunt and a close girl friend whom she did not want to leave . Increasing air raids shifted to Altona/CAMP where conditions were worse . She worked in a cement factory together with Russian and Italian Prisoners of War all kind and helpful especially the Russians . When the British army was approaching she was sent on a Death March to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP where she was ultimately liberated by the English . Edith stayed on in Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP until 1948 and put herself at the disposal of the American Joint for relief work . In spring 1948 she emigrated to England/GPE becoming a nurse at University College London . At Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP Irma Grese with her dogs . Edith Neumann born 27 March 1938 When Hitler came to Vienna/GPE Edith was barely 10 years old . Her parents were both dead . Her grandmother took over the role of parent . There was a close bond between the grandmother and grandchild as the former was deported to Theresienstadt/GHETTO Edith only care was the absolute certainty that she would soon follow her there . Now her aunt assumed the role of caring for her . Her aunt was a Nurse at the Rothschild Hospital in Vienna/GPE . This property was annexed to the Cultural Association and it was known from experience that such employees were sent to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . Edith went there with her aunt in 1942 met her grandmother who lived in a room with 12 other women and was again separated from her since Edith was housed in a German children home . A â€˜ German children home in this context meant that the children all had a very strong command of the German language in contrast to the Czech children who lived together in another home . The children home was managed in the most exemplary manner by a young Czech man and his four friends . These five splendid men turned the children home into a Kibbutz . It consisted of five to six rooms . Within each room were housed 20 girls between 10 and 16 years of age . On the opposite side was where the boys lived . Within the rooms the bunks were stacked three high . They slept in pairs . So that the room was kept tidy there was a competition amongst the children . The cleanest room received a prize in points . The eldest girl supervised . The elder children taught the younger they learnt languages they also worked within the garden which lay outside the ghetto . Every evening when they came back from work they were searched to see if they had taken an apple or a carrot . The children also had to wear a yellow Star of David Patch . Edith was unable to make sense of the rations she only knew that she suffered hunger yet food played not so great a role as for a child there was so much to see to take in and to understand the separation from her home from her home from her grandmother communal life with so many children and the totally different meaning of life . Somehow life was still worth living until roughly two years later the deportations began . On each occasion people were taken never being seen again . One day the grandmother and aunt were also taken Her aunt also worked as a Nurse in Theresienstadt/GHETTO . Edith did not know where the transport went yet on the next deportation she volunteered for it she did not want to leave her grandmother alone . 2 They travelled in a wagon two days and two nights without food without drink and without sleep . For purposes of ablutions etc .. two buckets were set out . They sat next to each other without being able to move them . During the night the train suddenly stopped . The guards shouted Get out ! They had arrived in Auschwitz/CAMP . They heard terrible screaming it smelled horrifically of human bones . They stood before a square building they saw flames rise . It was the crematorium . Bundles of hair lay roundabout as well as children shoes and clothes . An electric wire circled the camp whoever touched it was killed immediately . The children were warned . Auschwitz/CAMP was divided into different camps children women men and old people . Edith name had been tattooed onto her arm . The scar is still visible today . In England/GPE a Surgeon cut out this Nazi branding . The huts in which they lived looked like stables . Within the so called family camp the women lived on one side the men on the other . They all changed very terribly . They looked like animals . They all got leather straps and were beaten blindly on all sides . The head of the camp was a robber . He had at one time committed a bank robbery and had murdered people during its course . As punishment they sent him to Auschwitz/CAMP . The days proceeded thus Early of a morning at 4 everyone was required for parade called people stood or kneeled until 10 in the morning . Then two SS men came to count . After they had done this we were given a beaker of soup and a slice of bread . From 3 in the afternoon until 6 in the evening was held again . The SS men were mostly drunk and took people spontaneously from the rows of people . A man and a woman were shot dead without any such reason before Edith eyes . They took a baby from the children home and dashed its little head against the wall . After Appel the prisoners were allowed to mix with one another for an hour . And on the second day Edith saw her grandmother and her aunt again . After three weeks during Appel all those between 16 and 36 years of age were taken out . Although Edith was not yet 16 years of age she too reported herself as she knew that were she to stay in Auschwitz/CAMP the gas chamber would await . She and her aunt had to undress completely they were examined probably to see if they were capable of work . Edith did not know what would happen to her . She ran quickly once more to her grandmother in order to say farewell . An SS man stood there with a loaded revolver and urged them to hurry up . Yet the grandmother had time enough to bless her grandchild . 3 Then Edith arrived with her aunt and a friend she met in Auschwitz/CAMP in a women camp where career criminals ran the place . Thousands of women were housed there within a stable block . Within both washrooms with water taps a cruel woman the oldest in the camp governed over them . She had a leather strap in her hand and would beat anyone she could . Those women imprisoned within the camp would be forgiven were they to do without washing altogether . After two days Edith her aunt and the friend went to a delousing station . They all had to get undressed there . They were given prison clothes . After spending four weeks at Auschwitz/CAMP they were all transported in a cattle wagon this time under the watch of German soldiers who were not war veterans . These soldiers were more lenient they had a touch of humanity . Edith was in a very bad state . There was terribly little to eat then the horrific fear in which she continually lived for one of course did not know what would happen from one moment to the next a lack of blood to the brain which makes this whole cruel experience appear so unreal and lacking in care . They travelled for two days and two nights arriving in Hamburg/CAMP and were taken to a camp block this was in May 1944 . Around women were divided into groups and sent to work in a factory guarded by soldiers . Within the block were also housed Italian prisoners of war . The women had to work hard in the factory ... shovelling sand lugging bricks etc . The factory lay far away from the camp huts . At 4 in the morning they were loaded onto boats where they travelled for two hours along the Elbe to the factory . In their thin grey linen clothes they succumbed terribly to the cold . Whenever it rained they took off their wet clothes to wring them and then to put them on again . There was nothing to eat until the afternoon only then a slice of bread and a bowl of soup . Only German boys were employed in the factory . Sometimes they threw them sandwiches . They came back from work at 5 in the evening to the huts . The rooms had long troughs with taps they washed there and then there was soup once more with a slice of bread . This is where Edith experienced the first bombs . During an air raid they had to go down into the shelter . The shelter led to the Elbe where the water was sometimes at a high level . Edith and her friends preferred to sleep in their beds they hid themselves under their beds so that no one found them . They only crept out when everyone else was in the shelter . They were dead tired and slept soundly despite the air raids . As already mentioned Italian prisoners of war were housed in the huts . Edith became friends with one of them his name was Aldo Babieri . He spoke many languages fluently also secretly hidden a warm pullover and some food . He also had a medallion which he gave to her as a gift 4 he got it from his mother . Edith still has this small item of jewellery today . One day when they had to work clearing the streets in Hamburg/GPE people passed by and stared at them . It was only then that Edith became aware exactly how greatly she had changed . She began to cry she began to do so hysterically . Why you shoot me ? she shouted at the soldier who guarded her . He sent her to the guard post and followed her there . He said I feel more for you all than I am allowed to show . I have a daughter she is 15 years old . as old as you are . You remind me of her The soldier whose name Edith did not remember perhaps he was called Kessel often brought her something to eat . As he knew that she shared everything with her aunt and friend he gave her three small parcels one for each of them . He once said to her You speak German . bring you clothes and help you get to Berlin/GPE to my wife . You can stay there until everything is over . Edith refused she did not want to leave her aunt and friend . Four months had passed and they were taken to a camp in Altona/CAMP which was guarded by female members of the SS . These women were terrible even the Camp Commandant was fearful . He threw women to the ground kicked and beat and trampled on them with his hobnailed boots . He was an abnormal person . The eldest within the camp could only keep him calm by going to him and saying how handsome he was and how magnificent to behold . This compliment calmed him . The terrible SS women left Edith and her friend in peace perhaps because they were so young only 15 years old ! They even gave them warm things . Once during a particularly heavy air raid they were sent into a bunker just Edith and her friend . It was in a bridge which had a cement structure and a door . When it was opened you were inside the bunker . Outside bombs rained down . Suddenly the door was torn open and a whole load of Russian prisoners of war entered to hide from the bombs . The two girls were terribly afraid her friend began to scream . The air raid ebbed away and a soldier opened the little window . The Russians asked the girl who she was . They told the men of their fate . The Russian soldiers emptied their pockets and gave them everything they had in terms of confectionery and other things . And when they had nothing else to give they sang Russian songs to them to console them . Edith worked in the cement factory along with Russians French and Italians . The Russians were the kindest they passed on news to them . They were able to find just the right words of comfort . This gave them courage and strength . Edith her aunt and friend had to work very hard they had to build houses canals and trenches . The air raids became ever worse 5 the English troops were not too far away as a result of which the Nazis transported the women to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP concentration camp . The three women withstood three weeks in a room with thousands of women . They lay or sat on top of each other their feet could only find room on other feet . Many women died many suffocated . On the death march to Belsen/CAMP innumerable women were left behind on the roadside they died from weakness or were shot . Irma Grese was there with her dog .... Edith saw her . The worst of all were the Hungarian soldiers who had become wild and who shot incessantly at people even through locked doors . The corpses lay roundabout in large piles . The food was horrific dirty red turnip peelings despite desperate hunger Edith was unable to eat it . For 14 days she ate nothing . She was so weak that she could no longer stand on her feet . She thought that the end had come for her . She crawled over the bodies towards freedom . It was dark yet she recognised a figure approaching her . Bald headed and emaciated she heard her name being called . Dita ! She was a former schoolmate . Edith was unable to answer as she could see a tank enter the camp . The English troops had arrived as liberators . Dita summoned up all her strength crept back into the room to tell the others many did not want to believe it many wept many were apathetic and could do nothing . For so very many freedom came too late ! The English troops arrived with two large pails of soup . Unfortunately those starving people ate too much of the unaccustomed nourishing food .... A great many became sick others died . Edith spent a few days in a wonderful camp for soldiers from where she quickly recovered whilst her aunt and her friend contracted typhus and had to be admitted to hospital . Only Edith remained and made herself available to the English troops . She assumed responsibility for registration duties concerning people from the old camp into Belsen/CAMP . She was one of the last in the old camp . There were people who did not want to go . It took a lot of persuading to get them out of these insanitary conditions they had lost their minds . Captain Gillow did a great deal for these unfortunate people . He helped wherever he could . According to his rank he was probably not the most senior yet he suffered alongside them he helped find Edith aunt and friend . Edith aunt is in England/GPE the friend in America/GPE . This friend who once gave Edith a potato for her birthday whilst at the concentration camp 6 It had been the most delicious gift she had ever received . For this potato not only had an inscribed face it was also edible . Edith Neuman remained in Belsen/CAMP for two years . In 1948 she came to London/GPE . Initially she worked for the American Joint . Then afterwards she trained as a nurse a profession which she very much enjoyed . She worked at one of the best hospitals in London/GPE the University College Hospital . 
report is interesting because it shows the important role the Jewish resistance movement played during the German occupation of France/GPE and the many ways in which it was assisted by the French population . It is written by the above who in 1933 as a child of 6 left Frankfurt/GPE am Main with her parents and her sister and emigrated to France/GPE . As soon as Hitler invaded Northern France/GPE in 1940 the travels of the family started . They were among the thousands and thousands of refugees who crowded the roads to the south of France/GPE stayed at different places which they had always to leave after a short while . Mr Guenzburg the father was several times interned but either was released or succeeded to escape from the camp . In autumn 1943 when the Germans occupied the south of France/GPE the Jewish resistance movement saw to it that all children found shelter . The Resistance was so well organized that it was able to follow up the fate of almost every child . Many of the children were taken to convents and were thought by their surroundings to be Christians . Mrs Unger and her sister were taken to a boarding School at Villeneuve sur Lot where only the director a Protestant knew their origin . In 1944 Mrs Unger and her father crossed the Spanish border in one of the small groups of 10 people regularly organized by the resistance . With the help of the American Joint they finally reached Israel/GPE . Mrs Guenzburg and her other daughter who were staying in a home for aged people belonging to the Heilsarmee at Tonnein/GPE and would not have been able to endure the flight over the mountains followed them a year later . My time as a child refugee in France/GPE Experiences of Frau Eva Unger nÃ©e Guenzburg/LOC During the Rule of the National Socialists . In 1933 at the time the National Socialists came to power in Germany/GPE I was living with my parents and my elder sister in Frankfurt/GPE Main . My father ran a bookshop there . This was taken over by the National Socialist administration already in early 1933 . As my father also felt himself to be personally in danger he left Frankfurt/GPE and relocated to Paris/GPE . My mother my sister and I followed him about 6 months later . I was 6 years old at the time . In Paris/GPE we lived in peace until the beginning of the war . After the outbreak of war the French authorities issued an order for all families with children to be evacuated from Paris/GPE to the French countryside . The evacuation of the inhabitants of each neighbourhood was designated for a specific department . In September 1939 my father brought us to Nevers near in the department responsible for us . He himself went back to Paris/GPE with the intention of voluntarily enlisting in the military . He was however not accepted â€“ in fact he was interned by the French as a former German . It was only shortly before the German invasion of France/GPE that he was released . My father then attempted to join the Foreign Legion . In this too he was unsuccessful as he did not appear to be physically suited . Eventually he managed to join a British Army labour battalion . We stayed in Nevers until June 1940 . At that time the German troops had already moved into France/GPE . Apparently a defence front was to be formed at the Loire very close to where we were . As a consequence the inhabitants of this region fled southwards . We joined the flow of refugees and came to ChÃ¢teau de Chaumont Creuse . There was a children home here belonging to the Jewish organisation OSE where we found accommodation for the time being . By chance we met my father there and were reunited . In September 1940 we relocated to Aubusson/LOC with a few of the other children looked after by OSE as there was a lyceum that we could attend there . Shortly after in November 1940 my father was interned as a German Jew by the Vichy/LOC government and brought to Gurs/CAMP . Later he went to a labour camp but was released in March 1941 as he had leased a piece of land near Aubusson/LOC to convert it for agricultural use which exempted him from internment . 2 He was now restricted only in his freedom of movement and was like us not allowed to leave the place without permission . In Aubusson/LOC we lived as penniless refugees in difficult conditions . We had taken in the children who had been entrusted to us by OSE and who went to the local school together with us and received financial support for this from OSE which was however only very little money and barely sufficient to make ends meet . In the summer of 1942 we learned that the danger for German Jews who had been arrested by the Vichy authorities to be transported back to Germany/GPE had grown immensely . At the time we were constantly in contact with the French Jewish scout movement which had formed resistance groups everywhere . This organisation offered to attempt to get us children to Switzerland/GPE . During this time my sister and I were ourselves constantly wearing scout uniforms as this was safer for us . We agreed to be separated from our parents but were afraid that something would happen to them if our disappearance from the place became known . It was therefore agreed that my parents would say we had run away from them . My sister and I as well as a few other Jewish children were initially brought to Montpellier/LOC . Here we were housed by various families . The plan was to bring us from there to Annecy/LOC where the group of children would be gathered for the crossing to Switzerland/GPE . At the last moment however this plan had to be abandoned because the preceding group that was to be brought to Switzerland/GPE had been sent back to France/GPE by the Swiss authorities . We now went to a children home in Moissac/LOC near Toulouse/LOC which had been set up by the Joint Distribution Committee . Here I was in the care of the director of the home under the alias Evelyne Ginsbourg with Andlau/LOC Bas Rhin as my place of birth . This was necessary to avoid difficulties with the French authorities which occurred especially when they were dealing with foreign Jews over the age of 14 years . The latter were therefore regularly provided with FALSE papers indicating them to be French citizens . Thanks to the good connections the director of the home had with the authorities the latter intervened only rarely and sent a German Jewish resident of the home back to Germany/GPE only every now and again in order to keep up appearances . In the meantime my father had been brought to a labour camp again . When it became known that the camp inmates 3 were to be transferred to Germany/GPE my father escaped from there after being provided with FALSE papers by the Jewish resistance movement . He managed to obtain a position as a worker on a farm . The farmers liked to take on refugees as workers as they did not need to pay them much however they generally did not treat them very well . My mother had stayed behind in Aubusson/CAMP for the time being . When it became too dangerous for her to continue staying there I was sent to her with FALSE papers that had been issued to her . I then brought my mother to the same village where my father was . Here she was taken in by a family . Life in the same place was particularly difficult for my parents as they had different names on their papers and could not show that they were a married couple . The village priest who knew this went out of his way to help them . By contrast the farmer for whom my father was working treated him very badly . When my father fell sick the farmer simply threw him out . After this the resistance movement directed my parents to another village where my father again found work with a farmer . However they soon had to leave this place again as they were in danger of being arrested . They were now brought to Tonneins/LOC farther south . There my parents found work in a Salvation Army retirement home . They were posing as Protestants but the General of the Salvation Army knew who they were . In the meantime the south of France/GPE had also been occupied by the German troops by October 1943 . Shortly before that the Jewish children home in Moissac/LOC like all other Jewish children homes was dissolved as Jews of every age were in great danger of being sent to Germany/GPE . The Jewish resistance movement now searched for new accommodation options for all the children and were successful . The movement was exceptionally well organised and tracked the fate of every individual child . I can not say anything about the type of organisation it was as we were always in contact only with individual members and anything pertaining to their operations was kept very secret . All children were from now on no longer Jews but posing as Catholics or Protestants . Many were taken in by convents . Posing as a Protestant I was taken in by a boarding school for girls in Villeneuve/LOC sur/LOC Lot/LOC in October 1943 together with my sister and a few other girls . I also had to change my name again and was henceforth known as Evelyn Grandjean . Our background was however known to the director as well as to several teachers . In Villeneuve/LOC and already before that in Moissac/LOC too 4 the French police and later also the Germans occasionally carried out raids targeting foreign Jews . We therefore had to be very careful and I went outdoors only rarely . Once when I was in Toulouse/LOC I was stopped by a patrol in the street and asked for my papers . I presented them and simultaneously contorted my face to hide my Jewish facial features as I had been taught . Thankfully the patrol was satisfied . At the time French hatred of the Germans had already greatly increased and they helped us in whatever ways they possibly could . As soon as they had reached a certain age the Jewish youths joined the Jewish underground organisation in solidarity . The good relations that had developed with the French Christian families were demonstrated by the fact that we regularly received invitations from Christian families on the days we had no school Thursday and Sunday where we usually ate until we were properly full . By this time it was 1944 . My father had become tired of life in occupied France/GPE and decided to cross the border to Spain/GPE with me . We could not expect my mother to join in the difficult walk over the mountains because of her health . We left her behind with my sister in the Salvation Army home . The crossing of the refugees to Spain/GPE was led by an organisation that had been created by the French Resistance . Every few days a group of about 10 people set out on the journey with Spanish guides . The guides were not always trustworthy . Shortly before we struck out a group of refugees had been abandoned by their guides and left to wander in the mountains for 10 days . Our guides were trustworthy . After a difficult three day walk over the mountains we slipped over the border unscathed at night . Having arrived in Spain/GPE we escaped the measures of the Spanish authorities who were interning all refugees who were 20 to â€“ I believe â€“ 50 years of age . There we were soon in the charge of JOINT which brought us first to Lerida/GPE then to Barcelona/LOC and finally to Cadiz/GPE . Months later we were able to begin the journey to Israel/GPE from here . As the Germans had in the meantime been driven out of France/GPE my mother and my sister followed us to Israel/GPE a year later . 5 Transcript . Account of the Persecution Eva Unger nÃ©e Guenzburg . I was born on 20.12.1926 in Frankfurt/GPE the second daughter of Paul Guenzburg and Else nÃ©e Trefousse . I went to the Schwarzburg/LOC comprehensive school in Frankfurt/GPE from 2.5.1933 to 1.11.1933 . My father was forced to flee shortly after the Nazis came to power and my mother followed him to Paris/GPE in November 1933 together with my sister and me . After I had mastered the French language at an adequate level I could continue my schooling until 1939 . After the outbreak of the World War it became impossible to go to school regularly . My mother my sister and I were evacuated to Nevers/LOC ViÃ©vre/LOC in September 1939 . In June 1940 upon the invasion of the German troops we fled to the south of France/GPE and went to de Chaumont Greuse/LOC . In the summer September of 1940 we moved to Aubusson/LOC Creuse/LOC where I was able to go to school again . In Aubusson/LOC we lived as penniless refugees in difficult conditions . In the summer of 1942 it became dangerous to be known to the Vichy authorities as German Jews . My sister and I were entrusted by our parents to an underground movement that unsuccessfully attempted to smuggle us to Switzerland/GPE with a group of other children . We made it close to the border but there we were warned that a group had been captured a few days earlier and had to give up the attempt . We were sent to a children home in Moissac/LOC Tarn et Garonne where I stayed until October 1943 with FALSE papers in the name of Evelyne Ginsbourg born in Andlau/LOC Bas/LOC Rhin/LOC . During my time in Moissac/LOC I could not go to school . In October 1943 we had to leave Moissac/LOC and were brought to Villeneuve sur Lot Lot et Garonne by the French underground movement . There I was taken in by a school under the name Evelyne Grandjean . In Moissac/LOC and in Villeneuve/LOC I was constantly in danger of being reported to the authorities and had to go into hiding during police raids on several occasions . Against my religious convictions I was forced to participate in Christian religious classes and services in Villeneuve/LOC . In July 1944 I managed to pass the first part of the Abitur . Shortly after however I fled to Spain/GPE with my father by walking over the Pyrenees/LOC for three days from there we later emigrated to Palestine/GPE Israel/GPE . It was impossible for me to finish the Realschule and consequently I was unable to fulfil my wish to study medicine . London/GPE 22.2.1957 . signed E. Unger 6 Transcript . Affidavit . I the undersigned Gordin NoÃ©mi born on 3.7.1927 in Siauliai/GPE the daughter of Jacob Gordin and his wife Rachel nÃ©e Zeiber residing at 14 Avenue du GÃ©nÃ©ral Clavery Paris/GPE 16th arrondissement declare the following affidavit . I am aware of the meaning of an affidavit and am also aware that a FALSE declaration is a criminal offence . I have known Frau Eva Unger nÃ©e Guenzburg/LOC since the summer of 1942 when she came to Moissac/LOC Tarn et Garonne together with her sister Ruth Gorans nÃ©e Guenzburg/LOC . There they were illegally in hiding and lived as French citizens with FALSE papers . The Aryan name of Frau Eva Unger was first Evelyne Ginsbourg and later Evelyne Grandjean . In the autumn of 1943 we were forced to flee Moissac/LOC and I was brought to Villeneuve sur Lot Lot et Garonne by the French underground movement together with the Guenzburg sisters Eva and Ruth . In the summer of 1944 Eva Guenzburg left Villeneuve sur Lot with the intention of fleeing to Spain/GPE . I met Eva Guenzburg again only after the war in Paris/GPE in 1949 . I am not related to Frau Eva unger . In the summer of 1942 the sisters Eva and Ruth Guenzburg were brought there after having attempted unsuccessfully to be smuggled to Switzerland/GPE . In Moissac/LOC they were constantly in danger of being arrested . During the first three months they were hidden and after that FALSE papers were obtained for them with which they were classified as French citizens under the name Ginsbourg . Around October 1943 the Guenzburg sisters were forced to flee Moissac/LOC and were taken in by a boarding school in Villeneuve/LOC sur/LOC Lot/LOC Lot et Garonne . Their papers were changed again this time to the name Grandjean . They were not allowed to go out into the street and never had enough food since they did not possess ration cards . In July 1944 Eva Guenzburg fled to Spain/GPE with her father Ruth Guenzburg went to Montauban/GPE . I am not related to Frau Eva Unger . on some small incidents of anecdotal character demonstrating the kind and helpful attitude of the average Berliner towards the Jews . 4 . Date 1933 onwards . 5 . Number of pages 2 . 6 . Author or Source Dr. Martha Mosse November 1955 . 7 . Recorded by as above . 8 . References Berlin/GPE . P.III.f . No.183 Advent 1933 or 1934 a teacher makes some disparaging remarks about the Jews to a class of 6 7 year old little girls . One little one then stands up and says But FraÃ¼lein how can you say such a thing when the Lord Jesus is coming soon and when he was himself a Jew ? She sits down and begins to cry . The teacher says Silly child I have to tell you these things because the government wants it that way . But I did not tell you to write it down . At this the child says to the little Jewish girl next to her Tell him that if you meet him . The teacher herself told this story to a lady who is a friend of mine . I was sitting on the bus . No one was wearing the yellow star yet . A small deformed gentleman was sitting next to me who was obviously Jewish . When a lady got on with a girl aged about ten who looked very sensitive and miserable there was standing room only and so the gentleman stood up and offered them his seat . At this the child whispered to her mother That was very kind of that gentleman . The mother replied Yes you see and that was a Jew ! One morning during the first few days after the yellow stars had been imposed on us an official from the Jewish community was setting off from his home . Three small girls who were standing in the road next to the wall of the building made a deep curtsey when they saw him and said Heil Hitler Herr Jew ! When he asked them why they were being so polite they replied Our mother has told us that whenever we see a Jew we should be particularly friendly . He told me this himself . I was on a tram standing by the door at that time we were no longer allowed a seat and also by then we were wearing the yellow star looking out of the window . Then a lady who was obviously a member of the nobility came right up to me and whispered Do be sad . Lots of people think the way I do . Jews were no longer allowed to use public transport . Only officials from the Jewish community had been given special permits from the Gestapo to travel for work purposes as an exception was made under these circumstances . I had to go to a municipal department and got on a tram . The conductress looked at the yellow star and the Gestapo permit and came up to me . You must not stand here ! Your fellow countrymen do want you so close to them . Go and stand there right at the back near the exit . I did so although I had to stand among other passengers in the crowded tram and gave her one mark as I had no change . After a while she came and threw some coins at my feet with the words Here have your money . I did not move but a lady who was standing next to me immediately bent down and picked up all the money for me . A very young soldier said to the conductress If you feel like that you not suited to this work . We are after all a cultured nation . The poor child ! . An old lady obviously a member of the nobility hissed as she was getting out What is the number of this coach ? That woman has to go . That was the only occasion when a member of the public was rude to me . It is worth noting that not one of the people there supported her . 2 During the time when we were no longer allowed to buy any fruit vegetables meat fish etc I knew an official from the Jewish community who told me herself about the following that happened.on the tram . There was a wonderful smell of tangerines and she thought how nice it would be if she could have some one more time . She got out at the station in Friedrich Strasse . Suddenly she heard footsteps first behind and then next to her and noticed a soldier push some tangerines into her bag as he went past . Hardly a day went by without my fellow workers telling me that people they did not know had put fruit meat butter or cigarettes in their bag without being noticed . When a little Jewish girl came into the Jewish community she had a big apple in her hand and her mother told me that a lady wearing a large swastika had quite openly ! given the child the apple on the tram . Even shopkeepers joined in . Some sold forbidden goods to the Jews although at excessively high prices or in exchange for valuables . However the majority tried to help as much as they could on the quiet . For example there was an old potato seller at our market who would carry the potatoes inside for the Jews . A non Jewish lady took her own cards together with those from various people that she knew which had been marked with a J to this very market and bought goods from the stallholders . When on one occasion she was denounced by an effeminate informant who incidentally happened to be Jewish â€“ to an SS man who was standing around at the market and he asked her to show him the contents of her bag and the food ration cards she refused with the comment that he had no police authority and turned to the policeman in charge of supervising the market . He sent the SS man packing and took no further action . This very policeman even went shopping for elderly Jewish ladies who did not have the strength to go into the shops at the times stipulated for Jews using their cards and he would carry the goods into the building for them putting in some fish or meat etc . He would only take the right money and would not accept any reward . He also warned Jewish passers by for example if â€“ which later happened with the Austrian SS a raid on Jewish passers by was going on somewhere in front of them so that they could go a different way . 
Berendsohn and her husband emigrated from Germany/GPE to Denmark/GPE in 1933 . When the Germans marched in in April 1940 the country was crowded with refugees . Mrs Berendsohn husband Prof. Walter Berendsohn worked in the Danish Resistance Movement and in 1943 he had to go into hiding . A German Navy Captain and old friend of Mrs Berendsohn warned her of the forthcoming measures against Jews and advised her to flee to Sweden/GPE . Mrs Berendsohn thereupon co operated with a Mr Bertelsen a university lecturer in building up an organisation which effected the escape of Jews to Sweden/GPE . In the course of this operation many Danes risked and some of them lost their lives . All those who were detected were taken to concentration camps in Germany/GPE . The author states that from Norway/GPE about 700 Jews had been deported and later gassed as early as 1942 . Walter Berendsohn escaped to Sweden/GPE with the help of the Resistance Movement . Dora Berendsohn and her daughter followed on 14 October 1943 on one of the last transports . Danish doctors nurses railway officials students and policemen risked their lives to take small groups to a meeting place on the Danish coast . These refugees were smuggled into Sweden/GPE in fishing boats under constant danger from German Navy patrols . In Sweden/GPE they were received with great hospitality . Refugee life in Denmark/GPE and escape to Sweden/GPE Dear Sister I had long intended and looked for time to describe in detail how it went for us in the years from 1933 45 . I think above all of the years 1940 â€“ 1943 before we came to Sweden/GPE . Although we have seen each other in the meantime several times in fact but whenever the conversation turned to this time you hardly listened or you told with such depth and dramatically of your experiences in Germany/GPE that I kept my mouth shut . At least on this topic . By no means do I want to diminish what you have gone through in your life the heavy bombing nights the hunger the constant worry about husband and sons in the battlefield . You and the other sisters after all you had to hand over your most beloved . â€“ You always thought we abroad had nothing to cope with we had plenty of everything because we sent you packages of whatever we had left over . We ourselves went without regarding the food as well as clothing so that you probably had the impression that we must be doing very well . But we thought of our old mother of your little children and the children of the other sisters . We did not enjoy the food if we could not share it with you so to speak . But we had to work for it work hard . Our savings disappeared in the first years after 33 in Denmark/GPE . It is after all always difficult to find a footing in a foreign country â€“ and in addition came the sadness and worry for home . Try sometime to move abroad as people between 40 and 50 years old with little children and to start from scratch with a new language abroad . After all with we had to go through this starting from scratch in a new language again ten years later when we fled to Sweden/GPE . We have found many good friends and in the most difficult time for us from 1940 43 in Denmark/GPE it became apparent how they stood with us . In April 1940 one morning German planes came over Denmark/GPE and occupied the peaceful country . From then on everything was dark in the evening and the brightly lit strip of coast on the Swedish side of the Ã–resund/LOC seemed to us like a Fata Morgana . 2 We were captured and felt like that too . There was no way out anymore as all the borders were closed . The small country was literally bought up by the hungry German soldiers and by a stream of refugees who had lost their home through bombs or had been chased out by the enemy . They came rolling up from Germany/GPE and added to it all . Schools barracks large offices and dancing halls were requisitioned and these poor innocent people slept by the hundreds on the floors sparingly provided with bedlinen clothing and food . There were thousands and thousands . They were hated by the Danes because they brought poverty and worry to their country . â€“ Just at that time when the Nazis attacked Denmark/GPE â€“ 9 April 1940 â€“ our daughter Karin was confined to her bed as a result of a knee injury and was lying in traction . As she had a place at the window she heard â€“ and saw â€“ the airplanes bearing Swastikas one morning circling over Copenhagen/GPE and knew immediately what that meant . She screamed and cried and said father would be murdered now . She had to go to him immediately . The whole hospital came running doctors and nurses tried to calm her down and to tell her that it was the Germans â€“ but she knew better . She had after all seen it . From then on we were exposed and lived in constant fear . That lasted until 1943 . Then the government resigned and the German had a free hand . Many political opponents had managed to escape were partly in hiding many were shot . One was now expecting the persecution of the Jews and those people who were working in the resistance movement . Walter had already tried every so often in the three previous years to disappear from the scene . He was however known throughout the country through lectures at schools further education colleges universities and associations in the country . Wherever he happened to be it news of his presence immediately spread like a wildfire through the town or the village . But now when it became really serious he thought of a hideout in Copenhagen/GPE . A good friend had once said to him that in an emergency he could rely on his help . It was a well known Dane who had a good standing in public life . One day Walter was then settled there but I had no idea who this emergency helper was . I was meant to know anyway . I could reach Walter through a chain of connections if necessary . In the meantime we heard again and again from many sources that this or that person had been picked up by the Gestapo but these were still only single events . It was a very unsettled time . 3 When I came home one afternoon there was a letter from a childhood friend who as captain of a corvette with the German navy was based outside Copenhagen/GPE and urgently wanted to speak to me â€“ and indeed had to . We had not seen each other forever for many years but he had heard that I had emigrated to Copenhagen/GPE also found out my current name â€“ and so I was easy to find in the telephone register . In the letter he asked me to make an immediate call to the Hotel Astoria as he would have to sail off again very soon . I was in a state of great agitation and really did not know what to do . Although he had been here in civvies to put the letter in our letter box himself but if he dared to go into a Jewish house then I as a non Jewish woman could also dare to do this . After all it had to be something important . As I was invited an hour later to our good friend Reader Bertelsen I decided to discuss everything there . Bertelsen is by now Rector at the Cathedral School in Aarhus/LOC . I can still see today how surprised Bertelsen was and with what interest he listened to me . He immediately allowed me to make a telephone call even though as was said all conversations were tapped . He was one of the resistance people after all ! I kept it short and promised to be at the hotel the following morning . There I found out that large scale persecution of Jews would now take place and he advised me that I should immediately transfer my husband to Sweden/GPE . I had hardly returned home when Bertelsen came and wanted to find out what was so urgent . I quickly told him he jumped up and said we have to get going immediately and do everything we can to help . I joined in and helped from one day to the next to build up an organisation and to prepare the ways by which then about Jews reached Sweden/GPE . Many SS people and soldiers must have been bribed otherwise this great campaign would have never succeeded even if everything happened in the dead of night . There were several more organisations alongside the political ones already existing were strengthened . These had already for a long time brought individuals to freedom and I have to say very many risked their lives and some of them lost their lives . â€“ There was work to do day and night . Well meaning and well off people could be found aplenty . Of course everything had to take place in silence and be carried out without being noticed and a lot of money was needed . But the number of people who understood what was at stake was great . Students doctors professors police businesspeople fishermen railway staff â€“ everyone contributed where it was needed . Cars were sent out to the most remote areas in Denmark/GPE when it was found out that a Jew was still living here or there . Friends provided apartments to sleeping there was good supply of ? food . Hospitals took in people under FALSE names . 4 I had not been able to sleep in my apartment for quite a while as it had turned out that twice at night gangs of heavily booted German and Danish Nazis wanted to bring us in . Our landlord who lived on the ground floor of the villa called in those people on the second occasion and questioned them . He said the family Berendsohn had not been in Denmark/GPE for a long time . He also asked what they wanted from Mrs B after she all she was not a Jew . The answer was if she had been married to a Jew for 25 years she is one too . /The landlord too and his wife later had to leave Denmark/GPE i e quickly disappear because they were active in the underground movement/ The black booted Nazis avoided daylight so I dared to spend a few daytime hours in our apartment . During these hours too I was in constant fear but I had to be there to be reachable . From near and far people came to me strangers persecuted people who had heard I knew a way to Sweden/GPE . In such situations you get to know people . Despair worry fear â€“ after all it was about life ! How did they know my name my address ? Everything happened like wildfire . It only in a situation like that that one gets to know oneself and sees one strengths growing at such a time â€“ and the fear disappearing . As an individual I could do little . The large number of people of goodwill worked together for the fixed goal . I could only direct those people who came to me to other addresses first of all places to stay because nobody dared to stay in their own apartment anymore . One could get money consolation and a quick prospect of freedom . There was literally no sleep for days and weeks one could not one did not want to they all had to be saved first ! Friendships for life came out of that . Now I have to go back dear sister for in the meantime Walter had been transported to Sweden/GPE . One day Frau Dr. S. sent news to us that this evening my husband was to be at 10 at the coast at the small train station X he immediately had to go to Sweden/GPE . I tried my luck at quickly reaching Walter and then met him in the dark at Hellerup/LOC station in a small cafÃ© . We had not seen each other for a long time and we were facing hard times . Whether it would yes it worked but only just about by the skin of our teeth ! It was the Danish resistance movement that transported him even before the persecution of Jews set in ! A few months later Walter became seriously ill probably as result of the very difficult flight of which he himself has written quite a bit . For several months he lay in a critical condition in a sanatorium in Falun/LOC high up in the mountains very prettily situated . The Danes paid for that too we were still in their care . 5 Walter courageous host in Denmark/GPE was shot at night in his bed very soon after Walter flight . His wife was Jewish which Walter did not know . She and the son also had to flee the daughter stayed with the father and she witnessed the attack . So now many thousands of women children and men were getting to Sweden/GPE within three weeks through many helpful hands who again and again were risking their lives . But one does think of that is always obsessed with the idea of helping . Some transports were unfortunately discovered the people were sent to Germany/GPE and Theresienstadt/GHETTO ca 900 people . But nearly all of them by a stroke of luck came back unlike the Norwegians from where about 700 Jews including Walter relatives all /6/ were sent off to Germany/GPE and gassed . That was already in 1942 . Only few could save themselves . I was told that it was time to disappear . The senior doctor of the hospital in which Karin was kept under a FALSE name gave me a hint as the girl was sick with anxiety fear and yearning for the father of whom she knew that he had long been in safety . So one day I also had to be ready . My wish and my last word to Walter before he went off into the unknown was to save as many Jews as was in my powers was fulfilled as I had the great fortune to have Bertelsen as my friend . Because of that I was within a large organisation that did everything that was possible and had the means to do it . See also Bertelsen book Oktober 43 published in Aarhus/LOC 1952 in Danish and in translation also in USA/GPE and in Israel/GPE . There were now practically no Jews anymore in Denmark/GPE only a few stayed in hiding for the whole years thanks to caring courageous people who had taken them in . Many helpers finally also had to disappear and so Karin and I came with one of the last transports in a dramatic way to Trelleborg/CAMP a harbour town on the southern point of Sweden/GPE . That was on 14 October 1943 . I have to add that such transports were attempted along the whole Danish coast and as German patrol boats with torches were out at night every transport was again a risk . Once again it was doctors nurses hospitals railway staff students policemen and civilians who fearlessly led the fight against the Nazis . Always endangering their own lives they took us in very small groups of 3 â€“ 5 people from one place to another from the car to the train . This time the collection point was a small hotel in southern Denmark/GPE where about 15 endangered 6 people came together including those who wanted to get across Sweden/GPE to England/GPE to join the fight there . In the hotel upstairs on the first floor there was a little hall laid out and to calm our spirits we were served the loveliest dishes . The chef the waiters all of them were in the know . From there it continued in three cars after it had got dark through a large forest for about an hour to a remote / children summer home . It was heated and everything was prepared . There too we had to wait again for several hours . Again we got sandwiches tea from thermos flasks . There were about four helpers from the underground movement who were with us three students and one nurse . The wait was difficult but eventually we got the sign to get back into the car . We drove for half an hour through the forest along the coast to a little fishing harbour . There was our boat . We were stowed one by one in the storage room . There were benches up and it smelled of herring as usually there was fish stored there . It was nearly dark down there but we silently put up with everything . The goal was in sight and we hoped for freedom . The eternal hours that followed were incredibly difficult . We had to get around minefields storms and rain started . Our little nutshell caused us to be thoroughly shaken and many of us lay on the floor feeling very seasick . There was no toilet . Every one of us was a heap of misery when we looked at each other the following day in the light in Sweden/GPE . The feeling of happiness when long before we were on land the fishermen called down to us Sweden/GPE in sight ! was indescribable . We could not have had a warmer welcome from Swedish customs and the police officers . Everything was taken care of and in a gymnastics hall camping beds had been put up where we were initially all housed . Boats had also arrived in the previous days and the little town was full of refugees . The following day everyone was to be transported to a summer hotel in the centre of Sweden/GPE where a refugee camp had been set up . As everybody coming from Denmark/GPE was only allowed to carry the absolutely necessities with them a small hand carried suitcase of a bag everybody was clothed and given warm dry stuff . â€“ I was at the end of my strength after weeks of hard and dangerous work and needed to be on my own . Therefore I asked first of all to move into a hotel there on the square with my daughter for a short while . As I had last minute by friends been given Swedish money 7 that would have worked . I also had Danish crowns that eventually I could exchange for Swedish ones . At the police office they said that they could not make an exception . I would have also liked to get in touch with Walter who in the meantime had been given somewhere to stay by his friend Professor Lamm and a job by another friend . The police wanted as already said to send me on the following day there was no hotel room available there were conferences and we would have to leave in a closed troop and stay under supervision . I went back to the police again and this time got hold of the most senior police officer I was very lucky . This man knew Walter from his previous lecture tours in southern Sweden/GPE he also knew Professor Lamm . I immediately got a lovely big room at the city hotel where we then stayed for three weeks before we could get to Stockholm/LOC . There we finally reunited with Walter and were able to move into a small apartment which we got purely by chance . There we could finally breathe more freely and begin a new life . After all those dark year our eyes were now blinded by the illuminated shop windows and advertisements . The way we enjoyed our weeks in Trelleborg/CAMP is indescribable . Above all it was light and free around us ! Everything we had not seen for years was spread out in front of us in the shops . From our hotel window we saw a beautifully laid out fruit shop . I immediately sent Karin down there she was to buy a large bag of the most wonderful things . She did it with joy and enthusiasm . In the evenings we talked on the telephone to Walter who of course was very glad that we had arrived in Sweden/GPE in one piece and healthy albeit traumatised . Yes dear Anni now we had arrived in our third home . Now 12 years later one can say that luck had once again stayed with us . We had only had a little suitcase with us a tiny one and only a little money and nothing to furnish an apartment and to pay for it . We only had our strength will and the desire to get back to calm circumstances . An apartment was then a highly valued item and still is now . This time it was Swedish people who helped us to get going . It all moved forward even though Walter serious illness already mentioned above interfered . It was of course a great concern but it too was dealt with . Progress was made with diligence and great sticking power . After all you know what Walter is like when he wants to achieve something . I have often admired him how then already over 60 he again managed to muster 8 so much power of resistance to start anew again . And today at 72 he is still busily working But in the meantime we have seen each other and talked . What I have reported today I wanted to put down in writing so that you can read it in peace and we can talk about it later . 
Demuth left Germany/GPE in March 1933 . Shortly afterwards he took over the leadership of the Notgemeinschaft deutscher Wissenschaftler i m Ausland founded by Philip Schwartz who was then called to Istanbul/GPE in Switzerland/GPE . He continued with this activity when he moved to England/GPE in 1936 . He got his certificate of discharge and an indemnification of RM 10 in 1934 and is now receiving his pension . 8 .
