Formerly Syndikus der Berliner Handelskammer and curator der Hochschule fuer Politik . Interview with Geheimrat Demuth Privy Councillor Demuth left Germany/GPE back in March 1933 . Someone had warned him that he would be arrested the next day if he did not leave of his own accord . He had been accused of spreading stories of atrocities as propaganda . With the usual point being made that The whole thing will just take a few months but why subject yourself to all the unpleasantness that will ensue during that time he was strongly advised to leave the country . Privy Councillor Demuth left Germany/GPE in a sleeping car and had absolutely no trouble at all crossing the Dutch border . The whole process was so easy in fact that he assumed that orders must have been issued to allow him to leave freely ? ! . Demuth had friendly ties with a number of the foreign embassies in Berlin/GPE and they very generously put themselves at his disposal before he left . For example one member of staff at the French Embassy approached him to pass on regards from Poncet himself and to offer their assistance . When Demuth first emigrated he found himself in Switzerland/GPE . As soon as he had arrived there he got involved with the organisation Notgemeinschaft deutscher Wissenschaftler i m Ausland Emergency Association of German Scientists Abroad founded by Professor Philip Schwartz and he soon took over leadership when Professor Schwartz was summoned to Istanbul/GPE . The organisation was predominantly active between 1933 and 1939 continuing on a smaller scale up to 1949 . Over the years they managed to achieve a great deal . The rigidity of the regulations in Switzerland/GPE made it hard to make progress there but Mr Braunschweig the President of the Jewish Committee was very willing to offer help . Antisemitism was rife in Switzerland/GPE and impoverished emigrants were treated horribly . 2 Privy Councillor Demuth then continued with this work in England/GPE from 1936 seamlessly shifting over to work for the Central Joint illegible European Committee and the Ministry of Economic Warfare during the war . He interviewed refugees for the Foreign Office who reported to the government shortly after the outbreak of war or even later provided information relating to the pioneers and so on . He worked directly on behalf of the Cabinet and compiled some 5000 reports over the years . In 1940 he focused heavily on getting prisoners released . When asked at what point he first became aware of the danger posed by the Nazi Party and started to take it seriously Demuth mentioned the following incident In January 1930 ? his colleague Oskar Meyer Member of the Reichstag German parliament and Municipal Councillor came to his office and explained his view that the situation was intolerable . Oskar Meyer wanted to leave Germany/GPE and suggested that they should both go together so that it would be seen as taking a stand . He did not think that going alone would have any impact . Demuth considered this level of alarm to be excessive and decided not to leave . Oskar Meyer also ended up staying in Germany/GPE . Shortly after this episode Judicial Councillor Waldschmidt announced that he too wanted to get out . Demuth was involved with the central economic organisations and wholesale and retail associations in Germany/GPE and he also had ties with the trade unions . The umbrella organisation assembled for regular meetings and there was still a lot of uncertainty surrounding the Nazi party and their manifesto within such circles in 1932 . Nobody was clear about what they were trying to achieve . On that basis Funk who was Editor in Chief of the Berliner BÃ¶rsen Zeitung newspaper at the time was invited to attend a meeting so he could be asked As you know the Nazis can you tell us what exactly it is they want ? As another rather typical story from the same period goes The Chamber of Commerce ran a holiday home in Riga/LOC for tradesmen and before the party had even come to power the people in charge wanted to introduce a 3 numerus clausus . Demuth opposed this but they found another Member of the Board who was willing to sign the corresponding restrictive regulation . In September 1932 Demuth spoke at the Industry Club in DÃ¼sseldorf/LOC where he urged all members to stay firmly in the centre . He said that any other approach would lead to rearmament and warned that a second world war would then be inevitable . He managed to convince his audience that his arguments were well founded with the sole exception of Thyssen which was to be expected . Oppenheim did also have his own doubts . The purpose of the session was merely to enter into a discussion with a view to clarifying the situation . No vote was held or agreement made . Three weeks later Hitler spoke in front of the same committee for several hours . In the end he managed to win them all over with the promise that the Nazis would dissolve the trade unions and instead establish state associations . This was crucial in Hitler success in getting everyone on his side . Demuth view on this now is It was a clear victory and everything that came later was undeniably a consequence of this . Within the National Industry Association an umbrella organisation with just ten members Frowein announced that he had been liaising with the party shortly after they came to power . Frowein was the leading intellectual figure within the national association and he gave a speech at this time along the following lines We all saw how things progressed after 1918 . At first there was a whole lot of noise about the move towards Socialism and so on . But then it all came to nothing . The exact same will happen this time too . Just do be so afraid . In the summer of 1932 Gelpke President of the Berlin/GPE Chamber of Commerce had asked Demuth for help on behalf of his son in law who was in serious financial trouble . Demuth obliged meaning that Gelpke was very much in his debt . 4 He promised that he would support Demuth at all costs . According to Demuth today this lasted all of five minutes ! Demuth received his certificate of discharge in 1934 and a one off compensation payment of Mark but nothing further . He now receives an adequate pension which in his own words allows him to live quite comfortably . 

November 1938 Mrs W. was arrested by the Mayor of the small town with the hearty approval of a big mob who demolished her house . The Warden his wife and the bailiff were very kind to her . After sixteen days she was released and Mayor Hummel was reprimanded for his action . 8 . References â€˜ Rassenschande Amtsgericht Freiberg . The Tenth of November 1938 Incidents in a small town in the Erzgebirge/LOC . The story of Mrs. W. can be understood best if a few seemingly unconnected incidents are related first . Mr. and Mrs. W owned a laundry . They had a partner in it a Sozius and there was an arrangement that if this method of running the firm was not to the liking of either party they could terminate it after a period of five years . In that case the laundry would revert back to Mr. and Mrs. W. Yet the Sozius had other ideas he wanted to drive out Mr. and Mrs. W. and since he could not do it by fair means he was prepared to do it by foul . He tried to denounce Mr. W. of Mietwucher/LOC overcharging on the rents . He accused them of being involved in illegal abortions . He also accused Mr. W. of Rassenschande . The Rassenschande case went to court and the judge who could see that the whole case was a put up job gave judgement in favour of Mr. W. This was at the Amtsgericht in Freiberg/LOC . On the 9th of November Mr. W. and his son were in England/GPE . Still in Germany/GPE in the Erzgebirge was Mrs. W and her parents . They lived in a nice house there respected by all . On the 10th of November unaware of what had happened in Paris/GPE in the 9th November 1938 Mrs. W went to the Rathaus the townhall to pay some taxes . In the town hall she heard ominous murmering Volksgemurmel and the BÃ¼rgermeister called Mr. Hummel came up to her . 2 You are herewith under arrest . You are responsible for the murder of Rath . When Mrs. W. tried to speak and explain she shouted down Jude bleibt Jude once a Jew always a Jew . She was dragged on to the market square and there from the stairs of the town hall the BÃ¼rgermeister delivered a speach . To make sure of a large audience the school had been closed early and the less pleasant people of the village and some students had assembled to listen . The policeman was conspicuous by his absence . The speach promised the Jews that they would be shown how things would turn . Then with the audience following her Mrs. W. was marched off to her home . There the laundry workers were assembled . The mob that is what the crowd had turned in to went into the house breaking things . Mrs. W. was asked whether she owned any arms . She admitted to having a revolver . The BÃ¼rgermeister found an airgun from Mrs. W son and was very proud of his discovery . In the yard the BÃ¼rgermeister made another speech in which he mentioned thigs which he could have learned only from the Sozius . A big pile was made of forbidden literature and other books and also old bibles which Mr. W had been collecting over years . They were burned . Other valuable things lost during this morning was jewelery from Mrs. W mother and her daughter . While some of the people who went into the house were causing a havoc inside others threw stones through the window . Yet some of the people who went into the house were different . They hid things which they thought had sentimental value . They hid them beneath beds . 3 At about six that evening when Mrs. W had just had time to clear up a little after the mob had left the BÃ¼rgermeister arrived with the gun . When Mrs. W said that she had always admitted to having this gun he shouted Shut your dirty mouth Halten Sie Ihr ungewaschenes Maul At seven the police arrived to take Mrs. W. into protective custody . The policeman was most curtious asked who would look after the canary and when they were in the street offered to walk ahead so that it did not look too much like an arrest . Mrs. W declined the offer . Her remarks to his offer were If anybody has to be ashamed at this moment it should be you . Mrs. W. spent 16 days in jail . It was the AmtsgefÃ¤ngnis . The warden and his wife were very kind to her . On Sunday she was visited by the bailiff and was most upset at her fate . Mrs. W. worked in jail trimming feathers . Mrs. W brother came from Dresden/CAMP on the 10th November . He had to carry his radio a Telefunken into the SchÃ¼tzenhaus and he had a screaming mob follow him . He got back safely though from delivering the radio but was arrested later that night and sent into concentration camp . Mrs. W. feels that her affair would not have happened if the Amtshauptmann a senior official had not been on leave . As soon as he returned she was released . 4 The BÃ¼rgermeister was reprimanded over his action in privet but the news leaked out . To justify himself he said that letters were exchanged between members of the W. family in which they said that the Nazis were like a comet on the sky and that they would disappear in the same way . This provoking letter was found only much later than the incident had taken place . The fact that the BÃ¼rgermeister had to justify himself at all is most interesting . Among the people who lived in this small place were many kind folk . The warden in jail was kind to Mrs. W. and was concerned when he learned that her brother had been taken to jail . He said to her on the morning after the arrest How did you sleep . We could not sleep all night and just sat up smoking cigarettes all the time . This same man collected toys for the children of a Russian prisoner shortly before his release at Christmas . He also phoned Mrs. W. after her release to ask her how she was . And yet there had been the mob composed of otherwise normal citizens who ransacked a house burned books thew stones and were rude and vulgar . And neither the BÃ¼rgermeister nor the Sozius can claim for themselves the excuse if it is one that they were only ignorant people momentarily fooled . They were deliberately malicious . A small town composed of many people !

Interview with Mr and Mrs David Flieg London/GPE On the day of the 1933 boycott the chairman of the local branch of the R.j . F. Jurist Dr. Weiner was collected from his house . He had set up an alarm for the police . His wife asked him if she should set off this alarm to which Weiner said no . He went to his desk and took out his officers patent and thought that this would keep him safe because he took it with him . He was put in a car which drove through a forest . Here he is supposed to have been told to get out and walk into the forest which W. also did . And then he was shot in the back and killed . On the day of the 1938 pogrom Herr . Flieg in his villa on the outskirts of SchÃ¶nau/LOC lay in bed with heart troubles and was arrested from there . He was taken to the police prison . Here in a corridor he saw the local Rabbi Dr. Fuchs whose face was completely covered with blood and who looked terrible . Yet because of this Dr. Fuchs did not end up in a K.Z. An â€˜ Aryan doctor saw to it that he was admitted to a hospital in Chemitz/CAMP and out of humanity exaggerated his descriptions of the wounds so that Dr. Fuchs could stay in the hospital . All the other Jewish men in Chemitz/CAMP were taken to KZ/CAMP Buchenwald/CAMP . His brother in law Jurist Hartmann with the impression of the famous and terrible march in Buchenwald/CAMP in mind wanted to persuade Flieg to commit suicide together . Jurist Hartmann was chairman of the Saxonia â€“ Loge B.B and was prominent in Jewish life there . Flieg calmed Hartmann and rejected suicide as H. realised . A man from Chemitz/CAMP was beaten to death in a bunker in Buchenwald/CAMP another by the name of â€˜ teinhard died after his release as was the case with a man named â€˜ GrÃ¼nberg who had bladder troubles . On the march Jurist Cohn helped the severely war wounded Wangenheim from the lorry in which they were brought to the camp . In doing so he was so severely injured that he collapsed covered in blood . In spite of this he made it known that W. was war wounded . Cohn had sustained a severe head injury . A man from Chemitz/CAMP was mentally disabled . A certain Simon was only able to save him by laying him among the plies of dead . Simon lives still . In Chemitz/CAMP the window panes of all the shops were destroyed . In the district of Ober/LOC Wuchwitz/LOC a house was destroyed . In the Villa Fliegschen in the district of SchÃ¶nau/CAMP a pane of glass was destroyed . The officials of the responsible police station Siegmar/LOC were very humane and watched over the Jewish houses after this . In the warehouse Schocken/LOC large damages were perpetrated . The perpetrators had obviously not known that that the company had just been bought by a British corporation . This is later said to have received compensation . Already in Buchenwald/CAMP myself the affair was related to me by Dr. Curt Cohn then a member of the Regional Court and now a member of the Supreme Court of the DDR in Berlin/GPE . 
M. van Iperen was a Dutch Christian and was manageress of a grocer shop in  Amsterdam/GPE . On the outbreak of the war she joined the Resistance . The account describes in detail her various activities . She also participated actively in the strike of Dutch workers in sympathy with the Jews . In October 1942 the SS came to her house . She had built a hiding place for all incriminating material and succeeded in stowing everything away before the men led by Lages chief of SD forced their way in . Mrs M. van Iperen and 3 friends were arrested . They had been denounced by one of their colleagues who had been caught . The Gestapo never found the hiding place and throughout the interrogations at Euterpestraat/STREET Mrs M. van Iperen never confessed anything . At first she was in Amstellveenscheweg/CAMP prison but after the fifth unsuccessful questioning she was taken to a coffin like cell in Weterino Schans prison and confronted with the informer . She still denied everything and was taken to a punishment cell in Amstellveenscheweg/CAMP in complete darkness by day and glaring lights at night . After 4 days she could return to her old cell and the interrogations continued . In January 1943 she was allowed to work and this enabled her to disseminate news and letters among her fellow prisoners . Twice she was denounced for these activities and was eventually sent to Vught in June 1943 . Here she had to work for Philips . In February 1944 there was a tragic incident As a result of a denunciation by a German prisoner Mrs Jedzini a fight broke out amongst the women in the course of which Mrs Jedzini was shot by a guard . The 92 participants were locked overnight in a tiny prison cell and 15 of them suffocated . In September 1944 the prisoners could hear the guns firing and on 7 September Vught was evacuated . Mrs M. van Iperen travelled for days in a cattle truck without food or water or lavatory . On arrival in RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP they had to stand for 2 days and nights out of doors . Then they had to exchange their clothes for dirty verminous rags no shoes or knickers . Their barrack was built for 300 but housed . 11 women shared a mattress in three tiered bunkers . Out of 5 lavatories only one worked . Mrs M. van Iperen had to work for Siemens for 12 hours per day . She worked in the Nickelei where parts of aeroplanes were chromium plated . The acid in the material corroded their clothing and the air became poisoned . The workers therefore received an extra ration of half a pint of milk . Their lunch consisted of half a pint of warm water with potato peels or turnips . Towards the end of the war work for Siemens stopped and Mrs M. van Iperen returned to the general camp . In order to escape work in the quarry she hid behind a loose board in the ceiling above the bed of her friend Hilde Sternberg . Via Sweden/GPE Mrs M. van Iperen returned to Holland/GPE but her sufferings have left her a very ill person . 10 . Further References Riek Suel and Jo Elsendoorn fellow prisoners in police car . De Groot Jewish fellow prisoner in Amstelveenscheweg/CAMP prison for whom Mrs M. van Iperen smuggled a letter out of prison . See also account by Hilde Sternberg P.Ill.h . RavensbrÃ¼ck No . 823 for further information . Work and Sufferings of a Non Jewess Mrs M. van Iperen is Dutch by birth and lived at one time in Amsterdam/CAMP where she worked as the manageress of a grocer shop . Mrs van Iperen is a non Jew . Immediately after the outbreak of war she became involved with an illegal group part of the Dutch Resistance movement . She first came into contact with these illegals through her work at the grocer shop . She sold pamphlets and used the money raised to help those who were in hiding . These included not only Jews but also anyone holding left wing political views . Mrs v. I. was also able to provide these illegals with extra food rations . She became a member of the group in December 1940 and started to shop for the Jews in her lunch break as they were not allowed to do so themselves during normal shop hours . The Jews then started coming to her to pick up their parcels . During the night she used to go out into the street and stick up anti Nazi posters . A curfew was in place between one and five in the morning during which time she too was not allowed to be out on the streets . She also operated a courier service delivering letters from one individual to another . She collected money from addresses given to her cash to be used to help those in hiding . She even went to pick up incendiary bombs which she then delivered to another part of town . Someone always accompanied her on these missions to make sure there were no accidents en route . The recipients would then place the bombs where they would destroy valuable German materials . She was then instructed to learn shorthand and typing . During the night it was her task to transcribe text onto wax plates for use in printing illegal newspapers . The paper and wax plates had to be bought out of her own money . Other members of the resistance movement would come to collect these newspapers and then 2 distribute them to smaller outlets from where they were sold . She continued with this work every night and on Sundays . She had a free evening once a week and a Sunday off every fortnight . If something particular happened and extra duties were required she gave freely of her time . Sometimes she worked until 4 5 or even 8 in the morning . One of her tasks was to grind sugar into a fine powder which was then used to make incendiary bombs . The resistance workers decreed that everyone should wear a yellow star including Christians . This was then retracted for fear that the Germans would arrest them in reprisal and that would put an end to the work they were doing . It was also felt that having everyone wear the yellow Star of David armband would in fact do little to help the Jews . Interested parties came to Mrs van Iperen shop to buy illegal newspapers . At this time people knew the bare minimum about each other one man was unlikely to know the identity of another man or anything else about him . Anti Jewish measures were becoming more and more stringent . Mrs van I. saved up food to give to the Jews . Her workplace was in the north of  Amsterdam/GPE . In February 1942 workers from the Fokker plant and other factories came to her among many others warning them to stock up on food supplies and go home early . They were about to stage a strike to oppose the anti Jewish measures that were being enacted . The last ferry into the centre of the city where they lived left at two . All the shops were shut . Almost the entire province of Nordholland/LOC was involved in the protest . The tram drivers â€˜ aim was to cause major disruption on the street called the Munt and Mrs van I. was involved in this action . Afterwards the strikers all went home to lie low for a few days . The whole time this was going on the Germans marched through the streets armed with bayonets and guns . If anyone dared come to the window to look out the Germans immediately shot at them . After three days the strike intended simply as a demonstration of support for the Jews was over . 3 The work of the underground movement continued . Mrs van I. was now involved solely with the production of posters and newspapers . The identities of those who came to collect the newspapers were kept secret but each had a codeword by which they could be recognised . Those who came regularly were easily recognised by sight but no one ever knew their names . It was just too dangerous knowing too much about other people while doing this work and could have led to all kinds of trouble . If ever a member of the group was arrested all incriminating material had to be burnt and work ceased for a day or two so as not to endanger anyone else . This never happened in the group that Mrs van I. belonged to . Her work continued night after night . In October 1942 the doorbell rang in the middle of the night at Mrs van I flat in Keizersgracht/CAMP where this work was being carried out . On seeing German and Dutch SS soldiers outside they refused to open the door but instead set about burning all the illegal material in the oven . There was a built in hiding place in the wall where stencil machines cardboard oil and explosive substances were kept . After 45 minutes the Nazis had managed to get through the neighbouring garden and flat and into their house breaking the door down to gain entry . The head of the security services himself a man by the name of Lages arrested them there was no chance to hide because the roof the garden and the house were all surrounded by SS men . All three of the women there were taken away . The SS stayed in the flat for five days and nights hoping to catch more perpetrators but no one came . They went right through the flat searching every nook and cranny and ripping up the floor but found nothing . They completely missed the real hiding place and when Mrs van I. returned home after the war she found the materials and equipment still there untouched . The reason the SS spent so much time searching the premises was because they were convinced this was the place where illegal communications were being produced . A man who had come regularly to collect newspapers from Mrs van I. which he used to distribute on trains travelling into Germany/GPE had been captured by the Germans and interrogated . He had denounced all 29 members of the group which was why suspicion had fallen on Mrs van I house . When the SS failed to find anything incriminating they assumed the premises had just been used as some kind of halfway house . The women were taken away by car with an armed SS guard to the security service headquarters in Euterpestrasse/STREET . A woman called Mrs Riek Suel and a man called Mr Jo Elsendoorn were in the same car both 4 accused of buying the illegal newspaper . That night they were put into individual cells at Euterpestrasse/STREET . The following day the interrogation began nobody confessed to anything . They were then taken to Amstelveensche Weg prison and locked in the cells there . They stayed there until the end of June 1943 . During this period they were interrogated eight times . These interrogations always took place in Euterpestrasse/STREET . The fourth time Mrs van I. was questioned Lages showed her a stencil machine and said We found this in your flat . Mrs van I immediately recognised the machine as hers but it was one that she had used for some time and had given away . She and the two other women stuck firmly to their statement that this could not have been found in their flat . So adamant were they in their testimony that the SS ended up believing that in fact no printing had taken place in their flat but that it had merely been used as a halfway house . Had they not believed this the women would have been shot right there and then . For the fifth interrogation Mrs van I. was taken to Wetering Schans prison escorted there by a special division . On arrival she was put into a wooden lock up resembling an upright coffin . They then brought her face to face with the man who had betrayed her . The interrogation lasted a whole day . When asked Do you know this man ? her reply was always No . The informer however maintained that he knew Mrs van I. and again told in detail of the illegal work in which she had been involved . But Mrs I. remained steadfast and confessed nothing . She was taken back to Amstelveenscher Weg prison but was not locked up with the other women . Instead she was put in a punishment cell â€“ a two and a half metre square barred cage down in the cellar . There were even bars above her head . The only furniture in the cell was a wooden plank bed . She was forced to hand over her jacket and long trousers . She sat there in pitch darkness all day long and then at night under glaringly bright lights . She was given a sack of straw to sleep on but no blanket to cover herself and was unable to sleep anyway because of the lights . Marking time by the church clock she walked round and round her cell changing direction every half an hour . She spent three days and nights incarcerated there just walking round and round . 5 On the fourth day they brought her back to Euterpestrasse/STREET . Yet again she was asked if she knew the informer . She repeatedly denied that she did . They threatened to shoot her still she confessed nothing . As they already had her imprisoned she felt emboldened to say to the SS men You never going to win this war you know . She was then taken back to her old cell in Amstelveenschen Weg prison . In subsequent interrogations too she was asked repeatedly whether she knew this or that person but their questioning was pointless as she steadfastly refused to reveal anything . One of the Dutch SS men tried to get her to talk by putting all the blame on the Jews . Of course that didnâ€˜t work either . In January 1943 she was given more freedom and was allowed out to clean the prison corridors and distribute food . Her cell was not locked during the day only at night time . This meant she was able to go into the other cells . Amongst the other inmates there were a large number of students who had been caught distributing ration cards stolen from the local registration office . When prisoners returned in the evening after being interrogated they would write down any news or information they had gleaned during the day on small pieces of paper and Mrs van I. would take these from cell to cell so that people were kept abreast of anything new . She also passed letters to the prisoners through the hatch in their door . Then someone betrayed her and she was summoned to the camp commandant for questioning . She never told them where the letters had come from claiming she had found them under a mat . As nothing could be proved she was allowed to go . A Jew by the name of de Groot asked Mrs van I. to smuggle a letter out to his family . He wanted to warn them that they were in danger and should take their weapons and go into hiding . Mrs van I. promised to take the letter . Every fortnight families were allowed to come and collect the prisoners â€˜ dirty linen and clothing for washing . So it was that she managed to smuggle this letter through despite the bundle of washing being searched by a female prison guard . Mrs van I. would sew the letters into the seams hems and shoulder pads of laundry items . Once again she was betrayed â€“ this time by her Christian cellmates . 6 A further interrogation was carried out . Once again she was sent to the punishment barracks for a day . She continued to deny everything and as it was impossible to prove her â€˜ crime â€˜ she was released . The others involved were saved as a result . During the night Jews were transported to Westerbork/GPE transit camp . It was Mrs van I.â€˜s job to leave the bags that these people were going to take with them outside their doors . One of the women who was to be deported gave her 10 guilders as a thank you gift as she left . At the start of June 1943 the prison was so crowded that many of the inmates were sent to Vught/CAMP concentration camp . Once the command realised they were not going to get any new information out of Mrs van I. she too was sent to Vught . There were some people very few of them Christian who accepted huge sums of money for hiding Jews . For them it was a good way to make some cash . But if they got caught they complained bitterly about getting locked up for helping filthy Jews . Mrs van I. number at the Vught camp was l67 . While there she worked in the Philips workshop . Of the civilan workforce by no means all were Nazis . Many offered their help for example by smuggling letters to them from Westerbork/CAMP even those that had to be taken to  Amsterdam/GPE prison . While in Vught/LOC the Christians also received parcels from both their relatives and the Red Cross . The Jews were allowed neither . Mrs van I. recalls a tragic event that took place in February 1944 . Two women were standing out on the parade ground â€“ one of them was Mrs Jedzini a German prisoner with definite Nazi sympathies and the other a Dutch woman . The latter was telling everyone that she had managed to carry on working illegally and hiding Jews . Quite by chance this Dutch woman was then released that same day whereupon Mrs Jedzini â€“ no one knew why she had originally been arrested â€“ went straight to the camp commander to complain about the fact that she a German had not been released while someone who was still hiding Jews had been allowed to go home . 7 Mrs Jedzini behaviour enraged the other women they beat her and refused to let her sleep in the barracks that night . Mrs Jedzini used this ill treatment to her advantage and complained to the commander the following day . The other prisoners were at work in the Philips workshop until the evening except for one girl . In retaliation for the way she had been treated Mrs Jedzini cut off this girl hair . Once again she used this incident to complain to the commandant . After that the other inmates hurled such violent abuse at her that she feared for her life and tried to escape . She ran to the barbed wire fence and was shot by one of the guards . The bullet pierced her lung and she died in hospital a few days later . That afternoon the girl was sent to the Bunker as the prison block at Vught/LOC was known . There she was questioned about which of the other prisoners had been involved in ill treating Mrs Jedzini she said nothing . The whole block came forward en masse to say that they had all been involved in what had happened . The result was that all 92 women were taken to the prison block and put into one cell measuring just two by three metres . The block had only recently been built . The walls and the nitric acid that had been used during their construction were not yet dry . The windows could not be opened . The women were so tightly crammed together that their oxygen supply was soon depleted . As the vapour rose from their bodies so nitric acid dripped down on them burning the skin on their faces heads and bodies . When the chief prison guard a German woman opened the cell the following morning the cloud of vapour that issued forth was so great that she slammed the door shut again and went to fetch the commandant . When they both returned the prisoners were released having spent from 6 pm the previous evening until 8 am that morning confined in that tiny space . Fifteen of the prisoners had died others had fainted . Mrs van I. tried to revive them with artificial respiration . An SS doctor was called . He followed his instincts as a doctor rather than as a good Nazi and tried to help the women by 8 tering injections . All the women were now taken to other cells in the prison block this time no more than 2 or 3 prisoners to a cell . They were given food and straw to sleep on . After four days they were forced to testify that they were guilty of mutiny this was their only chance of being released . They were taken back to the barracks under cover of darkness so that no one could see what sort of state they were in . That same day the doctor flew back to Berlin/GPE and reported the camp commander a few days later that same commander was sent to the/LOC Eastern/LOC Front/LOC . The girl around whom the whole incident had erupted was kept in prison and there she stayed until June 1944 . Accused of fomenting the disturbances she was then returned to the camp for a couple of days before being sent to RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP . Mrs van Ipern was not the only one driven to collapse by these terrible events and was hospitalised for a fortnight . Even today her ability to work is severely hampered as a result of this and other wartime experiences . All the women continued working in the Philips workshop . In September 1944 further transports of Jewish prisoners arrived in Vught/LOC from other camps . The rumble of cannonfire could be heard in the distance and Dutch Nazis were fleeing to Germany/GPE with their families . On 5 September many of the younger prisoners were shot as political criminals . On 6 September the entire camp was evacuated . Prisoners were allowed to take two blankets and some food with them . Mrs van I. was loaded into a cattle truck along with 80 other women . As they travelled through Holland/GPE the doors were opened at each station and they were given water . Once they reached the German border the doors remained closed they were given nothing more to eat or drink and were given no access to toilet facilities . They travelled like this for two days and nights . On 9 September they arrived in FÃ¼rstenberg/CAMP from there they had to walk to RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP . On arrival they were made to stand out in the open for a further two days and nights . The only food they had during this time was any bread they had left 9 over from the train journey . They were given nothing else to eat or drink . As the floor of the camp was covered with coal dust it was long before the women were completely black including their eyes . The dust caused many of them to contract TB . At the end of the two days and nights they were registered and given numbers â€“ Mrs van I was . She was registered during the night and then taken to the washhouse where all her clothes were removed . In return she was given a lice infested vest and a thin dress â€“ not a prison dress but an ordinary civilian dress with a cross sewn on the back . She was given neither shoes nor underclothes . On the rare occasions when the showers worked the water came out ice cold . In the dormitory barracks eleven women had to share a bed that was only really big enough for three . They had only a layer of wood shavings as a mattress and these too were crawling with lice . They slept in three tiered bunks . The whole camp was infested with vermin . Mrs van I. stayed here until the end of April throughout this whole time she was given neither soap a towel nor fresh clothing . One of the other inmates gave her some old underwear and 2 odd socks . After a week the Philips people were selected to go and work for Siemens . The working day ran from 7 am to 7 pm with 45 minutes for lunch . Their food ration consisted of half a litre of hot water with potato peelings or water with caraway seeds or turnips . They were taken out in columns to exercise . The barracks that Mrs van I. occupied was designed for 300 people but actually accommodated women . Of the five toilets only one worked . So they were forced to â€˜ do their business â€˜ outside the barracks which meant people had to walk through the mess . The prison guards often came at 2 in the morning and beat the women with long leather whips . They were then made to stand out on the parade ground until 7 in the morning even in snow and rain . Not having any shoes Mrs van I. improvised by tying two pieces of wood to her feet with cord . She worked in the Nickelei department at Siemens chromium plating aircraft parts . The atmosphere was toxic so 10 they were given an extra ration of half a litre of milk per day . Mrs van I. gave hers to a woman who was very severely malnourished . The acid in the material they were working with corroded their clothing and before long it was full of holes . In January 1945 the temperature had dropped to minus 28 degrees . Mrs van I. managed to get her hands on a pullover in exchange for four slices of bread . There was no â€˜ pulling together â€˜ among the prisoners . People did help each other everything had to be bought . Towards the end of the war the work at Siemens came to an end and Mrs van I. returned to the main camp . Knowing the physical toll it took on the women involved she had no desire to be sent to work at the quarry . She managed to avoid it by hiding in her friend Hilde Sternberg bed . She turned up at the roll call and was counted . But then a bit later when the women were being lined up ready to go to work she found a better hiding place . Mrs Sternberg slept in the top bunk and one of the planks in the ceiling above the bed had come loose . Mrs van I. crawled inside whenever the guard came along and started lashing the empty beds with her whip to see if anyone was hiding there . From RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP Mrs van I. returned home to Holland/GPE via Sweden/GPE . Having shared the final part of her ordeal and endured the same experiences as Hilde Sternberg Mrs van I. recommends that people also read her friend account of the events described here . Mrs van I. who now lives in  Amsterdam/GPE was very sick for two full years following the end of the war . 
author lived in Berlin/GPE throughout the Hitler period hidden by GrÃ¤fin von Maltzan whom he later married . His mother was deported to Theresienstadt/GHETTO in 1942 . She died later in the same year at Auschwitz/CAMP . Maria von Maltzan was well known in the circles of the underground movement . She helped organising the escape of sixty Jews to Scandinavia/LOC . She gave a number of people asylum in her tiny flat . She was denounced at one time by a Mrs Milan . The Jewish Gestapo agent Isaacsohn and his wife Stella Goldschlag Kuebler were concerned in this incident . She was kept under close watch by the Gestapo until a Mr Hoffmann a high ranking police officer went to her assistance . During the last days of the war Mrs von Maltzan also offered hospitality to a great number of deserters from the German Forces . Illegal Life in Berlin/GPE At the time when Hitler rose to power I was still employed in a leading role in commerce . I was permitted to pursue my profession without any constraints up until 1938 . My contract was terminated without notice in November 1938 . My emigration to England/GPE which I had planned jointly with my mother ran into considerable difficulties mostly due to unforeseen personal circumstances . We therefore had to remain in Berlin/GPE . In 1939 I undertook a retraining course in metal analysis and then worked in the laboratories of a certain Dr Lewin . Dr Lewin a leading authority in the field of metal analysis was forced to close his laboratories in 1940 because of his racial background . In 1941 I came down with polymeritis . At the same time I was affected by one of the catastrophic evictions . Back then all houses that ceased to be in the possession of their Jewish owners from a certain closing date onwards would need to immediately be cleared of all of their remaining Jewish residents as well . The eviction notes were distributed by Jewish congregations at the direct orders of the Nazis . We then received an apartment on the premises of a Jewish landlord on KonstanzerstraÃŸe/STREET . In 1942 a chain of unfortunate events led to the deportation of my mother 2 to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . The pretext for my mother deportation was that the Star of David on her chest had been covered in parts by her fur boa . In September 1942 my mother was forced to conclude her life in Auschwitz/CAMP . All these events eventually persuaded me to go underground . I moved in with my Aryan fiancÃ© the Countess Maria von Maltzan who later became my wife . At this time she still occupied a small two bedroom apartment built into a former ground floor shop on DetmolderstraÃŸe/STREET . Countess von Maltzan was not an unknown figure in the underground movement . Although she was a Protestant she had become the closest confidante and associate of Father Muckermann in Munich/GPE . There she also obtained a Ph.D. in the natural sciences . When she began to feel the heat in Munich/GPE she left the city for Berlin/GPE . In Berlin/GPE in 1939 she was conscripted into the ranks of the Foreign Ministry mostly because of her excellent command of several foreign languages . Shortly thereafter she was transferred to the Red Cross search services as her anti Nazi convictions had made it impossible for her to further be employed by the Foreign Ministry . Once again my wife took up studies in her spare time this time to complete a doctoral degree in veterinary medicine . I stayed at her place for three quarters of a year without being allowed to leave the flat even just once . At this time my wife and I both lived off of her ration cards . My activities were limited to keeping our household in good order to the best of my abilities . Later my wife managed to get an editing job at a theatrical publisher . I did this work for her . My wife dedicated her days to her studies and her nights to those who were persecuted by the Nazis . In close cooperation with Swedish churches she succeeded in moving 60 people across the Scandinavian borders removing them effectively from the reach of the Nazis . One day we had Jewish writer and resistance fighter Georg Zavier visit us at our apartment . He asked whether we would be able to give shelter to a young Jewish nurse by the name of Luise Ehrenreich . Luise Ehrenreich was meant to be transported to Auschwitz/CAMP . At night she arrived at ours . Equipped with FALSE papers and a Red Cross nurse uniform she was supposed to pass over the Swiss border . In Baden/LOC bei/LOC Wien/LOC she was arrested by SS patrol guards 3 and transported back to Berlin/GPE . From Berlin/GPE she was sent on to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . Nothing is known about her fate . Nazi terror increased in step with the intensification of allied air raids . This meant that more of the men and women who had been involved in anti Nazi work had to go underground . And that is how our two bedroom flat eventually became a kind of mass asylum . The radiologist Dr Bothe HollÃ¤nder came first . After him there came my former colleague GÃ¼nther Herschel and then the chemist Willi Buschhoff . Frau Dr Lotte Bamberg a former classmate of my wife moved in with us as well . She had also endangered herself by working for the resistance movement . At around the same time my wife had already started working as a veterinarian at a local animal welfare organisation . She also received many visitors in private consultation hours so that it became exceedingly difficult for external observers to decide who actually lived on the premises and who came only to visit . In the autumn of 1945 we were bombed out . Our fellows from the resistance had to move into different quarters . Only Dr Bothe HollÃ¤nder and I stayed behind at the flat . With our dogs in our backpacks we went looking for a suitable room . We found one in the apartment of the widow of writer Emil Milan . In the meantime my wife had a wall erected in place of the shopfront which fixed our flat up to a certain degree and made it somewhat inhabitable again . Now however the flat was left with only one exit out onto the courtyard . We moved back in . In October 1943 my wife was denounced by Frau Milan who told the authorities that my wife had given shelter to Jews . Frau Milan who had herself been anonymously denounced believed to be able to exonerate herself by sharing this information with the police . The concierge warned us as she had found a note in the hallway reading At Countess Maltzan there are J ! Jews . This note had seemingly been dropped by a Gestapo officer . Dr Bothe HollÃ¤nder had to move into a different accommodation immediately whereas I remained with my wife . A few days later the Gestapo arrived . 4 Thanks to a clever diversionary maneuver by my wife we were able to distract the officers attention for a few seconds so that I had enough time to climb into the bedstead of our couch which had been prepared especially for this purpose . The bedstead had several unobtrusive air holes in it and its lid could be closed so firmly from the inside that not a single gap gave away the hollow space that lay underneath . The search lasted for four hours . As my wife recalled later the notorious Jewish Gestapo officer Isaacsohn was present at the operation . His wife Stella Goldschlag who had denounced many a Jew to the Nazis and thereby caused their arrests stood waiting at the front door . The house search did not suffice to have my wife cleared of the charges levelled against her by the Gestapo . In a ruined building opposite our house they deployed a permanent observer who took note of all people who entered our flat and spied on our guests with binoculars . The Gestapo attempted further to determine how many people were staying in our flat with the assistance of very sensitive wiretaps . A count of all breaths recorded in the flat at night was supposed to reveal the actual number of occupants . This type of surveillance failed however because in our flat there were also many injured animals which do after all breathe rather loudly as well . At night the Gestapo sent spies to peek through the windows of our flat . Eavesdropping at the door also belonged to the many types of surveillance employed against us . The head of the AuÃŸendienst of Police Department 155 Hoffmann hated the Nazis and was quite blunt about his convictions . My wife told him about the measures employed by the Gestapo . When one night somebody was fiddling with our windows again my wife decided to call the police . Hoffman and his officers arrived promptly to arrest the alleged burglar . Hoffmann pretended to be quite astonished when it became clear that the arrested men were his colleagues from the Political Department . From this point onward they left us in peace . During the final days of the battle of Berlin/GPE our house once more filled up with deserters of all military types and formations . They had received our address from other members of the resistance who had been organising for the resistance movement within the fighting troops . The exciting period of our life came to an end with the Soviet invasion of Berlin/GPE . 
World War II the author was a member of the military government in Zloczoe/GPE Poland/GPE . He lived with his family in a small flat and when his rejection of the Nazi doctrine was soon found out Poles and Jews came to him for help . Among his protÃ©gÃ©s was a Jewish lawyer Dr. Altmann and they frequently exchanged views and information . In May 1943 when the situation for Jews became critical they worked out a plan how to save Mrs Altmann . As she did not look Jewish she was supplied with forged papers and sent with another Jewess in the author official car to Lemberg/LOC . Under the guise of an Aryan she could buy a railway ticket there and proceed to Warsaw/GPE where she took a domestic job . In careful and lengthy negotiations a hiding place was then arranged for Dr. Altmann his son and his father . A small farmer nearby agreed to give them shelter and in return the author as a member of the Food Department of the Government obtained the permit for him to run a snack bar . He could thus allocate extra rations for him with which to feed Dr. Altmann and his family . On 14 July 1943 the author took leave of Dr. Altmann . A few days later a particularly brutal aktion took place in the course of which fighting broke out and a few Germans were shot . Upon repeated requests of Dr. Altmann the author went to see him one Sunday morning in August 1943 . He pretended that his car had broken down and called for help at the snack bar . The farmer asked him into his own room where he met the sadly changed Dr. Altmann . Together they went down into the stable which housed 3 cows . Under the trough was a small hole through which the men had to crawl into a tiny windowless space . A small drawing attached to the document explains the lay out . The news that Dr. Altmann survived was given to the author by another Jew Joseph Batisgh whom author had taken into his house as a servant on the recommendation of Dr. Altmann . Mr Batisgh was an accountant by profession and friendly relations between him and the author family were soon established . Whenever danger threatened Mr Batisgh and other Jews spent the nights in the author kitchen but when Zloczow was declared Judenfrei in July 1943 it was decided that Mr Batisgh and his wife had to go underground They found foster parents for their small child who however died 6 months later . The young couple went to stay with a Polish farmer in a village nearby . For more than a year they lived in a camouflaged potato camp until the Russians arrived . In 1946 the author heard from Mr Batisch that they had survived . In his concluding remarks the author explains that his Catholic faith and abhorrence of the Nazi crimes made him act as he did . Remarks . The author was traced by the Wiener Library following a short note in the SÃ¼ddeutsche Zeitung Munich/GPE 19 December 1957 describing his attitude during the war . The Rescue of Two Jewish Families by a German Civil Servant in Poland/GPE During the war I was employed by the Generalgouvernement the German administered part of Poland/GPE during World War II at the department for Food and Agriculture and came to Zloczow/LOC in Galicia/LOC from November 1941 where the District Office was headquartered . My job was to record and distribute the agricultural products and to monitor all operations associated with food . When I first came to Zloczow/LOC I had a small room in the home of a Ukrainian cleric and after several weeks I was assigned a small flat by the District Office giving me the opportunity to have my family visit me temporarily from the Reich/LOC . I had only been in Zloczow/LOC for a few weeks when I was approached by Polish as well as Jewish circles mostly academics as far as these still existed who soon found out that I was somewhat different to the other Germans and had kept a clear view with regard to politics . It was a Dr. Altmann who came to visit me often concerning all kinds of pleas and concerns . I provided help as far as was possible . In some instances I had to be extremely careful in doing so as a { the } Gestapo was also present in Zloczow/LOC who had already put me on the black list due to an encounter before the war . It was Dr. Altmann who recommended Josef Batisch to me as a housekeeper . As I had my family join me in January 1942 I was very grateful for this service . Batisch who was about 28 years old back then turned out to be a very pleasant and highly respectable character to whom I could entrust my two 2 children 2 girls aged 9 and 11 without hesitation . We developed a relationship as is only possible in a healthy family environment . B. who was an accountant by trade felt safe and comfortable in our home as he knew he was living with a German family who had the necessary understanding for his situation . My children were and still are very attached to their Josef who now lives in Denver/LOC Colorado/LOC USA/LOC . It was therefore very hard for our family when Mr. Batisch could no longer stay with us because of being a Jew and had to leave us in the summer of 1943 to go underground . I still remember today how I discussed all options with Mr. Batisch in particular how we could stay in contact and should we survive the war and the Third Reich we promised each other to meet again afterwards . So Mr. Batisch had my home address which he actually used later when he sent the first sign of life in 1946 from Bad Gastein/LOC in Austria/GPE . Naturally for my children who had been raised with the Christian Catholic faith there was no place for the Nazi ideology . Even the lessons at school could not convince them ultimately it was just the understanding and opinion of their father that mattered to them . No teacher at the school could change that . However they were smart enough not to compromise their parents at school . It is this attitude which helps to understand why my children did not see Mr. Batisch the Jew but Josef the person who protected them from the outside world as much as they were his faithful friends and advocates at home . In the spring of 1943 the so called actions against Jews started 3 in Zloczow/LOC . One of them took place on 2 April 1943 . If such a danger presented Mr. Batisch did not go home as usual but he stayed and slept in our kitchen . During these actions which took place several times throughout the next few months and were always unannounced my flat was always the refuge for several Jewish families . If I was being visited by colleagues or other Germans at the time our protÃ©gÃ©es disappeared in the cellar and adjacent rooms of course whereby my children were always most worried about their Josef . In July 1943 the time came when Zloczow/LOC was declared as clean of Jews which means that anyone was entitled to shoot a Jew on the spot if he came across one . Such cases did really occur . We now had to see how we could help our protÃ©gÃ©es over this horrific time . For with the ever closer approach of the front the day would come when my family would have to return to the Old/LOC Reich/LOC just as the civil administration would be forced to move away one day . Consequently it was important to find a way which was safe enough for our protÃ©gÃ©es during the transition period as well as with the arrival of the front . We came to the conclusion to seek refuge in the countryside . Josef Batisch and his wife found shelter with a Polish farmer in Remizowce/LOC about 10 km south of Zloczow/LOC after having handed their one year old baby to a farmer for fostering where it died unfortunately after six months . You have to imagine the pain a young woman will feel when being separated from her own child like that . But 4 under the given circumstances it was a desperate need to hand the child to foster parents so as not to risk to be caught out by the child crying . Josef Batisch lived with his wife in a camouflaged potato clamp about 30 m from the farm from July 1943 until the arrival of the Russian troops in July 1944 . So Mr. Batisch and his wife had to live in the most difficult circumstances for a whole year . We stayed in touch of course but had to be extremely careful indeed and just verbally through the farmer himself . He reported back to me about Mr. Batisch as he brought food and medication to them from me . In the middle of 1944 I left Zloczow/LOC with the civil administration after the German women and children had already returned to the Reich/LOC in January . Mr. Batisch now had to fend for himself and until the Russian troops arrived this must have been the most difficult underground existence for him and his wife . Sure before I left I provided Mr. Batisch and his wife with all kinds of things . I returned to Krakow/GPE and had lost our connection . It was only in 1946 that Mr. Batisch sent message to my home address in Nuremberg/LOC from Bad Gastein/LOC in Austria/GPE about his rescue . I would have very much liked to have Mr. Batisch and his wife whose health had suffered greatly and who are still not fully recovered today join my family where they would have found far greater and more favourable care for their health than in Austria/GPE in foreign Bad/GPE Gastein/GPE for sure but 5 the regulations of the occupying allied forces in those days were more than strange and despite my greatest efforts with the competent occupation authorities a correspondence with Austria/GPE was not permitted . Before Mr. Batisch left for America/GPE with his wife in 1947 he now lives in Denver/LOC Colorado/LOC we were able to meet twice namely at the border by Bayerisch Gmain near Berchtesgaden/LOC in Germany/GPE which was prohibited . I succeeded with another rescue from the claws of the henchmen with the family of Dr. Altmann . Dr. Altmann was a lawyer and lived with his family wife 10 year old son and 65 year old father in Zloczow/LOC . Dr. Altmann visited my flat frequently and discreetly . He kept me up to date about local occurrences and I in turn told him about any actions against Jews that were to be expected as much as I knew about these . When the situation for the Jewish population became ever more critical in May 1943 and their total extermination had to be expected seriously we deliberated together how a rescue could be possible . We sat together for many hours and hatched all sorts of possible and impossible plans . First of all the wife of Dr. Altmann had to be brought to safety . As a woman she had already made the future situation which was only set to become worse even more difficult . Finding shelter for Mrs. Altmann was not too big a problem as she did not look Jewish and could easily pass as an Aryan with her blonde hair in an area where nobody knew her . It was decided to bring her to Warsaw/GPE as going into hiding was easier and less risky in a big city . Already on 29 May 1943 Mrs. Altmann and another 6 Jewish woman were driven to Lemberg/LOC which was 80 km away by my Polish chauffeur in a company car . Travelling by train was generally forbidden for Jews and not possible either as Mrs. Altmann was a well known personality in Zloczow/LOC and would have been easily recognised at Zloczow/LOC train station . So we had no other option and had to take the risk of travelling in my company car . From Lemberg/LOC Mrs. Altmann travelled to Warsaw/GPE with a fake passport and took up a position there . So the lady was safe for now . After careful consideration of all circumstances Dr. Altmann decided to negotiate with a reliable Polish small farmer he knew in Jeleohowice/LOC about 2 to 3 km from Zloczow/LOC whose small property was situated directly on the road between Zloczow/LOC and Brody/LOC . We agreed that the farmer would be given permission to run a small breakfast bar approved by the Food Department I was working for which was reasonable as the property was located favourably on a busy through road to Brody/LOC . This way the owner of the breakfast bar was automatically assigned a certain amount of food every month determined by me which of course benefitted Dr. Altmann and his family and the farmer himself also received some for his willingness to help . I also applied for the official permission to run a breakfast bar in case I was moved away from Zloczow/LOC so that Dr. Altmann and his family would still be catered for with regard to food . Dr. Altmann visited me in my flat for the last time on 14 July 1943 . It was high time for him 7 to go into hiding in his hiding place . As he had stayed longer this evening than the curfew imposed on Jews I accompanied him home at 10 pm that night to ensure his safe return . It was hard for both of us to say goodbye . The fact that we had chosen the right time for Dr. Altmann to disappear was confirmed by the radical actions against Jews that started on 20 July which were performed with unprecedented cruelty . The Jews that had stayed behind in Zloczow/LOC finally gathered and shot back on 22 July . A proportion of them barricaded themselves in the attic of the Zloczow/LOC town hall as well as adjacent houses . There was considerable gunfire on 27 and 28 July 1943 and the German police also had to accept some losses . The gunfire only ceased on 29 July . In the meantime Dr. Altmann sent word to me through his Polish host in several letters which of course did not mention any name . Amongst others Dr. Altmann asked for an allowance of alcohol . I I sent him some bottles of vodka which of course were not for him to drink but were for medical as well as hygienic purposes and as I will detail further below were of enormous use to him and his family . His need was completely understandable to me . He confirmed receipt very soon . Unfortunately I was not able to keep these letters from him as I myself did not feel safe from the Gestapo and therefore destroyed all correspondence immediately . Dr. Altmann asked me several times to visit him in his shelter . I hesitated first of all as this posed a significant risk to me . I only agreed to visit him on Sunday 8 August 1943 after giving this some careful thought and after being 8 repeatedly urged by him . I let him know that I would visit him in the morning while the family of the Polish farmer was in church . I drove to the near Jelechowice/LOC around 9 am in my company car unaccompanied and without chauffeur . I stopped in front of the house of the supposed breakfast bar opened the bonnet and started tampering with the cooler of the car pretending to need some water for it . I entered the house where the farmer was already waiting for me greeted me in hushed whispers and led me to his parlour ceremoniously where he asked me to take a seat . He then disappeared immediately and left me on my own . I listened tensely and did not hear the slightest sound in the house . Waiting for further things to happen I saw how the door was opened after a short time and Dr. Altmann appeared dressed in a nightgown barefoot in light sandals . The farmer retreated and left us alone . I was quite shocked by the sight of Dr. Altmann who approached me pale and looking like a ghost and held out his hand to me . The greeting was accordingly the impression it left on me inextinguishable so that a flowing conversation was impossible . At the end of the conversation Dr. Altmann asked me to come with him downstairs so that I could see his hideout and see for myself the conditions him and his 65 year old father and 10 year old son had to endure . He led the way and guided me down small wooden stairs at which end he opened a door and we entered a stable which housed three cows . To gain a better impression I am attaching a drawing showing a cross section of how and where Dr. Altmann and his family were sheltered . 9 The floor plan of the stable might have been 6 x 4 m. Dr. Altmann showed me a hole in the brickwork below the feed trough in the cattle box sized about 40/30 cm leading to a hidden room of about 3 4 m2 and a height of approx . 1.5 m. A room where you could neither stand up straight nor stretch out with stuffy air and not a single ray of light . They had to endure these conditions until the front arrived . As we stood together in the stable Dr. Altmann pointed to an ashlar rock lying below the feeding rack amongst the cows which would be inserted into the brickwork by the farmer in case of danger . Only blankets were used in the hideout on which they could sit and lie . Furthermore there was a bucket for human needs onto which a small tabletop was placed when the farmer handed food through the hole . The room could only be left by its occupants in the middle of the night to breathe some stable air or at best to get some fresh air in the farmyard . But even there utmost care had to be taken . Now it becomes clear why alcohol was asked for to wash and maintain a scanty level of hygiene . 10 The farmer was reliable as well did not let his family in on the secret at least not his children to prevent any type of betrayal . He would also place the ashlar rock back in the brickwork very carefully as soon as Dr. Altmann had gone back in . My farewell from Dr. Altmann whom I had seen for the last time on this occasion was more than moving . I could barely believe that people could exist in these conditions for a whole year . This only seems possible if those concerned have strong confidence and a firm hope of being saved . Needless to say that this experience affected me greatly emotionally and adding to this burden was the fact that I was not able to share any of my concerns with those around me . Mr. Batisch whom I met in secret in 1946 and again in 1947 at the Bavarian Austrian border the occupying allied forces had stopped and prohibited any communication with Austria/GPE ! told me that Dr. Altmann had survived the war and was living in the east . I have not yet been able to establish contact with him . These lines might help to open up the chance of sending some sign of life . My explanations of the events portrayed are partially based on my memory which has remained clear despite the long period that has passed since which does seem understandable as such experiences are unique and will therefore stay with a person forever . However my diary also provided valuable information in particular 11 with regard to dates . Even though I kept a meticulous diary during the war I was only able to record a rough outline of these events for obvious reasons of my own safety . However these were sufficient for me to provide a reliable timeline . Finally all this begs the question what my reasons might have been to take such an enormous risk for myself as well as my family and offer my help to rescue these creatures who had been dealt such a heavy hand by destiny . Asking this question demands an answer at the same time . While I was often horrified at home even before the war by the injustice in many areas and the sheer brutality of the Nazi ideology this can not be compared to what I then had to experience during the war in the east . The more nastiness and savagery I saw the Polish population subjected to by the SS as well as the civil administration the more I felt the urge to help those that were suffering . Despite the great victories gained by Hitler I was absolutely certain that the day would come when justice would triumph over injustice . By getting involved personally to help those in need I believed to best serve my fatherland as the world had to realise one day that there was another side to Germany/GPE as well . My religious belief also helped me in my doing . If these lines help to heal the wounds 12 we have inflicted on the Jewish people most of all I feel great satisfaction and am glad that my actions at the time have somewhat contributed to an emerging communication . 
19 March 1944 the Nazis occupied Budapest/GPE and after a very short time the terror of chasing looting humiliating the Jewish population was spread all over Hungary/GPE . The authoress lived at PÃ©cs/GPE a town with a community of Jews p.1 . Together with her husband and their eighteen year old son she had to move into a small kitchen at the Ghetto but soon all men had to join labour companies and the rest of the Hungarian Jews apart from those at Budapest/GPE were evacuated by rail to destinations unknown p.2 . The PÃ©cs/GHETTO Ghetto was the last to be emptied 7 July 1944 .
