Click here to read more about this project . Auschwitz/CAMP RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP and Reinickendorf/CAMP . The experiences of a Hungarian Jewess 1944 1945 . During the war I lived with my husband and my son in the Southern Hungarian city of Pecs/LOC German name Fuenfkirchen/LOC . However when the Germans occupied Hungary/GPE on the 19th of March 1944 I was staying for a short time in the capital Budapest/GPE with my son who at that time was 18 years old . We succeeded with difficulty and hardship in returning home . All of the stations were already keenly watched the police conducted a real manhunt for Jews who wanted to travel to Budapest/GPE or to leave it . At the entrance to the station a policeman let me pass but caught my son by the arm and wanted to take him away . I began to scream and cry and begged the policemen to let my boy go free . The man certainly had a bit of human feeling and after a long to ing and fro ing he finally let us both pass . Arriving in Pecs/LOC we found everything there was still peaceful but after a few days even there as in all parts of the country there was a regime of terror . All Jews had to wear the yellow star from the 4th of April onwards and from then on new special laws against the Jews appeared almost daily . They had to hand in their valuable objects their jewellery and their radios their wealth was confiscated and Jewish businesses closed . Pecs had a large Jewish community of around and also a considerable number of Jews lived in the small villages that surrounded the city . They were all now drawn into the maelstrom of destruction . The order came at the beginning of May that in Pecs/LOC as in all of the other Hungarian cities with the exception of Budapest/GPE the Jews had to give up their residences and move into a ghetto . Each person was allowed to take 50 kilogram of luggage with them . The ghetto in Pecs/LOC was created in a suburban area outside of the city . The Christian residents who lived there were evacuated and were assigned better residences . By contrast the Jews were herded together into small rooms . We were able to count ourselves lucky that we three were allocated the kitchen of a small house in this ghetto area . Others were sandwiched much more tightly into small rooms . 2 â€“ In the first days my husband who had a leading position in a large industrial company still went to work . Though this soon stopped . The entire ghetto area was cordoned off . It was guarded by the police and the gendarmerie . New transports of Jews from the neighbouring localities and also from the city of Mohacs/LOC were herded in . The crowding became increasingly unbearable . Then came the conscription of the men for forced labour . The conscription order was delivered to the ghetto . My husband went to a forced labour company in Szigetvar/LOC and my son to one in Mohacs/LOC . With this the entire family was riven asunder . We women had to carry out garden work around the ghetto area . When I returned in the evenings tired from the work to the small kitchen room I found now and then a hurriedly scribbled message from my husband or my son tucked into the door . Someone from the labour company had smuggled it through . By contrast letters which we wanted to send by regular post came back as undeliverable . Several weeks passed like this . Mainly only the women the children and the old men remained behind in the ghetto . News trickled through that the ghettoes throughout the land were being cleared and the occupants were being deported in train waggons to an unknown destination . Also our turn would come . However for unknown reasons the ghetto in Pecs/LOC was the last of the Hungarian/GHETTO ghettoes to be liquidated actually on the 7th of July . When we were deported on this day from that time on the entire Hungarian province had become Judenrein/LOC / free of Jews . Jews remained only in the capital . We were herded together into an even narrower area in the stables of the barracks a few days before the deportation . Now the Hungarian gendarmes and the German SS were in charge . The treatment was unbelievably brutal . We were driven and harried like cattle . In between there were body searches which in reality meant that everything that we had with us was stolen . Money valuables and even wedding rings were taken away . The midwives from Pecs carried out body searches on the women . Finally every one of us received a piece of bread and another piece of rotten sausage as food for the journey . We were herded to the railway area and packed into waggons like animals . There were around 75 people to a waggon . During this indescribable scenes took place . Sick people who could not go were pushed or thrown in . Pregnant women and babies were added to this . A bucket with water and another 3 â€“ for use as a toilet were placed in the waggon and then the doors were closed . We travelled throughout 3 days and 2 nights without receiving any further food or having the water renewed . We went through the station at Kassa/LOC German name Kaschau/LOC and there the doors were opened for a short time . However nothing was reached in . Only the bodies were taken out â€“ at this time every waggon already had several dead . Then the journey continued onwards . It was unbearably hot inside the waggons and the air was suffocating . People driven to despair by the heat and by thirst ripped the clothes from their bodies . Some had fits of raving madness . Once again there were several deaths . Late in the evening of the 9th of July it was already completely dark the train finally stopped again . After a wait of several hours the doors were yanked open and the order to get out given . In the darkness we stumbled out into the fresh air . We had no idea where we were . Later when by some means we learned the name of the station this name meant nothing to us . No one of us had previously heard of this place before . The name was Auschwitz/CAMP . All around us was shouting and pandemonium . Orders which we did not understand were yelled out . We found ourselves on a type of ramp from which we were ordered and pushed down . A column was formed in the darkness in which the rows became confused and individual family members lost each other . As far as we were able to make out SS men and also women in SS uniform stood around us and yelled at us and drove us forwards with the help of beatings and kickings . There were other forms recognisable nearby dressed in the striped uniforms of prisoners mainly women . These engaged themselves in pulling out of the waggons those who could no longer lift themselves up by themselves . All of this proceeded with unbelievable brutality . We were driven along a path whereby truncheon blows rained down on us constantly from both sides . Scenes occurred on the way the meaning of which we were only able to understand much later . Still on the ramp when everything was muddled and confused it occurred that a woman wearing prisoner clothing lunged at a young woman who was deported with us and who held a small child in here arms . She ripped the child out of her arms and ran with him straight to another group of deportees and pushed the child there into the arms of an old woman . The mother ran after her screaming and attempted to get the child but in the disorderly turmoil the groups moved apart and the little child with the old woman remained to the immense despair of the mother . 4 â€“ We only learnt much later the implications and importance of this action . That is at the selection all old people and all small children were sent automatically to the gas chambers . In addition also all women who carried a child in their arms were sent . The young woman who had the child taken away from her was saved in this way . The child and the old woman were lost in any case . The selection took place under floodlights . We learned later that the name of the man who had sent the individual victims either to the right or to the left was Dr. Mengele . The meaning of this process was also only clear to us later . I myself went with a group of younger women to the right . We were now conducted to a building where we still had nothing to eat but at least after many days we received fresh water to drink for the first time . Then we went into another room where we had to undress and were searched in the most brutal of ways . Anyone who still had the slightest thing with them had it taken away . We were only permitted to keep our shoes . In the next room we went under the shower and were then hustled onwards our hair was cut off and that involved not only the head but also all of the body hair was shaven . This all took place in the presence of SS men who went here and there urging us onwards and shouting at us . Most of us were much too exhausted and too apathetic to rebel somehow against this treatment . However if anyone made a sign of resistance or a gesture of modesty they were immediately mistreated with blows and kicks . In this way the final ounce of human value was beaten out of our bodies and we were completely degraded to animals . Finally after all of this was over we were allowed to dress . But all of our old things had disappeared never to be seen again . We were only allowed to keep our shoes which were completely wet through . We received as underwear only a rough shirt and no trousers . Then everyone of us received a piece of clothes that was thrown at us which in most cases did not fit but which we had to put on immediately . Some got torn evening wear others in turn received the remains of uniforms or prisoner clothing . In summary we all appeared as caricatures . Finally we were pushed into the open air . Two further days and nights passed during which we only received hard bread to eat and had to stand around until we were finally herded into the so called B camp and were accommodated there . Because in this barrack there were neither plank beds nor any other camp facilities the accommodation consisted of lying on the bare earth jammed together where most people did not even have enough room to stretch their limbs . 5 â€“ We stayed several weeks in this camp . The ranks thinned out because many died every day in addition there were selections time and again . In addition new groups were also added . We had to carry out the bodies ourselves using sheets as litters the same sheets that the bread was brought into the barracks on . Besides the bread for nourishment there was a type of dehydrated vegetables as well as a soup in which long hard inedible threads or muck swam . Non one wanted to find out what in reality it was . The general opinion was that it was broom bristles . This brew was brought in in large dirty troughs whereby a trough came for every 5 women . Without any cutlery or spoons we had to slurp the pulp from these nauseating troughs . There was no water at all to wash and very little to drink . You were only allowed to go to the latrines at certain times . SS men stood around there and made their humorous remarks . An epidemic broke out soon after our arrival and almost all of the inmates of the barracks were afflicted by it . The mouth swelled up the body was covered with a type of leprosy and there were open wounds on the legs . During the selections which would sometimes occur several times a week we sought to hide traces of this illness in order not to be sent to the gas chambers . In the selections naked we had to file past a row of SS men . I had a large wound on the thigh . I succeeded in hiding it by marching past the selection committee with my arms stretched out on my legs in military strictness . We were not made to work . However standing in the assembly was a particular torture which lasted for hours every time . During this if you were caught not standing sufficiently straight enough you had to do innumerable knee bends as a punishment . There were blows and beatings in addition at every opportunity . In this it was not only the SS people who distinguished themselves in this but also the Capos and the latter consisted mainly of Polish women who had been in the concentration camp for years and who were completely brutalised . We had no contact with the other parts of the Auschwitz/CAMP camp . Despite that news trickled through . At the end of July or the beginning of August we heard that a riot was supposed to have taken place in the gypsy camp . We also heard in our own barracks wild screams shots and the barking of dogs from the gypsy barracks . This lasted for many hours . Later it was said that the riot was put down by the SS and all of the inmates of the gypsy camp had been taken to the gas chambers . 6 â€“ In August many Polish Christians arrived in Auschwitz/CAMP whole families with children . They talked about the uprising in Warsaw/GPE . The majority of them were led to the gas chambers . In the middle of August we women from the B camp were deported away . Again we were put in waggons . This time there were around 50 people to a waggon . Before that everyone received a piece of sausage and a piece of bread . The journey lasted more than 24 hours . We froze terribly in the night in the thin clothes that we had on . The doors of the waggons stood open . During the entire journey an SS man and an SS woman stood guard . Both of them paid little attention to us and devoted themselves completely openly and unashamedly to the joys of love . On the next day at daybreak we arrived at Ravensbrueck/CAMP . In contrast to Auschwitz/CAMP where the look of the area had been bleak and dismal with scarcely a tree to see and no birdsong to hear Ravensbrueck/CAMP was situated in the middle of beautifully wooded surroundings . However we did not have much joy in that . At first we had to stand and wait for hours and then we were herded into the camp where we spent a further 24 hours in the open air without receiving anything to eat or drink . We were still primarily together as Hungarian Jews and the group from Pecs/GPE was also still together . But the total number had declined dreadfully . We had to lie down in the open air on a type of coal tip and we were black and dirty from head to toe . Then we were herded into a barrack in which at least there were plank beds and we received something to eat which was more substantial than we were used to from Auschwitz/CAMP . We stayed for 8 or 9 days in Ravensbrueck/CAMP which were filled in part in lying in the barracks and being fed and in part being driven out into the open air for a roll call where we had to constantly stand for many hours on end whilst SS people and capos who surrounded us on all sides regularly hit us with sticks obviously for no reason at all or because it pleased these completely dehumanised women . Once again at the end of August or the beginning of September we were herded into waggons and taken under very similar circumstances to our previous journey to Reinickendorf/CAMP near Berlin/GPE . There we went to a smaller work camp whose barrack rooms were furnished with wooden beds and small table and wooden stools all of which given what we had up till then endured 7 â€“ appeared as an unbelievable luxury . The guards here consisted partly of SS personnel and partly of Wehrmacht soldiers . The latter were replaced later by Gestapo officials . Soon people in civilian clothes also appeared and asked after our jobs and our skills and work groups were put together . We went to work in the Argus aeroplane factory in Reinickendorf/CAMP where we had to work in two 12 hour shifts changing weekly from 6 am in the morning till 6 pm at evening to 6 pm in the evening to 6 am in the morning . Apart from us forced labourers and prisoners from all nations worked in the factory . There were French Russian Czechs Yugoslavs and men and women of all ages . The forced labourers were in a bit better position than we prisoners . They had the opportunity to go into the city and were also better fed . They were forbidden to speak to us . However they slipped us bread cigarettes or food whenever the opportunity offered itself . Our work consisted of simple hand work on machines . I never grasped and I can still not say today what sort of work we performed . It was certainly of not much value and as a result the foreman who was in charge of the supervision threatened to send us back to the concentrations camp . So our circumstances were bad enough . When we were sent back from the factory to the concentration camp there would always be a roll call during which there would be beatings on the part of the SS people again and again . Our position worsened at the end of January 1945 . Only a few remained in the factory . We Jewish prisoned were driven into the surrounding fields and woods and had to dig trenches there for the whole day long in the bitter cold . The instructions for the construction of an extension of a defence position were given by military engineers . However the supervision remained in the hands of the SS who were now even crueller than before if that was even possible . There were beatings at every opportunity . We froze terribly in our thin clothes but it was forbidden to protect ourselves against the cold . If the SS people or the female SS guards found out that someone had wrapped around their body a rag or a cloth that they had found against the cold then they hit the unfortunate woman with sticks and clubs and more than once it happened that the person was hit so long until they lay there dead . In addition to the cold and the abuse there was the torture of hunger . A result of the undernourishment which had by now lasted for months and also the present hard work and the completely inadequate food was that for many female prisoners nutritional oedemas appeared . The face and the limbs swelled up . We knew that in such cases the fellow sufferer was lost . 8 â€“ Anyone who reported sick was taken away and we never heard anything from them again . On the 15th of March the fate of being taken for very special treatment different from the usual general mistreatment overtook me . Around this time we heard the thunder of artillery in the distance and the advancing front line and I expressed to a fellow prisoner that the Russians would soon be here and possibly that we would die before they come . This comment was overheard by a capo who immediately reported it to the SS . At first I was punched several times in the face by a female SS guard then I was taken away and sentenced to 25 strokes with a stick . I was laid on a wooden block and another female prisoner was ordered to hit me with a stick on my body . When she did not do it hard enough the female guard took the stick herself and completed the punishment herself . At the end I hung semi conscious over the block . I do not know if anyone counted the number of blows but in my opinion it must have been more than 25 . In addition on the same day my head was shaved completely and I was threatened that I would receive more strokes every evening . I would probably not even have survived a single repeat because I could neither sit nor walk . But in the following days my comrades in misery hid me regularly in their ranks and so in any event it remained a threat . Slowly I recovered more or less . The work on the trenches and redoubts continued but the signs of panic and confusion by the leadership increased . At the end of April we were no longer driven from our barracks to work . One day it could have been the 27th of April we were assembled and marched off in rows of 5 . The SS personnel were a bit friendlier to us and one of them said that he would personally cook us a good soup . He even did that but nothing good came out of it . All who had taken the soup suffered terrible diarrhoea on the subsequent march which was just that bit worse as we were not allowed to break ranks or even to stop . We were driven along further at the greatest possible speed and arrived on the same day at the Oranienburg/CAMP concentration camp . There complete chaos prevailed . Thousands of prisoners men and women stood and went around between the barracks . All order had evaporated . My attention was especially drawn to the large number of children who they had apparently herded here from somewhere just at this time . SS personnel ran around with their rubber truncheons some attempted to bring some type of order to the chaos others again were blind drunk . At several places ample food was distributed . There was even milk rice . 9 â€“ In the evening it was announced by the SS that everyone must assemble in groups . The camp had to be cleared by midnight because then it would be blown up . A small group of Hungarian Jews got together and we decided not to march any further but to hide . We slipped into one of the bigger barracks and hid between the plank beds . Several times the SS opened the door and called that everyone should come out but apparently they did not dare to come inside and search the barracks . We remained silent and stayed where we were . Finally after many hours when complete tranquillity had occurred outside we slipped outside . Similar groups who like us had kept themselves hidden also appeared from other barracks . We also noticed that some SS personnel who were no longer in uniform but had put on civilian clothes were hurrying to the camp exit . We bumped into a group of Dutch and Belgian prisoners who were in a better physical condition than us and who now took over the leadership . They set out to investigate if the guards had disappeared from the camp . Because from time to time shots were heard from all sides we hid ourselves again in another barracks that was filled with bodies . We huddled for a long time behind the bodies and between the dirt and faeces . Then the Dutch and Belgian came back and said that the coast was clear . We came out again the SS had disappeared we were free . However some days passed before the Russians occupied the camp . We received some food from them and a Russian lorry took us to Landsberg/CAMP where they had established a large quarantine station . All of the main roads and also Landsberg/CAMP itself were filled by a vast amount of liberated forced labourers prisoners prisoners of war and so on who were all trying to go home . In Landsberg/CAMP itself there were many French prisoners of war . However these soon went home . Then the Poles the Czechs and the Yugoslavs were gradually transported home . We Hungarians had to wait more than 3 months until we had the possibility to go to our homes by way of large detours . It was only on the 13th of August that I reached Budapest/GPE and then got back to Pecs/LOC from there in a short time where I found my husband and my son already safe and sound . They had both survived the worst of times in the forced labour companies in different places and then after the failed separate 10 â€“ peace attempt of Horthy on the 15th of October 1944 found themselves together in Budapest/GPE . There they then spent the rest of the time of persecution in hiding . Signature of Janka Galambos The eye witness Frau Galambos lived for several years after the war with her husband and son in Pecs/LOC . The family then moved to Budapest/GPE where they survived the years of the communist regime . After the Hungarian uprising of October 1956 the whole family fled to the west . The son is abroad . Frau Galambos and her husband have settled in London/GPE and both have jobs . Signature of A. Szanto 
description of the illegal life led by a Jewish woman who went underground 6 months after the death of her husband in Berlin/GPE . Non Jewish friends provided her with FALSE papers refuge at their own or friends houses and with food fuel and ration cards . Her submersion was prepared by her present husband Arthur Veit who at the time lived in the same flat . Among the people who gave her refuge were a landed estate owner and adherent of the Confessional Church Wolfgang Lent on his estate near Landsberg / Warthe a Catholic family in Duesseldorf/LOC Terwort/LOC a woman doctor in Berlin/GPE Lichterfelde Dr. Stoltenhoff the mayor of a village near Rheinsberg/LOC Georg Steffen . She was persuaded to go underground by the former editor of the social democratic paper Vorwaerts Alois Florath who died during the war who had heard in autumn 1942 from a policeman about the experiments made with gas vans for extermination . Other people who helped Mrs Veit during her illegal life were Friedrich Kroner after the war editor of the Frankfurter Illustrierte Dr. Stadtler formerly with Ullstein Prinz Salvator von Isenburg Dr. Schattauer her doctor Herta Zerner social democratic journalist Bruno Manuel journalist Otto Suhr the present Lord Mayor of West/LOC Berlin/GPE 9 . Untergetaucht In mid 1942 people believed that the only way to secure protection in Berlin/GPE was by forced labour or employment within the Jewish community before evacuation . In August 42 we received another call for evacuation these calls were always disguised as a summons entitled Residence of the Jewish community . An over eager young doctor presumably employed by Prof. Lustig in the Jewish hospital â€“ came to us to confirm the fact that my husband would not be fit for transportation . I remember exactly how the gruesome grotesque scene unfolded how my emaciated crippled terminally ill husband was forced to stand up and move around as she filled out the assessment . He died a few weeks later . The funeral was led by a man approved by the local authorities who was still permitted to use public transport and make phone calls . The day after the funeral I walked across town and went straight to the Jewish employment agency to apply for work in a factory . The woman in charge whose name I unfortunately ca remember shared some confidential information with me they had received a call a few days ago asking them to name all of their employees who were single . These single people would be taken away regardless of their job status â€“ so she discouraged me from registering . The cemetery administration also had to pass on lists of those buried in the cemetery so in theory my protection ended the day my husband was buried . After his cremation I asked the man in charge to postpone the scheduled burial of the urn . I then waited a while before writing to the cemetery administration to inform them that I was ill and in no condition to come to Weissensee/LOC I was allowed to travel b y public transport for the burial and asked them to postpone the urn burial until I was in good health . A few weeks later I was informed by the cemetery administration that the ground was so frozen that it would be possible to bury the urn until the New Year . As a result I was safe for three months after the death of my husband . I left in the New Year . My school friend Alice Schnell who worked in forced labour for Siemens arranged for the urn to be buried at the same time as her aunt who died before she was evacuated . The burial was scheduled to take place on 28 February 43 . But a few days before this she received news â€“ I do know where from â€“ that a sudden â€˜ collection of Siemens employees was imminent and would take place without warning . 2 My husband urn was placed with his parents but would eventually be lawfully moved to another location where my other family members were already buried . I rarely left the house after my husband died because more and more people were being taken off the street and taken away for the slightest thing . It was like watching dogcatchers . Another reason for my reluctance to leave the house was that the plans for my disappearance had come together . On 3 January 1943 a survey was circulated to gather information about marital status . The Jewish community was obliged to complete the survey and return it within two days . It seemed like the perfect time for me to escape . . . so I left on 7 January 1943 . At my husband requested I collected barbital . Over the course of two years I collected four tubes of it . I did keep it because even though I did see any way to disappear in the time following my husband death and felt completely useless and unprepared it never occurred to me to take my own life . After his death a relative from NeukÃ¶ln/LOC arrived on 19 October 1942 and begged me for the barbital . She worked for the Jewish authorities so she and her husband were protected from evacuation . They took their daughter Alice Jacobsohn to a Jewish children home in southern Sweden/LOC when the war began . Then the Gestapo demanded lists of certain local government employees this is how strict and sneaky Nazi bureaucracy was and received certain information . I tried to give my relatives the courage they needed to come up with the best solution but ended up giving them the barbital . A week later I learned that they were both dead and had been buried . In the mean time they tried to persuade me to disappear . Alois Florath former editor of VorwÃ¤rts was the first person to immigrate to Prague/GPE . But while he was there he developed pernicious anaemia and went back to Berlin/GPE to be with his wife and doctor . He was allowed to return based on his wife diplomatic status and he subsequently worked as a non political cartoonist . He regularly worked with a former police commissioner at Souchay â€“ a company that the Nazi had no legal control over . He was summoned to travel with the Berlin/GPE Jewish transport company the Jews would be handed over to the Gestapo or SS at the border . In the autumn of 1942 he heard about the buses being used for exterminations as they passed behind the 3 Czech border . They were known to Florath and his colleagues . It was clear to me that it made absolutely no sense to travel with them it was a path to certain death . I knew I had to try to save myself for the sake of my son . This was also the first time I had heard of this sort of extermination . At this point I realised that even F1 was not a safe place to be . Veit my partner lived in the same apartment in which we met â€“ a real rarity at this time . He had been encouraged several times to move out of the Jewish apartment but he merely pretended to be looking for a new place . He convinced people that we lived separate lives in the apartment that we each had our own entrance our own allocated times to use the kitchen and did really know each other . He maintained that our situation was to make our lives a bit easier for example with the small things like cigarettes white bread and milk â€“ things we could get anymore and that when our Aryan friends came to visit they used his door instead of mine . After spending a lot of time trying â€“ and failing â€“ to come up with ideas he finally figured out a way to obtain a legal birth and christening certificate for me using the name of an old friend . As soon as I had these documents our old friend Friedrich Kroner was able to make things happen for us . Kroner himself was in a â€˜ mixed race relationship as his wife was Aryan . She was a really active helpful woman . After the war he established the Frankfurter Illustrierte â€“ the best illustrated newspaper in Germany/GPE â€“ in it current form . I was introduced to Dr. Stadtler who was originally born in Alsace/GPE and worked as the editorial director at Ullstein Verlag for many years before the Hitler Regime in the hope that his job status would help us work against the regime . It should have been clear to him straight away that this idea would work . As I got to know him I believed he was unemployed but somehow officially registered as employed in manufacturing . In reality he worked on the black market all the time waiting for the fall of Hitler as is way into politics . I think he belonged to a centre or people party . His older son was in the German army and at that time based in Rome/LOC where he fell in love with the daughter of an immigrant art dealer . His wife Christin Dr. Stadler had just returned from Rome/LOC after going to meet the bride . During her trip she made the secret engagement official and arranged for her son and his love to be married after the fall of Hitler . The last time they heard from their son was before the allies landed in Sicily/GPE . He then went missing and presumably died in the first battle after the landing . 4 Unfortunately before he died my husband witnessed the Germans hoisting the flag on the summit of the/LOC Caucasus/LOC Mountains/LOC and died with the feeling that we had lost to them . When I met Dr. Stadtler in November 1942 the situation could not have been more different . Dr. Stadtler used a map of Russia/GPE that he knew very well to point out the German front and show us that defeat was imminent . He also emphasised that I should try to cross the border during this time . He then took me with him to see the catholic priest in Frohnau/LOC where he lived in the hope that he could give me a FALSE identity card or passport . But a week later the passport supplier was exposed and as far as I am aware the priest also had to â€˜ disappear for a while . Dr. Stadtler along with one of his co conspirators then made his first attempt to find me refuge with one of his other co conspirators â€“ a landowner . I was registered with him starting 7 January 1943 . Veit my husband would still be named as a contact person . On the evening of 6 January he brought a suitcase containing my most important possessions to Zoo train station and in the morning I left the house to meet Kroner . He would take me to the train heading for KÃ¼strin/LOC . The train leaving at the same time from the next platform was an official train . Lots of high status officers stood beside the train in their brown uniform draped with medals . Wolfgang Lent the Lord of the Manor â€“ and his wife were waiting for me at the small station in Lipke/LOC village . They had a sledge ready to transport my suitcase through the snow to the castle . He was an incredibly intelligent and well read man and the owner of a large library . Apart from Lent his wife and the inspector no one was allowed to know my identity . And then the training began . I had to verify that there was no record of my monogram anywhere always thinking about how I behaved in different situations and how I answered questions . Shortly after the radio channel announced that lots of German nationals had registered with the job centre and taken up work which made everything more difficult . Between 10 and 12 French prisoners were employed as farm workers officially in a strictly segregated camp but in reality they were always in and out of the castle . I stayed there longer than originally planned until one night the inspector delivered the news that the bicycle seller in the neighbouring town â€“ who was a close friend â€“ had been arrested . His arrest led us to the conclusion that the Gestapo from 5 Landsberg am Warthe were blackmailing people . The castle had already been searched â€“ a document had been filed to the Gestapo in Landsberg/LOC about Lent himself . So that night I packed my case and got up at 4 am . One of the French prisoners who was standing at the door with a horse drawn carriage ready to make the two hour journey through the fields in the dark until we reached our destination of a neutral train station . In Berlin/GPE I met Lent again but could travel any further due to the ever stricter train controls in the East/LOC . I am still good friends with Mrs Lent today . She now leads a somewhat modest life in LÃ¼beck/LOC with her three children but is still regarded as the wife of a refugee by the locals . After volunteering himself Mr Lent was drafted in to deal with the complaints on behalf of his inspector . Part of the reason for his drafting was that like many others he believed that the collapse of Hitler was imminent . He went missing in Silesia/LOC shortly before the war ended . In the meantime Dr. Stadtler had found a new accommodation for me this time with friends of his wife in DÃ¼sseldorf/LOC . I stayed with a friend in Berlin/GPE until it was time for me to go . Opportunities were more limited by this point because even at this stage mixed race families were already being rounded up . For two days Jewish family members â€“ especially husbands â€“ were taken away . This Nazi exercise failed as the courageous â€˜ Aryan wives staged a protest next to the centre where their husbands were being held . The protest was so fierce that the Nazis had to give in and let everyone go . Stadler also sent me to friends of his in Germany/GPE Ms. Von Paczenski and Generalswitwe Tenczin . Mr Ladewig held a high position in Westermann publishing house and despite being married to a Jewish woman still went on business trips to Paris/GPE . They had a very good marriage . If I saw any officials during my day to day life and had to protect myself I hid my documents in my shopping bag and made sure the bag was as far from me as possible either in a corner or under a bench . Mr Terwort represented the whole family in the party . His membership card was kept in a drawer in the kitchen table and I had to get a monthly ticket from the cashier . Every morning he brought the newspaper into the kitchen and we discussed the likelihood of the fall of Hitler . When it was time to return to Berlin/GPE I had to travel by passenger train . My stay in Kagar/LOC where I was know as Charlotte Klose the name on my birth certificate â€“ features on page 102 . 10 The mayor of this tiny village â€“ whose family had been mayors of the same village for generations â€“ joined the party in 33 . My next stop was Lichterfelde/CAMP Ost/CAMP a suburb of Berlin/GPE that I had never visited before . A good friend of Florath worked there as a doctor . Dr. Stoltenhoff who now lives in West Germany/GPE belonged to a practice . Her first marriage was to a mixed race man which led her to lose her position as a recognised doctor . She was forced to set up her own practice in order to raise her children from her first and second marriage . Joining the party was her only option . The bombings got worse and she worked in the doctor surgery day and night . She was an intelligent and skilful woman . After Alois Florath died his wife tried to find another alibi for me in the village . There were only a few people in the villages who had a position within the party â€“ they were know as the NSV leaders â€“ so I stayed out of their way as far as possible . Mrs Florath used some sort of excuse to take me to one of the leaders and told him that was leaving me her typewriter so that I could take care of her late husband manuscripts and the estate he had left behind . In reality this did not need to be done . But the NSV leader said that he knew of a landowner who urgently needed a capable secretary . I then had to go to the labour office where they were able to help me find a post easily . I really do know how we pulled it off . In any case I had to tell different stories until the war ended in order to get the work I so desperately needed from the labour office . In Kagar/LOC I had to sit for hours by an open window and type anything that I heard coming from outside the office . The writer Peter von Hamm was a good friend of Herta Zerna . After the war he worked as a dramaturge in the German theatre then was suddenly arrested by the Russians . We do know why he was arrested but he later died in a concentration camp . Before he died he would send envelopes containing newspaper cuttings to our isolated village . These envelopes were always addressed to Miss Klose . They would also contain work from Berlin/GPE for me and I would take them to the real addressee . In certain circumstances I had to go to Berlin/GPE to deliver work in reality I went to our piece of land in Meilensee/LOC . Thanks to Otto Suhr â€“ the current mayor of Berlin/GPE â€“ and his wife I did have to stay in an unheated house while I was there . He had also got to know the mayor of Kagar/LOC through Herta Zerna . So when things in Berlin/GPE got a bit 13 difficult he and his wife would come to stay with the Steffens for a few days . Since he came from the area that I often stayed in in Meilensee/LOC they offered us some briquettes that they had stored in their cellar . Veit took them little by little from the house in Meinlensee/LOC . The journey to Mellensee/LOC was mainly on local and city trains . You could usually be sure that you would be checked . And I had already figured out that to get past the military controls in Zossen/CAMP and WÃ¼nsdorf/CAMP all I had to do was walk confidently with the silver shield pressed against my chest . It was best if I walked behind the deserters because they would go straight to the controls to ask for information . On this particular journey luck was on my side . A cordon at the train station and checks on the trains in search of escaped prisoners and polish farm workers was taking place on the day that Veit took the earlier train . He knew that I originally wanted to take the later train so he decided to come back and let me know what has happening . The day time bombings were getting worse and worse and as a result two things happened on one hand there were far more days filled with confusion and on the other hand it became more and more important not to attract attention . Up till this point the people who stood out were the busybodies and the informers . In the last few months of the war you could even travel the short distance from Rheinsberg/LOC to Berlin/GPE by train without a permit . But because I still officially had work to collect in Berlin/GPE I snuck out of the house before dawn and went to Herta Zerna house . There I hid in the basement ate the bread I had brought with me and went back to the inn when it was dark so that I could talk to the guests about the journey to Berlin/GPE the next day . The last time â€“ in March as the tracks of the refugees from East/LOC Prussia/LOC and Pomerania/GPE became visible on the country roads an NSV official came to the village to visit Herta Zerna and allocate some refugees . For whatever reason she managed to delay him by one more day . She was very skilful . The staff followed the paths that the refugees had taken . The paths veered to the West and used our village as a sort of temporary location . I had a somewhat distressing experience at the end . Everything was gone even some of the families from the village had left heading west on their journey . The Russians had to be quite near we were waiting for them calling it the calm before the storm . Then two young soldiers appeared at the inn with the order that they should wait by the telephone and pass on any relevant information . We sat with them in the restaurant 14 trying to gently make it clear to them that they could illegible their lives if they gave up on this pointless task and abandoned the illegible . One of them 25 years old at most and obviously an academic or student he told us that he was married and had a young child instantly became defensive expressing his distaste at the suggestion that he should disobey what his spiritual leader Alfred Rosenberg had said and written . He spoke in a string of well formed sentences but I ca remember what he said word for word because although everything sounded clear it was still confusing . I saw for myself how an intelligent person had been so convinced by nonsense and was willing to give his life based on what he had been told . The end began after we had greeted the first Russian tank . There was one more counter attack from Germany/GPE â€“ target from the surrounding forests â€“ and in the last few seconds of the night from 30 April to 1 May I got injured another concussion and a hole in my temple . I think it was caused by a grenade shell which landed in our stable . I had to walk around with a dressing on my head luckily this was uncommon . The village remained cut off from the rest of the world for another seven weeks . For this entire time I had to stay close by the mayor coattail . As a result even the GPU â€“ who had been staying with him for a while â€“ left us alone . A delegate from the socialist communist party in the neighbouring village came to us and asked him to keep his Amz ? But after I left the Russians arrested him . I am sure this happened as a result of informing people and harassing former Nazis . When the news reached us in Berlin/GPE he was already well into his train journey . We spent months years looking for him in an attempt to free him and then we heard that he died in a concentration camp six months after he was arrested . Veit was still around when the war ended . When he heard that his office would be closed and merged with the armed SS he fled Berlin/GPE and made his way to Meilensee/LOC . By this point Mellensee/LOC was occupied by the Russians . After seven weeks he made his way to me . It took him several days to reach Kagar/LOC on foot and then go back to Berlin/GPE with me . And then I hid away in the very same â€“ albeit Â¾ damaged â€“ flat that still belonged to him . The same flat I once fled . 
witness a doctor receptionist by profession was sent from Theresienstadt/GHETTO to Auschwitz/CAMP in January 1943 . Working as a nurse in Block 10 she frequently saw Dr. Clauberg arriving by car from his private clinic in KonigshÃ¼tte/CAMP . He always wore civilian clothes . Block 10 had been part of the male section of the Camp and was erected on the site of the former quarantine station . Here Dr. Clauberg and his assistants Dr. Schumann Dr. Wirtz Dr. Munch Dr. Weber and Dr. Gobel carried out the notorious experiments . They were aided by Dr. Poring originally a prisoner who went over to the Germans and Dr. Samuel who wrote a scientific study on their work and who was shot later on . In the estimate of the witness there were approximately 500 women in the block who were always changing as those unfit for further experiments were sent back to Birkenau/CAMP or gassed and replaced by newcomers frequently selected directly from the arrival platform . The selections were mostly made by Dr. Wirtz and Aumajer . The experiments were carried out with some of the products of I.G. Farben who paid the camp administration through Dr. Clauberg for this arrangement . At some time Block 10 was intended to be closed down but Dr. Clauberg prevented this in order to continue the experiments . Once about 90 women were sent to the Rasseninstitut at Innsbruck/CAMP their fate is unknown to the witness . The experiments consisted of 3 painful injections administered at intervals which induced sterilisation . After each injection an x ray was taken . Dr. Clauberg attitude was cynical and obscene . The witness corroborates other statements that selection for Block 10 was equivalent to a death sentence . 9 . Further References Sylvia Friedman now Vesela assistant to Dr. Clauberg . In December 1942 I was brought to the camp in Theresienstadt/GHETTO and from there I was taken to Auschwitz/CAMP at some point in January 1943 . First I was in block no . 15 in Birkenau/CAMP . After approximately a month there I was taken to block no . 30 or no . 31 in Birkenau/CAMP and a few months later I was taken to block no . 10 in Auschwitz/CAMP . I know that the experiments began in the Birkenau/CAMP block which Dr Clauberg and I think Dr Schumann carried out . Dr Clauberg came to Birkenau/CAMP in his car from his private clinic in KÃ¶nigshÃ¼tte/CAMP and he was the only one of the SS as far as I could see that wore civilian clothes and did wear a uniform . The experiments carried out in Birkenau/CAMP were initial experiments . 2 Block No . 10 in Auschwitz/CAMP was part of the male camp even though women were housed there . It was built on the site of the previous quarantine station of the men camp . Dr Clauberg and Dr Schumann did their experiments in this block . Also Dr Wirtz Dr MÃ¼nch Dr Weber and Dr GÃ¶bel then also Dr DÃ¶ring who was originally a prisoner but then registered himself with the Germans . There may possibly have been others but I ca remember any others . The imprisoned doctor Dr Samuel also worked here for Dr Wirtz . When he wrote about the results based on the experiments carried out with the help of his medical expertise he was shot and Dr Wirtz picked up his work . I worked as a nurse in block No . 10 . On the ground floor there were two rooms which were provided for the doctors work . But the women rooms intended for the experiments were on the first floor . The staff including nursing staff lived on the ground floor . As a nurse I worked the same as the rest of the staff for both rooms and therefore for all of the doctors who did experiments in block no . 10 . Aside from the women who were experimented on there were also sick people there whose illnesses had nothing to do with the experiments . This was kept secret however as otherwise they would have been sent to the gas chambers . To my knowledge on average there were around five hundred women who were experimented on . There were around five hundred the actual population varied continuously of course as some left who were sent back to Birkenau/CAMP and other new women topped up the numbers again . The newly added women were selected directly from the transport on the train station . I can not say with certainty who selected them but I believe it was usually Aumajer and Wirtz . I do know if Dr Clauberg made selections himself and I can not claim that he did . I do know however that Dr Clauberg was also an agent for I.G. Farben and that he paid a certain sum for the management of the concentration camp in Auschwitz/CAMP on behalf of this company . For this sum he bought the concentration camp women who were selected for experiments using products of I.G. Farben on living healthy women . I know that the administration of the concentration camp wanted to close down block no . 10 . But Dr Claubergâ€˜s main task was to work on these experiments and he had an interest in it continuing and prevented the closure of block no . 10 . He needed these women for his experiments and it being closed down would have meant they would be sent to . In block no . 10 there was to my knowledge Dr Clauberg assistant Sylvia Friedman now VeseiÃ¡ who knew the most about Dr Clauberg experiments . I know that classification in the Birkenau/CAMP labour camp meant death for every woman . 3 I remember a case where a certain number of women were selected from block no . 10 from the staff in the block and from other women in order to be sent to Innsbruck/CAMP to a race institution . Then approximately ninety women were sent however none of the staff from block 10 were there . I do know any more about the fate of these women after that . I also know that some women were sent back to Birkenau/CAMP after the end of the experiments . From time to time transport went from the block to Birkenau/CAMP and transport also came to block no . 10 with new women . What I know about the experiments of Dr Clauberg is that the women were given injections containing some substance or another in three intervals so in three doses which was supposed to sterilise the women . However I do know what the injections were made up of . An x ray image was taken after every injection . The injections were painful as a result of them the women had ovarian inflammation and had fever which was however suppressed with the help of medication from the SS hospital . Dr. Claubergâ€˜s behaviour with the women he carried out experiments on was cynical . He made inappropriate comments and jokes . The women were of course scared of him but they had no choice . I do not know about the surgical experiments carried out by Dr Clauberg i.e. ones other than the ones I have already spoken about . Dr GÃ¶bel participated in the experiments as a chemical employee . I know that there were deaths in block no . 10 but I can not claim that these were cases that were a result of Dr Clauberg experiments . I know that those who were sent to Birkenau/CAMP after Dr Clauberg experiments died there and that there were only a few that survived the work in Birkenau/CAMP . I wasnâ€˜t there during the last phase of evacuation of block no . 10 as block no . 10 was taken to a new SS camp and as I was evacuated from this camp I was together with the women from block no . 10 . I met many of them on my way though . My overall conclusion about the experiments is that it was horrific . Dr Clauberg visited block no . 10 from outside was there all the time I ca remember what his relationship was like with the other doctors it is such a long time ago . In my opinion based on the whole issue even taking into consideration the amount of time that has passed I regard Dr Clauberg as a 4 war criminal as he deprived hundreds of young women of the possibility of fertilization and therefore the possibility of a proper existence . I think it is most urgent and necessary that Sylvia Friedman is questioned as she knew the most with respect to all of the details of Dr Clauberg work .
