Milman a Polish Jew worked as a gardener at the house of SD HauptscharfÃ¼hrer Gustav Wilhelm Maybauer from Berlin/GPE outside the ghetto in Radom as the Nazis allowed Jews in Radom to work only if in possession of special identity papers issued by the SD . In 1941 Mr Milman was transferred to an arms factory . When the Russians approached Warsaw/GPE he was sent to various concentration camps Tomaszow Mozowieck Auschwitz/CAMP Winenden/CAMP near Stuttgart/CAMP Unter Rexingen Kochendorf/CAMP and in 1945 to Dachau/CAMP . Conditions were the same everywhere inmates who had to work under inhuman conditions died of hunger and privations or were brutally shot . In 1945 Mr Milman was evacuated in the direction of Seefeld in Tyroi/LOC he escaped and was liberated by the American forces in Bavaria/LOC . 4 . Date 1939 1945 . 5 . Number of pages 4 . Language German . 6 . Author or Source Paysach Milman . 7 . Recorded by Dr. Fritz Friedlaender . Experiences of a Polish Jew in Ghettoes and Concentration Camps When the Nazis invaded Poland/GPE in 1939 the 18 year old unmarried Mr Milman lived with his parents together with 2 brothers and 5 sisters . He worked with his father in the leather trade . In the fourth week of the Nazi occupation he fled with 5 other young Jewish people to Lemberg/LOC which was then occupied by the Russians and was considered safe . Thousands of refugees had gathered there already and not only Jewish refugees . The group of the 6 young Jews remained together and carried out casual labour . Because the Russians mobilised skilled workers and forcibly enlisted those fit for military service for the Red Army Mr Milman voluntarily returned to Radom on 31.12.1939 out of fear to be enlisted by the Russians . Here he experienced the usual persecution measures by the Nazis the enlisting of Jews to degrading forced labour such as street cleaning etc . Abuse of Jews of all kinds the forced resettlement to ghettos carried out under the lead of a Judenrat Jewish Council K.W. the ever deteriorating famine the recruitment of Jewish workers for the construction of fortresses at the German Russian border . Mr Milman lived unregistered and hidden with his family in the ghetto his father could only support the family with savings because he had been forced to liquidate his business . 1941 a member of the Jewish militia gave Mr Milman the urgent advice to take on such employment for which the SD issued special identity papers for essential employees because only holders of such special identity papers were exempt from the imminent evacuation . On this advice Mr Milman accepted a job as a gardener for the SD HauptscharfÃ¼hrer Gustav Wilhelm Maybauer from Berlin/GPE other than him two young Jewish girls worked there . He continued to live with his family in the ghetto and went every day with his identity card to work at Maybauer house located outside the ghetto with whom he did not come in contact even though he had the opportunity to the see him coming home blood stained because the execution of any kind was part of his obligations . When a large evacuation took place at night in 1941 Mr Milman family was also deported he never saw them again . The two Jewish girls who worked with him lost their families in the same way . Mr Milman remained alone in the house at first until a general relocation 2 of the Jews to a downsized ghetto took place . There murders happened on a day to day basis Jews either were killed on the spot or abducted to be shot . The sparse food that was given out at the ghetto had to be obtained by food tickets . On 13.1.1942 another resettlement took place only younger Jews â€“ about 1200 â€“ stayed behind . Those Jewish workers employed by the SD were registered there was a rumour of a plan to exchange them for the Templars in Palestine/GPE . But instead the SD administration received the command to let go all Jewish workers . One morning people of the Jewish militia came to collect Mr Milman early in the morning from his bed and brought him to an arms factory where he as a worker was replaced by two 2 carpenters . In this factory located in Radom 2 â€“ 3000 people were occupied with the manufacturing of guns there was no pay but a starvation diet the people had to sleep in barracks â€“ like cattle . The downsized ghetto was liquidated and converted into a concentration camp surrounded by barbed wire the remaining inmates were divided into workers they had to wear inmate clothing instead of plain clothes and work hard despite the worst alimentation . Mr Milman worked at the arms factory until the advance of the Russians on Warsaw/GPE 1944 . The labour camp in which he was was then evacuated and moved to Tomaszow/CAMP Mozowieck/CAMP about 2 â€“ 3000 Jewish workers were forced to march for two days and two night without sleep elderly members of the marching column who could not walk any further due to weakness were shot on the spot . When the survivors arrived in Tomaszow/CAMP â€“ near Lodz/GHETTO the women were quartered at the town jail while the men were remained guarded in town for three days with no occupation . Then â€“ it was in the summer of 1944 â€“ they were transported to Auschwitz/CAMP on a cattle truck with no food . As found out after the war in general and also to Mr Milman the Nazis transported the women to Auschwitz/CAMP as well in separate cattle trucks . A selection took place upon arrival remaining children and youths were sent to the gas chambers . The women stayed in Auschwitz/CAMP their fate is unknown to Mr Milman however he does know that some of them survived . Himself was because he was deemed fit to work spared . He had to take a seat in the cattle truck again with the others who were spared and begin the long journey to the new concentration camp Winenden/CAMP near Stuttgart/CAMP . The accommodation was the usual for a concentration camp many 3 inmates died of starvation . The Nazis planned to use the inmates for the construction of an underground factory . Shortly afterwards Mr Milman was transferred to another camp that was only being opened â€“ Unter Rexingen â€“ where only 400 randomly selected Jewish workers were tasked to dig underground tunnels for the construction of a factory . They had no water to wash and only a weak coffee sludge to drink . When the very hard 1944/45 began many Jewish inmates died either from hunger or cold . Mr Milman saw many acts of violence by the SS who beat Jewish inmates to death on the spot . After two months the Nazis sent two groups of Jewish inmates to other camps . Mr Milman got to Kochendorf/CAMP where the concreting of floors in salt pits was commanded for an underground factory site for Messerschmitt Flugzeugwerke Aircraft Works K.W. . Here the conditions were even worse that before the Jewish inmates had to get up at 3 or 4 in the morning march from the barracks to the salt pits for an hour into which the conveyor caged were lowered to work hard in shifts of 12 hours without food . In the twilight of the salt pits the kapos pummelled them in the most brutal way . Being sent to daylight after work the Jews had to march several km . back to the camp often stand in the cold for hours during the evening roll call so we would only get the food which consisted of a thin soup a little bit of bread margarine a bit of sausage at 10 in the evening and then to go to bed at half ten which ended before the break of dawn . Under the threat of the American offensive the Nazis commanded at the beginning of 1945 the evacuation of the camp the Jewish inmates only provided with a small piece of bread were sent under SS surveillance on death marches from the salt pits to the concentration camp Dachau/CAMP while the SS commander had them carry his bed . On the march many died of exhaustion a vehicle pushed by the inmates collected the bodies and semi dead who were dumped into a mass grave a few km . on . When the survivors spent the nights in stables etc . it occurred that they â€“ tortured by hunger â€“ drive way pigs to subsequently voraciously devour the pig food . The death rate was so high that the SS commander eventually assumed that he would only arrive in the company of his SS men in Dachau/CAMP . Therefore he commandeered milk and raw potatoes in a village and had them distributed . The consequence was horrible because only some bothered to boil the potatoes instead of eating them raw an epidemic of dysentery broke out so that of the original 2000 Jewish inmates only 4 about 200 remained who were loaded on cattle trucks that drove the last part to Dachau/CAMP where they were â€“ half starved â€“ brought to get deloused and bathed to get a little bit of food afterwards . During the last time before the liberation there was no more organised work at the concentration camp Dachau/CAMP however many Jewish inmates died of hunger or by weakness . According to Mr Milman observation both the German Army as well as the SS already seemed disorganised when the SS Commando gave the command to evacuate the camp towards Seefeld/CAMP in Tyrol/CAMP in April 1945 . During the march a part of the SS did no longer keep up the surveillance some however still used weapons and Jewish inmates died as the last victims . One group which Mr Milman was part of managed to escape and to march towards the American troupes to Mittenwald/LOC in Upper/LOC Bavaria/LOC . They stayed the nights at barns and were liberated on 1 May 1945 by American troupes . Mr Milman remained provided by UNNRA at a hotel in Mittenwald/LOC until 1949 where he carried out casual work for instance in the kitchen . The Radomir Committee an ethnic aid organisation enabled him to come to Melbourne/GPE Australia/GPE in November 1949 . During the ship journey he met his future wife Livia Bluecher whom he married in May 1950 . He works successfully in the scrap material trade in his new home . 
the beginning of the year 1936 the authoress who lived in Breslau/GPE Silesia/LOC made an insulting remark about GÃ¶ebbels she was denounced summoned to the Gestapo and released after three days of solitary confinement . At that time the large Jewish Community of Breslau was more annoyed than anxious and the authoress was optimistic enough to return to Germany/GPE from her trips to Czechoslovakia/GPE and Switzerland/GPE some months later . On 14 October 1936 she was summoned to the Volksgerichtshof p.3 and sentenced to nine months imprisonment for the crime of Malicious Attacks Against The Government Of The Reich . The textile manufacturers whose commercial representatives her family firm had been for 50 years were forced to give notice and the business in which Miss Lewin had been working as a partner was dissolved . Visitors able to help commercially were admitted to the prison without restriction so she could see her cousin brother in law and partner . For some weeks she was kept in the same cell as Rosa Luxembourg/GPE before her p.3 4 . The Manageress of the prison a Catholic lady who was obviously not pro Nazi behaved very friendly towards her p.4 . Her passport was confiscated by the Gestapo but after her release on 14 July 1937 she immediately applied for another in order to emigrate to some English relatives . She got it after Christmas and was allowed to take her jewels with her as well as Â£ 200 . Miss Fellner at Woburn House helped her to get permission for some work to do i.e. translating and interpreting for immigrants . From 1940 1943 she lived in some places in the provinces where she gave lessons . Back in London/GPE she occupied herself with teaching members of the British and American forces who wanted to learn German . 9 . Further References Non Jews helping Jews p.4 . The Dresdner Bank dismissed Jewish employee after 27 years p.2 . Nine Months In Prison For Incitement Name Lotte Lewin . Place of Birth Breslau/GPE 6th January 1892 . Area of residence before emigration Breslau/GPE . Profession In Germany/GPE Languages teacher Secretary . 1914 17 Secretary for the American consulate . Then librarian for the public library and for the law and political science faculty of the University of Breslau . Religion Jewish . Father Businessman with concerns in the textile industry . He came from the German province of Posen/LOC . Died in 1921 . Mother Without profession the daughter of a Jewish teacher she also came from the province of Posen/LOC . Died a natural death in 1934 . Following inflation the salary rate at the university worsened considerably for Lotte Lewin . So she decided in the year of 1923 to enter into the textiles business of her deceased father in order to maintain it for her mother . The company where the Lewins warehouse was situated had for years employed a Christian worker whose loyalty was doubted by no one . He was as the correspondent reported certainly no Anti Semite and as he later testified what happened was on no account an outcome of malicious intent . At the beginning of the Nazi regime everything relating to the business continued similarly as before the sales even increased further and the Christian factory owners showed no signs of Anti Semitism whatsoever . The Jewish company distributed amongst other goods a red fabric which even though it was without the swastika symbol found use as material for flags and much of it was bought by shops . At the beginning of 1936 when Goebbels was supposed to be coming to Breslau/GPE for an event Lotte Lewin referred to Goebbels as the spawn of filth and fire in a private conversation with the Christian employee who was mentioned above . The young man who did not know this quote from Faust appeared to be amused by it and related it to a lady friend whose brother was in the SA . This brother felt it was probably his duty to report it further to the Gestapo . 6 weeks after the conversation Lotte Lewin was unexpectedly summoned to the Gestapo who had their main office in the police headquarters . The people there all wore black glasses which Lotte guesses were probably to arouse yet more fear in the public . No question was asked quietly she was only screamed at . She tried to twist the comment about Goebbels by making it appear as if Goebbels 2 had applied this quote to Jews in his speech against them . She attempted to make it seem like a misunderstanding . She did not know that the young man had been interrogated in a very rough way just before her . Because of this her manoeuvre did help at all and she went directly without being able to go home in between to a remand prison where she stayed for 3 days in solitary confinement . On the second day as she was led to cross examination the young man was present . He was very cowed and uncertain as accusations were made against him that he had participated in political discussions with a Jewish lady . They tried to persuade them both that the conversation in question had been overheard how he and Lotte Lewin were suspected because of holes which Nazi neighbours had supposedly bored into their walls . But the whole thing was clearly a trick in order to try and unsettle them . On the third day L.L was released . Prior to this she had to sign a document stating that she would do nothing against the Reichsregierung and would in no way engage herself in politics . Immediately after her it was currently she went to see her sister who she met with in a synagogue . The husband of her sister was later dismissed from the Dresdner Bank commissioner after a service of 27 years . Back then in 1936 in Breslau/GPE where there was an especially large number of Jewish people living one generally seemed not to be sufficiently perturbed and viewed the whole matter of the Nazis more as a transitional period . The businesses carried on and so relatively few Jewish people emigrated . One was more angry than fearful . Lotte Lewin distinguished herself through a misguided optimism and following the experience described above even travelled for Pentecost to see friends in Czechia/LOC GrÃ¤fenberg/LOC for 10 days . She was warned there against going back to Germany/GPE however she turned back to go to Breslau/GPE . She travelled again in the August of the same year for 3 weeks to Switzerland/GPE where she stayed until the beginning of September . Because she owned a passport she could travel unhindered . From Switzerland/GPE L.L. wrote to relatives in England/GPE about her imprisonment although she clearly did not see or did not want to see the seriousness of the situation . The relatives who were aware of the German state of affairs promised her security immediately and requested that she would come to England/GPE forthwith . However she wanted for as long as she had her existence not to emigrate and be a burden to others . 3 It was arguably only when on 1st October 1936 she received a summons to appear before court on the 14th of October that she became deeply conscious of the danger in which she found herself . Finally she now wanted to leave the ownership of her passport would have made that possible especially as Breslau/GPE really was not far from the country border . Now however her relatives her brother in law and a cousin insisted on her first consulting a lawyer . He trivialised the issue and pointed out that she would probably qualify for an amnesty that had recently come out . So she stayed and went on the 14th October to her court hearing in the Volksgerichthof . It became a secret meeting all of the approx . 200 people had to leave the room . The young man to whom she had said the indiscriminate comment about Goebbels was present as a witness . He reportedly testified under oath that she was responsible for the comment . L. L. supposedly stayed with her former claim that she had only quoted the words Goebbels had expressed . The prosecuting attorney sentenced her to 2 years in jail because of incitement . The court ultimately agreed on 9 months . She was immediately led off to prison . Now she was distraught and reproached herself for not fleeing early enough . She even wanted to take her own life she made herself very ill about it . Her lawyer who came to visit her brought her back to reason . There was also a Rabbi Dr Hoffmann who came to the prison every three weeks and consoled her . Incidentally he expressed later that he could always recuperate a little when visiting her after he had seen and heard much worse elsewhere her attitude would be so positive . The business was along with her things disbanded . The manufacturers who had represented the company of Louis Lewin for more than 50 years were forced to terminate their business with Lotte Lewin and her associate . As the prison regulations gave the prisoners the right to receive visits from people who could help in matters relating to business her brother in law cousin and associate could come to her more often . She was allowed to have other types of visit only every 4 or 6 weeks . For the first 6 weeks of her imprisonment Lotte Lewin lived in a solitary confinement cell . It was same one that Rosa Luxemburg had once been within . Like her L. L. fed the birds . Though she only received insufficient food there was still more bread than she could consume . So she would place her 4 table beneath the high up window then put the chair and a stool on that so that she could climb onto them and then lay the crumbs on the windowsill . The blackbirds quickly grew used to being fed and would come early every day and in the evening and comforted the prisoners with their chirping . Atop her construction she could also look out the window at the Star of David of the nearby Synagogue at the verdigris roof of the museum also at the courtyard next door where the male prisoners did their daily walk . Amongst them to her utmost horror she also sometimes saw familiar faces . An important role was played by the directress of the prison who visited all of the cells every morning . She was a benevolent understanding lady a catholic who L. L. felt showed through her conduct not through her words that she was not pro Nazi . With her L.L could discuss specific questions and wishes . Above all she wanted to have a job however this was not possible at that time for even outside a shortage of work prevailed . She recommended that she should occupy herself in the prison library however even this was not permissible as political offenders were not allowed to work there and come into contact with other prisoners . The prisoners were only allowed to write and receive letters once a month . Only business was allowed to be sent out more often . However everything went under the censorship of the directress . She soon realised that they were not dealing with a real political prisoner here and furthermore this prisoner was commended to her by a friendly outward manner . Because of this L. L. received special permission to receive letters and write as much as she wanted . Once when the Generalstaatsanwalt was supposed to come on an inspection visit the collection of letters were picked up and kept secure by the directress herself however L.L. got them back when she left the prison . After three days L.L. was made exempt from the standing to attention when one name was called and one crime malicious attacks against the Reichsregierung identified . You know how it is done however do not forget in the case of an inspection . The head patrolwoman of the prison and her young assistants were in contrast to the directress extremely coarse and often screamed at the prisoners 5 only one was friendly and nice she was also a catholic . On the daily walks in single file all conversation was forbidden still L.L. soon learnt to like the others talk inaudibly that is to say without moving her lips and by these means she discovered much of her fellow prisoners . The prison library contained many good books even some which were no longer allowed outside under the Nazis so for example Thomas Mann books . Catholic literature was readily available . For her study L.L. busied herself primarily with English literature and English shorthand . She was also allowed to do needlework which she could send to her sister every week . One day a man from the Gestapo also again equipped with black glasses entered her cell and demanded that she would give in her passport . If the passport is not there within a week something will happen . This threat pertained to her siblings who had the passport . The prison Rabbi took it upon himself to warn her brother in law . And so her passport was handed in . On the 14th of July 1937 L.L. became free . Her relatives were awaiting her before the portal and it immediately appeared strange to them how she behaved anxiously spoke quietly looked around timidly . Upon her questioning she discovered that people from their circles who after being liberated from prison had apparently been rearrested and had been brought into KZ/CAMP . L.L. soon requested for the issuance of a new passport for the purpose of her immigration to England/GPE yet she only obtained it after Christmas . So she travelled in August to Bad/LOC Kudowa/LOC zur/LOC Kur/LOC . In prison she had lost 20 lbs during the 9 months . She had all kinds of afflictions in other ways as well . On the 3rd March she then immigrated to England/GPE . At that time she could take Â£ 200 and her jewellry with her . She came on the warrant of her English relatives with whom she also initially lived . However she did not have a work permit . With the financial aid of Miss Fellner of Woburn House she obtained in June 1938 the approval of the Home Office to work as a translator and interpreter for immigrants who had not mastered the English language . At the same time she was strongly involved in getting relatives and friends across which was something she attempted for about 20 cases of which a great deal were successful . In 1940 L.L. was evacuated to Whitehaven/LOC and later to Darlington/LOC and supported herself through teaching . In the Summer of 1943 she returned to London/GPE where she then gave German classes for the English and American army . 
personal report by Fritz Pagel born in 1895 in Berlin/GPE . He served in the First World War and was a textiles businessman p.3 . In 1941 he and his 17 year old son were working with Siemens in Lichtenberg/LOC . Foreman Hirsch a non Nazi was anxious to help as much as possible his Jews special Jewish department Nazi inspector decent . When taken ill for many weeks Siemens paid Pagel his wages plus sickness benefit . In 1943 when underground with family he was invited by ardent anti Nazi tailor Gustke to his cottage at Herrensee/LOC near Strausberg/LOC . Many helpful German people slater Palm lent his van for removal without a penny proprietor of a garage Wolf supplies the petrol for nothing etc . p.4 5 June 1943 flight because of denunciation . Former neighbour in Weissensee/LOC Kurt Selig shelters the whole family for three weeks . In July 1943 the family was arrested and taken to the Sammellager collective camp for deportation at Grosse/LOC Hamburgerstrasse/STREET . In August 1943 the author was transported to Auschwitz/CAMP Birkenau/CAMP ./CAMP Soon after his wife and 3 year old daughter were gassed . Pagel and son were working for the Bunawerk IG Farben in Monowitz/CAMP Auschwitz/CAMP III/CAMP where the son died of pneumonia . From February to June 1945 he was at Camp Dora/CAMP near Nordhausen/CAMP where he had to be operated on fourteen times without narcosis because of frozen fingers and hand later arm amputated . 4 . Date December 1955 . 5 . Number of pages 32 . 6 . Author or Source Fritz Pagel . 7 . Recorded by Dr. H.G. Adler . 8 . Remarks Some interesting photostatic copies documents Siemens & amp Halske and his temperature chart and medical report at Camp Dora/CAMP . P.III.h . Auschwitz/CAMP No . 198 FRITZ PAGEL The fate of one individual among many thousands Recorded by H.G. Adler Autumn 1955 . I. In Berlin/GPE 1933 1942 I was born on 30 November 1895 in Berlin/GPE and spent most of my life in that city . I enlisted in 1914 to fight in World War I and was awarded the Iron Cross Second Class . I was taken prisoner by the British in August 1918 and released in October 1919 . At the start of the Nazi period in 1933 I had been married for some years and had a nine year old son GÃ¼nther . In 1940 we had a daughter Judith . I was employed in the ladieswear industry and worked at that time for a company called MOTU wholesale dealers in dresses and blouses in Kronenstrasse/STREET later Mohrenstrasse/STREET . To start with I was a travelling salesman later becoming managing director . Until 1936 I lived in Weissensee/LOC in a house that belonged to the Social Democrats and had been taken over by the German Labour Front DAF . At this point I had to leave the property and managed to find an apartment in the same district in a Jewish house in Trarbacherstrasse/STREET . After leaving elementary school in 1934 my son took up a place at grammar school but was forced to leave the following year thereafter attending the Jewish school . In 1935 I was elected onto the board of the synagogue association of Weissensee/LOC . Up until the start of 1943 services were held by Rabbi Heinz MAYER until he was sent to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . In the autumn of 1944 he died in Auschwitz/CAMP . My father died in 1937 in Berlin/GPE . My mother brother and sister escaped to London/GPE during the first half of 1939 and still live there today . In 1937/38 MOTU had a substantial turnover . We lived and worked unmolested until the November catastrophe of 1938 . I spent the evening of 9 November playing skat . On my way home there was unrest on the streets . The following morning I went to my work premises on the fifth floor of a building in Mohrenstrasse/STREET . On the way I noticed that shops had been vandalised and people were throwing rolls of fabric out of windows onto the street . I sent the Christian staff away and instructed the Jewish employees to remain inside the building and we barricaded ourselves in . Nazis tried to break in but could get to us . Apart from our premises I doubt if there was a single Jewish business in the street that escaped this orgy of destruction . In the evening I hurried home to Weissensee/LOC but then immediately returned to Mohrenstrasse/STREET where I spent three days and nights together with my brother who was also hiding there . I then ventured home once more . No one had come looking for me . Weissensee/LOC seemed to have remained relatively unscathed . My boss Hugo Schloss who had hidden in the shop fell into the hands of the Gestapo at his apartment and ended up in Sachsenhausen/CAMP . Frau Schloss asked me to liquidate the company so I sold the stock for cash at rock bottom prices . Herr Schloss was released from the concentration camp at the end of December and we completed the liquidation process together in January 1939 . Being unable to work I lived off my assets until December 1940 . During this time I tried to organise the emigration of a 2 group of people to Argentina/GPE . This was a project designed to save 100 families . The idea was for 30 people to club together to raise the sum of 5 million Reichsmark but the plan failed because no one was prepared to commit the necessary funds . All of these people were later killed . The Jewish Aid Association also refused to get involved describing the whole business as a sham . In 1939 my son was taken on as an apprentice in an ironmonger . In the winter of 1940/41 the labour exchange forced him to work clearing snow from the streets . In 1941 he tried for a job with Siemens & amp Halske . He was successful and was taken on as an unskilled labourer . He suggested I apply as well . We were both assigned to a special Jewish Department in Lichtenberg/LOC MÃ¶llendorfstrasse/LOC . A total of around 50 60 men and women aged between 16 60 worked there under a Christian foreman named Hirsch who was not a Nazi and tried as far as the situation allowed to make things easier for the Jews â€“ all unskilled workers at the beginning . Even the Nazi guard behaved decently towards them . At the start working hours were from 7 am to 6 pm with a 45 minute break . Later there was a day shift and a night shift . The Jewish workers were given papers which allowed them to come and go and to drive . Sundays were free . In addition workers were entitled to twelve unpaid days off a year . We were trained as grinders turners and millers and also learned how to operate the drilling and punching machines GÃ¼nther and I were put to work at a lathe . On the whole we adapted incredibly well and quickly to this new and unfamiliar work . During the four weeks training we were paid around 35 RM a week gross then we moved on to piecework . From our nominal wage of 48 RM we lost 15 RM in deductions for general taxes health insurance and the so called Jewish tax . This meant we only received 33 RM which was in practice the maximum you could earn because so many regular deductions were made from this nominally higher wage that you still ended up with just 33 RM . As a result I used to calculate the amount of piecework I completed so that I earned a nominal wage of exactly 48 RM . I suffered for a while from oil acne and was well provided for under the Siemens insurance scheme I even received the sick pay to which I was entitled . All was as it should be . After nine months or so my son and I were the only ones in our group to be trained as machine setters . Our job was to ensure the smooth running of the individual machines . I remained on the same wage as before however as I was not interested in a nominal increase . In the autumn of 1942 they started putting Polish civilian workers in with us in the Jewish department and we had to train them up . One lunchtime I was chatting with friends and said I have a feeling that one day all the Jewish departments will be closed down and all the Jews will be taken away . I do want to be amongst them . II . Living illegally January to July 1943 At no . 8 Trierstrasse/STREET lived a men tailor named GUSTKE with his wife and children . I knew very well that he was anti Nazi . He used to listen to foreign radio and always kept me abreast of any news . He was an ex soldier and now too old for military service which is why the Nazis employed him as a Schupo member of the security police . On a visit to him one day I told him of my fears . He replied Well . I sure you know where you are headed Herr Pagel . Gustke owned a piece of land and a cottage in Herrensee/LOC near Straussberg/LOC and he declared 3 himself happy for us to make use of it . My wife was prepared to accept his offer and we set to thinking how we could make this work . I decided first of all to continue working at Siemens until my holiday which was scheduled for the period 26 December 1942 2 January 1943 . We settled on 2 January as the day of our escape . Once my holiday had started we began moving essential items such as bed linen and clothes etc . from our apartment to Gustke place . This had to be done secretly under cover of darkness . As my holiday was due to finish GÃ¼nther reported sick so that he could join us in our escape . A roofer from Weissensee/LOC Herr Palm with whom I had been in contact â€“ he planned to take in our daughter Judith and hide her â€“ gave us the use of his truck for our escape and our local garage owner a man named WOLF gave us free petrol . Early in the morning on 2 January Palm left Gustke place in his truck along with GÃ¼nther and all our belongings . My wife took Judith with her and the two of them travelled by train . Frau Gustke and I were also on that train but sat away from the others . It was still early morning when we arrived at our destination deep snow lay on the ground . Palm truck got stuck in the road so the owner of a haulage company provided us with somewhere to store our things . Herr Palm returned to Berlin/GPE in his truck and GÃ¼nther turned up with two hand sledges . The next day he and I went out with a cart to collect our belongings for whose safekeeping the woman from the haulage company refused to take any payment . Frau Gustke also returned to Berlin/GPE on that first evening . Gustke cottage stood among a group of grand dwellings in what had been woodland an hour and a half walk from Straussberg/LOC . We settled in as best we could . Gustke had given us two or three hundredweight of coal . Even the question of food had been sorted . At our apartment in Trarbacherstrasse/STREET we had had to give up a room so that it could be used by a Jewish man with a Christian wife . On our last day in Berlin/GPE I told them both of our intention to go into hiding and asked the woman to let us have four weeks worth of food coupons . She refused . But we got by without their help . The Gustkes came to see us every weekend and brought food . Sometimes we obtained more food by trading in some of my wife clothes to a woman who was head of a branch of Meyer . She was a respectable businesswoman who always gave us food without asking for coupons and only ever charged us the proper official price for other goods . We were also given bread again without coupons and at a ridiculously low price by a baker in Trarbacherstrasse/STREET called MAYER . GÃ¼nther and I took it in turns to pick it up when we went into town . However our diet consisted mainly of potatoes and sour skimmed milk which I was given by a farmer in a neighbouring village in exchange for work . He had no idea who I was . The Gustkes never took a single penny for all that they did for us . I kept their property in good order and tidied up their untended garden . One of our neighbours a friend of Gustkes suspected that there was something not right about us but said nothing . His wife was of Lorrainian origin and therefore had French sympathies whereas his mother was high up in the National Socialist Women League . I also tended this neighbour garden and he paid me with generous amounts of food . Also neighbours were the WOLFF family who â€“ unfortunately â€“ my son befriended . In her earlier years Frau Wolff had worked as a servant for a Jewish family and she became suspicious of us living there under the name of Lehmann and without any papers . 4 One day the Women League leader said to me Frau Wolff maintains that you are Jews but I told her that ca be TRUE because the Lehmanns read the VÃ¶lkischer Beobachter . In response I threatened legal action but this woman talked me out of it . Herr Gustke was having a well dug on his land and the well builder took GÃ¼nther and me on as unskilled labourers without demanding any papers . Helping us was a 15 year old Russian Ostarbeiter forced labourer from the East/LOC . We were paid 2.6 Reichsmarks an hour and the work took about four weeks . And so the months went past and life was tolerable until one Sunday in June 1943 the Gustkes and I decided to go into the woods to look for strawberries . On our return my wife told me that a police officer had called asking for me and my son . Apparently he had said Do take this the wrong way but are you sure you not Jewish ? My wife denied it and the policeman went away but not before he had asked for Gustke to come and speak to him that afternoon . Gustke duly went along returning with the message that the official wanted to see both my and GÃ¼nther employment records within the next 8 days . This ominous change in our fortunes came as a result of our sycophantic and malevolent neighbour Frau Wolff loose tongue . On the following Friday night we set off for Berlin/GPE Ostkreuz/LOC station/LOC with just a few essential items to our name arriving early the next morning . We had no idea what to do next but then I remembered a phone number I had been given . In summer 1942 we had had a visit from one Kurt SELIG and his wife and daughter . The Seligs had lived in the same house as us in Trierstrasse/STREET for many years and wanted to know how we were doing . As they left Herr Selig had said If you ever find yourself in difficulty and need my help just remember my number â€“ but do write it down . So I phoned the Seligs who lived by then â€“ as they still do today in Werner Voss Damm 20 Tempelhof/LOC . We were given a warm welcome and food to eat for which the Seligs refused payment . If Herr Selig had to leave the house early he would leave us 20 cigarettes . Unfortunately staying with them was not a long term solution as it was too cramped so after 3 weeks we had to leave that temporary refuge . Our son was able to stay with friends while we moved around without any fixed abode even camping out in Grunewald/LOC forest at one point . Whenever we were all together in the street I would always make GÃ¼nther keep his distance from us . III . From Berlin/GPE to Monowitz/LOC July 1943 We continued to lead this precarious nomadic life until the beginning of July when we were stopped near Berlin/GPE town hall by a plain clothes police inspector arrested and taken to the transit camp in Grosse/LOC Hamburgerstrasse/STREET . My son who had witnessed the arrest was able to escape unnoticed . It being Saturday afternoon there were no SS in the transit camp so we escaped interrogation and punishment . We were given a room and decent food . At that point there were around 200 prisoners in the camp mostly people in the same situation as us i.e. had attempted to live illegally . Many of us knew of Jewish informants living in the transit camp including a Dr. JACOBSOHN . Dr Jacobsohn who had practised in SchÃ¶nhauser Strasse thought his underhand dealings would mean his family 5 would be saved but in the end he went down the same route as all the others and was gassed at Auschwitz/CAMP . These informants roamed the streets during the day without wearing the obligatory Star of David intent on catching Jewish looking passers by . Jacobsohn recognised a former patient of his a dyed blonde and handed her over to the police . The man had no choice but to take the woman to Grosse Hamburgerstrasse/STREET saying to her on the way What pigs they are ! But unfortunately I ca let you go otherwise I end up in prison myself . One day a Jewish man at the assembly point threw himself out of a third floor window and landed in the middle of the street . One evening three days after our arrival the doors opened and our son entered the room . He had handed himself in . I was beside myself and remonstrated loudly with him but in the end I held my tongue when he explained Papa where you go I go . Those who were capable were put to work but only the men . I was assigned to a group responsible for preparing the building occupied by the Higher Institute for Jewish Studies in Artillerie Strasse for use by the Gestapo we did all the painting . While we were there it was often possible to get away for a time and so we could meet up with Frau Selig who brought us cigarettes . During those evenings we kept ourselves entertained by playing cards etc . At the beginning of August 1943 a transport was put together of 99 men women and children â€“ the youngest was just 6 months old â€“ and I was put in charge . We took food for everybody I recall it consisted of two loaves of bread per person plus we took flour and salt . We had heard that every time a transport arrived at Auschwitz/CAMP from Berlin/GPE there was bread soup to eat . Early in the morning on 3 August we were taken on trucks to a station â€“ it might have been Jungfernheide . At the same time Goebbels had issued an order that Christian hospitals were to be evacuated because of air attacks . The entire transport and their luggage were loaded into two closed cattle trucks which were then coupled to a passenger train bound for Silesia/LOC . The accompanying SS officers travelled separately . One of the wagons remained locked throughout the journey the other was opened at certain stations . The closed wagon contained all those who had attempted to escape including many who had fled from prison camps even Auschwitz/CAMP . While in the transit camp these absconders were held in a cell and had to be taken to the toilet by guards . Our two wagons were uncoupled in Kattowitz/CAMP Katowice/CAMP and then taken on to Birkenau/CAMP where we arrived at about 8 in the evening . We were met by SS who told us we were being taken to a labour camp â€“ more details were not forthcoming . We were made to clean out the wagons and then we were loaded onto trucks and taken to a former stable in the camp . Here we stayed all together until around 11 pm . We were then led out in two columns men in one and women and children in the other and told to move towards a truck with its headlights blazing . Between them stood an SS officer . The men sent left and the women sent right were being despatched to their deaths . Those left behind numbered around 20 25 men and â€¦ women . The men women and children selected were taken off to a red building . The following day I learned that this was the gas chamber . Among 6 those poor victims were my wife and our little Judith . Once the selection process was over those of us men who had been spared were taken to a barrack where we were made to undress . We were ordered to file past an SS officer with our arms above our heads and fingers apart during which my wedding ring was removed . We were then taken to the sauna block and forced under the shower before having our heads and all other bodily hair shaved off . We were then herded into a large hall where our personal details were recorded and we each had our prisoner number tattooed into our left arm . My number was 135396 . We were issued with civilian clothing a jacket and trousers but no underwear and not even basic wooden clogs or a hat . In this miserably inadequate get up we looked like the worst kind of criminals . It took all night to get through this whole process . At around dawn we were taken to our accommodation block where they left us in peace for the rest of that first day . The following morning we were taken off barefoot as we were to man the tipper trucks at the gravel pit . We were not mistreated but we saw girls also in their bare feet having to drag ten heavy bricks at a time and being beaten all the while by SS women with canes . A few days later a call went out from the Bunawerk factory in Monowitz/GPE Auschwitz/CAMP III for carpenters mechanics lathe operators and other skilled workers . GÃ¼nther and I applied to work as lathe operators . Altogether they took on around 100 men 15 of whom had arrived on the same transport as me . They took us first of all to Auschwitz/CAMP I where we were bathed disinfected and kitted out with the now familiar zebra suit . This time we were also given undergarments a cap and a pair of wooden clogs . The SS then marched us on foot to Monowitz/CAMP keeping us in line with blows from their rifle butts . My feet were soon rubbed raw from the ill fitting shoes hence my decision to walk most of the route in bare feet . IV . Monowitz August 1943 January 1945 On arrival in Monowitz/CAMP we were once again put through the whole bathing and dressing procedure as it seemed to be the custom for prisoners to have to wear different things after every bath . We were quartered in a vast tent fitted out with hundreds of triple bunks . Everything was scrupulously clean but we were not welcome as so called preventive detention SV prisoners ruled the roost and they treated us badly . After about two days I was admitted to the hospital suffering from enteritis and so was separated from my son . Even after my discharge a further three days went by without my seeing him . But when one of the work details was in need of mechanics we both put ourselves forward and so were reunited . This â€˜ Kommando 109 was led by a Kapo called Erich and was made up of between 50 and 60 men mostly Polish Jews and some German Jews . This work detail was known for its cleanliness . Erich men were expected to keep themselves scrupulously clean and tidy but he took good care of them . On joining this detail we were moved into decent barracks . The block elder was a decent Polish Jew . He was particularly kind to GÃ¼nther giving him extra helpings 7 of food over a period of many weeks to keep him in good health . Furthermore Erich also made sure there was always sufficient food . He managed this because in addition to our work detail there were also musicians living in our barracks who enjoyed special status . Among them were Poles Germans and Dutchmen the choirmaster was a gypsy who was also an excellent violinist . We spent several months in Kommando 109 until one time we were caught organising i.e. stealing bread . Erich was not happy about this and we were removed from his detail . Unfortunately GÃ¼nther was then moved to a much tougher Kommando as a result of which he ended up contracting double pneumonia . One Monday he was admitted to hospital . I managed to get permission to visit him on the following Thursday . I had no idea what was wrong with him he just lay there drenched in sweat feeling thoroughly wretched . He said to me Papa I wo be around much longer . I contradicted him with as much conviction as I could muster . On the Saturday two days later I too was admitted to hospital with a lung infection and found myself in the room next to GÃ¼nther . I was in such a state that I did even ask after my son . Sometime later a selection took place . Being an old soldier I knew what to do . After three weeks I was discharged . When I returned to my barracks I was greeted by a comrade who said to me Did you know your son died ? I did believe him and went straight to the office . They told me that GÃ¼nther had been transferred to Auschwitz/CAMP I/CAMP camp as was usual when a patient had been sick for longer than six weeks . I did not trust this information and tried to get further confirmation but without success . It was until last year that I learned that my son had succumbed to his pneumonia in the prisoners hospital in Monowitz/CAMP on 17 January 1944 . By May 1944 I had been admitted to hospital twice more first with pleurisy and then with yet another lung infection . During that time I survived another SS selection . In order to report sick you had to have a temperature of 38 degrees or have visible wounds . You first had to report to the block elder and then to the camp hospital . On one occasion I had a large festering wound on the back of my heel . It was treated not by doctors but by medical orderlies who cut out the sore using scissors and a knife â€“ no anaesthetic or antiseptic . Injuries like these were treated as outpatient cases and there was no being signed off from work . If the prison doctor needed to examine you you were required to strip off completely . The food in the hospital was not bad there was even a convalescent diet consisting of for example sweetened semolina or rice soup . During the period from summer 1943 to autumn 1944 I would say the mortality rate was not especially high . I shall now attempt a short general description of everyday life in Monowitz/CAMP . We were wakened at 5 am by someone banging on an iron bar . We had to get up immediately and make our beds . There were usually two men to each bed . The barracks were meant to hold 120 130 men but actually accommodated 260 prisoners or more . We kept the barracks very clean . Most people had just the one blanket to sleep under . With no toiletries or towels â€“ we used our jackets to dry ourselves â€“ it was only possible to have a rudimentary wash . There was plenty of water but it was drinkable . The toilets were made deliberately insalubrious so as to discourage prisoners from lingering too long . After washing we were given what they called coffee and our daily food ration 8 of 250 300 grams of bread . In addition we received a small amount each of margarine sausage cheese or jam during the course of the week . After breakfast came roll call . We had to line up in our work details and were then led off one by one to our workplaces outside the camp . It was rare for anything too awful to happen during these daily routines . A wind band played as we left the camp at 6 am and again when we returned home in the evening . It took us about half an hour on average to reach our workplace . We started work at 7 am had an hour for lunch then worked through until 6 pm in the summer or until it got dark in the winter . You either helped in construction work on the Bunawerk factory which was constantly being enlarged or else in the individual workshops . The German civilian workers with whom we came into contact were reserved towards us . During the lunch break we were given what was known as Buna soup which was made mainly from the leaves of turnips nettles etc . At the end of the day there was a head count of each individual work detail and we usually arrived back at the camp by 7 pm . Evening roll call lasted between one and four hours . Afterwards we were each given a litre of passably good soup made from beans etc . In summer we had to be in our barracks by 9.30pm and lights out was at 10 . In winter when our barracks was connected up to the Buna plant heating system the lights were turned off at 9.3 . On alternate Sundays we were not required to work although there could be as many as men picked out by the barrack functionaries and the Kapos for punishment and they did have to work . If you did find yourself with free time you would actually be left in peace and could do what you wanted within the constraints of the camp . There was often sweetened tea on Sunday evenings . Monowitz/CAMP camp was built at the end of February / beginning of March 1942 and held an average of 10 prisoners . The number of inmates never went below . During the time I was there there were still some of the original cohort of prisoners . The youngest inmates were 15 or 16 years old the oldest around 50 there was the odd prisoner who was even older but these were very rare . As many as 80 % of those in the camp were Jewish . Until 1944 most were from Poland/GPE and just a handful from Germany/GPE . Then in much lower numbers came French and Dutch Jews . Their morale was generally speaking very low and their attitude toward the other Jews was hostile . Autumn 1944 saw the arrival of a large transport of Hungarian Jews who were in excellent physical health and well nourished . This meant however that they found it hard to cope with the privations of camp life and the majority of them soon perished . Arriving at the same time as the Hungarian Jews were a few individuals from Theresienstadt/GHETTO . I knew one of them from Weissensee/CAMP . He had previously worked in a cemetery . Although half Jewish by descent he was not officially recognised as a Mischling i.e. of mixed blood because he was married to a Jew . His wife and child were killed shortly after their arrival in Auschwitz/CAMP . This same man also told me of the demise of other acquaintances who had been deported with him from Theresienstadt/GHETTO including our rabbi Heinz MAYER and his wife . About a fifth of the inmates were Aryan Germans and Poles in equal number . The German contingent was made up of prisoners of all stripes from political detainees to Jehovah Witnesses . The overwhelming majority however were SV Sicherheitsverwahrte prisoners i.e. career criminals 9 most held positions as camp functionaries . The way the Germans behaved towards the Jews varied between individuals . Most of the Poles were political prisoners and refused on the whole to speak German . They used to receive parcels containing the finest delicacies . The Poles were mostly hostile towards the Jews and hated those who spoke only German Jews who spoke Polish had less to fear . As the end of the war approached the Jews were more terrified of the Poles hatred than they were of SS reprisals . There were many different work details e.g. cement carriers this was a particularly gruelling Kommando led by an infamous Kapo carpenters and joiners welders turners etc . there was also a detail who worked in offices requisitioning the required numbers of skilled workers for the Buna factory . There were considerable social differences within the camp . For example the Kapos musicians and other privileged groups had the tailor alter their prisoner uniforms for a better fit . Normal inmates rarely had any undergarments etc . whereas all the functionaries from room elders upwards seemed to have no problem getting their hands on underwear socks toiletries etc . Over time I gained experience in several different work details with varying amounts of success . Gradually I learned what it took to stay alive in the camp and how important it was for prisoners to help and protect each other e.g. so that no one individual had to labour too hard or go without sleep . By the end of 1944 I had become so crafty that I was often able to â€˜ skive off just as the detail was preparing to leave for work . One time I feigned a fall and limped back to the camp as if I had sprained my foot . I reported to the hospital and at first the doctor did not want to examine me but then he changed his mind . But as soon as he went near my foot I screamed loudly . This was my way of getting myself 8 10 days convalescence . Experienced prisoners contrived various methods by which to organise i.e. steal valuable items such as lamps and tools from the factory and smuggle them into the camp even though spot checks were carried out on leaving for the factory and on return to the camp . Anything that you managed to secrete into the camp had to be kept concealed until a suitable â€˜ customer was found who would pay for the goods with soup bread or other rationed items in quantities that were in line with normal camp prices . So for example in exchange for a lamp I received extra soup for a whole month . Sometimes even whole engines would be â€˜ traded i.e. sold by prisoners to civilian workers for cash . But this type of transaction could only be carried out by Bonzen privileged prisoners with the help of their friends . During the early months of my time in Monowitz/CAMP the punishment for anyone caught doing this kind of business or indeed committing any other kind of â€˜ offence was to be tied to a whipping block in front of the other prisoners and given 10 20 lashes . Many prisoners died as a direct result of this mistreatment . An order later went out for these punishments to stop and for the offenders to instead be locked in the punishment cell . From time to time there were escape attempts . During my time in the camp four or five of these escapees were recaptured and hanged on the camp parade ground again in full view of all the other inmates . These hangings carried out by prisoners specially selected for the task were done in such a way that the victims did not die immediately 10 but suffered a slow death due to the knot in the noose being positioned to one side . The bodies were still twitching after ten minutes . I can clearly recall the last such execution which took place at Christmas 1944 . A large tree had been erected in the camp decorated with electric lights . The recaptured prisoners were three young lads and they were hanged simultaneously . With the noose already round his neck one of them shouted Chin up comrades we are the last ! One work free Sunday in August 1944 I was appointed as foreman of a group that was chosen to go into the factory . While there we were taken by surprise by an daytime air attack the bombs so well targeted that the whole works â€“ soon to start production of synthetic rubber â€“ was completely destroyed . We had no proper shelters and took refuge in various buildings . The number of dead and injured prisoners was small . I sustained three splinters to the lower part of my left leg but they were only flesh wounds which earned me 14 days convalescence . There was substantial damage to the buildings and the factory had to be shut down . In the weeks following the only work to do was clearing the place up . One bomb fell onto the road running through the camp but caused no damage while another hit the nearby British prisoner of war camp killing 37 inmates . In the summer of 1944 I was assigned to a work detail as a mechanic working alongside British prisoners of war . Both sides were forbidden to talk to each other on pain of death . As far as possible the British were friendly towards us although there were some anti semites among them . One particularly decent chap was Gunner Arthur HAMPTON from Manchester/LOC who treated me like a brother . It was common knowledge that the British did like their food ration which consisted of six pieces of round Harzer cheese . Hampton brought me what amounted to about 8 rations 48 pieces without expecting anything in return . As a result of my time as a prisoner of war I was able to speak English and so it came about that Hampton offered to help me make contact with my family in England/GPE . He sent Red Cross letters direct to my brother in London/GPE from which the latter could glean that I was still alive while at the same time using clever phrasing to prevent the censors realising that this letter was from a concentration camp inmate . After a few weeks I joined a different Kommando which meant I lost touch with Hampton . Then winter came around and I found myself having to work outside clad only in thin clothes . I heard nothing from my Englishman for six months . One day I was standing on a clay hill when I saw him suddenly appear waving to me . I dropped my spade pretended to stumble and rolled down the slope . Hampton said I got a letter for you . Despite the risk of death for both of us we met in the toilet block having left the ranks and gone off site and Hampton quickly handed me the letter . I hid it away then once back at the camp I read it through several times before handing it back to Hampton . If they had found the letter on me I would have been hanged . I never saw Hampton again but I did correspond with him in England/GPE after the war was over . In Monowitz/CAMP I met a former close acquaintance from Berlin/GPE Weissensee a metalworker called Peisachowitz who had worked for many years training up other metalworkers . Aged 60 Peisachowitz was among the oldest camp inmates and his specialist knowledge and skills meant he had a relatively pleasant job . He helped me a great deal and acquired food 11 for me which helped to keep me going . The last time I spoke to Peisachowitz was on the evacuation march to Gleiwitz/CAMP in January 1945 but sadly I heard later that he had died . We were relatively well informed about political and military events . Our mood in the camp alternated between optimism and pessimism . In conversation with a German civilian worker following the attempt on Hitler life in July 1944 I was asked If the situation changes and we end up losing the war what will you Jews do to us ? I answered Nothing at all because it not your fault . Leaving aside whether my answer would turn out to be right or wrong at that time my survival instinct meant I could have said anything different . In the autumn of 1944 the situation deteriorated further . We heard that the Russians were approaching and would be in Cracow/GPE by Christmas . We had no idea what they would do to us and could not discount the possibility that we would be gassed . The weeks went by amid great uncertainty until the day arrived when we were confronted by the facts . V. Evacuation of Monowitz Dora On 18 January 1945 I remembered it was my aunt birthday and also ReichsgrÃ¼ndungstag German Empire Day we were standing on the parade ground when they told us we would no longer be going off to work but were to be evacuated . Everyone was allowed to take their personal belongings with them which amounted to very little . We were each given a loaf of bread and a piece of sausage . At about 12 we marched off in the direction of Gleiwitz/CAMP . We spent the first night in a brickworks where some individuals managed to hide in some straw and so escape having to march any further . The rest of us had to move on the following morning . I was accompanied part of the way by a Berlin/GPE SS officer who urged me to keep going anyone lagging behind was shot . He even gave me two cigarettes . We spent the second night in a small camp just outside Gleiwitz/CAMP which was so crowded that I and many others were forced to sleep outside in the snow . It was until the following morning that I managed to climb through a window into a barrack building and warm myself up a bit in what was a crowded space . I lost my package of bread while I was there . We had been given hardly any food as we marched in Gleiwitz/CAMP there was at least morning coffee . On the afternoon of 20 January 140 of us were loaded into open coal wagons and then given more bread . We had no idea where we were being taken . We learned along the way that several other camps had refused to take us in due to overcrowding . Our journey lasted ten days and nine nights and we were given no more food during that time . We stopped regularly in the middle of nowhere in order to let other trains pass but only twice pulled into a station where civilians hearing our desperate pleas for water tried to throw snowballs to us . 12 That was our only nourishment . But it was long before the SS men stopped even these modest attempts at kindness while themselves enjoying something to eat at both stations and sipping hot drinks right in front of us . We on the other hand were busy removing the many dead amongst us from the wagons dragging them along the platform before loading them into the carriages at the back of the train . We had tried to dispose of the corpses at night by throwing them onto the track . When the SS found out it was announced that anyone putting their head or a hand outside the wagon would be shot . We had to go to the toilet in these wagons . While we were travelling in these dreadful conditions the likes of which it is impossible to imagine the SS sat in passenger carriages taking it in turn to go and do guard duty in the brake vans attached to the freight wagons . Sometimes we came across transports of women who seemed to be no better off than us . A few of our number had empty food tins which they let down on pieces of string in order to gather snow as we went along . People fought each other over this precious resource which was distributed by the spoonful . As space in my wagon increased somewhat as a result of so many people having died two warring factions emerged â€“ for no apparent reason . There were many on both sides who had lost all reason and set about attacking each other . Barely half the prisoners in our wagon survived this transport . Anyone who tried to sit down was done for as others would sit on top of him and he would end up being suffocated . It is impossible to judge the way people behaved during this journey against any normal human standards as it was dictated entirely by blind instinct for which there was no accounting . I found out later that of the men loaded onto our train in Gleiwitz/CAMP on 20 January only were still alive when we arrived in Nordhausen/LOC on 30 January . But even those who had survived were by no means saved many died later of exhaustion or the consequences of it while others suffered permanent damage from frostbite . VI . At Dora/CAMP camp February to June 1945 We were unloaded in Nordhausen/CAMP . Those who were still able to move had to drag the most exhausted prisoners into Dora/CAMP camp . I was given a comrade to carry but I was so weak that I could not bear his weight and could scarcely move myself . Once in the camp we were fed straight away and then assigned to different barracks I was fortunate enough to end up in a decent one . It had something I had not seen for a very long time â€“ decent washrooms and flushing toilets . In the evening we handed over the filthy rags we were wearing were showered and then â€“ naked and still dripping wet â€“ we were led across the camp main street to be issued with underclothes trousers a jacket and shoes . The following morning we had to stand around for hours in the freezing cold to be registered I was given prisoner number 106217 . Then they took us back to the barracks . The 13 food in Dora/CAMP camp was much better than it had ever been in Monowitz/CAMP . Once a fortnight we received double rations of bread . I was unable to work at first due to the pain from my frostbitten hands I also managed sometimes to skive off . Later on I applied for relatively easy work as a turner in the underground factory . My frostbitten fingers on both hands were treated as an outpatient case . One time while I was working at the lathe the foreman noticed pus dripping from my bandage into the machine and sent me away immediately . I had to stop work and report to the hospital that evening to have my dressings changed . But when I got there I was immediately admitted and put into the Jewish ward where patients slept two to a bed . The following morning the camp doctor amputated the little finger on my right hand under general anaesthetic . That was in in February . Three days after the operation I developed heavy swelling on the back of my right hand and on my lower arm near the wrist . At first they treated it with cold compresses but when it did improve they made incisions â€“ without either general or local anaesthetic â€“ on the top and bottom of my hand . They repeated this same treatment fourteen times over a period of seven weeks using razors and serrated scissors on my hand and arm â€“ without any form of anaesthesia . If I cried out from the intolerable pain of this â€˜ treatment a Polish medical orderly would hit me round the face . As a result of the procedures my temperature always went sky high and I was totally unable to sleep . On 23 March the doctor decided to amputate my right arm and I was given the news in the morning . I was told to report to the infirmary naked at 3 pm and told to lie on a table where an anaesthetic injection was administered . When I woke up the next morning both my arm and the pain were gone . I felt a great relief and asked for something to eat . On the second day I had to have my dressing changed . For some time after that I was given medical attention every two days . I found out later that the amputation had been done badly they left 8 cm more flesh than bone which was left to heal by itself without the use of a clamp which meant I ended up with a scar that resembled a sunflower . In the first few days of April rumours started to circulate that the Americans were approaching and that the camp was to be evacuated which indeed it was on 6 April . Only the patients in the camp hospital were to remain behind . On the afternoon of that day the doctor went to each individual barracks to see who was physically able to march and I was deemed to be one of those capable . However I was determined not to go . Despite my name being called several times I refused to leave the camp . 14 of my comrades who were also meant to be leaving and had been given clothes turned back lay down on their beds and pulled their blankets up to their chins . Nobody bothered us any further even when the room elder 14 an anti semitic Christian orderly from Berlin/GPE came back into the ward a short time later he took no action against the 14 who had refused to leave . A total of 600 patients plus doctors and nurses stayed behind in Dora/CAMP camp . On 7 April the SS moved out and we were unguarded . Our only concern now was food but there were supplies . I have no idea where they came from . We later found out that a raiding party Rollkommando made up of armed SS men had arrived on 9 April but that a German army major who had taken over supervision of the camp refused anyone entry which probably saved our lives . For four days we existed in a kind of no man land until on 11 April at 6.30pm we were liberated by American troops . Led by our Berlin/GPE orderly who described us as his special patients four tall soldiers entered our Jewish ward and greeted us with the words You do have to speak English it fine to speak Yiddish ! The next day some uniformed American war reporters arrived I saw that one of them was a woman and addressed her as Madam . We got along well . German doctors and nursing staff were commandeered to Dora/LOC from a captured military hospital . However many former prisoners still perished because they were so weak and were unable to tolerate the good food they were given . Already in the first few days we were given forms on which to fill in our personal details . Under nationality I wrote English . We thought the whole world was open to us . My arm healed slowly . After a fortnight I was moved to another barracks where the German chief medical officer wanted to discharge me as fully recovered . Despite my stubborn reluctance to this I had no choice but to report to the specified quarters but not before going to see the Dutch camp doctor I had been under previously . He intervened on my behalf and succeeded in getting me sent back to the hospital where incidentally a few individual sick German prisoners of war had been cared for . As my arm stump had begun to suppurate I was operated on again and then moved to a large barracks known as the TB barracks . Here there were 60 former prisoners looked after by a Pole a decent man assisted by German orderlies . Every time we had an Allied visitor to the hospital to monitor how things were going they would be directed to me as I was the only one among the patients able to communicate in fluent English . As a result I was well looked after . In May during one such visit I asked an Englishwoman to let my sister know that I had survived this she was able to do through a friend of hers who lived in London/GPE . In just a short time the empty main camp had filled up again with displaced persons often whole families . 15 VII . In Belgium/GPE June October 1945 In mid June we were told that all those who were citizens of western countries should prepare to be transported home . As I had registered as an Englishman I was counted among this group and managed moreover to ensure that my young friend Wolf was also able to join us . He had lost his whole family apart from an uncle in America/GPE . We were still dressed in our zebra suits . As there was no civilian clothing available they gave us German uniforms to put on . I was given a set of women clothes of which only the jacket was usable which meant I had to continue wearing my striped trousers . We assembled on 8 June and were boarded onto trucks and taken to Nordhausen/LOC station . Here we were transferred onto an American hospital train and taken to LÃ¼ttich/CAMP LiÃ¨ge/CAMP where we received a rapturous welcome from the local people . They took us by truck to a school . The Belgians among whom there were a number of voluntary foreign workers and collaborators were separated from us . A Belgian nurse approached my friend Wolf and explained that she was very sorry but he had to go as being German he would be arrested . I pointed out that although Wolf had been born in Germany/GPE he was Jewish . The nurse asked why we had said that in the first place . And with that the matter was settled . The following day I got talking to a Belgian Jewish female doctor who urged me to go to Brussels/GPEwhere I would be looked after by the Jewish Community there . When I asked how on earth I was going to get to Brussels/CAMP she reassured me that I could leave this problem to her . I was given essential toiletries at a Red Cross post and shortly afterwards was driven to Brussels/GPEin a private car in the company of a Belgian woman a former inmate of RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP and a former Polish officer . Wolf stayed in LÃ¼ttich/LOC but after repeated pleas from me he too was moved to Brussels/GPEa few days later . On 15.6.45 I was taken to the British Centre which was based in an artillery barracks and there I stayed for a few weeks . The food was fantastic . I was brought before the British Consul where I requested permission to go to England/GPE . This he politely declined as I had no proof of British nationality . There were people in the Centre who were pretending to be Commonwealth citizens or Americans . Of course there were all kinds of dubious characters among them many of whom were no more British than I was . I was desperate to get to England/GPE at any cost and decided to contact my family in London/GPE . As there was no way the British Consul could single handedly deal with all the research that had to be done they appointed a Vice Consul who operated within the camp itself . One day I was summoned to see him . He received me with great courtesy and spoke to me at first in English but then suddenly explained in excellent German It would be better if we spoke German as every word counts . I told him a long story but to give the man his due he soon realised that it did ring TRUE . 16 In the end he said he could help me . Eight days later I was discharged from the British Centre and handed over to the Belgians â€“ like many others in my situation . Although things were not so good as when I was with the British it was perfectly adequate . My arm was now fully healed but the flap of skin â€“ about 8 cm too long â€“ annoyed me . A friend advised me to go St Pierre Hospital to have the arm re operated on . I went to see the doctor at the Jewish Aid Committee who had helped me out previously and was recommended for referral to the hospital in question . It was not until 2 August two weeks later that I was actually admitted . A successful re amputation was carried out two days later . I ended up staying in hospital until 10 October as I came down with another lung infection in the middle of September . During that time I was visited once or twice a week by a lady from the Jewish Aid Committee who brought me gifts . In the meantime my family in London/GPE had also been busy and had gone to great lengths to acquire a visa for me . I was issued with a visa stamp on my Belgian travel documents which I at first hesitated to sign because they said Nationality German . I then headed to the British Centre where a female captain recognised me straight away and asked whether I wanted to travel to England/GPE by plane or by boat . I decided to fly and this was soon organised . I was even given British repatriation papers . On 12 October 1945 I landed at Croydon/LOC airport . 17 SIEMENS & amp HALSKE AKTIENGESELLSCHAFT Herr Fritz Pagel 1 Berlin/GPE W KurfÃ¼rstendamm 217 Hotel Pension Adler Your ref Your message dated Our ref âž€ BERLIN/LOC SIEMENSSTADT Dr. Schl / Ba . Date 14.1.54 Re Dear Herr Pagel With regard to your visit of the 7th of this month and following discussion with the signatories on the right we are pleased to inform you that from the documentation that still exists relating to your case we are able to provide definitive confirmation of your earnings during your period of employment in our company . On entering the firm on 16.12.40 you worked first as a machine operator and later from mid December 1941 as an assistant machine setter . Your earnings were in line with wage levels at that time . There were no payments made below that level . We had no influence over any deductions made in accordance with prevailing laws or paid to competent authorities . In light of this the company can not be said to have profited from your forced labour and is therefore unfortunately unable to accept any claim to compensation for damages as these were not caused by the company .
