These are the Dregs of Europe Ghettoes photograph The Editor of the News Chronicle yesterday received the following letter your readers may like to see those two dregs of the ghettoes . They are my sister children who together with their mother were gassed in Auschwitz/CAMP exactly a year ago after two years of famine epidemics and ill treatment in Terezin/CAMP . Their crime was the supreme one of being non Aryans . L.H. The writer refers to the statement by Major Winwood . Kramer defence counsel that the concentration camps came to contain the dregs of the ghettoes of Middle/LOC Europe/LOC . LATER a News Chronicle reporter went to see the writer of the letter â€” a woman . Czechoslovak by birth and of Jewish extraction . Her husband is a doctor at an English university . She does not want her identity disclosed in case relatives in Europe/LOC should suffer . Not that she has many relatives left . Twenty members of her family including her sister and her sister two children whose photographs appear above perished in Nazi/CAMP concentration camps . This is the story she told of these two children My sister Mrs. Susan S. lived happily with her husband a lawyer and their two young children Oldrich aged eight and a half and Marie aged five in Prague/GPE until the of the Nuremberg/LOC illegible in 1939 . that they were illegible of all privileges and humiliated in every possible way . Soon after the Germans entered Prague/GPE they deported all Jews to concentration camps in Poland/GPE and my sister and her husband and their two children were among those taken away . Mr. S. was soon separated from his wife and family and sent to work as a coal miner in Upper/LOC Silesia/LOC but escaped . In a letter written on June 22 from Prague/GPE to his sister in law Mr. S. says that he has since his return met several men who have come back from Auschwitz/CAMP . They told him that all the women and children who were taken there in the same transport of cattle trucks as his wife and children were put to death in the gas chambers . Eighty thousand were taken there he says and only a handful have so far returned . I have long since ceased to hope that Susan might be alive .

Bergen Belsen After having been spared for a long time from home raids and street checks on account of our Turkish papers my wife and I we had left my daughter Malkitta with Aryans from the Netherlands/GPE in the provincial town of Helmond/LOC under the name of Rietje/LOC were taken away by two plain clothed Dutch policemen . According to them we were being taken to a hearing at the Zentralstelle fÃ¼r jÃ¼dische Auswanderung Central Department for Jewish Emigration at Adama von Schletemaplein in  Amsterdam/GPE with a view to a speedy return . We had been given permission to keep a packed suitcase with Jewish neighbours which would potentially be forwarded to the Westerbork/CAMP camp . In the meantime the authorities allowed us to enjoy our breakfast . We went by foot to the nearest police station . There we were put in a truck and taken to the Zentralstelle . There we had to wait alone in a basement room equipped with chairs and benches before being taken to the chief of the security services . We were informed that owing to a special order lying in front of him from The/LOC Hague/LOC we were being sent to a work detail in Westerbork/CAMP . Our Turkish nationality was not recognised in The/LOC Hague/LOC in June we had seen the official Fraulein Slottke in The/LOC Hague/LOC who on the basis of the papers presented had compiled a comprehensive transcript . He gave us back the money taken by the police officers but kept the ration cards . All of our objections were brusquely rejected . We were led back to the basement room . After a long and anxious wait the police officer who had taken us away emerged in a state of agitation and asked for the whereabouts of our child . We gave evasive answers and were led to a room in which several German officers and female SS helpers were who were by all means necessary trying to find where our child was . We had invented the following story on the day of a big raid that morning during my absence I worked at the Joodschen Raad a male stranger came to my wife and offered to take the child who was 1 Â½ years old at the time into safety . In the understandable commotion of the day my wife agreed without asking the name of the man . When I arrived home I was angered by this but reconciled myself that as a Turkish citizen nothing unlawful would come of it . This was met with an unhappy response and they proceeded upon us with threats and insults . We remained steadfast and further explained how we did not know the whereabouts of our child . We were told that we would be put on a penal transport . Accompanied by an SS man we were taken in a small car to the Jewish theatre Joodschen Schouwburg . Thanks to an ingenious manoeuvre by an employee present at the Joodschen Raad we were fortunately not recorded on the list of criminal cases but on the normal transport list instead . The Joodschen Schouwburg was where all  Amsterdam/GPE Jews listed for deportation 2 were assembled prior to their onward travel to Westerbork/CAMP . During the night the majority â€“ if they were not sleeping on the dirtiest and most vermin infested of mattresses â€“ had to sit on chairs . Victuals and other services above all the provisions for the further transport were provided by the employees of the Joodschen Raad in an exemplary fashion . Above all by using all possible reasons to defer they endeavoured to hold back people for as long as possible there were people who had remained there for many weeks and now and again they succeeded in allowing some to disappear . Even though we only had to stay there for half a day we were still sufficiently depressed by this dismal theatre . On that day a transport day the SS made an unpleasant visit to the desert sons . A nurse who could not hear well and who was in the lavatory at the time of the transport list rollcall was beaten pulled by the hair and kicked . We all had to endure the most salacious insults thrown at us and not move . Finally to our relief they marched off . In large motorcoaches we were together with approximately 200 people a small transport taken to the strictly guarded railway trains which took us to the Westerbork/CAMP camp . We arrived there in the night . To our surprise we were received in a large and well lit room in which Jewish workers from the camp registry sat in long rows at typewriters and took down our details . Afterwards we were greeted by our friends and acquaintances . They immediately took into custody anything of value . Afterwards we had to pass the office of the Bank Lippmann and Rosenthal where money valuables and ration stamps were being taken by the wicked Dutch officers with bags and briefcases etc . also being searched . After a brief search in quarantine we there then taken to the penal barrack no . 67 where we all initially stayed until the next day . On the next day those like us who had no criminal record were taken to a different barrack . We came to barrack 66 where we remained until our departure to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP in January 1944 . The Westerbork/CAMP transit camp located in the northern Dutch province of Drenthe/LOC near the town of Assen/LOC originated out of a camp built by the Dutch government in 1939 for Jewish refugees following the events in Germany/GPE in November 1938 . As old camp inmates the Jews who were still there from this time had a preferential position and carried out all important administrative functions in this autonomous Jewish camp . For the purposes of transportations of Jews to the East/LOC the camp was greatly enlarged with living working and administrative barracks provided . Owing to the vast camp terrain one had free movement and only rarely was there a commandant often in plain clothes or an SS man to be seen who all lived outside of the camp . Every person fit for work 3 had to carry out work be it in one of the basic camp range of services administration office duty security the kitchen the hospital the school workshops camp cleaning etc . or in industry battery disassembly old metal sorting sorting beans etc . . Food was administered as such morning coffee at lunch a stew mostly a stamppot in a Dutch style i.e. potatoes and vegetables cooked together . In the hospital where my wife worked there was better food . In addition a large proportion of the camp inmates received food packages from outside which were only allowed to be sent once a month however . There were talks on a variety of things in a similar way to an organised school lesson . On high holidays there was a well attended service . There was even a large theatre hall where satirical and musical performances took place the German commandant was a regular guest . The hospital boasted a comparatively large number of barracks and good doctors . This relatively bearable existence â€“ considering the conditions of camps in Germany/GPE and Poland/GPE â€“ was nevertheless under the constant threat of transportations where once or twice a week in numbers from to people were sent to Auschwitz/CAMP and other eastern camps . The transport lists were read out in the middle of the night by the barrack leaders in the barracks . The atmosphere at the readings resembled a death sentence . Apart from the officials on duty no one was allowed into the transport carriages themselves . The transportation days placed great stress on the nerves of everybody but also provided many examples of mutual support . At the beginning I worked in the cleaning detail . At first I had to drive the refuse bins from the hospital barracks to the waste pits situated outside the camp . Then I had to keep the hospital clean with a brush hoe shovel and wheelbarrow . Later I was assigned to quarantine . There I had to take out the disinfected clothes from the hot air chambers which remained at 120 130 % for two hours and then bundle them up and make them available for collection . The work hours amounted to seven hours . We got a daily bath and later an extra 200 g of fat as an extra allowance . In the quarantine which was under the leadership of the Viennese physician Dr Pick the baptised were very well represented and lived in a special barrack . On January 11th 1944 we went together with the first transport to Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP . For the most part this transport of approximately 1000 people was comprised of applicants for the Palestine/GPE exchange holders of South American passports and dual citizens . One was told the nicest things about the model camp Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP and the remaining inmates envied us . We travelled through the night in a third class carriage for transports to the East there were only ever cattle cars â€“ across the Reich border for the first time in 11 years â€“ past bomb ravaged Bremen/LOC to Bergen/CAMP where we arrived early in the morning on January 12th . 4 The situation immediately became clear to us upon arrival . At the platform stood numerous SS men with fixed weapons and dogs who greeted us with Raus ! Raus ! and Schnell ! Schnell ! The camp commandant Haas a large and stocky man with a sinister look observed the performance with great interest . Women with small children and large suitcases were loaded into trucks . All the others had to walk with all their hand luggage . The 1000 long line moved in a slow march across the country road . After 1 Â½ hours we arrived at a black and white barrier to the SS camp . When all we could see on all sides was barbed wire weathered barracks and signs such as political prisoners arms depot etc . it became ever clearer to us that all positive reports were just fantasy and that we had arrived in a German Nazi camp . After an endless wait we did not receive anything to eat for the whole day of role calls registration and turning in money we were divided into barracks . The SS men screamed insulted and commanded . Everything had to be done quickly . Hurrying harrying and improvisation were the hallmarks of camp life in Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP . The barracks â€“ in a dismal grey green â€“ were comprised of a dining hall with cupboards and tables and a dormitory with wooden bunk beds . I went into a barrack with a connecting washroom the occupants in other barracks had to go the dirtiest of routes in all weathers to this single washroom . Male and female camps were divided with barbed wire the gate closed in the evenings . Upon our arrival in Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP we found a group of roughly 80 Greek Jews who had left Westerbork/CAMP destined for Theresienstadt/GHETTO without ever having heard anything from them . They were later put on transport from Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP to Theresienstadt/GHETTO . The hospital referred to as Revier made a very poor impression . When we were there with our child to remove a boil from the back of their head in the operating room there was literally nothing apart from an operating table and an instrument cabinet with three rusted pairs of scissors . Consequently the doctor had to use my own pair of scissors with a sterile gauze which we had with us . Shortly after our arrival I was taken ill to the hospital with facial erysipelas . The new second barracks were divided with a row of cabinets into male and female sections . There was neither a lavatory nor a washroom . A waste bin served as a lavatory and had to be carried to and fro by the nurse and if it was overflowing it was carried by two helpers . The lighting and heating were insufficient . The medical administration was very perfunctory and the German staff surgeon mostly only came to determine who to discharge . Later the conditions in the hospital improved . 5 There were more doctors even specialists appointed as well as even more nurses . There was even an outpatient clinic and a dentist . Towards the end of our stay in Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP with the reduction of space the conditions became much worse . After a few days we were divided up for work . As a mother to a child of under three years my wife did not have to work . I was put into the so called Schuhkommando whose task it was in poorly heated and dusty stone barracks to remove the rubber part from the leather from a pile of shoes as high as a house . At 6 in the morning one had to report for roll call . Then one marched in a long line in rows of five to the work barracks . One was forced to work there until midday . In every barrack there was a Jewish foreman . The SS OberscharfÃ¼hrer who was supervising alternated from barrack to barrack and pushed us towards higher work output with threats and insults . Later more and more were beaten with kicks and leather straps . Various people were so badly treated that they had to be taken to the hospital . Later I came to the Bekleidungskommando clothing Kommando which operated in the magazine of the Waffen SS . The engagement involved loading and unloading hauling things to and fro piling up and counting military equipment from steel helmets to boots . The Kommando had a HauptscharfÃ¼hrer sergeant major with an UnterscharfÃ¼hrer and several SS men of Lithuanian and Romanian descent reporting to him . The work was harder than in the Schuhkommando yet not as depressing as it was more varied and one could be out in the fresh air . The surveillance was in such a way that sleights of hand were possible such as holding Hebrew courses reading books or sleeping . Lunchtime lasted 45 minutes and was enough to march in single file back to the Appelplatz roll call area walk quickly inside the barracks wait in line to receive a warm meal mostly swede soup with boiled potatoes to start with later on without quickly gulp down the Â¾ litres of soup rush to drop by my wife and child and finally report back to the Appelplatz for the roll call . One returned home in the evenings at 6.45pm . One washed and hurried one always hurried in Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP to the women barracks in order to share the meagre bread ration and filling with the wife for the evening meal for a long time there was a thin soup served on certain evenings . One had to be back in one barracks by 8 . There one could still read for a short time listen to a talk discuss the chances of liberation and the current situation in the war based on the most recent JÃ¼dische Presse Agentur JPA rumours or argue about internal barrack matters . Then one would fall asleep exhausted . Special occasions within the camp were the roll calls for the non workers women the elderly children which often lasted for several hours 6 who willingly stood in bad weather one time for eleven hours without food when the SS forgot to count one person . We even had to stand for the roll call for hours on end in the evening when we came back exhausted from work . Punishments involved the deprivation of food being made to stay at the gate without standing or food for hours on end relocation to a particularly arduous or dirty Kommando or spending several days in the bunker on just water and bread . Beatings at the start were very rare but later on became very commonplace carried out with leather belts or rifle butts . From March 1st the Arbeitskommando were not allowed to wear jackets anymore . During the official non work hours on Sunday afternoons we were regularly fetched to carry out work of all kinds often just out of harassment . In some particularly difficult outdoor Kommandos only the elderly were employed . In all weathers they had to dig up tree roots saw wood haul tree trunks etc . all with inadequate equipment and suffering ill treatment . One was only excused from work like in all other Kommandos/LOC when one had a fever of more than 39 degrees . Whoever was very ill but did not meet the minimum fever requirement still had to do the roll call and go to work . The barrack authorities of the SS enforced this order and it happened often enough that ill persons were taken from their beds and forced to work . The number of deaths increased constantly and varied from 25 to 40 each day . Causes of death were above all pneumonia starvation with the associated diarrhoea camp fever even typhoid fever . The later built so called Altersheim old peoples home whose inmates were exempted from work and roll calls became more and more a preparation station for the crematorium . Mystery surrounded the later disappearance of two young Chalutzim who lived cut off from the outside world in a small wooden shelter on the way to the crematorium . As the crematorium later became insufficient corpses were collected and burned in open spaces . At the beginning of June 1944 we were called up along with other Turks and Argentinians and taken to the so called Schneebaum Lager the camp for Jews of neutral nationality . A few days after our arrivals due to the change of the camp elder the name was changed to Aufenthaltslager detention camp Benadon . After we had been put together in the Albala camp initially with Dutch and stateless formally German Jews then later with Frenchmen Albanians Tripolitanian Englishmen Italians South Americans and all other possible nationalities together around 4000 people in the neutral camp there were around 250 persons two thirds of whom Spanish and the rest of Turkish Argentinian Portuguese and Swiss nationality . The marked improvement was that apart from internal camp duties there was no forced labour . Even the food was by all means in the beginning better the hot food was more generous and substantial with a larger bread topping . 7 There was sufficient time for lectures and studies . Minyan was regularly held . Even a Sefer Torah and a shofar were available . Talks in Spanish and French were held and I spoke about the Jews in Holland/GPE and the role of Jewish Palestine/GPE in the/LOC Middle/LOC East/LOC . In spite of all of this the state of health in the neutral camp constantly decreased if at least not as quickly or to the same extent in the Albala camp . The diet here was permanently and wholly insufficient and all the appearances of malnourishment were on show here . There was no doctor in the camp . Very seldom came the staff surgeon or one of the Jewish doctors from the general camp . The administration of medicine was insufficient . For the first time in August and then again for several weeks in September and October 1944 my wife was taken to the hospital in the general camp with a severe and lengthy case of typhus which owing to the poor operating methods took long to diagnose . It was in this time that she had the opportunity to convince herself of the rapid deterioration of conditions there . Due to the constant lack of space three storey beds were put tightly next to one another where the bunk beds were and several people had to sleep in one bed . It often happened that one would wake up in the morning next to a dead person . The lavatories and washrooms were wholly insufficient . For hours and sometimes days there was no water . More and more people were escaping . The punishments became ever more draconian the whole camp went without bread for three days because someone had burned straw in the oven from their mattress . If someone tried to take a turnip or a potato from the kitchen they were beaten half to death and either put in the bunker or put on the gate for a whole day with turnips or potatoes in their hands and a sign around their neck saying I am a thief . I stole from my comrades . During my visit to the hospital after every food distribution I was allowed to take the rations to my wife I was shocked every time by something new in the appearance of people in the general camp . They were emaciated with pale skin and swollen from hunger trudging arduously on their weak legs . Each time my wife would tell me of a group of friends and associates who had died since the last visit . Later the camp elder at Albala/CAMP was dismissed and in his place came a non Jew by the name of Hanke who brought with him a squad of non Jewish Kapos . They were armed with canes which they got generous use out of . As early as five they would appear in the barracks and beat the people out of bed . In January 1945 when Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP began to be converted into a concentration camp and thousands upon thousands of Jews and non Jews came from Auschwitz/CAMP Birkenau/CAMP RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP and Oranienburg/CAMP we had to leave the camp . Fortunately we only had to squeeze into another barrack for two weeks . 8 There were not enough beds a few had to sleep in the gangway and two of whom soon died after . The long roll call was abandoned and the food had to be eaten on the beds . Even during our stay in the old neutral camp large transports of women and girls all without children came from Auschwitz/CAMP and other concentration camps . We had to stay in the barracks during the near approach of these tightly packed shapes who arrived emaciated in clogs and without jackets . We could still them all out of the window . They were accommodated in a tent camp in the rain and snow without any wash facilities or lavatories . Water was administered through a hose for one hour a day whilst the majority of them were already out at work and out of necessity were digging holes . The tents regularly blew and washed away so the women had to stand around all night soaked through in an open space . Many died because of this . Later they did not go past our barracks and instead were redirected into the camp . When we were in the last neutral camp the transports would pile up from the concentration camps . They came night and day . They were forced into a barrack fully unclothed and received a shirt trousers a dress and footwear . Even the bread that they had with them was taken away from them . Some of the SS women took pleasure in throwing the rest of the bread over the camp fence which many of our hungry people then fought over . During the night we heard anxious screams from the women driven into the barracks drowned out by the commands of the SS . My wife witnessed a group of men in the open space forced to fully undress it was in February and the snow had set only to wait two hours to be then dressed in striped cotton prisoners uniform . Women and men from all the occupied European nations came from these transports . Our last stay in Bergen/CAMP Belsen/CAMP was in a complex of old primitive and dirty barracks right at the end of the camp . There was an old and squalid washroom . The most terrible was the lavatory â€“ just one for men and women . It had never been excavated and was difficult to clean off the coarsest of dirt . To get to the washroom and lavatory one had to walk a long way through mud . The food provision was noticeably worse and more disorderly that we often went without coffee or food at 11 and sometimes did not get anything until 5 . One day all food rations were reduced to a quarter . There was no talk of any medical administration . The formerly weekly warm shower had discontinued for some time . The water often failed to materialise for a long time . All the more it leaked through the roof so we had to put several bowls out to stop our beds and clothes from getting soaked to some degree . Furthermore it was like in all other barracks always terribly cold . During the whole winter I constantly had cold feet and whenever it was possible we would lay in bed together . During the evening it was mostly dark due to the regular air raid alarm or alleged cost cutting measures . Often the dim light 9 went out during the meal . There were 105 people of us who belonged to the Turkish group happy when we were told on February 28th that we were to make ourselves ready for the replacement transport on March 4th when our departure really was going to happen the Spaniards and the others were to travel later in the evening that same day . We went by train to Lubeck/CAMP where we met the group from RavensbrÃ¼ck/CAMP and the Turkish students and then onto Flensburg/CAMP through Denmark/GPE to Helsingoer/LOC where we stayed for a few days and then from Helsingborg/LOC in Sweden/LOC to Goteborg/LOC . On March 15th we departed on the Drottningholm and arrived in Istanbul/GPE on April 10th . Dr. Rudolf Levy . 
Milman nÃ©e BÃ¼chler was born in 1928 in Puchow/LOC in Czechoslovakia/GPE . In 1942 both her brothers were deported . Livia herself went into hiding escaping from place to place and on several occasions living in the open forest . Once she was given refuge by the wife of a Policeman though without the latter knowledge . In Modva/LOC she attended a Protestant girl boarding school which had taken on a group of converted Jewish girls . Many of these were taken away by the SD in 1944 . Mrs Milman together with 60 other Jews was hidden by farmers in a forest near Piestany/LOC until the end of the war . 8 . References Non Jews helping Jews . Illegal Life in Czechoslovakia Report on the underground experiences in Slovakia/GPE 1939 1945 based on the information from Mrs. Livia Milman born Buechler on the 29th February 1928 in Puchov/LOC Czechslovakia/GPE . Livia lived together with her two brothers and their parents in their town of birth where her father owned and ran a big and flourishing butcher shop which included a kosher and non kosher department . Whilst she attended the Buergerschule in town her older brothers attended the nearby Gymnasium in Trenein/CAMP . After the Nazi occupation in 1939 her two brothers had to leave high school and she had to leave her school . Whilst her older brother Ferdninand hence forth worked in her father shop and her other brother Otto trained as an electrician in Trenein/CAMP Livia attended the newly founded Jewish school in Puchov/LOC which had around 30 â€“ 40 Jewish children who were taught in three different classes . The prosecuting measures from the Nazis that soon began put Livia then 12 years old in great fear and anxiety since her father was wealthy he was wrongly imprisoned several times and subjected to blackmail after confronting witnesses who made FALSE accusations when he was once in prison for 3 weeks . But since he denied the FALSE testimony the attempted blackmail was at first in vain . As Slovakia/GPE was affiliated with Nazi Germany/GPE the Slovakian police carried out nightly searches whereby valuables such as silver furs radios etc . were confiscated without compensation . At the beginning of 1941 the butchers which Livia father owned was taken under provisional administration and then aryanised . Livia father started working in another shop and obtained the normal wage of a journeyman however his assets and property were seized . As the first extermination transport in March 1942 from Czechslovakia/GPE departed Livia brother Ferdinand was sent to the collection depot in Zilina/LOC . One week later he was deported no one heard from him again . In April 1942 Livia other brother was brought into the spotlight . His mother tried to see him one more time as he was deported from Trenein/CAMP . She did see him for the last time just as the transportation passed through the station in Puchov/LOC thereafter again nothing was heard from Otto . 2 From that time on the deportations were implemented in a systematic sequence 1 Male Jews from the ages of 16 to 40 years old 2 Female Jews of the same age 3 Married Jewish couples with no children 4 Married Jewish couples with children . Only labour vital for the state who received yellow identity papers were exempt from deportation . When such identity papers were issued they were delivered by post . Livia uncle the lawyer Dr. Emanuel Denes in Pressburg/LOC had attained Identity papers for Livia parents â€“ the married couple BÃ¼chler which arrived on the 4th June 1944 in Puchov/LOC . This was of great importance as on the following day a transport for exterminating Jewish married couples with children who did not possess identity papers was compiled . Since the successor of the Aryanised butchers â€“ a Slovakian married couple â€“ who were interested in preventing the timely delivery of the Identity papers to the married couple BÃ¼chler the Slovakian authorities in Puchov/LOC held back the Identity papers and let it go back to Pressburg/LOC . Notified by Dr. Denes Mr. BÃ¼chler knew the identity papers was in the county town Trencin/CAMP and due to the transportation made a final important appeal to Dr. Denes urging the delivery of the identity papers within three days as the married couple BÃ¼chler were still spending time in the detention camp for the final deportation . As Dr. Denes got the identity papers on the 7th June 1944 for the married couple BÃ¼chler it was already too late the BÃ¼chlers had already been transported from the detention camp in Zilein/CAMP and Dr. Denes found out through Ayrian contacts that Mr. BÃ¼chler was forced through ill treatment to disclose which Aryan friends he had deposited cash contributions . As . Dr. Denes Mr. and Mrs. BÃ¼chler met at the last minute in front of their removal transport to Zilein/CAMP on the platform they expressed their last wish for Dr. Denes to hide Livia and to deal with the matter of identity papers . Livia then found herself not with her parents Mrs. BÃ¼chler had in the expectation of doom sent her on 4th June 1944 to her sister Mrs. Bertha Wohlstein in Dolne/LOC Wasardice/LOC near Hlohovec/LOC . This aunt of Livia was married but did not have any children . Her and her husband cultivated a country estate whose principal owner was Dr. Denes who was the brother of Mrs. BÃ¼chlers and Mrs. Wohlsteins . Mr. and Mrs. Wohlstein as well as Dr. Denes possessed identity papers the latter was however a lawyer under occupational ban . As the Slovakian authority â€“ in front of the removal transport to Zilein/LOC â€“ searched for Livia her parents explained that they did not know where she was and then she ran away . Mr. Wohlstein hid Livia for the next three days in an attic . 3 Food was given to her through a roof hatch . On behalf of the police the gendarme searched for Livia but they could not find her . Mr. Wohlstein hid her for ten days at sympathetic friends in Topolony/LOC . He then brought her back and hid her in a back room . Eventually and probably through betrayal Livia was found by the gendarme . Whilst her Aunty Mrs. Wohlstein bombarded the gendarme with pleas and gave him money Livia ran away and hid in the woods nearby . Mr. Wohlstein found her at night and took her back to the people in Topolony/LOC who could no longer keep her which is why her Uncle Dr. Denes took her to be accommodated by Mrs. Chlapik in the area of Nitra/LOC . This was ensured by the daily receipt of money as Livia was unable of paying herself she could withdraw money from another source where her father amongst others had deposited it . Mrs. Chlapik was the wife of an policeman who was transferred to Pressburg/LOC and new nothing of the whole thing . She referred Livia to a protestant boarding school in Modra/LOC by Pressburg/LOC in which school age baptised Jewish girls were able to still be christened . When someone came to visit Mrs. Chlapik Livia immediately hid under the bed and when Mrs. Chlaplik left in the evenings she sat still in the dark . One time Mrs. Chlaplik spoke to Livia about a wicked man who was also incidentally called Chlapik who took money from the Jews . She also revealed that she steals the confidence of young Jewish girls in the guise of protecting them who are then subsequently raped . After eight days Dr. Denes fetched for Livia from Mrs. Chlapik with a taxi of which he knew and trusted the chauffeur . During the drive he proposed to his niece to accept the position as a maid on the basis of Aryan identity papers for which a certain Mr. Chlaplik would provide the money for . Thereupon Livia reported in a whisper what she had learnt about a certain Mr. Chlaplik from his wife . Dr. Denes which at first brought Livia to the Wohlsteins kept the revelations about Chlaplik as he considered them unbelievable and gave him praise . But Mrs. Wohlstein guided by the finer scent of a woman in danger was completely against Dr. Denes suggestion and as Chlaplik came she told him that Livia who they had hid in their house has had an accident and is being treated in hospital in Nitra/LOC . From the Wohlsteins Livia set out to an evangelical Pastor in Deges/LOC recommended by Mrs. Chlaplik the wife of the policeman and was baptised . It was arranged that Dr. Denes should attempt to contact the evangelical boarding school in Modra/LOC . 4 He did not have any success which Livia did not know about as she sneaked to Modra/LOC and turned to the pastor Derer who presented her with her certification of baptism . The pastor told her that he could not take her in the boarding school as there was no more space in the dormitory . Henceforth Livia went to the headmistress of the boarding school Maria Sobinova a Slovakian who â€“ it was in August 1942 â€“ took Livia in the school . She attended the boarding school until June 1944 furthermore she obtained a place for her younger cousin Eva Denes who had also been baptised . As the headmistress was fond of Livia she took her in June 1944 into her own home . As the school headmistress in August 1944 was on a trip the SD surrounded the boarding school as the attendance of 16 baptised Jewish girls had been given away . As Eva Denes had prewarned Livia in a timely manner she hid in the house of the school headmistress as her husband an engineer lay by chance in bed ill . The SD limited themselves in asking him a respectable man through a window if he had hidden any Jews which he chose to deny in order to save Livia . The other girls in the boarding school tried as best they could to hide . For example Eva Denes hid in the vineyard . However only four succeeded in escaping the other twelve â€“ among them Eva Denes â€“ were the next morning abducted by the SD which the headmistress threatened to shoot dead . The headmistress who came back the same day explained that Livia must immediately flee . Livia travelled at night to Pressburg/LOC she arrived at 4 am . She searched immediately for Eva Denes mother who lived in hiding after her husband the lawyer Dr. Denes was deported . On Livia advice and at the risk of her own life Mrs. Denes searched for her daughter to save her at the last minute in which she begged the evangelical priest Derer in Modra/LOC to take action in favour of Eva . However she came 5 minutes too late and in total despair she handed herself to the Nazis . Livia herself took FALSE Aryanian identity papers which she bought just in case a position as a maid in Pressburg/LOC . This position which she had obtained from a newspaper advertisemen was however for her incompatible because her landlord used to come home drunk and 5 his harassment in turn was to be feared . Therefore from a recommendation from another cousin Livia Salzer she took another position as a maid in Piestany/LOC which she occupied until November 1944 . Once again she was then betrayed . However Livia Salzer could warn her in real time and thus Livia BÃ¼chler left her position in Piestany/LOC immediately and together with her cousin Livia Salzer they fled to a woods 30 km away from Piestany/LOC where approximately 60 Jews from neighbouring Slovakian farms hid for money and were housed . In case of emergency they had prepared in a nearby forest a bunker in which they both spent the last remaining months of the war which contributed to their safety that the Slovakian partisans conducted themselves in a sympathetic manner . In the middle of this group of Jewish refugees both Livia BÃ¼chler and Livia Salzer survived . After the liberation Livia BÃ¼chler attended the commercial academy in Bratislava/GPE until the end of her examinations . Afterwards through the Australian Jewish Welfare Society she obtained the entry permit for Australia/GPE on the boat ride she got to know her future husband Mr. Peysach Milman who she married in May 1950 in Melbourne/GPE where she and her husband still now reside . For her marriage she reconverted to Judaism .
